abstract: AN UNKNOWN WOMAN FOUND WITH HER NECK BROKEN IN AN UNOCCUPIED HOUSE. -- Yesterday afternoon the agent of house No. 272 Pacific-street, which has been unoccupied for some time, took a person into the house to view the premises, when at the bottom of the stairs leading from the first story into the basement, they were startled at seeing the dead body of a woman. She had apparently fallen head foremost down the stairs, and was found with her head and shoulders down, between the lowest step and the door at the bottom of the stairs, with her neck broken. A bonnet and other articles of female wearing apparel were found in a room on the third story, probably belonging to the deceased. It is supposed that she gained admittance to the house several days ago. through a window found to be unfastened, with a view of lodging there, and, while attempting to gain the basement, being intoxicated, she accidentally fell down the stairs, and was instantly killed. The Coroner was notified, and an inquest will be held on the body to-day. The deceased was a middle-aged woman, and wore a mixed straw bonnet.
lead_paragraph: AN UNKNOWN WOMAN FOUND WITH HER NECK BROKEN IN AN UNOCCUPIED HOUSE. -- Yesterday afternoon the agent of house No. 272 Pacific-street, which has been unoccupied for some time, took a person into the house to view the premises, when at the bottom of the stairs leading from the first story into the basement, they were startled at seeing the dead body of a woman. abstract: -- The trial in this case has resulted in the conviction of the accused, who has been sentenced to be executed on the 7th day of February next. His guilt was beyond question, and the Judge, in pronouncing sentence, was clearly of the opinion that it was well merited, and should be carried into effect. We trust it will. It would be a violation of every principle of humanity for the President to interpose, and, in effect, to nullify the law against the Slave-trade. Of a cargo of 1,000 slaves taken from the coast of Africa for the West Indies, at least one-quarter, or 250 on the average, fell victims to the voyage, and are literally slaughtered in cold blood. Capt. GORDON is as responsible for the death of those lost on the voyage of the Erie, as if he had taken the life of each by his own hand. For once, when no doubt exists as to guilt, a terrible example should be made. It will do more to put a stop to the slave trade than a dozen war vessels on the African Coast. But this coast, the present war has compelled us to leave almost entirely unguarded -- only a single ship being detailed for this purpose. Immunity extended to Capt. GORDON would undoubtedly lead to the fitting out, in our town harbor, of a large number of vessels for the trade. The Augusta, just seized, is a good illustration in point. She came very near escaping the clutches of the law. Nothing will deter people from engaging in this infamous but profitable traffic, but the fact that detection and conviction is certain to cost the life of the offenders. To pardon Capt. GORDON would be a most inhuman and mischievous step, and we trust that in this case the law will have its course without mitigation or delay.

abstract: At this Church there was no regular sermon, the exercises consisting in reading the Scriptures, prayers, singing, and narration by various members of God's mercies to them socially and spiritually during the year, the Pastor holding to the belief that each person can testify to God's mercies to him or her personally better than could any minister. During the meeting, which continued from 7 1/2 until 11 3/4 A.M., many affecting and interesting narratives of the goodness and mercy of God were recounted -- two by returned soldiers, who had pushed unharmed through two battles. The pastor, in a few remarks, testified as to God's goodness to himself personally and spiritually, and especially to the Church over which he presided, and was thankful he could say that with the exception of one pastor, he had baptised during the past year more than all the other Baptist Churches in the City. He thought it was more primitive and more promoting of spirituality to assemble in such a manner, and to give personal testimony to the goodness and mercy of the Lord, than to listen to any Thanksgiving sermon, which were too often devoted to fulsome adulation of men and measures, and eulogies upon our national prowess. The exercises were of a highly devotional and interesting character.

abstract: -- One of the evening journals of this City has a terrible account of the pestilential climate of South Carolina, and the impossibility, except by fearful loss of life, of white soldiers retaining military occupation of the State, after they have conquered it. It argues that "if we attempt to hold, during the summer, by means of troops sent from the North, the ground we have gained in the winter campaign, we shall do it at an expense of life such as was never experienced in any battle; our armies must face a deadlier enemy than ever wielded weapons forged by man; they will be swept off by squadrons; the living will scarce suffice to bury the dead."
lead_paragraph: -- One of the evening journals of this City has a terrible account of the pestilential climate of South Carolina, and the impossibility, except by fearful loss of life, of white soldiers retaining military occupation of the State, after they have conquered it. abstract: A most enthusiastic mass meeting of citizens of all parties filled Cooper Institute to overflowing last evening, in testimony to the popular indorsement of the nomination of Hon. GEORGE OPDYKE to the Mayoralty.
lead_paragraph: A most enthusiastic mass meeting of citizens of all parties filled Cooper Institute to overflowing last evening, in testimony to the popular indorsement of the nomination of Hon. GEORGE OPDYKE to the Mayoralty. So large was the assemblage that many were unable to obtain admission, and testified their adherence to the cause, by organizing impromptu meetings outside. Within doors the hall presented a brilliant scene. The dense masses, the walls decorated with the National colors, the platform crowded with distinguished citizens, the frequent entrance of delegates from the various Wards, the inspiring music of the bands, and the cheering of the audience, as each sentiment of the speakers was indorsed, made the occasion one of unusual animation.

abstract: The Rev. Dr. HATFIELD took his text from the 13th chapter of Matthew, 17th verse. In the opening of his discourse the Rev. Doctor alluded to the Golden Age spoken of by philosophers and poets, and stated that when this fratricidal war had ceased we shoutd be nearer that epoch than ever. War was not an unmitigated evil; as with persons, so it was with nations -- they often have great evils thrust upon them, in order that eventually they may derive the greater good. It was said that the Old World could not get along without cotton. Europe has now found that corn is as equally important as cotton, if not more so. Corn now rules, and King Cotton is in shackles. It remains with the North to prevent cotton ever gaining the ascendency again. This war had already gained us three things, and they were -- financial, political and moral emancipation.

abstract: In his discourse, yesterdey, Rev. Dr. HUTTON said: Thanksgiving is an individual matter. Nations are composed of individuals; and when we speak of a great nation, we mean the great majority of individuals which make it a nation. Hence a true national thankfulness must be an individual matter; and just in proportion as every individual is thankful does a nation, in the sight of God, render thanks. Let each individual, then, recall, for himself, on such a day as this, for what he has reason to be thankful -- whether for success in his worldly affairs, for simple life or even for the dawn of this eventful morning, for which he should thank God. The sources of thanksgiving are many. They are derived for the individual from his position as head of a family, the domestic blessings which have clustered around him, the happy fireside, the delightful home. How many families have been broken up by death and suffering; and, even if death has entered the household, there are hopes of a better world, and thanks to be felt therefor. Then, thanks should be felt and rendered in each individual case for his church relations, for all the comforts he may have enjoyed during the year, for the spiritual strength and instruction he may have received, and the peace, harmony and prosperity attending his church operations. The speaker then gave a running sketch of the history of the country, marking the peculiar favors of God to us from the commencement of our existence as a nation. From hence he drew the assurance that, notwithstanding our present troubles, there is to be a hopeful, joyful termination of them.

abstract: -- It is unsafe, as a rule, to found very dogmatic opinions upon the numbers present at a gathering favoring a political candidate, but the Opdyke meeting last evening deserves note as an exception. Not only numerically, but in point of hearty and earnest enthusiasm, it raised itself out of the category of mass meetings. Men, connected by veteran association with one or the other limb of the bifurcated Democracy, participated in the deliberations, swelled the chorus of cheers and robbed the proceedings entirely of partisan characteristics. Mr. OPDYKE is evidently something very much more than a Republican candidate. He is a National Union candidate -- the candidate of all supporters of the Administration.
lead_paragraph: -- It is unsafe, as a rule, to found very dogmatic opinions upon the numbers present at a gathering favoring a political candidate, but the Opdyke meeting last evening deserves note as an exception. Not only numerically, but in point of hearty and earnest enthusiasm, it raised itself out of the category of mass meetings. Men, connected by veteran association with one or the other limb of the bifurcated Democracy, participated in the deliberations, swelled the chorus of cheers and robbed the proceedings entirely of partisan characteristics. abstract: The Richmond Dispatch of the 20th "deprecates the depreciating of the courage of the enemy, representing them as a race of cowards. By such representation we induce our brave soldiers to relax their vigilance, and when victorious, as they almost always are, the laurels won from a pusilanimous foe can neither be very brilliant nor enduring. The great masses of all races of men are endowed with physical courage, and the Yankees form no exception. * * Nor were the enemy uniformly triumphant, instead of uniformly defeated, would the result have any considerable bearing on the question whether the Yankees are or are not a brave people. For it is not the Yankees who compose the main body of the rank and file of the Federal army, but the Germans and Irish, who have always made splendid soldiers, and whose courage and endurance are proverbial. It is no common glory, in our opinion, to conquer such men as fought at Springfield, Columbus, Manassas, Leesburgh, and other great battles of this war. We should leave it to RUSSELL and other such caricaturists of both nations in America to report this as a more Chinese civil war -- a fight of Shanghai roosters or demented turkey gobblers."

abstract: By the November election, the administration of the County officers was placed in the hands of men elected by a small minority of the people. The election which takes place on Tuesday -- only one working day from the present -- is to determine whether the administration of the City Government is to remain in possession of the same small, but powerful and reckless minority. The question needs no clearer statement. Mayor WOOD, in possession of the veto power, possesses a controlling influence over the legislative action of the Common Council. It is within his scope to give office to this friend and a contract to that, and to defeat any contract, or leave vacant any office in the disposition of which he has not some profitable pecuniary interest to exert for those who surround him clamoring for such bits of patronage. It is in this coalition of the Common Council and the Mayor that all the possibilities of corruption in municipal matters reside. The redemption of the City is to be effected either by revolutionizing the Common Council, or by placing in the office of Mayor a man of tried honesty and capacity, who shall support an honest minority of the Council in its antagonism to corruption. The latter task is the easiest. To match the elaborate machinery by which the Democracy carries ward by ward, and district by district, would over-task the languid efforts which are usually enlisted on the side of good government. But it is still possible to elect a Mayor, who shall be beyond the reach of suspicion, and this possibility, we believe, will be fully demonstrated on Tuesday by the choice of Mr. OPDYKE.

abstract: The United States transport Ocean Queen, Capt. SEABURY, from Port Royal Nov. 27, arrived at this port at 1 1/2 P.M. yesterday. She has no passengers, and but a small mail. As she came out of Port Royal harbor, the steamship Bienville, hence, was going in. Commodore DUPONT had transferred his flag from the Wabash to the Susquehannah. He, together with Gen. SHERMAN, had just returned to Hilton Head in the steamer McClellan, having landed a force of United States Marines on Tybee Island, who had commenced repairing the fortifications and constructing new ones. A fleet of eight gunboats was atanchor off Tybee, to cover the troops in case of necessity. The rebels had sunk two vessels between Tybee Island and Fort Pulaski, in the narrow part of the Savannah River channel, to prevent the fleet from getting to that city.

abstract: Slips of the New-Orleans market reports to Nov. 1, and Charleston of Oct. 31, have been received at the Merchants' Exchange in Boston. At New-Orleans the operations in cotton were very few. One lot of 150 bales was sold for cash, deliverable when the blockade was raised. The articles affected by the military embargo in Tennessee continue to advance in price.
lead_paragraph: Slips of the New-Orleans market reports to Nov. 1, and Charleston of Oct. 31, have been received at the Merchants' Exchange in Boston. At New-Orleans the operations in cotton were very few. One lot of 150 bales was sold for cash, deliverable when the blockade was raised. The articles affected by the military embargo in Tennessee continue to advance in price.

abstract: Dr. TAYLOR selected for his text the first verse of the 101st Psalm. He began by adverting to the peculiar circumstances under which we had this year to celebrate Thanksgiving. He bitterly denounced the war and those who had caused it; spoke at some length on the influences that have been exercised over the world by the American cotton monopoly, and of the future fate of cotton and those who had trampled under foot every righteous feeling in the pursuit of gain through its means. In the course of his remarks, the reverend doctor (who is by birth a South Carolinian) declared it shameful to see "three millions of lazy people living on the produce of servile labor." Dr. TAYLOR thought the war would teach the nation many useful lessons. It would check the growing mania for luxury and extravagance, and would rouse our young men to a better, higher state of sentiment and action. Dr. TAYLOR hoped his hearers would that day form new resolutions that should tend to beneficially mold their future lives.

abstract: The chilly air of a November night is not calculated to arouse out-door enthusiasm. Last evening demonstrated, however, that in the present warmth of political feeling and excitement, the coolness of the outer air is forgotten, and that the thought of bodily comfort is secondary to the thoughts of public interest involved in the pending mayoralty contest. The outpouring of City clubs and citizens having soon filled the vast hall of the Cooper Institute, by 8 P.M., there were several thousands who found themselves "left out in the cold." But they were kept alive with pulsating warmth and in cheerful glow, by the booming of cannon, firing of rockets, music, marching, transparencies, cheers, speeches, and unlimited enthusiasm. There were two outside meetings; they were extemporized on wagons. Speaking was kept up for nearly two hours, the vast crowd listening with earnest and enthusiastic attention.

abstract: A sermon upon "The State of the Country" was delivered at St. Paul's Church, corner of Vesey-street and Broadway, by Rev. MORGAN DIX. The preacher remarked that we all well knew the disordered state of the country seven months ago; what a panic reigned, and how even the army was disorderly and ill fed. It was in this panic that the grim tyrant, Insurrection and Civil War, had stalked in; but see now how great the change. We were as a lump of clay in the hands of God, to be molded into any shape that the Modeler wished. The civil war had shown us that those most trusted were the worst traitors. What could we think when a holy father of the Church laid aside his Bishop's robes and assumed the garb of a soldier? It were better that we had known it sooner; but we can hope for the future, and then we will see how a soldier's life will suit the holy father. We should pray for a speedy peace, and we should pray that the Church should lift up its head again, and be seen among the community. We should pray and resolve that this Union, once more connected, should never, never be dissolved.

abstract: The usual Thanksgiving services were appropriately observed at Zion Baptist Church, (colored, in Sullivan-street, in the evening. A sermon was delivered by the pastor. Rev. J.T. RAYMOND, on the general state of the country, and the bounty and benevolence of God in the time of peril, when this great fabric -- a purely Republican Government -- was tottering in the balance, and concluded by uttering a very fervent prayer in behalf of the Union cause, and for the return of a speedy peace to our country.

abstract: A mass meeting of the Tammany and other political assocations, in favor of supporting C. GODFREY GUNTHER for Mayor, was held at Irving Hall last  evening. A band of music was present, and much enthusiasm was manifested. The banners and transparencies of the several Ward organizations were thickly scattered throughout the Hall, and among the numerous inscriptions were noticed, "FERNANDO  WOOD takes GODRFREY'S Cordial," "WOOD is Burnt Out," and others equally ludicrous.

abstract: In her recent speech at the opening of the Spanish Cortes, on the 6th inst., the Queen of Spain said that, "disorder and excess having reached their height in Mexico, treaties having been violated and rights forgotten, and her subjects having been exposed to serious at- ...
lead_paragraph: In her recent speech at the opening of the Spanish Cortes, on the 6th inst., the Queen of Spain said that, "disorder and excess having reached their height in Mexico, treaties having been violated and rights forgotten, and her subjects having been exposed to serious attacks and continual dangers, it becomes indispensable to make an example of salutary rigor." These are her reasons for the tripartite expedition against the Mexican Republic. Every person at all familiar with recent Mexican history is aware that nearly all these disorders and excesses have been due, primarily and mainly, to the Spaniards who have been sheltered in the Republic since its severance from the parent country, and who have repaid the Mexicans for their hospitality by inciting civil and political disorder within her borders. They have been the steadiest and worst foes of liberty in Mexico, the allies of the bigots and despots who have attempted her subjugation, and the authors of most of the excesses which have disgraced her history. In the face of these facts, it certainly indicates the height of audacity for Spain to assume the championship of order and right in the Mexican Republic.

abstract: The Richmond Whig complains bitterly of the grievance suffered by the farming community from the impressment of negroes, and wagons and teams for the use of the rebel army. It says: "We have received many letters, complaining of individual grievances at the hands of agents of the Government, from the peninsula and from the whole region of country from Manassas along the foot of the mountains to James River in Albemarle and Nelson. The complaints from below relate mainly to the pressing negroes for the service of the Government at Yorktown and vicinity, and the treatment which the negroes receive at the hands of the authorities. It is alleged that a much greater number of negroes have been pressed than were needed, and have not had sufficient food, and are without shelter to protect them from the weather. The effect of this press, without regard to the injury to the health of the negroes, has been to diminish the wheat crops sown in the Counties of Charles City, New-Kent, King William, &c., fully one-third. The complaints from the Piedmont region relates to the pressing teams for the Quartermaster's Departments, and the insolence of many of the government agents. In all this region the wheat crop is fully a third less than usual, in consequence of this abstraction of the teams of the farmers."

abstract: The text chosen by Rev. Mr. SMITH was II Chron., ch. xx., verses 21-22. He commenced his sermon with a terse and forcible portrayal of the contrast between the condition of the country now, and as it had been when we came together to celebrate former Thanksgiving days. Whilst acknowledging that we are now suffering Divine chastisement, he contended that the war, for many reasons, was a cause for thankfulness; that, though an evil, great good would come out of it; that, even as a chastisement, coming as it does from God, we should thank our Heavenly Father for punishing us in the promotion of our good. The main point in the preacher's discourse, however, lay in his exposition of the way in which Slavery must be affected by the war. He said the Providence of God is working a solution of the most perplexing and dangerous question that has ever agitated our national councils. He has taken it out of our hands, except so far as we are instruments in the process. By a method unexpected, unsought, and which would have been deprecated and dreaded on all sides, He is practically determining what men have theorized about in vain. Ravings and objurgations pass for nothing. Theories of divine right and pleas for unconstitutional violence are alike pushed aside as cobwebs from the path of God's movements. There is almost a universal disposition to do as the army of Judah did -- stand still and see the salvation of God. We can no longer direct. We must follow -- reverently -- humbly. And, while we cannot believe that unreasoning passion will be gratified, we are assured that God will be honored in the issue. In His own good time and in His own way, He will make oppression to cease, and humble the pride of those who have sought to sacrifice the liberties of a mighty people on the shrine of their Moloch. * * * That the system or institution, in whose interests this rebellion is carried forward, is the sole cause of this wickedness, I see not how any one can believe who reads and understands history. That it has a vast deal to do with it, and is made the grand rallying cry for the abettors of this treachery, none can deny. And who will venture to say that God is sending this tempest into our political atmosphere only to leave the clouds as dark and ominous when it is over, and the thunderings as deep and dreadful -- significant of a fierce conflict of the elements still. It cannot be. I would rather believe that, here and now, we are to meet our ruin or find our salvation, and that God, when his time comes, will show us what he means by those sweet words of Jesus: "The spirit of the Lord is upon me, because He hath anointed me to preach the Gospel to the poor; He hath sent me to heal the broken-hearted, to preach deliverance to the captives, and recovering of sight to the blind; to set at liberty those that are bruised, to preach the acceptable year of the Lord." The preacher went on to show how this promised good deliverance of the Lord was cause for gratitude and joy, concluding with an eloquent apostrophe to our country and its flag, and a plea for sympathy with those who have at this season peculiar occasion to mourn.
lead_paragraph: The text chosen by Rev. Mr. SMITH was II Chron., ch. xx., verses 21-22. He commenced his sermon with a terse and forcible portrayal of the contrast between the condition of the country now, and as it had been when we came together to celebrate former Thanksgiving days. Whilst acknowledging that we are now suffering Divine chastisement, he contended that the war, for many reasons, was a cause for thankfulness; that, though an evil, great good would come out of it; that, even as a chastisement, coming as it does from God, we should thank our Heavenly Father for punishing us in the promotion of our good. The main point in the preacher's discourse, however, lay in his exposition of the way in which Slavery must be affected by the war. He said the Providence of God is working a solution of the most perplexing and dangerous question that has ever agitated our national councils. He has taken it out of our hands, except so far as we are instruments in the process. By a method unexpected, unsought, and which would have been deprecated and dreaded on all sides, He is practically determining what men have theorized about in vain. Ravings and objurgations pass for nothing. Theories of divine right and pleas for unconstitutional violence are alike pushed aside as cobwebs from the path of God's movements. There is almost a universal disposition to do as the army of Judah did -- stand still and see the salvation of God. We can no longer direct. We must follow -- reverently -- humbly. And, while we cannot believe that unreasoning passion will be gratified, we are assured that God will be honored in the issue. In His own good time and in His own way, He will make oppression to cease, and humble the pride of those who have sought to sacrifice the liberties of a mighty people on the shrine of their Moloch. * * * That the system or institution, in whose interests this rebellion is carried forward, is the sole cause of this wickedness, I see not how any one can believe who reads and understands history. That it has a vast deal to do with it, and is made the grand rallying cry for the abettors of this treachery, none can deny. And who will venture to say that God is sending this tempest into our political atmosphere only to leave the clouds as dark and ominous when it is over, and the thunderings as deep and dreadful -- significant of a fierce conflict of the elements still. It cannot be. I would rather believe that, here and now, we are to meet our ruin or find our salvation, and that God, when his time comes, will show us what he means by those sweet words of Jesus: "The spirit of the Lord is upon me, because He hath anointed me to preach the Gospel to the poor; He hath sent me to heal the broken-hearted, to preach deliverance to the captives, and recovering of sight to the blind; to set at liberty those that are bruised, to preach the acceptable year of the Lord." The preacher went on to show how this promised good deliverance of the Lord was cause for gratitude and joy, concluding with an eloquent apostrophe to our country and its flag, and a plea for sympathy with those who have at this season peculiar occasion to mourn.

abstract: The object of the Rev. Mr. ALEXANDER's discourse was to show that the stability of national and individual prosperity is dependent upon the general diffusion of wisdom; first, by the intellectual culture of the people, then on their moral culture, then on their spiritual advancement. The preacher only incidentally referred to the war in his concluding remarks, which were an historical induction demonstrating that wisdom is the stability of our times.
lead_paragraph: The object of the Rev. abstract: The rebels, from the first, have not been wanting in fast friends in this City, whose cooperation they retained so long as was practicable, and who only at the last moment sided with our Government in crushing the rebellion. Should a reconciliation, or reconstruction be proposed, these men would still be the most efficient allies and advocates of the South.
lead_paragraph: The rebels, from the first, have not been wanting in fast friends in this City, whose cooperation they retained so long as was practicable, and who only at the last moment sided with our Government in crushing the rebellion. Should a reconciliation, or reconstruction be proposed, these men would still be the most efficient allies and advocates of the South. We do not question their loyalty, however much their sympathies may draw them in another direction. But these very men, either by accident or design, seem to have been the special target for rebel malevolence. This is as unkind as it is unwise. The steamer Nashville, on her voyage to England, seized and wantonly burned a magnificent ship, owned by a gentleman in this City, who has always been one of the staunchest and most unwavering defenders of Southern rights, and most closely identified with the rebels in business relations. But nothing is sacred against these ruthless destroyers. Friend and foe are alike sacrificed by them. Society among them is based upon the denial of the right of a man to own himself. From such premises it is not a great stretch to proclaim war upon all other kinds of property, irrespective of its ownership. It is everywhere destruction. Witness the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, the managers of which were in close sympathy with the rebels, and were only overawed from identifying themselves with them by the overwhelming power of Government. This did not save their road, however. In Kentucky the first step of the rebels was to destroy as far as lay in their power, the public works of the State, which friends as well as foes were interested in preserving. This passion for destruction they turn upon themselves the moment they give way to the advance of the Government forces. Wherever the National troops gain foothold, they find that devastation has preceded them. The rebels are thus fast revealing their true character, and fast weakening the hold they had, not upon the sympathies of the peace party of the North, but of the world.

abstract: A Thanksgiving sermon was preached at the Dutch Reformed Church, corner Fulton and William streets, by Dr. VERMILYE. abstract: A SINGULAR CASE -- MELANCHOLY DEATH OF AN ARMY AT THE METROPOLITAN HOTEL. -- The Coroner held an inquest yesterday afternoon, at the Metropolitan Hotel, upon the body of Maj. DANIEL J. SUTHERLAND, late of the United States Army, who was found dead in his room at that hotel, at an early hour yesterday morning. The facts of the case as developed by the evidence given at the inquest, were as follows: Maj. SUTHERLAND arrived at the Metropolitan Hotel on Thanksgiving day, from Philadelphia. After dinner, on Friday, he went up to his room, attended by a waiter of the hotel. This was the last that was seen of him alive. About 4 o'clock yesterday morning, the night-watchman was passing through the hall near deceased's room, and saw the door open and the gas burning. Thinking this unusual at so late an hour, he walked to the door, said there saw SUTHERLAND lying on the floor in a pool of blood. He at once notified the Clerk in the office. Dr. QUACKENROSS was sent for, who came and made an examination. Upon the inquest the Doctor testified as follows: "I found him lying on the floor in a pool of blood; he was dead, the body cold; he had probably been dead two hours when I saw him; I found that he had a contussed wound over his right eye, and a lasceration of the scalp on the left side of the head; I searched the room and everything in it, but could find no weapon of any kind, not even a pocket-knife; he had all his clothes on, even to his hat; I was present at the post-mortem examination, and, in my opinion, the immediate cause of his death was exhaustion from hemorrhage and congestion of the membranes of the brain." Dr. BOUTON, who made the post-mortem, testified that he found a contused lacerated wound on the nose, an inch in length; also a similar wound over the right eye, and a smaller wound on the left parietal bone. The body was in a bloodless condition. The cause of death was hemorrhage from the wounds above mentioned, and congestion of the membranes of the brain."
lead_paragraph: A SINGULAR CASE -- MELANCHOLY DEATH OF AN ARMY AT THE METROPOLITAN HOTEL. -- The Coroner held an inquest yesterday afternoon, at the Metropolitan Hotel, upon the body of Maj. Dr. BOUTON, who made the post-mortem, testified that he found a contused lacerated wound on the nose, an inch in length; also a similar wound over the right eye, and a smaller wound on the left parietal bone. abstract: The additional accounts which have reached us, through rebel sources, of the fighting at Fort Pickens, are more confused, if possible, than those which have preceded them. A great many rumors were prevalent on Friday -- the date of our last accounts -- at Fortress Monroe. One was that Fort Pickens had been taken by the rebels. Another, that the rebels had been defeated, and Gen. BRAGG killed, and still another, that after two days' hard fighting, a great storm arose, in consequence of which both sides had to cease fighting. A copy of the Richmond Dispatch, received in Baltimore, contains extracts from the Pensacola Observer of the 22d and 23d ult., from which it appears that the firing was commenced by Fort Pickens about 10 o'clock on Friday, the 22d. The accounts in the Observer are principally made up of bombast, and nothing can be judged from them. The Richmond Dispatch, however, contains a dispatch from Gen. BRAGG, dated Tuesday night, in which he states that everything was quiet about Pensacola, and that he was prepared to renew the engagement, -- from which it appears that there had been a cessation of firing, but for what reason is not stated.

abstract: One of the largest meetings ever convened within the walls of Cooper Institute assembled last evening pursuant to a call for citizens of all parties in favor of the election of Hon. GEORGE OPDYKE to the Mayoralty. Within the hall Judge E.P. COWLES presided, and on taking the Chair spoke in support of the objects of the meeting. Addresses were also made by D.D. FIELD, HENRY J. RAYMOND, and others. The outside demonstration was no less imposing, and comprised speeches, torchlight processions of the various Ward clubs, bonfires, and enthusiasm generally. The whole affair was well managed, and proved a complete success. After the mass meeting was over a procession of Ward clubs, joined by many prominent citizens, marched to Mr. OPDYKE's house in Fifth-avenue, where a fine pyrotechnic display took place and a speech was made by Mr. OPDYKE.

abstract: ROWDY BOYS -- WHERE ARE THE POLICE? --The residents of Tiffany-place, between Harrison and Degraw streets, are much annoyed and their lives put in jeopardy by a crowd of young ruffians who daily congregate there, and fight Bull Run battles with stones. On Saturday last, one of the boys was seriously and, it is thought, fatally injured by one of the missiles. Even on Sunday, they amused themselves in the same manner, and that, too, in the face and eyes of two policemen, who paid no attention to them. Will Captain HOLBROOK see that the men detailed by him do their duty?
lead_paragraph: ROWDY BOYS -- WHERE ARE THE POLICE? --The residents of Tiffany-place, between Harrison and Degraw streets, are much annoyed and their lives put in jeopardy by a crowd of young ruffians who daily congregate there, and fight Bull Run battles with stones. abstract: AN OLD GAME SUCCESSFULLY PLAYED. -- Mr. JOSEPH H. FULTON, a drover, hailing from the interior of the State, yesterday related a little of his experience in the City with a class of men familiarly known as "pocket-book droppers." The complaint, as taken before the Justice at the Tombs, states in substance that about two weeks since, as Mr. FULTON was passing along one of the streets in the City, he felt something suddenly strike against one of his feet. Uponlooking down he saw a well-filled pocket-book upon the walk. At that instant two men approached him, and one of them remarked that he had dropped his wallet. FULTON felt for his money and found it safe in his pocket. The swindler then went on with the same old story -- that the money had been lost by some one who would offer a large reward for its return, that they were strangers in the City, just leaving for home, &c. The pocket-book in the meantime was examined, and found to contain four double eagles, six one hundred-dollar bills and quite a number of a smaller denomination. They ended by proposing that Mr. FULTON should give them $100, and he might keep the pocketbook and obtain the reward. After some hesitation, he gave them $40; and the two strangers, being in haste to reach the cars, suddenly left. Mr. FULTON found great difficulty in opening his prize after their departure, but at last, when he succeeded in getting at the contents, he found them composed entirely of pieces of old newspaper. Since that time he has been on the watch for the swindlers, and yesterday he succeeded in causing the arrest of one of them. His name is ROBERT KNEELAND alias "Frenchy," and is well known to the Police. Justice BRENNAN committed him for examination.

abstract: The horses, twelve in number, purchased by Prince NAPOLEON on his recent visit to this country, and designed for the Emperor NAPOLEON, were placed on board the French transport Orione, now lying at Union wharf, yesterday afternoon. The animals were placed in well-padded boxes, with feeding mangers attached to each, and slung on board and placed on the second deck on each side of the main hatch, where the boxes are so secured that, in the event of stormy weather, their position will not be disturbed. The animals are severally slung in the boxes, so no harm can come to them by the pitching or rolling of the vessel. The horses have not been chosen with regard to uniformity of color, as they include blacks, bays, browns, and one white. They are very finely bred animals, and will contrast favorably with the chunky, round and plump-proportioned Netherlands horses which are so common in France (which, by the way, Paris is said to be) or the blooded grades which come in part of that heavy-headed stock. We could obtain no specific information relative to the origin of the horses in question; all we could glean on board the Orione was that they were of Western New-York and New-England stock, the crack descriptions which belong to the several branches of the Morgan family. The story of an export of sheep and swine by the same ship, is not true. Quite a number of these descriptions of animals were taken on board, but they are consigned to the butcher. -- Boston Journal, Nov. 29.
lead_paragraph: The horses, twelve in number, purchased by Prince NAPOLEON on his recent visit to this country, and designed for the Emperor NAPOLEON, were placed on board the French transport Orione, now lying at Union wharf, yesterday afternoon. abstract: Two late announcements from the South are well calculated to inspire fearful forebodings in the Northern breast. Firstly, HOLLINS, Rear Admiral (rear in more senses than one) of the "little Confederate Mosquito Fleet "   TWO AGAINST ONE AND ONE AGAINST TWO. At
lead_paragraph: Two late announcements from the South are well calculated to inspire fearful forebodings in the Northern breast. Firstly, HOLLINS, Rear Admiral (rear in more senses than one) of the "little Confederate Mosquito Fleet" -- the inventor of the "ram," -- the man who "peppered" our blockaders at the head of the Southwest Pass, and then made such indecent haste to get out of harm's way, that he reached New-Orleans before the news of his "victory" did -- is about to go up the Mississippi on the rampage and give the Northern Vandals battle on their own waters!

abstract: A GOOD NOMINA  TION. SAMUEL B. RUGGLES is a Candidate for Alderman in the Eighteenth Ward. He ought to be elected, without regard to any other consideration than his pre minent fitness for that or any other public position, and the absolute need which the City has of his services.
lead_paragraph: A GOOD NOMINATION. -- SAMUEL B. RUGGLES is a candidate for Alderman in the Eighteenth Ward. He ought to be elected, without regard to any other consideration than his preeminent fitness for that or any other public position, and the absolute need which the City has of his services. He is universally known as one of the very ablest men who have ever been connected with public affairs in this State -- as the friend and efficient promoter of retrenchment and reform, and the enemy of everything like profligacy and corruption in the expenditure of public money. It is a most hopeful sign of the times that such a man is willing to take a seat in our Common Council; and no event would better serve to revive the drooping confidence of our people in the possibility of having an honest and upright administration of municipal affairs, than his election by a triumphant majority.

lead_paragraph: The Herald has been filling its columns for the last few days with the most vehement denunciations of GEORGE OPDYKE, for having attended the delivery of Senator SUMNER's address at the Cooper Institute, and for having officiated as Vice-President on that occasion. Over and over again, after its usual style, does that print ring the changes on this evidence of his active sympathy with Abolition. It describes him as standing side by side with CHEEVER, JOHNSON, and other leading Abolitionists, -- as being foremost in the conduct of the meeting, and resolute in pushing through the resolution that was then adopted. Yesterday's Herald, for example, has the following:

abstract: Mr. WALLACK announces that the new comedy, called the "Magic Marriage," is the production of Mr. CHARLES GAYLOR, a gentleman well known to the public as the most successful of our cotemporaneous dramatists. We are glad that Mr. GAYLOR has trimmed his wings for a higher flight than any he has yet essayed, and still more glad that his success is unequivocal. The play will, of course, be repeated until further notice. It attracted overflowing houses during the past week.

abstract: A scout, who has followed the army of the rebels since the evacuation of Springfield, came in yesterday. He reports the rebels come 15,000 strong, moving North in three divisions. The right wing, 6,000 strong, commanded by Gen. McBRIDGE, resting on Stockton, Cedar County. The left wing held position near Nevada, Vernon County, under command of Gen. RAINS, with 4,000 men. Gen. PRICE, with 5,000 men, commanded the centre, and was near Montebello, Vernon County.
lead_paragraph: ROLLA, Mo., Saturday, Nov. 30.

abstract: FIRES -- AN INHUMAN ACT. -- Yesterday morning, between 12 and 1 o'clock, a fire was discovered in a tenement four-story building, in Essex-street, Jersey City, owned by Mr. BENJAMIN O. EDGE, and occupied by some thirty or forty families. Officers CALLAHAN and HARNEY, who were the first persons present, found that a quantity of cotton waste, saturated with oil and turpentine, had been set on fire near the foot of the main stairway, and in a few moments more the egress of the inmates would have been entirely cut off. As it was, men, women and children rushed into the street with only their night clothing. The fire was extinguished with but slight damage.... About 4 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, a fire occurred in the Jersey City Glass-house. The loss sustained was about $250.

abstract: -- Sir JAMES FERGUSON, who was accused of being a spy and of carrying dispatches from Lord PALMERSTON -- two such names mingled! -- to JEFFERSON DAVIS, was injudicious enough to address himself to the source of the calumny, and meets with the treatment an Englishman and a gentleman is certain to receive in that quarter, as we see to-night. Refuse an invitation to dinner, as I did on arriving in New-York, and you may know what to expect. But would not starvation in company with an honest man be better than the ill-gotten luxury and nasty companionship of such a foul knave? The worst of it is that, like a bloated and rotten carcass on the surface of a stream, the thing shows how the current flows and the tide sets. And so there is an incessant abuse of England and Englishmen. It is true that Americans often blush as they read. -- Russell's Letter to the Times from Washington.

abstract: Gen. LANE, the Kansas Senator and soldier, delivered a speech (already referred to by telegraph) in Tremont Temple, Boston, in the forenoon of Saturday. He was received with tremendous cheers. He said that he felt embarrassed at addressing the assemblage before him. When he set out in life, his mother said there was nothing to prevent his success in life but his unconquerable modesty. He thought he had got bravely over that, but still he was embarrassed where he now found himself.

abstract: Just about the moment when the echoes of DUPONT'S cannon were resounding through Charleston, the voice of a just judge also was sounding in the cars of the citizens of that city, denouncing the rebel tyranny and protesting against rebel usurpations.
lead_paragraph: Just about the moment when the echoes of DUPONT's cannon were resounding through Charleston, the voice of a just judge also was sounding in the cars of the citizens of that city, denouncing the rebel tyranny and protesting against rebel usurpations. The time was the opening of the first Court held in Charleston since the inauguration of the rebellion, and which was presided over by Judge MAGRATH, that very person who, with theatrical pomposity, threw off the judicial robe just a year ago. The orator was Judge PETIGRU, a man known in Charleston and throughout South Carolina, for his honorable life, his upright character, and high judicial attainments. The occasion was the response of the latter to a writ of garnishment which had been served upon him, based upon the rebel act sequestrating the property of Union men. It was surely strange enough, that, as the rebel Attorney declared, "the first duty which devolved upon his Honor since he had put on his robes, and opened the first term of the Confederate Court in South Carolina, was to listen to an invective against the Government whose commission he bore."

abstract: The approach of the holiday season is hearalded by unmistakable signs in the bookworld. We have books with golden backs and edges and illuminated pages, evidently designed for the centre-table; and then we have books in good, honest garb valuable editions of standard works fair of face and clear in type, which at Christmas time will undoubedly be transferred to library shelves.
lead_paragraph: -- The approach of the holiday season is hearalded by unmistakable signs in the book-world. We have books with golden backs and edges and illuminated pages, evidently designed for the centre-table; and then we have books in good, honest garb -- valuable editions of standard works -- fair of face and clear in type, which at Christmas time will undoubedly be transferred to library shelves. TICKNOR & FIELDS publish a very handsome gift-book -- the In Memoriam of TENNYSON. Those familiar with the poems in the compressed form it is obliged to assume in the "blue and gold" edition of the poet, will wonder at the dimensions to which it expands itself when a "rivulet of text" is permitted to "meander through a meadow of margin." The volume is prefaced by an interesting biographical sketch of ARTHUR HENRY HALLAM, the young friend upon whose grave TENNYSON flung this immortal wreath of poesy. With the certainty of thus being mourned, one would be almost willing to die.

abstract: The first session of the Thirty-seventh Congress commences to-day. There was not a quornm of the members of either House in Washington last night, but a sufficient number are expected to arrive by this morning's trains to insure an immediate commencement of business. It has been decided that the President's Message and the Reports of the Departments cannot be delivered to the Press in advance of their delivery, it being necessary to hold them back until the last moment for any modification which may be made necessary.

abstract: One of the largest meetings over convened within the walls of Cooper Institute assembled Saturday evening pursuant to a call for citizens of all parties in favor of the election of Hon. GEORGE OPDYKE to the Mayoralty. Within the hall Judge  E.P. COWLES presided, and on taking the Chair spoke in support of the objects of the meeting. Addresses were also made by D.D. FIELD, HENEX J. RAYMOND, and others.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest meetings ever convened within the walls of Cooper Institute assembled Saturday evening pursuant to a call for citizens of all parties in favor of the election of Hon. GEORGE OPDYKE to the Mayoralty. Within the hall Judge E.P. COWLES presided, and on taking the Chair spoke in support of the objects of the meeting. Addresses were also made by D.D. FIELD, HENRY J. RAYMOND, and others. The outside demonstration was no less imposing, and comprised speeches, torchlight processions of the various Ward clubs, bonfires, and enthusiasm generally. The whole affair was well managed, and proved a complete success. After the mass meeting was over a procession of Ward clubs, joined by many prominent citizens, marched to Mr. OPDYKE's house in Fifth-avenue, where a fine pyrotechnic display took place and a speech was made by Mr. OPDYKE.

abstract: -- Mr. Silas Condit, a prominent and highly respected citizen of Newark, N.J., died on Friday, at the advanced age of 80 years. He has held numerous offices of importance, having been by turns a member of the State Legislature, a Representive in Congress, and a member of the Convention which formed the present Constitution of New-Jersey. His funeral will take place on Monday, at 11 o'clock A.M., from his late residence; and his remains will be interred in the graveyard of the First Presbyterian Church.

abstract: Some of our contemporaries are puzzling their wits over a historical allusion in BEAUREGARD's late letter concerning the synopsis of his official report, which was all that JEFF. DAVIS would allow to be published. "ALCIBIADES," he says, "on a certain occasion, resorted to an extraordinary method to occupy the minds of his traducers -- let, then, that synopsis answer the same purpose for me in this instance." Now, ALCIBIADES is said to have cut off his dog's tail to attract public attention, in order that his more grievous [???] might not be brought under discussion. BEAUREGARD has allowed the tail of his report to be out off, as DAVIS would not allow it to appear entire, and presented it to the public In the form of a synopsis! The parallel is felicitous, but goes a good deal further than BEAUREGARD imagined. ALCIBIADES was a double traitor -- a traitor to his country and to those to whom he had betrayed his country -- and was finally put to death ignominiously by those to whom he had last proved treacherous. We commend the prototype to his careful study.

abstract: The telegraph has become a test of cotemporaneous notoriety. Whoever, to-day, occupies a corner in the public heart, or succeeds in exciting the public curiosity, may be sure that the trained lightning will chronicle his every movement, and notice his every pause. Thus, when three days since the item was flashed over the wires that Gen. JAMES H. LANE, of Kansas, supposed to be terrifying rebels and freeing their negroes in Missouri -- had suddenly dropped down in Cleveland, Ohio, where he was received with enthusiasm by the people, and of course made a speech, the electric current was not confined to the metallic conductors, but rippled perceptibly through the channels of Anti-Slavery feeling in the North. And those who know the man and understand the direction of his ambition, and the nature of his later policy, will be at no loss to know why he should take Boston in his route from Kansas to Washington, and strive to conquer the prejudices of that Puritan town by a speech in Tremont Temple; nor will such be astonished to learn that, at last, one of that class of Western politicians whom EMERSON describes as "half orator, half assassin," has fairly conquered the dilettanteism of the modern Athens, and, speaking from the platform where PHILLIPS and SUMNER have reigned, has aroused such a tempest of enthusiasm in his refined audience as has seldom, if ever before, been witnessed within those walls.

abstract: The Astor House was very quiet, yesterday, Gen. FREMONT devoting most of the day to business of chiefly private interest. However, a number of calls were made during the forenoon. Among those who paid their respects were Assistant Commissary-General...
lead_paragraph: The Astor House was very quiet, yesterday, Gen. FREMONT devoting most of the day to business of chiefly private interest. However, a number of calls were made during the forenoon. Among those who paid their respects were Assistant Commissary-General WELCH, Messrs. ROBINSON, WM. H. ASPINWALL, GEORGE W. CURTIS, and SYDNEY H. GAY. The noted dramatist and delineator, BARNEY WILLIAMS, was not the least observed or the least agreeable of the visitors.

abstract: has signalized its first sitting by passing a vote of thanks to Capt. WILKES for the seizure of Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL. Nothing is more natural than that which is uppermost in the public mind should leap to expression through the voice of the people's Representatives. In thus putting on record a formal approval of an act which has called forth universal public satisfaction, there is, of course, no intention to prejudge a case on which neither our own nor the British Government has as yet pronounced an opinion, and which is now properly a matter of diplomacy alone. We all liked the bold deed, and we liked it all the better because it seemed to be perfectly justified by the principles and precedents of international law. Should it not be so justified, there can be no hesitation as to the course to be pursued -- however gratifying the seizure of the rebel Ambassadors may have been, it is not worth the sacrifice of a single principle of the public morality of nations. Meanwhile, we can, of course, but await further developments. The resolution of thanks which Congress has voted to Capt. WILKES, therefore, embodies a perfectly just sentiment, without at all binding the policy of the Government, or embarrassing the Secretary of State in the pursuit of such a course as, on a full examination of the question in all its bearings, may seem to be dictated by right and the law of nations.

abstract: Both branches of Congress got into working order yesterday, and both of them entered at once into the active duties of the session. The Senate was called to order at noon and after the preliminary formalities.
lead_paragraph: Both branches of Congress got into working order yesterday, and both of them entered at once into the active duties of the session. The Senate was called to order at noon and after the preliminary formalities. Mr. TRUMBULL immediately gave notice that he would to-day introduce a bill to confiscate the property of rebels, and give freedom to persons in Slave States. In the House, also, Mr. ELIOT introduced resolution, advising the President, as Commander-in-Chief of the army, to issue an order of general emancipation whenever such action should be demanded by military necessities -- which resolutions were afterwards amended so as to apply only to the slaves of disloyal citizens. Other resolutions on the subject were offered by CAMPBELL, of Pennsylvania, and by THAD. STEVENS, of the same State, one looking to legislative and the other to military action on the question. These signs indicate that the slave question is likely to occupy the most prominent part in congressional discussion and action this session. If the vote on tabling Mr. ELIOT's resolution is any indication of the divisions of parties, it would seem that opinion is pretty closely divided -- at all events on military abolition. It is to be hoped that there will be no hasty and unconsiderd legislation on a question involving interests so vast, and principles so vital, and policy no untried, delicate and complicated.

abstract: The election to-day is one of very great importance to the City, and should command the attention of every citizen. We have not the least doubt that a very large majority of our people are opposed to the reelection of Mayor
lead_paragraph: The election to-day is one of very great importance to the City, and should command the attention of every citizen. We have not the least doubt that a very large majority of our people are opposed to the reelection of Mayor WOOD. The only thing which will cause doubt in their minds as to the vote they shall cast, is doubt as to which is the strongest of the two candidates against him. Thousands of both political parties would vote for either OPDYKE or GUNTHER, without regard to their political position, but governed solely by the consideration how best to defeat their common opponent. It is for the interest of each candidate to magnify his own strength, and having no special means of forming an opinion upon the subject, the great mass of voters are naturally puzzled as to the course by which their votes can be made most effective.

abstract: The Board of Underwriters has wisely abated its rate of insurance from the war standard of five per cent. to two per cent., a rate thought quite ample to cover all the risks the merchant navy is likely to incur from the
lead_paragraph: The Board of Underwriters has wisely abated its rate of insurance from the war standard of five per cent. to two per cent., a rate thought quite ample to cover all the risks the merchant navy is likely to incur from the privateers of JEFF. DAVIS. At the earliest moment of panic the larger exaction seemed not unreasonable, even to the shipper. The ocean, according to the rebel programme, was to be at once peopled with privateers, who should be set every highway and by-path of trade, and frighten the coward commerce of tho Yankees from the seas. The Rio broad-bottomed coffee ship -- the tea and silk laden clipper from China -- the steamer with treasure front California were to be unsparingly waylaid, and carried into rebel ports, there to disgorge their contents for the advantage of rebel shopkeepers. The thing was plausible. In the rebel ports was no lack of shipping; FLOYD only knew what stores of guns and war material were at their disposal; and as for the malignity, and the greed, and the poverty, which should stimulate such enterprises, could there be doubt? Therefore, in the Spring, the insurer said live per cent., and the insured contentedly paid it.

abstract: -- We understand thatthe American mail-steamer Fulton, which was to sail next Saturday for Southampton and Havre, has been withdrawn, in consequence of the lack of business. A good deal of uneasiness has been created among shippers, as well as among persons designing to go to Europe, by the utter lack of protection for any of our vessels on the main track to Europe. The rebel privateer Nashville was at Southampton on the 20th of November, and it was generally understood that she was intending to cruise against American vessels on the European coast. Some fears have been expressed lest she should capture the Arago, with Gen. SCOTT and THURLOW WEED on board, but there is little danger of this. The Arago was due at Southampton on the 21st, and there was no probability of the Nashville's leaving before that time.

abstract: Congress assembled, yesterday, at noon, with a quorum in both Houses, and immediately proceeded to business. The customary joint committee was appointed to wait on the President, and notify him that they were ready to receive
lead_paragraph: Congress assembled, yesterday, at noon, with a quorum in both Houses, and immediately proceeded to business. The customary joint committee was appointed to wait on the President, and notify him that they were ready to receive any communication he might be pleased to make and he signified his intention to send in his Message to-day, at noon. Previous to the adjournment of the Senate, Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois' gave notice that he will introduce a bill to confiscate the property of rebels, and give freedom to persons in Slave States, and Mr. WILKINSON, of Minnesota, similar notice of a bill to abolish the distinction between regulars and volunteers. In the House a number of new members were sworn in, among them Mr. MAYNARD, of Tennessee. There was some question as to his right to a seat, but it was explained that he was elected before the secession of Tennessee, and there was no further objection. The case of Mr. FOSTER, represented to have been elected from the Hatteras District of North Carolina, was referred to the Committee on Elections, as was that of Mr. SEGAR, holding a certificate of election from Eastern Virginia. A joint resolution of thanks to Capt. WILKES, for his arrest of MASON and SLIDELL, was passed. A resolution was passed expelling JOHN REID, member of the House from the Fifth District of Missouri, he having taken up arms against the Government. Mr. COLFAX, of Indiana, offered a preamble and resolution, which were unanimous-adopted, requesting the President to direct the confinement of the Rebel Envoy MASON in the cell of a convicted, felon, until Col. CORCORAN shall be treated by the rebels as the United States have treated all prisoners taken by them on the battle-field. It was subsequently decided to advise the same treatment of SLIDELL, in reference to the imprisonment of Col. WOOD. Mr. ELIOT, of Massachusetts, then offered a series of resolutions, solemnly declaring that the war now pending is simply waged by the Government for the suppression of the rebellion and the reestablishment of the Union, but twisting upon the right of the President to emancipate all persons held as slaves in any military district in a state of insurrection against the Government, and advising such a course. The Souse refused to table the resolution, 70 against [???], but its consideration was postponed for a week. Various other resolutions on the same subject were offered for future consideration. On motion of ROSCOE A. CONKLING, of New-York, the Secretary of War was requested to inform the House whether any steps had been taken to ascertain who was responsible for the disaster at Ball's Bluff.

abstract: The following gentlemen have declined the nominations tendered them: JOHN A. WEEKS has declined the nomination for Alderman of the Fourteenth District, tendered him by the Taxpayers' Association. ABRAHAM LENT, B.L. SOLOMON, S.T. RUSSELL, GEOGRISWOLD, E.J.COLGATE and J.T. JOHNSON have declined
lead_paragraph: The following gentlemen have declined the nominations tendered them: JOHN A. WEEKS has declined the nomination for Alderman of the Fourteenth District, tendered him by the Taxpayers' Association. ABRAHAM LENT, B.L. SOLOMON, S.T. RUSSELL, GEO. GRISWOLD, E.J. COLGATE and J.T. JOHNSON have declined the nomination for Councilmen of the Sixth District, tendered them by the Taxpayers. In publishing a list of candidates, yesterday, by mistake Mr. H.H. abstract: Our neighbor of the Herald is in ecstacies over a windfall that has happened to him in the shape of a bit of official pap. The Board of Canvassers has ordered the return of votes cast at the last election, which we published...
lead_paragraph: Our neighbor of the Herald is in ecstacies over a windfall that has happened to him in the shape of a bit of official pap. The Board of Canvassers has ordered the return of votes cast at the last election, which we published two days ago, to be advertised in its columns exclusively! The Herald is as tickled as a small boy with a new drum. It sings the praises of the Board of Canvassers, whom it considers the wisest and most virtuous body of men ever assembled on this continent, and is especially exuberant over one of them, a benighted individual named BLUNT, who seems to have supposed the Herald the only newspaper of any circulation in this City. His remark on this subject seems to have been a perfect godsend to the Herald, which will puff him for a year to come by way of reward. We hope his character is good enough not to be injured by such a process.

abstract: The prize schooner Albion, of Nassau, N.P., (formerly the Lucy R. Waring, of Baltimore,) Acting Master G.N. Hoop, arrived Sunday from Charleston Bar in four days. She was taken by the United States steamer Penguin on Nov. 25, off North Edisto Island.
lead_paragraph: The prize schooner Albion, of Nassau, N.P., (formerly the Lucy R. Waring, of Baltimore,) Acting Master G.N. HOOD, arrived Sunday from Charleston Bar in four days. She was taken by the United States steamer Penguin on Nov. 25, off North Edisto Island, and has on board a cargo of fruit, salt, saddles, boots and shoes, and a quantity of leather and bridles. Thesalt is stowed under a new suit of sails, and it is supposed there are arms concealed below it. She was from Nassau, and said to be bound to New-York. The log on board had been kept regularly up to Nov. 23. When taken, she was steering N.N.W., with the wind from S.W., heading for Charleston.

abstract: So far as public appearances went, last night was a very quiet one amongst the politicians; but, at their head-quarters and other places of resort for transacting their peculiar kind of business, they were as busy as bees.
lead_paragraph: So far as public appearances went, last night was a very quiet one amongst the politicians; but, at their head-quarters and other places of resort for transacting their peculiar kind of business, they were as busy as bees. There was all the machinery of ticket-distributingto be set in motion and "oiled;" the arrangements about polling booths to be completed; the last finishing-touches to be put to little private combinations amongst individuals and cliques, the results of which will be discovered early this evening. These things are not done openly, though, and consequently attract no attention from the uninitiated. Wherever a knot of politicians met, in the street or a refreshment-saloon, they canvassed the possible up-shot of the election, of course. It was universally conceded that WOOD could hardly fail to run strongly, whilst few believed that GUNTHER had the ghost of a chance. The general tendency of popular faith, however, was unquestionably in favor of GEORGE OPDYKE. The nearer the crisis of the struggle approaches the more enthusiastically his friends flock around his standard.

abstract: The right of the House of Representatives to measure the qualifications of its members is not to be disputed. The proper exercise of the right is one, however, which does not concern Congress alone, but may readily enlarge to the proportions of a National question.
lead_paragraph: The right of the House of Representatives to measure the qualifications of its members is not to be disputed. The proper exercise of the right is one, however, which does not concern Congress alone, but may readily enlarge to the proportions of a National question. This is strikingly so at the present moment. The mass of the people of certain States are in armed insurrection against the Government. They have withdrawn their Representatives from Washington. Many of those who were elected from the insurgent States as members of either House, are now actually engaged in rebellion. The right and propriety of expelling these, are too palpable to be doubted. Equally clear is the propriety of admitting to seats in the House, those who, like Mr. MAYNARD, of Tennessee, though coming from a disloyal State, was chosen by and properly represents a loyal constituency, and whose claim to recognition is as incontestable as that of Speaker GROW himself.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Aldermen FRANKS in the Chair. Before the regular session, the Aldermen organized as Board of Canvassers, but as the Committee having the returns in charge was not ready to report, no business was transacted, and the Board adjourned until Thursday evening next. Alderman STRONG, of the Committee, stated that he believed that there were not ten returns throughout the whole city correct, which accounted for the Committee not being prepared to report. The Common Council was then organized. Alderman LEMAN called up from the table the report of the Law Committee, relative to the Fifth-avenue opening between Flatbush and Atlantic avenues, when the resolutions attached were adopted, referring the claims against said improvement to the Law Committee, in connection with the Counselor and Comptroller, for settlement, with power to settle and pay the same on such terms as they may deem most advantageous to the city, and directing the Attorney and Counselor to prosecute the parties who petitioned for said imprisonment, provided he deemssuch a course expedient.

abstract: NEW-YORK ACADEMY or MEDICINE. -- A special meeting of the Academy was held, Nov. 30, 1861, at the University, Washington-square, to take action in reference to the death of a late Fellow, Dr. R.S. KISSAM, Dr. JAS. ANDERSON, President, in the Chair, and a large number of Fellows present. Dr. ANDERSON stated the object of the meeting, and, on motion, appointed Drs. VALENTINE MOTT, J.P. BATCHELDER and A.K. GARDNER a Committee to draft resolutions. The Committee soon afterwards reported a suitable preamble and resolutions, which were read and accepted as the sense of the meeting.

abstract: This regiment, which has been quartered at Palace Garden two months, finally departed for the seat of war yesterday afternoon. Prior to leaving, they marched to the vicinity of the Brooklyn City Hall, where Mayor KALBFLEISCU and a number of...
lead_paragraph: This regiment, which has been quartered at Palace Garden two months, finally departed for the seat of war yesterday afternoon. Prior to leaving, they marched to the vicinity of the Brooklyn City Hall, where Mayor KALBFLEISCU and a number of members of the Common Council received them. Subsequently the Mayor presented the regiment with a stand of colors, consisting of a silk national flag the gift of the City of Brooklyn. The speeches of the Mayor and Col. DODGE were commendably brief, and the regiment soon resumed their march and proceeded to the Jersey City Ferry en route for the seat of war. They number 750 men, and are armed with the Belgian rifle of 1842, altered to percussion locks. Their officers are as follows:

abstract: It seems that the accident which happened on board of the steamer Francis Skiddy a few nights since was more serious than was at first supposed. One of the boilers of the Skiddy exploded, by reason of her coming in collision with the schooner W.W. ...
lead_paragraph: It seems that the accident which happened on board of the steamer Francis Skiddy a few nights since was more serious than was at first supposed. One of the boilers of the Skiddy exploded, by reason of her coming in collision with the schooner W.W. Reynolds, of Poughkeepsie. The boom of the schooner entered the side of the Skiddy and stove in one of her boilers. The consequence was an explosion on the Skiddy, which killed two persons outright; another was fatally injured and several seriously scalded. The schooner was proceeding in the same direction as the steamer and carried no lights -- consequently, the pilot on the steamer did not discover her until a collision was inevitable. The names of the killed were ISAAC BLOOMER and URIAH BARRITT. ROBERT HARDEE, the cook was so seriously scalded that he died soon after. A man named SIPLEY was burned to such an extent that he cannot recover.

abstract: Commodore WILKES, yesterday, removed his quarters from the St. Nicholas Hotel to the Brevoort House. He was there visited by a few friends, and by the Joint Committee of the Common Council, who have his public reception in charge. The Committee after a brief interview, were informed that Capt. WILKES would appoint a day for the reception as soon as possible. Capt. WILKES passed the night at Staten Island, but will return with his wife and family to the Brevoort about noon to-day.

abstract: "Enfans Perdus" is the quaint designation adopted by a new regiment now organizing in this City under French auspices. The regiment will be commanded by Col. CONFORT, who has had fifteen years' experience in Algeria, was in the Crimea and...
lead_paragraph: Italy, and thoroughly -- practically -- understands his profession. Most of his officers have also received the "baptism of fire," (some of them with GARIBALDI,) and recruits will have to prove that they, too, have done duty in the field. The uniform of the new regiment is the neatest, jauntiest and most sensible (for light infantry) yet introduced amongst us. It is on the pattern of that worn by the famous Chasseurs d' A frique, (a pied,) and is an improvement on the well known Zouave costume. The trowsers are not so baggy, the jacket has short tunic lapels and the cap is of the kepi instead of the fez pattern. In color the uniform is, throughout, dark blue, trimmed with yellow; is made of serviceable cloth, and will wear well, at the same time it looks so handsome. Les Enfans Perdus are not to be brigaded with any other regiments, but are to form a separate corns, to act as scouts and tirailleurs under the special orders of Gen.McCLELLAN.

abstract: Evidences of the latent Unionism of the South begin to crop out more and more every day. Whether it be that the advance of our army is giving courage to the depressed and terrified loyalists, or whether it is that rebel tyranny is becoming so intolerable as to drive those who were once freemen to extremes, makes no difference. The sentiment evidently exists, and is beginning to make itself felt.

abstract: We print a letter from Washington this morning from an old correspondent of the TIMES, whose signature of "YEOMAN" will probably be recognized, as the author of the most valuable series of letters from the Seaboard and other Slave States ever published in an American newspaper.
lead_paragraph: We print a letter from Washington this morning from an old correspondent of the TIMES, whose signature of "YEOMAN" will probably be recognized, as the author of the most valuable series of letters from the Seaboard and other Slave States ever published in an American newspaper. He discusses the relations of Slavery to the Rebellion, -- and especially the belief, universal at the South and widely current in the Northern States, that Slavery contributes to the military strength of the South. He regards this as utterly fallacious, and refers to the incidents which took place on the capture of Port Royal as conclusive in its refutation. The fact that the slaves of that region, -- the most ignorant, secluded, and the least likely to be informed of the objects and progress of the war, refused to follow their masters when ordered away, and came voluntarily to our troops for protection, shows conclusively that we can paralyze whatever power Slavery contributes to the rebellion, just as fast as our armies penetrate the interior. He suggests that if the Government should take possession of certain districts, or mere fortified points in the South, at convenient distances around the planting region, and make them asylums for negroes, the very existence of such harbors of refuge would exert a prodigious effect upon the whole slave population of the Southern States.

abstract: TO ALL PERSONS NOW ENGAGED IN WORKING FOR THE GREAT FAIR FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE CHILDREN OF VOLUNTEERS FROM THIS CITY. -- The managers of the Union Home School now call upon all societies and churches, or persons that have been working for the Great Fair, to bring in all articles on Thursday, Friday or Saturday of the present week, any time after 11 o'clock A.M., as the Fair will be opened on Monday next, Dec. 9, 1861. The managers appeal to all persons to contribute one article for the benefit of the motherless children of our Volunteers. Any articles that can be used at the Fair or at the Home School, may be left before Thursday, with the President, Mrs. ROBERT ANDERSON, Fifth-avenue Hotel, or Mrs. DRAKE MILLS, Vice-President, No. 23 Fifth-avenue. On or after Thursday, all articles may be left at the rooms, No. 524 Broadway, one door below Spring-street, where the Fair will be held.

abstract: As the first rumors of the result of the election in favor of Mr. OPDYKE began to reach No. 618 Broadway, the headquarters selected by the supporters of the successful candidate for the Mayoralty, continuous streams of people set in for that centre.
lead_paragraph: As the first rumors of the result of the election in favor of Mr. OPDYKE began to reach No. 618 Broadway, the headquarters selected by the supporters of the successful candidate for the Mayoralty, continuous streams of people set in for that centre. By 7 P.M. the rooms and corridors of the building, which is very ill adapted to such occasions, were thronged, and the adjacent sidewalks densely packed with a swaying mass of men, eagerly canvassing the returns and debating the chances. It was already believed that GEORGE OPDYKE had been elected, but only, as some vehement partisans elegantly and anatomically expressed it, "by the skin of his teeth."

abstract: The interest which attaches to the military operations of the National army on the line  of the Potomac, has induced us to present the readers of the TIMES with the above very complete and accurate map of the impregnable lines on the Virginia side of the National Capital.
lead_paragraph: The interest which attaches to the military operations of the National army on the line of the Potomac, has induced us to present the readers of the TIMES with the above very complete and accurate map of the impregnable lines on the Virginia side of the National Capital. These masterly defences sweep from the neighborhood of Great Falls, ten miles above Washington, southward to the mouth of the Accotink Creek, 15 miles below the City; and occupy the arc of a circle the outermost point of which, in the direction of the main body of the enemy at Manassas, may be fixed at Flint Hill. This territory is actually in possession of our troops; the National pickets and reconnoitering parties frequently pushing miles nearer the rebel host, but fully maintainingthe ground embraced between the dotted line traced on the map, and the banks of the Potomac.
