abstract: DISTURBANCE IN THE SIXTH WARD. -- A fight took place yesterday afternoon, near the polls in Leonard-street, between DAVID LOFTUS and JOHN HELLIS (an emigrant runner) on one side, and MARTIN WATERS on the other. WATERS refused to vote for WOOD, and this gave offence to the others, who made an attack upon him. HELLIS drew a pistol, and struck WATERS on the side of the head. The force of the blow caused the pistol to go off, and the bullet passed through a throng of bystanders, but, fortunately, did no injury. At this point, Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinct Police, seeing that the affray was growing serious, rushed in and took HELLIS into custody. LOFTUS made his escape through the back window of a house in the neighborhood. The wounds inflicted upon WATERS are very serious. HELLIS was detained in the Sixth Ward Station-house last night. This morning he will be taken to the Tombs for examination.

abstract: CHRISTOPHER CHOLWELL, residing in East Houston-street, was so seriously injured in an affray about three weeks ago, that he died yesterday from the wounds then received. The deceased was attending a family party in Mulberry-street at the time of the occurrence, and put into a quarrel with his brother-in-law, JOSEPH MINNOW. During the quarrel, MINNOW struck the deceased on the head with a decanter. The wounds thus received were not at first regarded as serious, but inflammation subsequently set in, and he lingered until yesterday. A warrant was issued yesterday afternoon, by Coroner JACKMAN, for the arrest of MINNOW, and he was taken into custody, and held to await the result of the inquest. The deceased was lately employed as a driver on the Second-avenue line of stages. He was about 35 years of age, and leaves a wife and several children.

abstract: The Secretary of the Navy is happy in being able to make his report at a time when the whole country rings with applause at the brilliant service lately rendered by the arm of the National service which he directs.
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of the Navy is happy in being able to make his report at a time when the whole country rings with applause at the brilliant service lately rendered by the arm of the National service which he directs. The story of the Stars and Stripes on sea will not fall on cold or apathetic ears, for the navy is the peculiar pride of America -- our glory in peace, our triumph in war. At the outbreak of the rebellion, the public instinct spontaneously pointed to it as the arm on which we should chiefly rely. Our ships have sailed freighted with the Nation's hopes, and the country has a right to read with jealous interest the record of their achievements.

abstract: The memorable Mayoralty election of 1861 has gloriously terminated in the success of GEORGE OPDYKE, the Republican and Union candidate. The struggle was waged with spirit by the friends of all the three leading candidates, and until late in the day seemed of doubtful result, the Gunther...
lead_paragraph: The memorable Mayoralty election of 1861 has gloriously terminated in the success of GEORGE OPDYKE, the Republican and Union candidate. The struggle was waged with spirit by the friends of all the three leading candidates, and until late in the day seemed of doubtful result, the Gunther Party revealing unexpected strength, owing to heavy defections from the standard of FERNANDO WOOD and the aid of a considerable German vote. Mr. OPDYKE, sustained by the Republicans, the Tax-payers, the German Union League and a noteworthy conservative phalanx of National Democrats, received 25,258; C. GODFREY GUNTHER, 24,639, and FERNANDO WOOD, 21,084 votes, the result giving Mr. OPDYKE a plurality of 1,173 over WOOD, and 619 over GUNTHER -- the latter candidate outstripping WOOD by 565 votes. As the figures show, the total vote was much heavier than in November, and the most intense interest waited on the issue. Few disturbances occurred, and they were of no serious magnitude. The City, the State and the country have reason to rejoice over a result that strengthens the cause of the Union.

abstract: The Charter election, yesterday, was, considering the intensity of the feeling enlisted for and against the candidates for the principal offices to be filled, unusually orderly and well conducted. There has not been an election since that which resulted in the choice of ABRAHAM LINCOLN to the Presidency, which the people of the City have evinced so much eagerness ...
lead_paragraph: The Charter election, yesterday, was, considering the intensity of the feeling enlisted for and against the candidates for the principal offices to be filled, unusually orderly and well conducted. There has not been an election since that which resulted in the choice of ABRAHAM LINCOLN to the Presidency, which the people of the City have evinced so much eagerness and impatience to learn the particulars of, as the election yesterday. From an early hour in the evening, until the time the full vote for the candidates for the Mayoralty was announced, the business office of the TIMES, and a considerable portion of the space in front, was crammed with people who shouted for news, and when it came, shouted for OPDYKE, until news came again; and, when the grand result was announced, the cheering was tremendous.

abstract: The scenes in and around the Old Wigwam last evening were not of that spirited and jubilant nature which were witnessed in the days when she was the resort of the united and victorious Democratic Party. The crowd in attendance was less numerous far less enthusiastic, and infinitely less belligerent than of old.
lead_paragraph: The scenes in and around the Old Wigwam last evening were not of that spirited and jubilant nature which were witnessed in the days when she was the resort of the united and victorious Democratic Party. The crowd in attendance was less numerous far less enthusiastic, and infinitely less belligerent than of old. Still, there was a certain kind of joy manifested as the returns came in -- a joy not unlike that which one feels on seeing a bully antagonist, whom he is unable to whip himself, soundly thrashed by a third party, even though he has no particular liking for party No. 3. It appeared to be glory enough for one night to know that the great FERNANDO was whipped, even though Tammany did not apply the lash. And when the gradually accumulating returns indicated that WOOD was the third in the race, and that the great Mozart organization had finally dwindled down to a tail of the Tammany kite, shouts of triumph rendered the air scarcely less boisterous than if Tammany herself had been victorious. The early returns were quite favorable to GUNTHER, and the crowd that had congregated in the lower halls, previous to the opening of the Hall, began to get quite enthusiastic with the idea that their candidate was elected. Then it was that the utter insignificance and contemptuousness of FERNANDO and his faction were vividly portrayed. Above the din and cackle of the jabbering throng, through the clouds of smoke, and the all-pervading fumes of whisky, could be heard the constantly repeated declaration, that "WOOD was played out;" "WOOD's gone in;" "WOOD's nowhere;" "D -- n WOOD;" "$500 to $200 that GUNTHER's our next Mayor," -- (this remark came from a man who had just borrowed six cents to get a drink;) "Three cheers for GUNTHER." At length it was announced that the doors of the Council Chamber were open, and the crowd rushed up stairs. Mr. JAMES NESBIT took the stand, and called the meeting to order. He said they had assembled to hear the returns of the election of C. GODFREY GUNTHER as Mayor of New-York. [Cheers for GUNTHER.] He had not much to say, himself, but would call on his friend, Mr. BOGERT, Mr. BOGERT not answering the call, there were cries for "CORNELL! Senator CORNELL!" Senator CORNELL also failed to respond, although he was in the hall, and there were calls for EBLING. Mr. EBLING took the stand, and read to the audience the returns of two or three Wards which seemed to favor the election of GUNTHER, whereat the boys gave three more cheers for that gentleman.

abstract: When the monastic walls of the Brooklyn Academy of Music were unveiled to the heathen eye of this City, there was a vile architectural scandal that the place when it had done growing would become a church.
lead_paragraph: When the monastic walls of the Brooklyn Academy of Music were unveiled to the heathen eye of this City, there was a vile architectural scandal that the place when it had done growing would become a church. The severity of this judgment was subsequently modified when the Board sanctioned the performance of "Don Giovanni" and "La Traviata," works which are not regarded as strictly Eclusiastical in their character. Still there was a churchiness about the establishment notwithstanding an occasional concession to the flesh and the devil, that made the itinerant sinner tremble in his musical shoes. The Board, an awful Institution, of fabulous numbers, mediaeval austerity and unimpeachable virtue, pervaded the lobbies, lingered on the staircases, guarded the stage, and creaked in all the private boxes. The Board, to say the least of it, struck terror into the bosoms of infidel managers, abashed the most reckless of that desperate band who persist in selling books in English and 1 -- taitan, and gave the thoughtful critic a piquant theme for home elaboration. Indeed, although one usually got wet and chilled by visiting the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was impossible to resist the reflection that one must be the better for it, here or hereafter; and this penitential comfort we are glad to see is still, not to be denied us. A gentleman who has recently arrived from the sister city, where he enjoys the distinguished disfavor of several members of the Board, and who we are bound to confess, lusts carnally for the price of his shares, and is therefore an object of just suspicion informs us that the Academy will fulfill its destiny and at no distant day have an organ, and a choir, and a popular preacher, and a number of enthusiasts with dishes for the eleemosynary dime. So many theatres go to the bad that the happy destiny of this one would rejoice us but for a grave query: What is to become of the Board, and the pleasing and picturesque tableaux which the members thereof were wont to present to the profane gaze on opera nights? Next to the condition of Mexico, it is surely one of the most perplexing questions of the day. The Board would undoubtedly draw at BARNUM's but in that wicked establishment theatrica entertainments are permitted; moreover an undue preponderance of white choker might throw the Belunga off his balance and cause the Hippopotamus to yawn even more clamorously than he does at present -- a result which we may reasonably suppose would be fatal to that friendly power. It is this matter of theatrical entertainments, indeed, that endangers the very existence of the Board. There are stockholders, it must be known, who desire to witness the drama. In a memorial to the Board, they expressed this wish adding (as a frivolous reason for some attention from that august body,) that they owned a majority of the stock. The matter was brought before the Board, and a warm discussion ensued. It was decided that the Secretary should address a circular to each individual stockholder, requesting him to state whether he is in favor of or opposed to letting the building for dramatic performances, under proper supervision and restrictions. The answers are to be sent in by Thursday of next week. In the meantime, seven members of the Board have issued a circular warning the stockholders of the awful peril that awaits them, and exhorting them to think twice before they "incur the risk of converting what is now a prejudice against the drama into a feeling of hostility to the Academy itself." And then, in a more touching vein, the Seven -- who speak for the Board much as the three tailors of Tooley-street spoke for the people of England -- continue:

abstract: My last letter was dated at Pleasant Hill, Cass County. Col. ANTHONY'S command left that place on Thursday morning. Having secured of the Government property 470 head of cattle and 32 wagons, the Colonel considered it advisable to make that secure before undertaking to drive out of the bush the four or five hundred rebels who had taken to the timber on learning of our approach.

abstract: A meeting in behalf of the Boston American Tract Society, with a special reference to the supply of the Union army with religious reading, was held at Rev. Dr. HAGUE'S Church, corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-first-street, last evening. Notwithstanding the weather was slightly unfavorable, a large attendance was present, and much interest was manifested in the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: A meeting in behalf of the Boston American Tract Society, with a special reference to the supply of the Union army with religious reading, was held at Rev. Dr. HAGUE's Church, corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-first-street, last evening. Notwithstanding the weather was slightly unfavorable, a large attendance was present, and much interest was manifested in the proceedings. The exercises were opened with the reading of the Scriptures by Rev. ASA D. SMITH, after which a prayer was offered by Dr. BUDDINGTON, of Brooklyn. Mr. SMITH then made some remarks, in which he stated the object of the meeting, and contended that our soldiers went forth to sustain the idea of Christianity and all the food principles of Government. The Church should cheer them on in their perilous cause by sending them reading matter, and administering to their spiritual and bodily wants. He would not say that all the soldiers were what CARLISLE had described CROMWELL to have been; but he would say that no army possessed so much of lofty principle and high tone of morality as that of ours, and this should be encouraged by the Church.

abstract: The Sanitary Commission, with questionable zeal and unquestionable taste, has been again disporting itself in the columns of the World, as a rival to the Medical Bureau of the army. For many reasons this ill-advised and eccentric conduct is to be regretted.
lead_paragraph: The Sanitary Commission, with questionable zeal and unquestionable taste, has been again disporting itself in the columns of the World, as a rival to the Medical Bureau of the army. For many reasons this ill-advised and eccentric conduct is to be regretted. In view of the prodigious interests at stake in the present crisis, the public will not allow a voluntary organization, to which such cherished objects and ample funds have been intrusted, to misuse power, obstruct discipline, or seek patronage, by stabbing the reputation of so able, energetic, experienced and well-qualified an officer as our Surgeon-General. Facilities for visiting the camps are given for no such ends, and should any department of the service suffer from these escapades, justice demands that the offenders be held to answer. No more suicidal course could be chosen by the Sanitary Commission than to let the belief get abroad that in any of its operations private schemes are paramount, and personal ambition supplants the public good.
headline: {'main': 'Camp Inspection and the Sanitary Commission.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Camp Inspection and the Sanitary Commission.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: One of the crew of the Grenada, a vessel captured sometime since by the privateer Sallie, of Charleston, who has recently arrived from Charleston and Richmond, has given us some interesting particulars in relation to the state of things there, and his own experiences. The Grenada, after being captured, was carried into an inlet a few miles south of...
lead_paragraph: One of the crew of the Grenada, a vessel captured sometime since by the privateer Sallie, of Charleston, who has recently arrived from Charleston and Richmond, has given us some interesting particulars in relation to the state of things there, and his own experiences. The Grenada, after being captured, was carried into an inlet a few miles south of Charleston, and taken to Charleston, where she and her cargo were bought by the Government for $75,000. Her cargo was sugar and molasses, and would have been worth some $50,000 here.

lead_paragraph: Mozart Hall was by turns jubilant and despondent, last evening, while the returns came in. Alternately cheering as Mayor WOOD's prospects brightened, and groaning as they darkened; now mounting to the acme of delight, and next descending to the despondency of despair, the vast crowd in the room, half-stifled with tobacco smoke and foul air, kept up the excitement for several hours. Hon. D.B. TAYLOR officiated as Chairman, and LEVI D. WHITE acted as Secretary, the one announcing as the other footed up the momentous figures.

abstract: President LINCOLN'S Message is precisely such a document as any one familiar with his character would have anticipated. It is clear, unpretending, frank and perfectly loyal to the declarations and acts of his whole political life.
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN's Message is precisely such a document as any one familiar with his character would have anticipated. It is clear, unpretending, frank and perfectly loyal to the declarations and acts of his whole political life. It sets forth the actual condition of the country without the slightest attempt at vainglorious boasting, or the least effort to belittle and underrate its dangers. While the President shows a just and firm reliance on the resources of the country and the patriotism of the people, he rushes into none of those extreme and perilous measures which captivate the imagination and respond to the passionate indignation of the people, -- nor does he lose sight for a moment of the permanent results which must be achieved by the war, in his eagerness to achieve some immediate and brilliant advantage. The dominant feature of the Message is its plain, clear common sense. It appeals to the judgment, -- the solid convictions of the people, rather than their resentments or their impatient hopes and aspirations.
headline: {'main': "The President's Message.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Message.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Senate, yesterday, transacted no business of importance. It was principally occupied in listening to the reading of the President's Message. Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, introduced a resolution thanking Capt. DUPONT and the officers, seamen and marines under his command, for their...
lead_paragraph: The Senate, yesterday, transacted no business of importance. It was principally occupied in listening to the reading of the President's Message. Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, introduced a resolution thanking Capt. DUPONT and the officers, seamen and marines under his command, for their achievement at Port Royal, which was laid aside for the present. Bills were also introduced with reference to the protection of guano deposits, and providing for filling the vacancies in the Board of Regents in the Smithsonian Institution. In the House, Mr. MAYNARD presented the credentials of Mr. CLEMENS, Representative elect from the Fourth District of Tennessee, which were referred to the Committee on Elections. After which the President's Message was read. Mr. DUNN offered resolutions providing for the expulsion of HENRY C. BURNETT, of Kentucky, who is in open rebellion against the Government. On these resolutions Mr. WICKLIFFE, of Kentucky, made a very effective speech, in which he predicted that by the 25th of this month no rebel foot would be found on the soil of his State. The resolutions were then adopted. A resolution was also passed giving more time for taking evidence on the contested case in the Third District of Pennsylvania. After which the House adjourned to discuss, at its leisure, the President's Message.

abstract: "Two days since, Col. JENNISON mounted twenty-five of the boys, under command of First Lieut. BOSTWICK. Capt. BURCHARD, Gen. LYON's scout, who is raising a company for this corps, was also detailed to accompany the party. They were ordered to beat up the neighborhood of the Hays' settlement, which is only eight miles distant. According to orders the buildings of Col. HAYS and two others were burned to the ground. A quantity of arms, horses and 'contrabands' were taken. The party then moved to the house of SAM. HAYS, on the Westport road. This house stands back some sixty rods from the road. Lieut. BOSTWICK, ordering his men to remain in the road with Capt. BURCHARD, rode across to the house to search for arms. They hitched their horses, and entered the building. They passed through with Mr. HAYS, and stepped on the porch. The moment they did so, some fifty men rose in the corn-field a few rods in advance and lived upon them. HAYS fell very severely wounded. Capt. BURCHARD was shot through his clothing in several places, but not hurt. Both officers rushed for their horses, and as they seized their bridles, another volley was fired into them. Lieut. BOSTWICK's horse received twoballs and fell. Both then succeeded in reaching the road. The boys by this time had returned the Confederate fire. Only eighteen were armed with rifles. The advance scouts and guides had ridden away at the first fire. Within a short distance they were fired upon by an ambushed party numbering about fifty. From the other direction another party of the same size, was seen. Thus the little band was almost surrounded by six times their own force. They maintained their ground as long as possible, firing some thirty rounds. They know three were killed, and several wounded. None of our men were wounded. Lieut. BOSTWICK was knocked down by a glancing ball on the forehead and two horses were killed. A lad of 15, employed as messenger by the Colonel, had his hair cut by a ball, but, as he phrased, 'the man who did it was crossing a fence, but he didn't cross any more.' After a while, the Lieutenant ordered the boys to break for the brush. They were followed up sharply. Three of them, closely pursued by twelve, hid themselves in the brush; they were discovered, and avolley fired on them. Not a ball struck, though the dirt was thrown in their faces. Lieut. BOSTWICK turned and shouted, 'Come on boys!' The rebels fled. The Nationals returned to camp in safety, without furthercasualty."

abstract: In pursuance of orders issued by Gen. DIX, Major D.P. DEWITT, with a guard of nine men of the Second Regiment of Maryland Volunteers, left Baltimore on Monday morning with nine secession prisoners, who had been confined at Fort McHenry, for Fort Lafayette. The guard and the prisoners, on arriving at Amboy, embarked on a steamer for the Fort yesterday morning, and the captives were delivered to the care of Col. BURKE. Among them is the celebrated "French Lady," Col. THOMAS, who is charged with piracy and treason. The remaining prisoners are charged with having uttered treasonable language, and corresponding with the enemy. The following are the names of the captives:

abstract: Commodore WILKES, whose presence would, at almost any other time, have created a sensation amongst us, has been completely overshadowed by the election excitement. He has been in the City ever since Sunday, yet has scarcely attracted any public notice at all. This apparent neglect must not be attributed to any want of appreciation of the gallant exploit which has made his name the most famous of the hour; but simply to the accident of his arrival at a time when the people and the authorities were completely absorbed in local matters of the highest importance. Now that we know who is to be our next Mayor, we shall have plenty of time and enthusiasm to expend upon the welcome which is Commodore WILKES' due.
lead_paragraph: Commodore WILKES, whose presence would, at almost any other time, have created a sensation amongst us, has been completely overshadowed by the election excitement. abstract: By the annual Government report, it appears that this State is in a very prosperous condition. The Minister of the Interior recounts, with great satisfaction, the many improvements that have taken place in the country during the past eight years -- in the construction of roads, building of bridges, public edifices; in increased mail and commercial facilities, and in the development of agriculture. He states that iron wharves are to be made at San Jose; that Artesian wells have been bored, and that, in a short time, the port of San Jose will be one of the best on the coast. The finances are in a satisfactory condition -- the people contented and prosperous. Per contra: the editor of the Official Gazette says the people of San Jose are in a deplorable condition, -- no business, no money, -- and the heavy rains having made an island, almost, of the place.

abstract: The great excitement of the "naval engagement," yesterday, between the picket of gunboats on the James River, and the Yorktown, has not yet died out, and the pros and cons of the affair are still talked over. The general impression seems to be, among naval men and those who, at Newport's News witnessed the fight, that the gunboats did not behave in the most creditable manner.

abstract: The report of a battle between the Confederates and Buenos Ayres, on the 17th September, was correct. There were about 18,000 men on each side. The infantry of Gen. MITRE, of Buenos Ayres, completely defeated and scattered in every direction that of Gen. URQUIZA, while the cavalry of the latter seems to have done the same for the cavalry of MITRE. Altogether the battle does not appear to have been by any means a decisive one, both parties having fled --  URQUIZA having passed Entre-Rios, and MITRE was at San Nicola de los Arojos.

abstract: Our dates from Ecuador vid Paita, are to the 12th November. The acting President, Don GARCIA MORENO, as well as Gen. FLORES, were apparently pushing their schemes for a French ProtectorateFavorable accounts are said to have been received from ANTONIO FLORES, son of the General, who has been ten months in Paris, of the disposition of the French Emperor in that regard.
lead_paragraph: Our dates from Ecuador vid Paita, are to the 12th November. The acting President, Don GARCIA MORENO, as well as Gen. FLORES, were apparently pushing their schemes for a French Protectorate-Favorable accounts are said to have been received from ANTONIO FLORES, son of the General, who has been ten months in Paris, of the disposition of the French Emperor in that regard. And as a sign of what is going on, a merchant of Guayaquil has lately received a letter from Paris, directed -- "Senor BLANK, Guayaquil, French Colony." Another significant fact is the character of the appointments lately made; a Frenchman, Gen, BEAUMAN, has been made Commandant-General of Artillery; Col. TALBOT, an Englishman, Commandant-General of Cuenca; Gen. PALLARES, of Spain, has been given another Generalship; Gen. CORDERO, of Venezuela, a Generalship; Gen. GONZALEZ, of New-Granada, a Commandancy, and so on, evidencing that foreigners are being courted extensively.

abstract: Contrary to my usual arrangement, must have the precedence to-day over all the other States, as she has just exceeded them all in the enormity and atrocity of her crime. A year ago, or thereabout, Dr. LINARES, who had succeeded to the Presidency of Bolivia, after thirty six attempts at revolution, was in turn thrust aside by a military conspiracy headed by Gen. ACHA; the conspirators,
lead_paragraph: Contrary to my usual arrangement, must have the precedence to-day over all the other States, as she has just exceeded them all in the enormity and atrocity of her crime. A year ago, or thereabout, Dr. LINARES, who had succeeded to the Presidency of Bolivia, after thirty six attempts at revolution, was in turn thrust aside by a military conspiracy headed by Gen. ACHA; the conspirators, scarcely an hour before they drew the sword against LINARES, having broken bread at his table. The Ex-President went to Valparaiso, and died there only last month. Gen. ACHA, of course, on his accession to power, found Ex-President BELZU, Ex-President CORDOVA, the son-in-law of the latter, and the friends of Dr. LINARES all leagued against him, and inciting the people to revolution. But having organized quite a large military force, under the pretence that Bolivia was to be attacked by Peru, he was able to suffocate easily all rebellions and to defy his enemies. On the morning of the 30th September last, one of these attempts against ACHA was made by the friends of BELZU, at La Paz, but was not very well supported, and about forty of the principal men of the city, who were charged with being the leaders, were seized and thrown into prison. La Paz, a city of 60,000 inhabitants, was declared in a state of siege, and Gen. PLACIDO YANEZ appointed military commandante. The city became tranquil again, but nevertheless, a good deal of dissatisfaction existed among the friends of the prisoners, that they should be kept in confinement without trial, and there were undoubtedly threats made that they would be violently rescued. Gen. YANEZ, it is charged, wishing to get rid of these leaders, instigated a sham emeute in the vicinity of their prisons, the object being made to appear to rescue them from the authorities. Accordingly at 12 1/2 on the morning of the 23d of October, a cry of "Viva CORDOVA!" was raised in front of his prison, when a sharp fusilade was heard for a few moments, and then all was still. Sixty of the principal men of Bolivia had been murdered -- some of them in their beds, and all in a defenceless condition, without arms, and one hundred and eighty poor Indians, or cholos, as an excuse for this massacre, were shot down like dogs in the streets! Among the prominent men assassinated, and who had been identified in the Pantheon, were:

abstract: The announced object of Sir FENWICK WILLIAMS' visit to Quebec, his present Upper Canada tour, the movement of munitions of war from the seaboard to the interior, the construction of fortifications at exposed points of our lake coast, are amongst the circumstances which demonstrate the determination of the Imperial Government to discharge its whole duty to Canada, should hostilities occur. New, as in other days, if war come, the full power of England will be exerted in our defence. And though we think these precautionary preparations would have been better had they been undertaken earlier -- though we believe that the present number of Imperial troops should have been quadrupled before the close of navigation -- the signs we see about us may well silence the expression of misgivings and inspire our people with confidence in the future. With England to sustain us, come what may, we have nothing to fear. And the movements afoot tell us, in language not to be mistaken, that England is and will be with us in whatever trials may be in store.
lead_paragraph: The announced object of Sir FENWICK WILLIAMS' visit to Quebec, his present Upper Canada tour, the movement of munitions of war from the seaboard to the interior, the construction of fortifications at exposed points of our lake coast, are amongst the circumstances which demonstrate the determination of the Imperial Government to discharge its whole duty to Canada, should hostilities occur. abstract: Information reached Washington Last night that the rebel forces had occupied the town of Anandale, on the Little River Turnpike, and that their pickets had been extended some distance this side. abstract: JOHN A. COOLEY and JOHN EAGAN were arrested, on Tuesday night, in the Nineteenth Ward, for creating a disturbance, and for attempting to interrupt the progress of the canvass. It is charged that the two prisoners jumped into the inclosure where the canvass was going on; that COOLEY drew a large quantity of tickets from his pocket, and threw them upon the table where the ballots from the boxes had just been placed by the Canvassers, for the purpose of being counted. Before the disturbance was quelled, COOLEY drew a pistol; and threatened to shoot Alderman FARLEY. The disturbers were finally arrested, and yesterday they were taken before Justice KELLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court. COOLEY was held to bail in the sum of $500, upon each of two complaints. Ex-Alderman MCSPEDON became his surety.

abstract: It is generally understood that Gen. MCCLELLAN has issued orders for the establishment of Winter quarters among a large portion of the army. While there can be little doubt that this is the military policy so far as a part of the army is concerned, it must not be understood that it in any way interferes with the advance of the army, or its progress to Richmond. As a general thing, a course like this would be an unpopular one, but we do not see how it can be well avoided. The necessities of the army are such that it will be necessary for the officers in command to make arrangements for the comforts of the soldiers. They cannot expect to maintain an army in this inclement season in any southern climate north of Georgia or Florida without comfortably housing it; and whether it is concluded to detain our men for the Winter on the banks of the Potomac, the Rappahannock, or the James, it is certain that their residence must be made as pleasant as it is possible for it to be.
lead_paragraph: It is generally understood that Gen. MCCLELLAN has issued orders for the establishment of Winter quarters among a large portion of the army. abstract: Mr. ISAAC W. JONES, a widely known and highly esteemed commission merchant of this City, was killed on the New-Jersey Railroad on Tuesday evening. He was returning from New-York by the 5:30 P.M. train, to his residence in Metuchin, Middlesex County, N.J. In going forward from the cars of the New-Jersey Central to those of the New-Jersey Road, in the same train, he missed his footing, and, falling across the track, was run over by the greater portion of the train. The lower part of his body was brightfully mutilated, and instant death was the result. The accident occurred in the Bergen Cut. The remains were taken to Newark, where an inquest was to have been held yesterday.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ISAAC W. JONES, a widely known and highly esteemed commission merchant of this City, was killed on the New-Jersey Railroad on Tuesday evening. The lower part of his body was brightfully mutilated, and instant death was the result. The accident occurred in the Bergen Cut. The remains were taken to Newark, where an inquest was to have been held yesterday.

abstract: In addition to those published in yesterday's TIMES, the arrests for illegal voting were as follows; in the Eleventh Ward -- Peter Hogan was arrested, and Justice OSBORNE yesterday held him to bail in $300. Seventeenth Ward -- Thomas Fay. Eighteenth Ward -- Matthew O'Neil; committed by Justice KELLY. Nineteenth Ward -- Patrick Finnegan, and Michael O'Hele were arrested. James Kerrigan of the Twenty-second Ward, was arrested and committed by Justice Kelly for breaking ballot-boxes.

abstract: Is quiet. Congress has terminated its sessions. It has been discovered that the late Administration has disposed of the public money "as if it were the personal properly of the members, and, conseqently, the Treasury is in a critical condition." This relates to the $7,000,000 loan from England, with which to complete the Valparaiso and Santiago Railroad HARRY MEIGGS has made another offer to the Government, to complete it in ten months, instead of four years, on condition that he shall receive one half of the proceeds for the term of its charter.

abstract: The Wheat and Flour exported from New-York during the month of October is said to have amounted in value to more than a million and a half sterling. The imports of unmanufactured goods during the same period had been only 400,000, against 1,100,000 in same month last year; and of this total about one-half consisted of Woolen Goods for the army. Nearly all the markets had become drained of produce, andbrokers and merchants were anxious as to the effect or shipments of Breadstuffs being reduced to moderate proportions, which soon took place.

abstract: Christian Advertiser, a day or two since, what was styled a "Remarkable Prophecy," from Haggai, chap. iv., verses 8, 10 and 21st, wonderfully applicable to the present war, and its consequences to the South. We have received a multitude of letters informing us that there are but two chapters in Haggai, and that the Christian Advertiser has been badly hoaxed. It has this consolation, however, in common with ourselves, -- that it has stimulated a good many persons to search the Scriptures -- possibly for the first time.

abstract: The 29th of November is an ever-memorable day in the history of liberal Poland. Thirty-one years ago on that day, at 7 P.M., the students of Warsaw gave the signal of revolt, and drove fifteen thousand Russians from the city. For about a year the war for independence raged with fury, until discord among the leaders extinguished Poland's political existence.
lead_paragraph: FORT LYON, Va., Sunday, Dec. 1, 1861.

abstract: We publish in another column a curious letter from that logical, consistent and most unpractical philanthropist, GERRIT SMITH, to EDWIN CROSWELL, Esq. Its object is to remonstrate against the injustice done by that gentleman to the Abolitionists, by assuming that they will oppose the policy recommended by Col. COCHRANE, and indorsed by Mr. CROSWELL, in regard to employing the enfranchised slaves in the National army.
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column a curious letter from that logical, consistent and most unpractical philanthropist, GERRIT SMITH, to EDWIN CROSWELL, Esq. Its object is to remonstrate against the injustice done by that gentleman to the Abolitionists, by assuming that they will oppose the policy recommended by Col. COCHRANE, and indorsed by Mr. CROSWELL, in regard to employing the enfranchised slaves in the National army. Mr. SMITH says they will do no such thing. On the contrary they will give it, as he does, and as GARRISON and WENDELL PHILLIPS have done, their most cordial and effective support. Indeed, he says, it is precisely the policy which the Abolitionists have urged upon the Government from the very beginning of the rebellion.

abstract: Rumors were afloat yesterday that upon a canvass of the votes for Mayor irregularities and errors had been detected which would defeat OPDYKE and elect GUNTHER. After careful inquiry, we cannot find any ground whatever for these reports. The votes were canvassed on Tuesday night by the Inspectors of Election, -- and the result was given in the TIMES of yesterday. These returns were then sent to the Clerk of the Common Council, and have not since been reexamined by any one. Nor do we hear of any serious errors detected in any quarter, which can at all vary the result.
lead_paragraph: Rumors were afloat yesterday that upon a canvass of the votes for Mayor irregularities and errors had been detected which would defeat OPDYKE and elect GUNTHER. Nor do we hear of any serious errors detected in any quarter, which can at all vary the result.

abstract: By the City of Baltimore we receive the text of the treaty recently arranged between Great Britain, France and Spain, in reference to Mexican affairs. The treaty does not determine the strength of the combined force to be employed for the purpose of obtaining satisfaction from the Mexican authorities, but the contracting parties engage that "the total shall be sufficient to seize and occupy the several fortresses and military positions" on the coast.
lead_paragraph: By the City of Baltimore we receive the text of the treaty recently arranged between Great Britain, France and Spain, in reference to Mexican affairs. The treaty does not determine the strength of the combined force to be employed for the purpose of obtaining satisfaction from the Mexican authorities, but the contracting parties engage that "the total shall be sufficient to seize and occupy the several fortresses and military positions" on the coast. The allied commanders are to be allowed a wide discretion, and are authorized to execute the other operations which may be considered, on the spot, most likely to effect the objects contemplated. The three Powers do not seek any territorial acquisition, and they bind themselves not to interfere so as to influence the Mexicans in their choice of a form of government. A commission will be established for the purpose of settling questions as to the application of the money which may be obtained from Mexico. The Government of Washington has been invited to cooperate with England, France and Spain; but the three Powers will not await the accession of the United States beyond the time at which the European forces can be assembled in the neighborhood of Vera Cruz. Sir ALEXANDER MILNE's squadron will be greatly strengthened by the addition of the Donegal, Conquerer and Sans pareil; and two other vessels are under orders for the same station. The French squadron had left on the day prefixed by the French Minister of Marine.

abstract: At a regular meeting of this Board last evening, documents Nos. 3, 8, and 12, being the various schemes for graduating the salaries of teachers  which have occupied the attention of the Board for six months past were taken up in Committee of the Whole and discussed at length. The other business transacted was merely of a routine character.

abstract: One of the most gratifying features of the opening of Congress is the evidence afforded by the published Executive Documents, of the substantial harmony of sentiment among the gentlemen associated with the President in the conduct of the Government. This is still more gratifying from the fact that rumors widely circulated had prepared the public mind for a very different state of things.
lead_paragraph: One of the most gratifying features of the opening of Congress is the evidence afforded by the published Executive Documents, of the substantial harmony of sentiment among the gentlemen associated with the President in the conduct of the Government. This is still more gratifying from the fact that rumors widely circulated had prepared the public mind for a very different state of things. It was known that the private and expressed opinions of some members of the Cabinet concerning the relations of Slavery to the war, were somewhat at variance with those which the President had made the basis of his official action. And it was said that they intended to embody those opinions in their annual reports, and spread them thus officially before the country, without regard to their bearing upon the general policy of the Administration.

abstract: In the Senate, a resolution for the expulsion of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE was introduced by Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, opposed the resolution, on the ground that BRECKINRIDGE could not be expelled because he had already resigned his scat: but the expulsion was insisted upon in another resolution introduced by Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illionois, and the Senate so voted, unanimously. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, a resolution for the expulsion of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE was introduced by Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, opposed the resolution, on the ground that BRECKINRIDGE could not be expelled because he had already resigned his scat: but the expulsion was insisted upon in another resolution introduced by Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illionois, and the Senate so voted, unanimously. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, called attention to a list of colored persons confined in the Washington jail, and their cases were, after considerable debate, referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia. The Marshal of the District was also ordered to report, immediately, to the Senate, the names of all persons now confined in the jail, with all particulars in reference to them. The subject of the arrest of fugitive slaves in the District was referred to the same Committee, who were instructed to inquire into the expediency of abolishing Slavery in the District, with compensation to the loyal holders. A bill to abolish the distinction between volunteers and regulars was introduced by Mr. WILKINSON, of Minnesota. Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, offered a preamble and resolutions providing for the appointment of a Commission to confer with Commissioners from the rebel States with a view to the reestablishment of the Union -- hostilities to be suspended while the negotiations are proceeding. The proposition was laid on the table. The Secretary of War was requested to furnish copies of all general orders issued in Missouri relative to fugitive slaves. Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, submitted a resolution, which lies over, proposing to abolish and reestablish the Supreme Court of the United States.

abstract: Late Tuesday afternoon a young man, named PATRICK MCHUGH, was shot with a pistol, in the hands of THOMPSON MARTIN, on the corner of Tenth-avenue and Twenty-seventh-street. The ball entered one of his eyes and penetrated to the brain, causing instant death. MARTIN was taken into custody by the Police of the Sixteenth Precinct, and yesterday was committed to prison to await the result of the Coroner's inquest, which will be held today. The prisoner is about 25 years of age, a machinist by occupation, and was employed in Fourteenth-street.
lead_paragraph: Late Tuesday afternoon a young man, named PATRICK MCHUGH, was shot with a pistol, in the hands of THOMPSON MARTIN, on the corner of Tenth-avenue and Twenty-seventh-street. abstract: With the WEEKLY TIMES of this morning we publish a SUPPLEMENT containing a FULL PAGE MAP OF THE NATIONAL LINES BEFORE WASHINGTON, exhibiting faithfully the defences of the National Capital, and positions of the several Divisions of the Grand Union Army. The map is drawn from an official survey, and is printed on fine and firm white paper prepared expressly for the purpose, so that it may be framed for future reference.
lead_paragraph: With the WEEKLY TIMES of this morning we publish a SUPPLEMENT containing a FULL PAGE MAP OF THE NATIONAL LINES BEFORE WASHINGTON, exhibiting faithfully the defences of the National Capital, and positions of the several Divisions of the Grand Union Army. The map is drawn from an official survey, and is printed on fine and firm white paper prepared expressly for the purpose, so that it may be framed for future reference. With the accompanying letter-press, it will prove an invaluable aid to those desirous of understanding the defences of the Capital and the dispositions of the different Divisions of the Federal Army. The WEEKLY TIMES, with SUPPLEMENT containing the map, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter in wrappers, ready for mailing, at the usual price. In addition it contains:

abstract: As everybody supposed, the election for President in Peru was a mere farce. By law, President CASTILLA cannot succeed himself, so he gets a friend, Gen. SAN ROMAN, elected, and then sets the election aside, for probably an indefinite term, that he may hold on himself. Probably, however, if SAN ROMAN, who is now in the Province of Arequipa, at the head of six thousand five hundred men, can see a chance to seize the reins of Government, he will no doubt do so. It is denied by some that CASTILLA and his Government have set aside the election -- but if he has not, he will.
lead_paragraph: As everybody supposed, the election for President in Peru was a mere farce. By law, President CASTILLA cannot succeed himself, so he gets a friend, Gen. abstract: The universal congratulations interchanged by Republicans and Conservatives yesterday in reviewing the triumph of Mr. OPDYKE was disturbed during the afternoon by uncanny rumors that, owing to the omission to count some two hundred votes for the Tammany candidate because they read "Godfrey Gunther," and as many more that, in the clipping, had lost their last syllable, and came deformed into the ballot-boxes, as suffrages for an unknown party, entitled, curiously, "C. Godfrey Gunth." Mr. C. GODFREY GUNTHER had not been credited with a number that was sufficient to elect him Mayor by a plurality of from 50 to 80.

abstract: One of the most distinguishing and disgusting customs of savages, in warfare, is their treatment of prisoners. They regard them as inconvenient appendages to a march, productive alike of trouble and expense; for this reason they make as few prisoners as possible, and murder these few at their earliest convenience.
lead_paragraph: One of the most distinguishing and disgusting customs of savages, in warfare, is their treatment of prisoners. They regard them as inconvenient appendages to a march, productive alike of trouble and expense; for this reason they make as few prisoners as possible, and murder these few at their earliest convenience. To spare the life of an unarmed foe is a "social amenity" of war -- if we may so express it -- that would not spontaneously suggest itself to the savage. Civilized nations, however, have generally pursued a different practice. Even in the feudal ages, which, by the way, were not eminently remarkable for gentle and courteous customs, for a knight to buffet a prisoner laid him liable to the penalty of having the offending hand struck off and his lance broken. This was the custom of ancient chivalry.

abstract: We are indebted to a friend in the city for the reading of a letter from Christian County. Kentucky  dated Nov. 15. Our readers will recollect that the rebels are in possession of that part of Kentucky, and that some 3,000 Mississippi and Louisiana troops are encamped in Christian County. The letter before us ...
lead_paragraph: We are indebted to a friend in the city for the reading of a letter from Christian County. Kentucky -- dated Nov. 15. Our readers will recollect that the rebels are in possession of that part of Kentucky, and that some 3,000 Mississippi and Louisiana troops are encamped in Christian County. The letter before us is a full-blooded Union one, written by a very intelligent lady, and she gives quite minute particulars of what the people say, both rebel and Union folks. It appears that the loyal people are in good heart. They believe in a good time coming. They believe also that it will be along soon. The lady writes that "the rebels are expecting an attack daily, and fortifying positions on the different roads. They are also receiving reinforcements daily. One comfort is reinforcing here only weakens other points. I believe many of these reinforcements ran from Columbus, for I don't doubt myself Columbus being in the hands of the Federals. There has been great excitement here amongst the troops, and no little fear expressed. The secesh citizens are looking sadder and more desponding than I ever saw them. TILLMAN gets almost desperate, I am told. He has bills up forbidding Union men speaking to his soldiers; says he is afraid of mutiny, with which he is constantly threatened. He says his troops must hear nothing which would render them at all dissatisfied, which they were already, poor fellows. They are dying faster than ever. The average is now ton a day.

abstract: WINTER SPORTS. -- The citizens of Jersey, Hoboken and Hudson Cities, or that portion, at least, who enjoy and participate in the healthy and fashionable exercise of skating, will be gratified to learn that arrangements have been made for converting "Lake Lincoln" -- better known as the ice-field belonging to the Passaic Ice Company -- into a skating-pond, during the present Winter. The Lake is situated on Bergen Hill, five minutes' walk from the terminus of the Jersey City and Bergen Horse Railroad. It contains six and one-half acres, enclosed by a high board fence, and is so arranged that it can be flooded with Passaic water whenever desired. A comfortable building has been erected within the enclosure, which contains a sitting-room for ladies, with a dressing-room off, and another for gentlemen. The pond is to be well lighted, and officers will be present for the preservation of order. To prevent this from becoming a place of common resort for the multitude, admission can only be obtained by means of tickets. The arrangements are under the supervision of Mr. JAMES F. FIELDER, lessee of the Jersey City and Bergen horse railroads, who will run stages from the terminus of the railroad track to the lake.

abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest, yesterday afternoon, at the Sixteenth Precinct Station-house, in West Twenty-seventh-street, upon the body of PATRICK MCCUE, who came to his death on Tuesday evening last, by being shot with a pistol in the hands of THOMPSON MARTIN. A pretty full account of the affray was published in yesterday's TIMES, and the evidence taken upon the inquest has developed very few facts, not already made public. There were a large number of witnesses examined, and the inquest was not concluded until a late hour last evening. From the evidence of JOHN H. MCGINNESS, WILLIAM H. BULL, and several others, it appears that MARTIN fired the pistol at a time when he was closely pursued by a gang of Tenth-avenue "roughs;" that the attacking party had twice overthrown the box where he and his brother were engaged in distributing Opdyke tickets, and after beating the brother, JAS. MARTIN, in such a manner as to render him insensible, they turned upon him. He saw there was no chance for him to successfully resist so large a number. He, therefore, turned and fled, the crowd pursuing. He ran some distance, but finding himself closely pressed, he stopped short, drew a pistol from his pocket, and fired at random into the crowd. The shot took effect upon MCCUE, the ball penetrating his brain, and causing death almost instantly. MARTIN was immediately arrested by Officer ATKINSON, and held until last evening. At the conclusion of the testimony the jury rendered a verdict to the effect that the deceased, PATRICK MCCUE, came to his death, on the 3d day of December inst., by a pistol-shot from a pistol in the hands of THOMPSON MARTIN, and that said MARTIN was justified in the firing of the pistol, it having been done in self-defence. Upon the rendition of the verdict MARTIN was discharged from custody.

abstract: Our neighbor of the Herald is afraid to stake a dollar on his own veracity! He pleads all sorts of excuses against accepting the test we offered him the other day, and is even driven on to the extremity of pleading his religion as a reason why he cannot make a bet.
lead_paragraph: Our neighbor of the Herald is afraid to stake a dollar on his own veracity! He pleads all sorts of excuses against accepting the test we offered him the other day, -- and is even driven on to the extremity of pleading his religion as a reason why he cannot make a bet. This is running the thing into the ground. It is decidedly the most desperate dodge of the season. The Herald must be in extremis when it thus affects pious scruples. The devil must be dead, and has left the Herald a weeping and wailing orphan, deprived of its natural protector, and forced to resort to religion for refuge and consolation!
headline: {'main': "The Herald's Veracity and Circulation A Test for Both.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Herald's Veracity and Circulation A Test for Both.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The great body of the American population probably looks unalarmed to the contingency of a war with England. It is true none the less that the report of the reception of the Mason and Slidell affair in England, is awaited here with painful anxiety; and that apprehensions more or less solicitous are felt that to the task of repressing the rebellion at the South may possibly be added that of combating the first naval power of the world. To measure the resources of the country against this intensified strain may not unreasonably provoke doubts in minds not commonly addicted to prudent considerations.

abstract: In the Senate, a petition was presented by Mr. SUMNER, from citizens of Haverhill, Mass., praying that the slaves of rebels may be liberated un- conditionally, and the slaves of Union men, on fair remuneration being made. A resolution was ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, a petition was presented by Mr. SUMNER, from citizens of Haverhill, Mass., praying that the slaves of rebels may be liberated un- conditionally, and the slaves of Union men, on fair remuneration being made. A resolution was offered by Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, providing for the appointment of a Committee to inquire into the causes of the disasters at Bull Run and Ball's Bluff. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, wished to have Springfield, Wilson's Creek, and Lexington inserted, but the amendment was not agreed to. A substitute was offered by Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa providing for the appointment of a Committee' consisting of two members of the Senate and three members of the House, to investigate the causes of all the disasters to our arms, but the whole subject was finally postponed. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, gave notice of his intention to introduce a bill to abolish the office of Sutler in the volunteer force. An investigation of the case of Col. MILES, who was accused of being intoxicated on the day the battle of Bull Run was fought, was ordered on motion of Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa. Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, then introduced his bill for confiscating the property of rebels and giving freedom to their slaves. It provides for the absolute and complete forfeiture forever to the United States of every species of property, real and personal, wherever situated within the United States belonging to persons beyond the jurisdiction of the United States, or beyond the reach of civil process, who have or shall in any way take up arms against the United States, or in any wise aid or abet the rebellion -- of course, making their slaves free. The bill was referred to the Judiciary Committee.

abstract: Morristown is in Granger County, East Tennessee, about thirty miles south of Cumberland Gap, and two hundred and twenty-six miles east of Nashville. It is on the line of the great Tennessee and Virginia Railroad, through which nearly all the supplies and troops come from the South to Richmond. It is also a fire in the rear of the rebel ZOLLICOFFER. If the report should prove true, and the gallant Pasron is able to maintain himself, this is by far the most important victory the Union has yet gained.

abstract: The annual meeting of this Association was held last evening in the Cooper Institute Mr. ROBT H. McCURDY in the Chair. After the approval of the minutes of the previous session, Gen. WETMORE stated that the new system of providing refreshments at the close of the meetings of the Association had been found successful, and that about four hundred gentlemen.
lead_paragraph: The annual meeting of this Association was held last evening in the Cooper Institute -- Mr. ROBT H. MCCURDY in the Chair. After the approval of the minutes of the previous session, Gen. WETMORE stated that the new system of providing refreshments at the close of the meetings of the Association had been found successful, and that about four hundred gentlemen had attended at their last meeting, which was held in the rooms of the Historical Society. He thought they had a hopeful future before them, as they would be free from debt at the close of the year. The election held during the week in their City had resulted auspiciously for the Association, as whatever measures they might propose would receive the attention of the Legislature.

abstract: The Secretary of the Interior states in his Report that no branch of the public service connected with his Department has been so much affected by the rebellion as has the Patent Office. This year there is an exess of expenditures over receipts amounting to eighty-two  thousand dollars, whereas last year there was an excess the other way of ninety-four thousand dollars. As is well known, the Patent Office is required to defray all its own expenses.

abstract: FIRES -- A TENEMENT HOUSE DESTROYED. -- At 6 o'clock A.M. yesterday, a fire broke out in a five-story tenement house situated at No. 31 Baxter-street. Before it could be extinguished, the entire building was burned. Eighteen families, occupying the upper stories, lost nearly all their furniture, upon which there was no insurance. The fire originated in the basement, occupied by GEORGE MONTIGNEFI as an Italian dance-house. His loss is $200; not insured. The first floor was occupied as a grocery by ANTONIO CUNEO. He lost all his stock and fixtures, valued at $1,500; he is insured for $2,000 in the Pacific Insurance Company. The building was of brick. It was owned by JEROLOMON MORELLO, and was damaged about $300; fully insured. No. 33 Baxter-street occupied by JULIUS BRETTMAN as a liquor-store and dwelling, was partially consumed; insured for $1,000 in the Manhattan Insurance Company. The building was damaged about $300. No. 35 Baxter-street was also damaged to the extent of $150. This building and No. 33 are owned by PETER LYNCH, and together are insured for $500 in the Hamilton Insurance Company....At 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire was discovered in the Excelsior Stables, Nos. 22 and 24 West Thirteenth-street, occupied by EVADMUS SCARROTT. The damage to the building was about $500. The loss on stock was about $400. Mr. SCARROTT was insured for $850 in the Continental Insurance Company. The tire originated in the hay loft.

abstract: The official reception, offered to Commodore WILKES, by the common Council of this City before he left Boston, but which had been deferred till after the election excitement was over, took place yesterday morning. Commodore WILKES, attended by Alderman DAYTON, Chairman of the Joint Committee having the management of the reception, arrived at the City Hall at a rather earlier hour than was anticipated, and very few people were, in consequence.
lead_paragraph: The official reception, offered to Commodore WILKES, by the common Council of this City before he left Boston, but which had been deferred till after the election excitement was over, took place yesterday morning. Commodore WILKES, attended by Alderman DAYTON, Chairman of the Joint Committee having the management of the reception, arrived at the City Hall at a rather earlier hour than was anticipated, and very few people were, in consequence, present, to indulge in the demonstrations usual on such occasions. By the few that were assembled, however, the Commodore was warmly greeted on descending from his carriage, and, as the news of his arrival spread, folks began to pour in from all directions, until quite a large crowd had gathered, blocking up the passages of the City Hall building and striving to gain admittance to the Mayor's office, whither Capt. WILKES had been conducted.

abstract: Memphis papers state that the members of the rebel Legislature of Tennesse have been called to an account for the bridge-burning propensities of their constituents. They oil unite in condemning the acts, and protest that their people are devotedly loyal to the Confederate Government. They ascribe the burning to a [???] few extreme men, acting without concert and against the motives and consciences of the mass of the people." A resolution was introduced to give the East Tennessee members who were not present an opportunity to place themselves right on the record. The New-Orleans Picayune feels convinced, from the protestations of the members from East Tennessee, that "the apprehension that the Unionists there were in a general conspiracy to resist the Southern authorities and make open cause with LINCOLN," is unfounded. It is certain "the disaffection in East Tennessee is not extensive or concerted, and will be easily managed and repressed." The bridges, we presume, will not be so easily rebuilt.

abstract: Mr. PIERRE S. PEARCE, a ship-chandler doing business at No. 27 South-street, was arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by United States Commissioner HENRY, on the application of the District Attorney, charged with fitting out the ship Brutus at New Bedford, Mass., for the slave-trade. The Brutus, it will be recollected, was successful in her cruise, and landed a cargo of negroes in Cuba. The affidavit against PEARCE was made by parties in Boston. The examination is set down for Tuesday next, until which time PEARCE remains in custody.

abstract: In our issue of the 23d ult. we called the attention of Government specially to the necessity of increased railroad facilities between Washington and the Northern cities, and we are glad to find that the Secretary of War has taken this subject up and elucidated it in his report. He shows that the spirit of monopoly ...
lead_paragraph: In our issue of the 23d ult. we called the attention of Government specially to the necessity of increased railroad facilities between Washington and the Northern cities, and we are glad to find that the Secretary of War has taken this subject up and elucidated it in his report. He shows that the spirit of monopoly had so far ruled in the early necessity of transportation of the troops as to demand and receive $6 per head, and not until a more lengthy route via Harrisburgh had been greed to, and had carried them at $4, could the rates be reduced. This fact sufficiently illustrates the necessity for such a new and competing road as that indicated by us last month.

abstract: The Board of Delegates of American Israelites held an important meeting last night, to take into consideration the subject of appointing Jewish clergymen to look after the interests of such members of the Jewish persuasion who are fighting in the army for the Union. The Board of Delegates is composed of the representatives from the principal congregations in the United States. It is their duty to act for their congregations in all matters affecting Jewish interests at home and abroad, and hence this subject was one which called for their action.

abstract: This bark sailed hence Nov. 28, for Queenstown, grain loaded, having screw of 17 hands and the captain's wife. Had moderate breezes until morning of the 30th, which commenced with torrents of rain and threatening weather. By noon the wind had changed
lead_paragraph: This bark sailed hence Nov. 28, for Queenstown, grain loaded, having screw of 17 hands and the captain's wife. Had moderate breezes until morning of the 30th, which commenced with torrents of rain and threatening weather. By noon the wind had changed from south to northwest, and blowing a gale. During the gale the cargo had settled a great deal. At 1 P.M., the starboard side of the deck was under water. The weight of water on the ice covering board was such as to carry away the bulwarks, side-ports, start the stanchions and raised the covering boards. The cabin, which was a poop one, was fall of water up to the second tier of berths, as was the topgallant forecastle. At 4 P.M. wore ship to the south, the sea then breaking clean over the vessel amidships. At this time there were three feet of water in the hold, all hands at the pumps. 6 P.M. the vessel was in so crippled a state that a bark near by was hailed to lay by us. The crew at this time being alarmed, desired to leave the vessel.

abstract: The bill which Hon. FREDERICKS A. CONKLIN has brought before Congress, to reduce the salaries of the State officials, and of the officers of the army and navy, will, if it becomes law, have the effect of reducing the pay of all army officers, from the General
lead_paragraph: The bill which Hon. FREDERICK A. CONKLIN has brought before Congress, to reduce the salaries of the State officials, and of the officers of the army and navy, will, if it becomes law, have the effect of reducing the pay of all army officers, from the General Commanding-in-Chief to Majors of Infantry. Military and naval officers are, most assuredly, not overpaid at present, and if any alteration be made in their pay and allowances, it should be to increase, not decrease them.

abstract: It is desired that a commission of MajorGeneral be made out and forwarded, post free, to Rev. W.G. BROWNLOW, Morristown, Tenn. Of the desert of the reverend gentleman there can be no doubt. After pouring the thunders
lead_paragraph: It is desired that a commission of Major-General be made out and forwarded, post free, to Rev. W.G. BROWNLOW, Morristown, Tenn. Of the desert of the reverend gentleman there can be no doubt. After pouring the thunders as well of the Press as of the Church upon the heads of rebeldom, these many perilous months gone, a mob which besets his dwelling, silences his press, and stills his voice, drives him to the employment of carnal weapons. About the banners of this modern Balfour of Burley, the faithful throng -- faithful men, who have testified their zeal by serviceable bridge-burnings, and the timely rescue of loyalists set upon by rebel murderers. There were three thousand of them. At Morrisristown, about half-way between Knoxville and the Cumberland Gap, these found an insurgent army, in what force we have no information; but as the rebel reports describe the defeat of this force "as the most brilliant Union victory of the war," we are not to suppose the number of the beaten was less than that of the victors. And victory, even by the rebel reports, was on the side of the gallant Parson. Now, as the Confederate Cabal has set the hitherto unquestionable example of selecting for Major-Generalships clergymen of Tennessee, and in the case of Bishop POLK, of a clergyman whose victories had all been achieved with the spiritual arm, there is precedent and reason, we conceive, in bestowing the same grade upon that notable Anabaptist, WILLIAM BROWNLOW.

abstract: Last night was signalized, in this City, by a magnificent serenade offered to GEORGE OPDYKE, Esq., the Mayor elect, by the Republican Central Oommittee of this City. The interest of the occasion was greatly enhanced by the rumors circulated for two days past, by the opponents of Mr. OPDYKE. The Germans
lead_paragraph: Last night was signalized, in this City, by a magnificent serenade offered to GEORGE OPDYKE, Esq., the Mayor elect, by the Republican Central Oommittee of this City. The interest of the occasion was greatly enhanced by the rumors circulated for two days past, by the opponents of Mr. OPDYKE. The Germans went cordially, hand in hand, with those who planned this graceful compliment to a deserving and successful citizen, and met at 7 1/2 P.M. at WINKEL's, in Fifty-eighth-street, where, with a band of music leading, they formed line and marched all the way to the residence of Mr. OPDYKE, near Sixteeeth-street, on Fifth-avenue. By the time of their arrival in front of the dwelling, a very large assemblage of gentlemen had gathered inside. Among them were noticeable Messrs. Wm. R. Stuart, President of the Board of Supervisors; John Keyser, Esq., City Register; David R. Jacques, President of the Republican Convention nominating Mr. OPDYKE; Surveyor Andrews, Deputy Collector Stillwell, Hon. Henry J. Raymond, Amor J. Williamson, Esq., Ex-Police Commissioner Stillman, Dr. Wildey, Judge White. Alderman Dayton, Councilman Orton, Henry B. Stanton, Deputy Collector -----, Elliott C. Cowdin, Esq., District Attorney E. Delafield Smith, Coroner Naumann, and Henry Richard, Secretary of the German Republican Central Republican Committee, and a number of other prominent members of the Republican and Union organizations.

abstract: The condition of political affairs both in Europe and America, gives increased interest to the relative strength of the loading Powers, especially on the sea. The combined expedition against Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The condition of political affairs both in Europe and America, gives increased interest to the relative strength of the loading Powers, especially on the sea. The combined expedition against Mexico, shows that the Western Powers do not intend to remain idle spectators of events on this side the Atlantic, and our own internal commotions create an opportunity which cannot fail to be tempting to powerful and ambitious nations. In view of these circumstances, we have compiled the following condensed statement of she condition and strength of the three leading navies of the world.

abstract: Mater of the Will of Henry Parish. In this case, application was yesterday made before the Surrogate, for an order continuing the residuary estate of Mrs. Parish, since her decease, the annual allowance
lead_paragraph: Matter of the Will of Henry Parish. -- In this case, application was yesterday made before the Surrogate, for an order continuing the residuary estate of Mrs. Parish, since her decease, the annual allowance of $14,000, made to her by Mr. Surrogate Bradford, out of the estate of the testator, her husband. It was argued that this allowance should not be suspended upon the decease of Mrs. Parish, and that it was legitimately a part of her residuary estate.

abstract: In an article, which in another column we translate from the Paris Presse, M. FOULD, the new Premier of France, is reported as having pronounced the doom of the American Republic, and of republicanism generally, and to have predicted a monarchical government for this country. Such a dictum, emanating from the statesman to whom NAPOLEON has just confided the task of restoring the Empire, and a man always remarkably reserved in the expression of his views, is taken up with natural avidity by English toryism, and is sent home by the correspondent of the London Herald as the strongest confirmation of the opinions, or rather wishes, of the readers in high life, for whom his gossip is especially purveyed.

abstract: Mayor WOOD retires from the scene of his official duties with a good grace. His speech at Mozart Hall, on Thursday night, reported in the TIMES of yesterday, was marked by a magnanimous courtesy to his successful competitor, and by an entire absence of all petty resentments and regrets on account of his defeat. We are glad to see, too, that his opinions concerning the necessity of strengthening the Executive department of the City Government have undergone no change. Whether the Legislature will take the same view of the subject or not, may be a matter of some doubt -- but Mayor WOOD proves that his views of it were not prompted solely by selfish considerations. His tribute to Mr. OPDYKE's ability and personal character was cordial and just.

abstract: If a larger number of war-ships than any other country can command gives to a nation the rank of "The first naval Power in the world," then Great Britain is entitled to the distinction that her Press so often claims for her. After
lead_paragraph: If a larger number of war-ships than any other country can command gives to a nation the rank of "The first naval Power in the world," then Great Britain is entitled to the distinction that her Press so often claims for her. After NELSON's victories, in the commencement of the present century, this position of preeminence was tacitly admitted by European nations; and it was not until within a very few years past that England's supremacy on the sea was in any manner disputed by her Continental rivals. During the Crimean war, no Russian fleet ventured within gun-shot of the English flag, either in the Black Sea or in the Baltic. We then heard of no such instance as our own National conflict has evoked, of an enemy's ship venturing from the protection of her forts to challenge an adventurous rival to single combat. It was said at the time that no fleet like that which Admiral NAPIER took to the Baltic had ever before been manned and equipped; and when, a couple of years later, England sought consolation for misfortunes and disappointments, in a grand exhibition before the world of her immense naval armaments, her own citizens at least felt satisfied that the supremacy of their navy was still secure, and that it only failed to achieve such triumphs as had distinguished it half a century previous, because there was no enemy bold enough to dispute its superiority on the ocean.

abstract: As the French frigate Pomone was being towed down the North River, yesterday afternoon, by the gunboat Catinat, she came into collision with the British bark Statesman, which was lying in the river, outward bound, and carried away the bowsprit and all her head gear. She also came into collision with the Mexican steamer Los Marinos, lying further down, carrying away her foremast, maintopmast and all her head gear. The Pomone lost her jib-boom, but was otherwise not injured.

abstract: Our correspondence from Port Royal shows that our forces are beginning vigorously to spy out the land in Palmettodom. Several reconnoissances have lately been made, northward and southward, from our lodgment on Hilton Head. One went through the inland waters northward thirty miles, and inward ten or fifteen, which must have brought them well up and over against Charleston. The same strange phenomenon as around Beaufort everywhere presented itself -- complete dissolution of society, the whites having fled, leaving the blacks in a condition of bewildered orphanage.

abstract: We have interesting intelligence from Port Royal, by the arrival of the steamship Vanderbilt at this port yesterday. Gen. VIELE'S expedition had not yet sailed, but was expected to leave immediately upon the arrival of an expected accession of
lead_paragraph: We have interesting intelligence from Port Royal, by the arrival of the steamship Vanderbilt at this port yesterday. Gen. VIELE's expedition had not yet sailed, but was expected to leave immediately upon the arrival of an expected accession of troops. Beaufort still remained unoccupied, but was visited daily by officers of the army and navy, and the two gunboats kept watch and ward over her fortunes. During the few days which preceded the sailing of the Vanderbilt, stables had been constructed on Hilton Head Island for 1,100 horses; numerous ordnance storehouses had been erected, and the intrenchments across the island had been completed and the guns mounted. In addition to all this, several important reconnoissances had been made, which had resulted in establishing the fact that the whole seaboard, from Tybee Island to Charleston, is virtually in the hands of the National forces, it having been deserted by the white inhabitants. On Otter Point, at the northern extremity of St. Helena Sound, a fieldwork was found, which had mounted four or five guns, but it was entirely abandoned, as were also a battery on the Ashepoo and one on the Coosaw Rivers. The greatest distance touched inland was twelve miles, and the reconnoitering party approached within thirty-two miles from Charleston. The blacks everywhere seem to have remained behind when their masters fled, and welcomed our men with rejoicing. In some instances the cotton houses were set on fire on the approach of the Union troops, but this incendiary movement was by no means so general as the Charleston papers would have us suppose. Immense quantities of the staple are all ready for transportation, and under the regulations recently issued by Secretary CHASE, will soon be feeding the looms of the North.
