abstract: At the time of the starting of the naval expedition for Port Royal, the Alabama Legislature was about assembling, and the Presbyterian Synod met at Raleigh, North Carolina. In the organizing ceremonies of the Legislature of Alabama, Rev. Dr. MANLY, for eighteen years President of the Alabama University, officiate, and prayed most earnestly for the Divine favor, "upon the young nation," and especially that we might be saved from the fleet then in daily expectation on our coast, and that as we had no navy with which to withstand them, that the God of Heaven would send to their aid the waves and winds, and that thus they might be torn to pieces and defeated in their wicked designs.

abstract: United States Marshal MURRAY yesterday seized, at No. 111 Liberty-street and No. 13 Greenwich-street, 21 tierces of bacon sides, 8 barrels of beef, and 2 casks or shoulders, which had been sent to Washington by Cominissary-Gen. A.B. EATON, but
lead_paragraph: United States Marshal MURRAY yesterday seized, at No. 111 Liberty-street and No. 13 Greenwich-street, 21 tierces of bacon sides, 8 barrels of beef, and 2 casks or shoulders, which had been sent to Washington by Cominissary-Gen. A.B. EATON, but by some hook or crook found their way back to this City, where they were offered for sale by private parties. Some two or three weeks since, it will be recollected that 14 boxes of army clothing, valued at $12,000, were seized here by the Marshal, and the Quartermaster and Sutler of the Seventy-ninth Regiment were supposed to be implicated in an attempted fraud on the Government in connection therewith, but upon an examination were released. Whatever may have been the facts relative to their guilt, it is now certain that there have been extensive frauds of a similar character perpetrated upon the Government, and the seizure made by the Marshal yesterday is but a beginning of other and larger hauls to be made hereafter, when the whole modus operandi of these swindlers and robbers of the Government will be exposed, and the guilty parties, it is hoped, will receive their deserts.

abstract: The important news which we published yesterday of the exploit of the gallant Parson BROWNLOW in East Tennessee, is again directing universal attontion to that quarter of the scene of operations. The patriots of that region have become wearied out
lead_paragraph: The important news which we published yesterday of the exploit of the gallant Parson BROWNLOW in East Tennessee, is again directing universal attention to that quarter of the scene of operations. The patriots of that region have become wearied out waiting on the dilatory and wavering movements of the National forces in Eastern Kentucky, and have been driven to desperation by the outrageous persecutions of the rebel authorities, State and Confederate; and now, after having destroyed the bridges on the various railroads over which the rebel hordes might be precipitated upon them, they have taken the field, drawn the sword, and won the first battle that has been fought in that State.

abstract: There has been a curious consistency in falsehoods observable in accounts of matters in Missouri, sent by way of Memphis. We printed yesterday a dispatch coming that route, which represented Gen. SIEGEL as at Sedalia, surrounded by MCCULLOCH's army; and Gen. STERLING PRICE as advancing upon St. Louis at the head of a force, which promised to become sixty thousand strong before the leaguer of that city should be fairly instituted. The prima facie objections to the credit of this story were chiefly that MCCULLOCH, at the latest previous accounts, had retired into Winter quarters in Arkansas; that Gen. SIEGEL was not in command at Sedalia; that PRICE was known to be disbanding rather than recruiting an army. These objections are all abundantly confirmed by dispatches, direct and authentic, we give this morning. There is too much reason to fear that the greater part of Missouri is overrun with predatory guerilla bands, mostly fragments of the recent grand army of PRICE; but it is clear that there is no considerable body of rebels concentrated any where in the State, and equally clear that all thought of assailing St. Louis is abandoned. Formal military operations are in fact ended on both sides for the season. The circumstance is important in this, that it leaves the Union forces at St. Louis, Cairo, and Paducah, at liberty to push forward at the proper time towards New-Orleans. There is no hostile army to threaten their rear.

abstract: tions that a detachment from this regiment had made a daring reconnoissance up the mainland of the Palmetto State to within thirty miles of Charleston. They captured a spy, discovered a great deal of cotton, found and seized three rebel batteries and spiked the guns, fired a volley after a body of rebels who had deserted a battery, and who at once took to their heels, and performed various other neat and gallant actions. Since they went down to the sacred soil of South Carolina, the Seventy-ninth, which was one of the old militia regiments of this City, has done a great deal of hard work of various kinds, and done it all bravely and well.

lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, Recorder HOFFMAN presiding, John Hopkins, 28 years, native of Ireland, was tried and convicted of having in his possession, with intent to pass, a large amount of counterfeit money of the Columbia Bank at Chatham Four Corners. The prisoner, who was indicted with James Palmer, convicted on Thursday, was sentenced to the State Prison for the same term as his accomplice, viz., five years and four months.

abstract: During the last fifteen or sixteen years, the French navy, much neglected at the beginning of LOUIS PHILIPPE'S regin, has assumed such an importance as to be the object of German praise
lead_paragraph: During the last fifteen or sixteen years, the French navy, much neglected at the beginning of LOUIS PHILIPPE's reign, has assumed such an importance as to be the object of German praise and English jealousy, two things which, whenever French naval armaments are concerned, are pretty sure to go hand in hand together. Whether this navy will prove as efficient as that which gave France the supremacy of the seas under LOUIS XIV., or equal to that which balanced the fortunes of England under LOUIS XVI., is a question which the peaceful state in which these two powerful nations have lived, since 1815, prevents us from deciding. As far, however, as the small expeditions in which the French navy has been engaged for the last thirty years, affords us the opportunity to judge, it has not descended from the rank it occupied at the time when the names of TOURVILLE and JEAN BART, DE SUFFREN and D'ESTAING, illustrated that branch of the military service. Thus, the bold manoeuvre of Admiral ROUSSIN, forcing the entry of the Tagus, in 1831; the expedition of Ancona, in 1832; the taking of San Juan d'Ulloa, in 1838; the bombardment of Tangiers, in 1844; and, above all, the expedition of the Crimea, in 1856; and the embarkment of the army of Italy, in 1859, shows on the part of the officers a decision and a skill equal to that displayed by the English during the same period; while the administration of the naval service in all its branches evinces a real superiority over their mighty rivals.
headline: {'main': 'THE FRENCH NAVY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE FRENCH NAVY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: President LINCOLN raises the question, What is to be our future disposal of the negroes whom the progress of the war throws on our hands? There is, as we have already pointed out, a more pressing question as to
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN raises the question, What is to be our future disposal of the negroes whom the progress of the war throws on our hands? There is, as we have already pointed out, a more pressing question as to the present disposal of such as have already fallen into our hands. Any theoretical solution, we might give the general problem would probably be falsified by the progress of events; but it is possible to deal wisely and energetically with that part of the problem practically presented to us. The slaveholders' rebellion has left in the nation's hands a legacy of several thousand unserfed blacks: present duty demands that these be brought under fit social and industrial organization. At the same time, it is entirely fitting that Congress should take the general question into consideration, as it probably will, now that it has been raised by the President in his Message.

abstract: At the express instance of the World, we allow the Sanitary Commission to disclaim the indecency, and to purge itself from the odium attaching to certain "editorial expressions" which have adorned its defence as published in that journal. It were unjust that such a cause should suffer from any indiscretion of its champion. We shall be glad to learn further that under the operation of an unambitious, patriotic policy, the numerous officials of the Commission have received stringent orders to confine themselves to their self-imposed, but all-important duties. For the Sanitary Commission, as the public well know, exists only by sufferance, is supported for a special work, and cannot throw overboard its modesty without making shipwreck of its usefulness. The contributors to its funds are looking with interest for reports of the practical results of its labors in camp inspection and in relieving the wants of our suffering soldiers. A communication from Mr. OLMSTEAD, its Secretary, will be found in another column.

abstract: A lady who escaped from Bowling Green thinks there are 60,000 effective men there, and that the fortifications, five in number, are very formidable. lead_paragraph: This regiment has been raised in Roston, from the nucleus of the old New England Guards of that city, one of the oldest corps in New England, and one which did good service in the last war. There are many of its old members now engaged in mercantile and other business pursuits in this city. The regiment is fully equipped, as all Massachusetts regiments are, and is commanded by Col. THOMAS H. STEVENSON. Among the line officer is Capt. ROBERT F. CLARE, well known as the champion oarsman of Charles River, and many others of the Beacon and Harvard Boat Clubs.

abstract: A letter from Somerset, Ky., dated the 1st inst., Informs us that the writer, while at Camp Hoskins on that day, witnessed a fight at long-taw from one cliff to the other. The rebels came opposite to the camp and fired Several volleys at our men, and after each ...
lead_paragraph: A letter from Somerset, Ky., dated the 1st inst., informs us that the writer, while at Camp Hoskins on that day, witnessed a fight at long-taw from one cliff to the other. The rebels came opposite to the camp and fired Several volleys at our men, and after each fire retreated behind a hill. Our little "pop-gun" threw several shells at them, when all became silent. Soon after the firing Gen. SHOEFF arrived with two pieces of artillery and a quad of cavalry. There are several regiments on the road, which would all arrive within the next day or two. The roads are very bad, the river is very high, and the writer thinks there will be no crossing either way for some days. The present prospect in that the rebels will be driven into Tennessee, or that a fight will ensue. The enemy's balls fell short of the camp. The parties were from three-quarters of a mile to a mile apart.

abstract: The reconstruction of the grades in the naval service recommended by Secretary WELLES in his Report, is a natural necessity of the immensely increased proportions which our marine has taken on under the inspiration of the war. There is no doubt that the efficiency of this important arm of the public service will be greatly increased by instituting the proposed changes, thus bringing up the system to the needs of the times. Secretary WELLES suggests the establishment of several new naval grades. Thus, the Lieutenant-Commanders, a grade used during the Revolution, may be employed as First-Lieutenants, and in the command of the smaller classes of naval vessels. Further, it is recommended that a grade to be designated Flag-Officer be established (the number limited to seven) to command the squadron to which he may be assigned, the appointment (except when the officer receives the thanks of Congress, on the recommendation of the President, for gallant conduct in battle) to cease when he hauls down his flag. It should be noted, that though certain Commanders (as, for example, Commodore DUPONT) are now spoken off as Flag-Officers, the title is purely by courtesy. But why would it not have been better had the title of Admiral, borne in almost every navy in the world, been assigned to the new grade instead of that of Flag-Officer. However, the suggestion is an excellent one, and will remove the annoyance long complained of by our naval officers, of the inadequate honors paid to our national flag, when an American squadron is saluted by foreign vessels.
lead_paragraph: The reconstruction of the grades in the naval service recommended by Secretary WELLES in his Report, is a natural necessity of the immensely increased proportions which our marine has taken on under the inspiration of the war. There is no doubt that the efficiency of this important arm of the public service will be greatly increased by instituting the proposed changes, thus bringing up the system to the needs of the times. Secretary WELLES suggests the establishment of several new naval grades. It should be noted, that though certain Commanders (as, for example, Commodore DUPONT) are now spoken off as Flag-Officers, the title is purely by courtesy. lead_paragraph: Coroner Zeb, of Newark, held an inquest on Wednesday, to ascertain who was responsible for the death of Mr. Isaac W. Jones, of Metuchin. Theodore Barealow, conductor of the train by which he was run over, testified to finding the deceased in a Central Railroad car, and being a commuter on the New-Jersey Railroad, he was given a choice of three things: First, to pay ten cents; second, that he would stop the train and allow him to get into one of the New-Jersey Railroad cars, which were in the rear, or that he might pass through the train while in motion, and get into the car in which he belonged. To this Mr. Jones objected at first, but on seeing the conductor place his hand on the bell-rope in order to stop the train, he consented to pass through while they were in motion; in stopping from the central Railroad car to one of the New-Jersey Railroad -- a distance of nearly two feet -- he fell through, and the remainder of the train passed over his body. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the above facts, stating that as the "danger was heightened by a difference of some six inches in height between the platforms of the connecting trains, the jury are of the opinion that the conductor of the Central Railroad is censurable for not holding his lamp, it being very dark, and seeing him safe in the car of the New-Jersey Railroad."

abstract: whose death in Boston has already been announced, was born in Amherst, N.H., on Dec. 5, 1794, and graduated at Harvard College in 1818. He was a member of the Boston Common Council in 1840, '41, '42, and '43; an Alderman in 1847, '48, and '49, and was afterwards a candidate for Mayor, but failed of an election by a few votes. He has since served as President of the Cochituate Water Board, so that his municipal services extend over period of twenty years. In 1850 Mr. Wilkins was elected to the State Senate, and was reelected in 1851. He has since represented Boston in the House of Representatives. He exerted great influence in the Legislature, as well as in other bodies where he served. When the National Bank was chartered in 1853. Mr. Wilkins was with great unanimity chosen its President. He held this position until a short time before his death.

abstract: -Mr. Wimball, of Adermaston, England, has taken out a patent for destroying the turnip-fly and other insects injurious to crops, and it may be useful in the same manner for destroying the cotton-fly and the wheat-midge in our country. The apparatus consists of a small furnace placed on a small wheelbarrow, the fire being operated by a revolving fan-blast, through a strap from a pulley on the wheelshaft. On the top of the furnace is a tube chimney, bent downwards, and capable of being turned in any direction. Sulphur is thrown in small pieces, from time to time, on the fire, and the blast directs the gases thus generated through the bent smoke-tube among the plants on which the insects are operating. This appears to be a useful invention, and one not expensive or difficult for my farmer to carry into practice.

abstract: The Canadian Government maintains a navy consisting of one schooner called La Canadienne, under control of Commander FORTIN. Its duty is to cruise off the Gulf of St. Lawrence, and look after French Land American depredators on the fishing
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Government maintains a navy consisting of one schooner called La Canadienne, under control of Commander FORTIN. Its duty is to cruise off the Gulf of St. Lawrence, and look after French Land American depredators on the fishing banks and on Gulf commerce generally. We are sorry to learn, by way of Father Point, that the whole navy has been cast away in the river. On the 1st inst. La Canadienne was wrecked near the Carribon Islets, on the north side of the St. Lawrence, below Pointe des Montes, in a snowstorm. She had 37 people on board, including the crew and wrecked sailors. The schooner has received considerable injuries to the keel, but is not a total loss. The sea was most [???] when she struck. The gallant FORTIN escaped with all his crew, and at latest advices was making his way to Quebec by land. It is satisfactory to add, says the Toronto Globe, what, in the wreck of the old navy, the material of a new navy still remains to Cansula.

abstract: A day or two more will bring us news of the manner in which the Trent affair has been received in England. We look for a deluge of newspaper declamation, but nothing further at present, as the act itself is a sub- ...
lead_paragraph: A day or two more will bring us news of the manner in which the Trent affair has been received in England. We look for a deluge of newspaper declamation, but nothing further at present, as the act itself is a subject only for remonstrance and negotiation, till its exact nature, as well as the position of our own Government in relation to it, is ascertained. Similar acts are not of unfrequent occurrence, but never a cause for war, only a pretext for it, when such pretext is really desired. Is there any such desire? Certainly not on the part of this country. Apart from a common nationality, which implies mutual sympathy and good will, the loss to either of the commerce of the other would be a terrible blow, but much more terrible to England than ourselves. We could exist, as a people, and to a good degree of comfort, were we entirely isolated from all other nations. The first condition of existence -- food -- we have in profusion, Clothing we could produce in sufficient abundance; and though the closing of all our ports would cause immense loss and suffering, we should continue to be well fed and well clothed, preserve our industries and institutions intact, and upon return of peace, expand almost instantly into our former proportions.

abstract: RETURN OF A WOUNDED SOLDIER. -- EDWARD DE GRANVAL, who, it will be recollected, was arrested at Annapolis, last Spring, by order of Col. CORCORAN on suspicion of being a spy against the Government arrived at Hoboken on Friday, on leave of absence, having been wounded in the United States service. Upon examination, after having lain in prison nine weeks, DE GRANVAL was honorably acquitted, and immediately afterwards joined an Ohio regiment. At the time of FLOYD's attack upon Gauley, on the 1st of November, he received a severe gun-shot wound in the side, from which he is still suffering, and in consequence has obtained leave of absence.

abstract: A correspondent of the New-Orleans Crescent presents the following to the consideration of the authorities: It is high time that this city was purged of all person who express Northern sympathies, [we think so too,] or who manifest joy at any trifling suc- ...
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the New-Orleans Crescent presents the following to the consideration of the authorities: "It is high time that this city was purged of all person who express Northern sympathies, [we think so too,] or who manifest joy at any trifling success of our enemies. If the forcible arrest of Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL be not resented forthwith by Great Britain, the British Consulate should be required to be closed in this city instanter. The British Government has not sent a Consul to the Confederate States, and it is derogatory on the part of the Confederate Government to permit the residence among us of a British official accredited to the LINCOLN Government."

abstract: CULTIVATING MIXED VARIETIES OF WHEAT.  Selected samples of distinet varieties of wheathar, now generally cultivated in Scotland. It may be questioned however, if the practice has much to recommend it beyond securing a pure variety ...
lead_paragraph: CULTIVATING MIXED VARIETIES OF WHEAT. -- Selected samples of distinct varieties of wheath are now generally cultivated in Scotland. It may be questioned however, if the practice has much to recommend it beyond securing a pure variety for sale or for resowing. At one time the wheat usually grown was a mixture or a number of varieties of white wheats, including velvet-eared, and occasionally bearded heads. There are districts in England and on the Continent, where a mixture is still preferred. In some instances in England, red and white wheats are grown mixed, from the belief that the produce of grain is on the whole more uniform, and larger, and the sample brings a higher price in the market, than when either the white or the red variety are grown separately. This is the general result in those localities where the wheat crop is liable to become affected with mildew. With more attention to the cultivation of wheat in Scotland, selection has been carried out, and the greater portion of the wheats in cultivation are true to their kinds. It is, therefore, important to ascertain whether, by cultivating genuine or unmixed varieties, the produce per acre is not impaired, and, as a consequence, the money return less, than when a mixture of varieties are grown. Several eminent physiologists state that a mixture of kinds of any of the seed-producing plants usually yield a larger amount of seeds; and this opinion is very general among farmers where the growing of mixtures of the cereals and leguminous plants are carried out. It is supposed by physiologists that the different varieties spread their roots at different depths in the soil, and thus draw a larger amount of the constituents of plant-life from the soil. Perhaps something is due to the difference of produce in the different varieties, arising from the character of the season, climate and soil. There are several recorded experiments which support this belief, but more experiments are required to elucidate this question. -- North British Agriculturist.

abstract: It was to be expected that at Havana, where the rebel Ambassadors were so ceremoniously entreated, and sent upon their mischievous errand to Europe, with unanimous god-speeds, the news of their arrest would ...
lead_paragraph: It was to be expected that at Havana, where the rebel Ambassadors were so ceremoniously entreated, and sent upon their mischievous errand to Europe, with unanimous god-speeds, the news of their arrest would not be received with satisfaction. The expectation is realized. The Diario de la Marina, the organ of the Spanish population, gives voice to the popular disgust, and plunging into one of those inscrutable editorial discussions which so bewilder the readers of that stately journal, settles all the points of international law involved in the matter adversely to Capt. WILKES. Of the two legs upon which its reasoning runs, neither is stout enough to sustain the probability of a war with England. The first consists in an assertion that the Trent was stopped in neutral seas. It is needless to cite authorities to determine the law if such be the fact. The Government of the United States is not prepared, we may. rest assured, to controvert any well grounded and universally received principles of the international code; and none of these is clearer than that the right of search and seizure is confined to the high seas, and can under no pretext be exercised in neutral waters. The case of the Caroline might seem to place England in the category of maintaining the negative in this proposition; but the instance is exceptional. If the Trent was actually stopped in British waters, it is purely gratuitous to assume that the American Government will persist in approving the arrest, in the face of its obvious impropriety. The actual position of this Government is founded upon the conviction that no article of the international code was violated by Capt. WILKES.

abstract: The proceeds of this Fair, which was opened on Friday night, at the Academy of Music, are to be devoted to the support of the Home for Destitute Children, recently completed, on Butler and Baltic streets. The site is commanding and eligible, comprising eight lots.
lead_paragraph: The proceeds of this Fair, which was opened on Friday night, at the Academy of Music, are to be devoted to the support of the Home for Destitute Children, recently completed, on Butler and Baltic streets. The site is commanding and eligible, comprising eight lots. About the time of their last Fair a few friends, deeply interested in the cause of succoring the worse than orphaned, children from their surroundings of vice, contributed ten thousand dollars toward the erection of the building, and judging from the support which their annual display of useful and fancy articles received from liberal purchasers, it is believed that the enlarging of their sphere of enterprise will be accompanied with corresponding encouragement. There are in Brooklyn, as well as on this side the water, multitudes of little ones, dragging out a half-way existence in crowded lanes and hovels, whose condition precludes their admission, at once, into our public schools. It is for the benefit of such that Industrial Schools are established, and here in Brooklyn is a large and cheerful "Home," which shall be a temporary refuge for all who will accept its guardian influence, it will be thoroughly dry, and prepared to receive occupants, early in the ensuing year.

abstract: -- It is reported from Freehold, N.J., that Mrs. Marks, now in jail at that place, has confessed in reference to the late Fellner murder case, that Radetzsky stabbed Fellner and murdered him; that it was be who opened and robbed Fellner's trunk of its valuable contents. She has not as yet located the scene of the murder, but will doubtless make a full confession. She is fast improving in health and appears well contented.

abstract: The Swiss Benevolent Society held its annual meeting yesterday, at Delmonico's, on Broadway. The business statement exhibits a gratifying assurance of the prosperity of a most useful and estimable organization. The President, Mr. M.J. PAILLARD, and Messrs.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss Benevolent Society held its annual meeting yesterday, at Delmonico's, on Broadway. The business statement exhibits a gratifying assurance of the prosperity of a most useful and estimable organization. The President, Mr. M.J. PAILLARD, and Messrs. DE LUZE and LORIMIER, the Vice-President and Secretary of the last year, were reelected, and a new Board of Commissioners appointed. The occasion terminated with an elegant banquet, at which speeches full of sympathy for the American Union, and song and sentiment, wiled away the evening hours.

abstract: We have advices from a correspondent at Columbia, Adair County, under date of the 2d inst. The writer is one of a party attached to Col. HAGGARD'S regiment, which had just returned from the banks of the Cumberland River. The rebels having appeared on the opposite bank, and killed two Union men, an order was received by Capt. PALMER, at Columbia, to march with his command to Creelsburgh, on the bank of the river, to oppose the rebel advance. A prompt response was made to the order, and the company proceeded at once to the scene of the anticipated conflict. Capt. PALMER arrived upon the river bank at day break, and discovered the enemy on the opposite bank, but not within convenient range of the rifles of Capt. PALMER'S men. They fired, however, and a shot from Lieut. FUNK'S gun brought down the rebel Captain's horse. The First Lieutenant and five men from Capt. PALMER'S company subsequently crossed the river in canoes, and, visiting a house in the vicinity, found there the rebel Captain's sword and a smoking-not breakfast, to which latter they did ample justice. Capt. PALMER's company returned to Columbia on Sunday evening, gratified with the result of their reconnoissance, but disappointed that they could not have a more satisfactory encounter with the enemy. The rebel party, which numbered about seventy-five men, had arrived on the south bank of the Cumberland the night before the arrival of Capt. PALMER's men, and, after having murdered the two Union men, sunk the ferry-boats.

abstract: The new side-wheel steamer Octorara was successfully launched at the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday. The yard was thrown open to visitors, and hundreds of persons availed themselves of the opportunity to witness the pleasing spectacle. Her dimensions are: length over all, 207 feet; breadth of beam 35 feet; depth of hold, 12 feet; draft of water, 6 feet 9 inches; tonnage, about 800 tons. She is supplied with steering apparatus at each end, similar to that used upon ferryboats, which will be of great service in time of engagement. Her engines and machinery were built at the Neptune Iron Works, and are all ready to put in. According to the original specification, she will carry two pivot guns fore and aft, also two howitzers on the broadside ports. She will be ready for service at an early day.

abstract: On next Monday, at noon, the Fourth and Fifth Regiments of the Irish Brigade will be inspected, at Fort Schuyler, by the Adjutant-General of the State. The officers and men of both commands have been notified by order from Acting Brig.-Gen. MEAGHER to report themselves there to him on that morning, at 10 o'clock, in order to have all in readiness for the State inspection. This being the final inspection before the departure of these regiments for the seat of war, all officers and privates must be present. The following is the order:

abstract: One would really suppose, to read of the coddling which MASON and SLIDELL are receiving from the sentimental Mrs. Jellybys of Boston, that they had actually gone in the ambassadorial character which the first-named of those arch traitors prophecied would clothe him when next he visited the "Hub of the Universe." The portals of Fort Warren, it is reported, daily open to receive hampers of good things and tit-bits designed for the precious pair of diplomats manques. Nor are these presents confined to sentimental sympathizers among "the sex," for Mayor WIGHTMAN, it seems, has turned caterer to the traitors; and we find in the Boston journals a long schedule of "jars of jelly," "boxes of guava," "4 dozen white pocket handkerchiefs," "packages of cocoa" and other sumptuory supplies of a most dainty character. And what makes it worse is that Mayor WIGHTMAN took these articles from a depository of supplies, contributed by the patriotism of ladies of Massachusetts, and designed for sick loyal soldiers! This strange piece of business evokes the following merited rebuke from the Boston Advertiser:

abstract: the Washington Observatory, now, as he styles himself, "Commander C.S. Navy," has been invited by CONSTANTINE, Grand Admiral of Russia, to leave the Virginia "whirlpool" into which he has plunged himself, and take up his residence in Russia, where he can continue in peace his useful occupations. It was certainly thoughtful and generous in the free-hearted Russian sailor to make an effort to rescue from the rebel maelstrom a man who had at least been of some service to navigation; but if he had foreseen that in return for his offer, MAURY would have thrown in his teeth seven or eight paragraphs of rebel rigmarole, it is likely that he would have let him go to the bottom without stretching out a helping hand. MAURY adroitly falsifies the Virginia record so as to make out a case for secession; and as he doubtless guesses that the Grand Admiral is not posted up in the Richmond debates, he may fancy that by this stroke he has made a convert of the brother of the Emperor to the cause of rebellion. He then goes on to say how the President (whom he does not call, as most rebels do, a gorilla or a baboon) had set at nought the Constitution -- he does not say a word about JEFF. DAVIS and himself having previously trampled it under foot -- and how Virginia, in the exercise of her "reserved rights," resumed her "delegated powers." He tells that he was brought up in the school of "State Rights," but does not mention that this did not prevent him from living and fattening on the National Treasury for thirty-five years, or acquiring distinction from the position the nation gave him. He says he has tendered his sword to Virginia, and is now fighting for the principles for which WASHINGTON fought. By his "sword" he doubtless means those submarine batteries which he lately sent in pursuit of our blockaders in Chesapeake Bay, and which proved such a wretched failure; and by WASHINGTON's principles he must mean the principles of national destruction. Slavery and secession. MAURY declines the Admiral's offer, and it is wise in him to do so; for, if he carried his doctrine of secession to Russia, and succeeded in having it reduced to practice there, the mighty Empire of the Northern Bear would speedily be split into a thousand fighting fragments. It is evident that Secessionism has completely obfuscated MAURY's brain, and that the "winds and currents" of rebeldom must soon dash him to the bottom of its whirlpool.

abstract: THE DENSE FOG. At an early hour yesterday morning, a dense fog settled over the City and harbor, impeding the movements of vessels to a consideruble extent. The ferry-boats plying between here and Brooklyn made very slow time, and used every ...
lead_paragraph: THE DENSE FOG. -- At an early hour yesterday morning, a dense fog settled over the City and harbor, impeding the movements of vessels to a consideruble extent. The ferry-boats plying between here and Brooklyn made very slow time, and used every precaution to prevent accidents by ringing bells and sounding whistles. The same is true of the Jersey City ferry-boats. The boats running to Staten Island discontinued their trips for several hours. The Albany and Troy boats did not reach their piers till long after the time due. The City of New-York -- one of the Sound steamers -- arrived at her pier about 1 o'clock, having been delayed over seven hours. The other Boston steamers did not come in till late in the afternoon. The Eastern boats came in several hours behind time. The City of Boston, of the Norwich line, was compelled to anchor off Hampton until 11 A.M. She then resumed her trip, reaching her pier at 1 P.M. While coming down the East River she ran into a canal barge, causing it to sink within a short time. The name of the barge could not be ascertained. When endeavoring to enter her slip at the foot of Vestry-street, the steamer struck the bulkhead of the pier, damaging her to a considerable extent. The steamer Commonwealth, of the Stonington line, was detained off Port Morris during the fog, and arrived at 3 P.M. The steamer Metropolis, of the Fall River line, anchored off College Point until it cleared. She arrived at 2 1/2 P.M. The steamer Petrel, of the Providence line, arrived about 1 P.M. The steamship Chesapeake, for Portland, and many outward bound vessels ready for sea, are detained by the weather. The British steamship City of Manchester, for Liverpool, left her pier about 3 1/2 P.M., and proceeded down the Bay, but probably anchored at Quarantine. A collision occurred at 1 o'clock P.M., between the Brooklyn ferry-boat Montague and a schooner, which was lying at anchor a short distance from the slip. The Montague had one of her cabins stove in, while the schooner escaped with only the loss of her bowsprit, it is believed that none of the passengers were injured, although they were all greatly frightened. The fog lifted about 2 o'clock in the afternoon, but come on again more dense than ever at 4 o'clock, and had not lifted at a late hour last night.

abstract: This regiment was ordered away to the war in a burry and incomplete. One-half of It the right wing, with the Colonet and Lieutenaat Colonel went off in the great Expedition, and are now at Milton Head, S.C. Of the remaining half, two of there companies are already under orders for the salme place, ...
lead_paragraph: This regiment was ordered away to the war in a burry and incomplete. One-half of it -- the right wing, with the Colonel and Lieutenant Colonel -- went off in the great Expedition, and are now at Hilton Head, S.C. Of the remaining half, two of there companies are already under orders for the salme place, and expect to leave in the course of next week. The portion now at the seat of war lately received their first payment, the privates being paid as first-class engineers, $17 a month. They have been doing good service, and winning golden opinions. The regiment certainly offers a rare chance for good mechanics of various trades -- especially for those who feel the spirit of patriotism stirring within them. Two companies of the left wing, which is now under the command of Maj. RICHARD BULT, are not yet quite full, but are rapidly filling up. Now is the time for capable artisans who wish to serve both their country and themselves.

abstract: The treaty celebrated a year ago, between England and France, took effect on the 1st of October last, and its practical working has been attended with far less excitement, perturbation and disquietude, than might reasonably have been feared. It is known that this convention admits into France, under light duties, nearly all woolens, cotton yarns and tissues, cutlery, carriages, earthenware and provisions, etc., from English ports. As a certain quantity of these goods had been forwarded before they were allowed admittance, and as joint stock companies for the sale of them had been organized beforehand, the very moment the treaty between England and France came in force, the doors of the English stores were thrown open to the public in the cities of Paris, Havre and Marseilles, with the sign of Merchandises Anglaises written in front of the house, and the sale commenced.
lead_paragraph: The treaty celebrated a year ago, between England and France, took effect on the 1st of October last, and its practical working has been attended with far less excitement, perturbation and disquietude, than might reasonably have been feared. abstract: A remarkable and unlooked-for change has recently taken place in the general policy of the French emperor. France had been suffering from a deficient harvest, the decline of her American trade, and want of cotton; and her ...
lead_paragraph: A remarkable and unlooked-for change has recently taken place in the general policy of the French emperor. France had been suffering from a deficient harvest, the decline of her American trade, and want of cotton; and her revenue has so fallen off that neither the imperial credit system nor the Financial Minister's devices could keep the deficit from growing greater and greater. This convinced NAPOLEON that the old mode of conducting treasury business must be at once abandoned, and. that a new method and a new manager were needed to preserve the State from bankruptcy. M. FOULD was accordingly sent for and consulted, and, as his scheme for wiping out the deficit and restoring the balance between the revenue and expenditure met the emperor's approbation, that gentleman was immediately appointed to the office of Minister of Finance, in the room of M. de LAROQUETTE, with full power to carry his own programme into execution.
headline: {'main': "Napoleon's New Policy.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Napoleon's New Policy.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A correspondent of the Richmond Examiner writes front Charleston that since the descent upon Port Royal there is in South Carolina a universal rush to arms. "In districts which had seemed to be stripped of fighting men to swell the army of the Potomac, a ...
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Richmond Examiner writes front Charleston that since the descent upon Port Royal there is in South Carolina a universal rush to arms. "In districts which had seemed to be stripped of fighting men to swell the army of the Potomac, a new crop of armed men have sprung up at the roll of the drum. The coast has suddenly become a vast camp, and from the Pedee to the Savannah River the sea islands are bristling with bayonets. Regiment after regiment has come in from North Carolina, and others are on their way hither from Alabama, and even from Louisiana.

abstract: We are what is called a neutral Power. The Queen, in her proclamation of May last, has, under responsible advice, declared that she and all her subjects will hold "a strict and impartial neutralitity between the Government of the United States of America and certain States styling themselves 'the Confederate States of America.'" She warns her subjects against "adding to the warlike force of any ship or vessel of war or other armed vessel belonging to either of the contending parties." She especially recognizes the ships of war and the privateers of both these "parties," and denounces the penalties of the Foreign Enlistment Act impartially against any of her subjects "carrying officers, soldiers, dispatches, arms, military stores, or materials for the use or service of either of the contending parties." This is what the Queen -- we mean, of course, the Queen's Government -- has said to her own subjects. After this recognition of the two belligerents, the action of the Government must be understood to be restricted to the rights of a neutral Power as between two belligerent nations.

This is what the Queen -- we mean, of course, the Queen's Government -- has said to her own subjects. After this recognition of the two belligerents, the action of the Government must be understood to be restricted to the rights of a neutral Power as between two belligerent nations.

abstract: THE EARLY DEVELOPMENT OF PATRIOTISM. -One of the educational institutions for boys, in this city, recently added a military department to the school, under the influence of which, in one case at least, patriotism was developed rather too rapidly. A boy, 14 years of age, belonging to this school, was missed a few days since, and it was surmised that he had gone to Washington with a regiment, which took its departure that day, but no trace of him could be found in that city. Saturday night, however, the father of the young patriot found him boarding at a house on Washington-street, at the expense of a re-cruiting officer who had enlisted him as a drummer. It appears that, inspired with a patriotic desire to serve his country, he applied to the recruiting officer who, seeing that he was under age, refused to receive him unless he produced a written permit from his father. The father refused to furnish the necessary document, but the boy, not to be baulked by so small a trifle, got up a written permission to enlist, and presented it to the officer, when he was at once accepted. It is said the boy cried when he found that his attempt to go to the war was frustrated. His only hope now is that the war will last long enough to enable him to join the army without being required to obtain a written permit from his parents.

abstract: Several letters from Somerset and Stanford, dated the 6th inst., have just been received. They say that the National forces, under Gen. SCHOEPF, have been compelled to retreat this side of Somerset, and that the rebels, 10,000 strong, have crossed Cumberland River, and are marching on Somerset. Men, women and children are leaving Somerset in every possible conveyance, and rushing into Stanford.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon an alarming not of very threatening proportions disturbed the inhabitants of the Twenty-second Ward, especially in the neighborhood of Forty-third, Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth streets and Sixth-avenue. About 1,000 boys, of various ages, from 12 to 18 years, constituted the belligerent multitude. They represented the "Niads" and the "Double 3s," runners identified with Engine Co. No. 33 and Hose Carriage No. 51. They had been collected by an alarm of fire in the Second District, and on their return they concluded to fight out an engagement which had been commenced by a smaller number on a previous occasion. Stones flew in every imaginable direction. Heads were cut, faces disfigured, windows broken, and people fearfully alarmed, all along the route of riot. The Police arrested four of the rioters, PATRICK MURPHY, JOHN [???], FERDINAND LUTHY and MICHAEL GAUHAN, the last of whom had three stones in his pocket when searched in the Station-house. They will be taken before [???] KELLY, at Jefferson Market, this morning.

abstract: Engineers' estimates, especially of railways through a new and unknown country, are the wildest of business speculations. It may be that the million sterling estimated to construct this line would suffice to execute and stock it.
lead_paragraph: Engineers' estimates, especially of railways through a new and unknown country, are the wildest of business speculations. It may be that the million sterling estimated to construct this line would suffice to execute and stock it. But sad and almost universal experience suggests that it will not. Should it fail to do so -- should it be largely exceeded -- where, then, would be the six percent, per annum which it is suggested to capitalists will arise out of the contributions of the four Governments? Where any dividend at all? It is not, then, fitting for the Imperial Government to be mixed up with doubtful undertakings, or to give pledges, however indirect or implied, of the sufficiency of capital where all is doubtful and uncertain, and to encourage expectations of dividends which may never appear. This is a kind of business quite apart from the functions of Government.

abstract: Recruiting for the regular army has been very quiet during the past week. The number of applicants was very limited, and the enlisimenis at all the offices did not exceed ten.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the regular army has been very quiet during the past week. The number of applicants was very limited, and the enlisimenis at all the offices did not exceed ten. It is the opinion of those conversant with the recruiting business that a great number of men, free, able and willing to enlist, are holding back in the hope that Secretary CAMERON's proposition to pay part of the $100 bounty, authorized by the last Congress to the recruit as soon as he enlists, will be carried into effect. The recruiting parties also hope that the $2 premium for accepted recruits will be allowed again. It is only right that some compensation, beyond the mere pay of a private soldier, should be allowed to men on the recruiting service, because they are subject to expenses which a soldier on ordinary military duty does not incur.

abstract: Up to the present time the Union forces have not penetrated ten miles into any of the seceding States. With two or three exceptions, none of them have been invaded, yet the industry and prosperity of all, even of those most remote from threatened danger, have been as thoroughly wrecked as if blasted by the storm of war.
lead_paragraph: Up to the present time the Union forces have not penetrated ten miles into any of the seceding States. With two or three exceptions, none of them have been invaded, yet the industry and prosperity of all, even of those most remote from threatened danger, have been as thoroughly wrecked as if blasted by the storm of war. Commerce in all is at an end. The people everywhere are subsisting upon what little of previous accumulations are still left them. The precious metals have long since disappeared from among them -- an unerring evidence of impending want. People hoard gold when they see that they will have to compete with others for those articles which sustain life, the supply of which is inadequate for all. Already has this competition commenced by the excessive prices paid for everything that goes into consumption. Articles which, before the war, were abundant almost as the air we breathe, are hardly to be had at any price. Even the great property of the South, slaves, are almost wholly unsalable; and measured by the price they bring, very nearly worthless. A property counted worth $4,000,000,000 a year ago, is not to-day worth $1,000,000,000 in the Southern markets. The tie that holds it being force, not law, is easily severed. The slightest disturbance disconnects the slave from his master. This disturbance has already set thousands free, and threatens, no matter what policy is adopted by either belligerent, the destruction of the institution -- as a system of Slavery worth maintaining can never be reestablished in the path of our armies. But worse than all, the labor, not only of the slave, but of all other kind, has ceased to produce anything that can supply the most pressing wants. Capital is equally barren of any useful returns.

abstract: While awaiting for a day or two the news of the manner in which the Trent affair has been received in England, we have a most profitable study in the new revelation of the mysteries of British neutrality, presented by the case of the rebel steamer Nashville, the full history of which affair will be found on another page of this journal.
lead_paragraph: While awaiting for a day or two the news of the manner in which the Trent affair has been received in England, we have a most profitable study in the new revelation of the mysteries of British neutrality, presented by the case of the rebel steamer Nashville, the full history of which affair will be found on another page of this journal. If it had been given us to control events so as to prepare England for the reception of the news of our seizure of MASON and SLIDELL, we would hardly have done otherwise than ask that this transaction should take place, and that it should evoke the very opinions it has evoked.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the Second-avenue was the scene of an unusual excitement, occasioned by the horrible and sad circumstance of a woman having been murdered by her son. About 5 o'clock THOMAS ALEXANDER MCGILL, residing at No. 292 First avenue, went home grossly intoxicated, and found some unreasonable cause for a quarrel between himself and his mother, Mrs. MCGILL, residing on the fifth Floor of the same house. What passed between them is as yet unknown to the Police or to the neighbors; but he took his mother to the window and threw her out on to the sidewalk beneath. She was so horribly mangled that she expired instantly. Sergeant VOSBURG, of the Eighteenth Precinct, went to the room of the cruel and treacherous son and arrested him. The body of the unfortunate woman was conveyed to the dead-house at Bellevue Hospital, where the Coroner will proceed to hold an inquest to-day.

abstract: Great excitement was produced yesterday on 'Change by a telegram from Southampton, announcing the arrival of a privateer off that port, with the crew of an American ship which she had taken and burnt the day before.
lead_paragraph: Great excitement was produced yesterday on 'Change by a telegram from Southampton, announcing the arrival of a privateer off that port, with the crew of an American ship which she had taken and burnt the day before. This act, no less than the presence of the Nashville, indicated great boldness in the commander, and rivalled, to some extent, the daring in the old war of PAUL JONES The Nashville, it will be remembered, ran the blockade from Charleston, landed Confederate Commissioners it Havana, and then crossed the Atlantic successfully. A few people on 'Change lamented that private property should be destroyed, but the opinion of the majority decidedly was that the burning was legitimate and proper. The Federalists, under less pressing exigency, had done the same thing on the Southern coast. They had burnt vessels which had gone ashore, and, if they did not burn others which they had captured, it was because they could treat them as prizes, The Nashville had no alternative between destroying the Harvey Birch, or permitting her to float loosely or dangerously in the Channel.

abstract: The readers of our naval intelligence will perhaps remember that the James Adger, United States war steamer, sailed from Southampton on the 12th of November. It was known also, although for obvious reasons it was not thought expedient to make public proclamation of the facts, that the James Adger, an American merchant vessel, which had been recently converted into an eight-gun ship of war, had been sent over here to intercept a vessel loading at Liverpool with warlike stores for a Southern port. The James Adger had steamed into Southampton as a ship of war of a friendly Power, and, requiring repair, was, like any French or Russian ship in similar necessity, refitted in our harbor. On the 12th of November she went away. Where she is gone, of course nobody knows.

abstract: Acting in secresy, and on its own irresponsible caprices, the Government of Lord PALMERSTON refused the anti-privateering proposition submitted to it by the American Minister. The opinion of the other European Powers on such a question was comparatively unimportant. Privateering is therefore, still permitted by the law of nations and private property still exposed to capture or destruction on the open seas. But for this gross abuse of its executive powers by the British Government, the crew of the Harvey Birch would have been as safe under the flag of the United States as under the flag of France or of Great Britain. Commander PEGRAM would have had no shadow of authority for the pursuit of his ruffianly vocation. The atrocity of which he is stated to have been guilty would have been as much a violation of public law as of public morals, and he would have been chased from the seas as a tiger is hunted to the jungle. We can hardly hope that the United States Government would be willing to reopen, while at actual war, the question which was so bluntly closed by our own Cabinet under very different circumstances. The maritime superiority of the North is now making itself felt. The Nashville will not find it so easy to reenter New Orleans, or any other Confederate port, as to make her exit thence. The Federal cruisers may be vigilant enough to avenge the barbarity they failed to prevent. But our own Government now has in its hands the means of revoking its wicked blunder. Let Capt. Pegram be made to answer for his wanton destruction of the Harvey Birch. If he can produce commission or license from the Confederate States, we must let him go, since we have recognized the belligerent rights of his employers. But if he has no better authority for his piratic exploit than the flag that represents rebellion and Slavery -- a compound most strange and unnatural -- let him be delivered up to the United States Consul, to defend as he may a deed which nothing in law, authority, or usage, can morally justify.

abstract: We publish this morning two letters from Secretary SEWARD to our Minister at Paris, which illustrate very clearly and forcibly the position assumed by our Government towards foreign nations. In one of these letters, Mr. SEWARD informs Mr. DAYTON that the French and English Ministers had called upon him to read an important dispatch which they had been directed to present. Mr. SEWARD required first to be informed of its contents, and learning that it indicated a purpose to recognize the Southern States as belligerents, and to hold communication with their Capital at Montgomery for certain objects, he promptly, declined to receive it, -- and in this letter sets forth his reasons for so doing.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning two letters from Secretary SEWARD to our Minister at Paris, which illustrate very clearly and forcibly the position assumed by our Government towards foreign nations. In one of these letters, Mr. SEWARD informs Mr. DAYTON that the French and English Ministers had called upon him to read an important dispatch which they had been directed to present. Mr. SEWARD required first to be informed of its contents, and learning that it indicated a purpose to recognize the Southern States as belligerents, and to hold communication with their Capital at Montgomery for certain objects, he promptly, declined to receive it, -- and in this letter sets forth his reasons for so doing.

abstract: The report of the Commissioner appointed by the Government of India to report on the cultivation of cotton is a thoroughly practical business-like document. It is confined to the cotton districts of the Doab, the districts lying between the Jumna and the Ganges, from the junction of the two rivers at Allahabad to the base of the Sewalic range of hills. This district contains all the elements of a good cotton field. It is extensive, embracing 25,901 square British statute miles, three-fourths of which are under cultivation; it is populous, having rather more than 350 persons to the mile, possessing, therefore, labor in abundance. It is generally of a light sandy soil of considerable depth, and of great fertility when duly irrigated, thus being well adapted to the growth of cotton; it possesses irrigation canals, with numerous branches, running nearly the whole length of the Doab, and traversing it in many directions; it is, therefore, in every respect, a good cotton field. Thirty, forty and fifty years ago it witnessed a considerable trade in cotton. Merchants and planters had cotton factories and cotton screws at Futtighur, Calpee, and Mirzapore. The trade gradually died away for want of a market for the cotton. The factories went to ruin, and the screws rotted away. The trade at present is in the hands of native merchants, and confined to home (Indian) consumption. The Commissioner observes: " I have it on evidence from several native merchants that there are more than 50,000 bales of cotton at this moment at Mizarpore and Ghazeepore for which they cannot find purchasers. While, then, they hear on all sides that supplies of cotton to England from America have failed, while they are told that a great trade will spring up, and that hundreds of thousands of bales are wanted, while they see cotton seed distributed in all directions, and pamphlets teaching them how to cultivate by the astonishing facts that there is not one single purchaser among them, that their stocks of cotton are lying rotting at the marts of Mirzapore and Ghazeepore, and that the cry from Lancashire is merely a voice, and nothing more -- under these circumstances it will surprise no one to know that the breadth of cotton sown this year has been influenced only by their own probable home demands, and has in nowise been stimulated by the accounts from America or elsewhere." The Commissioner states that when a real demand for cotton comes from England, a large and immediate supply could be sent from these provinces. Fully to develop the cotton-producing resources of the district, European superintendents and European capitalists are indispensable.

abstract: The general news by the Africa is not of unusual interest. The leading item is the opening of the Italian Parliament, where Baron RICASOLI made an address, setting forth the condition and prospect of the Kingdom, and the state of negotiations with regard to the Papal States. abstract: Deputations from the Governments of Canada, New-Brunswick and Nova Scotia, had arrived in London for the purpose of urging the Imperial Government to aid the construction of the projected railway from Halifax to Quebec. One of the arguments is that the line will be a defence against the United States.

abstract: From the Herald, Nov. 2.  Whether the Tribune or the Times has the larger circulation we are unable to decide. According to recent accounts, they both of them distribute some where between TWENTY-FIVE AND THIRTY THOUSAND daily.  Of this we are not certain, but, concerning the Herald, there can be no doubt. Its daily sale of papers averages from ONE HUNDRED AND FIVE thousand to ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTY-FIVE thousand.

abstract: There are but few changes to record at the theatres. Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS having ventured on the dangerous ground of novelty, and with but dismal success, have fallen back on their well-tried repertoire. And that it is sufficient no one can doubt who witnesses the crowds that nightly beset the box office. We can readily believe that their present engagement is without a parallel. The bill for to-night contains three pieces -- "Shandy Maguire," "An Hour in Seville," and the "Irish Lion." The management announces, also, that the gallant Capt. WILKES will honor the theatre with his presence.

abstract: The Br. brig Elba, Capt. Beckwith. from Cornwallis for Cork, has returned to this port in distress. She sailed from Cornwallis for Cork Nov. 14, with a cargo of potatoes, apples and plaster. Had good weather until the 19th in lat. 42 56, lon. 61 28, when a gale came on from N.E.; amidnight, the gale increasing, hove her to under the [???] clew of maintopsail balance, with her head to the south ward; a tremendous sea running and the vessel laboringheavily and shipping large quantities of water; during the gale the cargo shifted, which hove her down, and caused her to lay much worse; the sea being very high dared not ware ship, and thus was obliged to lay until the 22d, when the gale somewhat moderated; made sail and attempted to run her, but she made such bad weather hove her to again, with her head to the northward, when the cargo shifted back again, and she righted up. Deemingit imprudent to cross the Western Ocean with the cargo staved in the manner it was, concluded to make for that nearest port in the United States; at 8 A.M..23d, the gale moderating, made sail, and being in lat. 40 50, lon. 61 50 made for this port; since 23d has experienced heavy. weather and contrary winds most of the time.
lead_paragraph: The Br. brig Elba, Capt. Beckwith. from Cornwallis for Cork, has returned to this port in distress. abstract: When the British steamship Africa left this port, on her last trip to Liverpool, and while lying in the stream, previous to proceeding down the Narrows, she was boarded by two police detectives, who demanded to see a lady from Georgia, who had taken passage on the steamer. Capt. SHANNON not objecting, the detectives were introduced to the lady, and, after a brief conversation, the latter was informed that she could not be allowed to go to England at that time. The lady remonstrated, and exhibited her passport, signed by Secretary SEWARD, which she considered was sufficient to insure her against detention, and, acting upon that conviction, respectfully, but resolutely declined to leave the steamer. The matter was then brought before Capt SHANNON, who asked the officers for their authority, and also questioned them with reference to a warrant. The detectives replied that they acted under, directions received from the Superinted of Police and were unprovided with a warrant. They were ununiformed, and did not even produce a badge to indicate their authority. Under these circumstances, Capt. SHANNON peremptorily refused to let the lady go. The officers intimated that the steamer would be stopped at the Narrows. Capt. SHANNON said he should not permit his passenger to leave the vessel against her will unless compeled to do so by force. The detectives then left, and the steamer proceeded on her voyage uninterrupted. The lady referred to is a native of England, and has resided in the State of Georgia for some years.

The matter was then brought before Capt SHANNON, who asked the officers for their authority, and also questioned them with reference to a warrant. The detectives replied that they acted under, directions received from the Superinted of Police and were unprovided with a warrant. They were ununiformed, and did not even produce a badge to indicate their authority. Under these circumstances, Capt. SHANNON peremptorily refused to let the lady go. The officers intimated that the steamer would be stopped at the Narrows. Capt. SHANNON said he should not permit his passenger to leave the vessel against her will unless compeled to do so by force. The detectives then left, and the steamer proceeded on her voyage uninterrupted. The lady referred to is a native of England, and has resided in the State of Georgia for some years.

abstract: CORONERS' INQUESTS -- A MAN FATALLY INJURES BY MACHINERY. -- JOHN MCGIBBON was fatally injured on Saturday afternoon by being accidentally caught in some machinery in the establishment of BALL, BLACK & Co., jewelers, on Broadway. Both his arms were broken, and he was otherwise so seriously injured that he died about 9 o'clock Saturday evening. Deceased boarded at the Metropolitan Hotel. The Coroner will hold an inquest to-day...... MARY FEELY, aged 10 years, accidentally fell from the fourth story window of No. 60 Spring-street yesterday morning, and was instantly killed. The Coroner's inquest developed the fact that the mother was intoxicated at the time of the accident. The father is at the seat of war. The jury censured the mother for not looking after her child......ROBERT ROGERS died yesterday at the New-York Hospital, from injuries received Oct. 14, by falling into the hold of the ship Josiah L. Hall, then lying at Pier No. 52 East River. He was a watchman on the ship at the time, but had formerly been shipmaster. He was a married man, 48 years of age, and resided in Newburyport, Mass. The Coroner will hold an inquest to-day....MARY DONOHUE died yesterday at the New-York Hospital, from compression of the brain, supervening a fracture of the skull, produced by having been run over by an express waggon, at the corner of Fourth-avenue and Ninth-street, on the 4th inst. Deceased resided in West Thirteenth-street. She was a domestic in the family of Mrs. CUNNINGHAM, at the time of the murder of Dr. BURDELL, and it will be remembered that she figured as one of the witnesses upon that celebrated trial. She was 45 years of age, and a native of Ireland.....The body of a colored man was found floating in the water at the foot of West Twentieth-street, yesterday morning. He appeared to be about 40 years of age. His name is unknown. The body is believed to have been in the water about two weeks. It was conveyed to the dead-house of Bellevue Hospital, and the Coroner was notified.

abstract: The Nashville was still at her berth at Southampton when the Africa left Liverpool, but no movement had been made to supply her with coals or stores, or to effect repairs. A body of Police was on duty, in case of any breach of the peace between the crews of the Nashville and the Harvey Birch. The voyage of the Nashville was, stormy, but devoid of interest until she fell in with the Harvey Birch.

abstract: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, June 17, 1861. SIR: Every instruction which this Government  has given to its representative abroad, since the recent change of Administration took place, has expressed our profound anxiety lest the disloyal citizens who are engaged in an attempt to overthrow the Union should obtain aid and assistance from foreign nations, either in the form of a recognition of their pretended sovereignty, or in some other and more  qualified or guarded manner.
lead_paragraph: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, June 17, 1861.

abstract: The Louisville Journal publishes as genuine a bogus report of the Secretary of War, containing a variety of recommendations which he did not make, and on the strength of this denounces Mr. CAMERON and President LINCOLN in very vehement terms.
lead_paragraph: The Louisville Journal publishes as genuine a bogus report of the Secretary of War, containing a variety of recommendations which he did not make, and on the strength of this denounces Mr. CAMERON and President LINCOLN in very vehement terms. It seems to us that this is traveling a good ways out of the record. There is nothing whatever in the President's Message, or in Mr. CAMERON's report, to which any loyal man, North or South, can take just exception; and the Journal evinces a much more captious and querulous spirit in its style of criticism than we were prepared to see.

abstract: FAIRFAX COURT-HOUSE AND FLINT HILL DESERTED. Scouts sent out from Gen. WADWORTH's Brigade  Friday, returned to-day. They report that Flint Hill and also Fairfax Court-house are entirely deserted by the rebel pickets. They passed through and beyond the village of Fairfax before they met the pickets of the enemy.
lead_paragraph: OUR SPECIAL WASHINGTON DISPACTHES.

abstract: Our American cousins have certainly the strangest method of making war that can well be imagined; and the affair of the Nashville, now lying at Southampton, and the Harvey Birch, now lying at the bottom of the sea, is not one of the least instances of the eccentricities of American warfare. The Nashville, it seems, a Confederate ship of war, comes here for the express purpose of bringing over an envoy from North Carolina, Col. PEYTON, on a special mission, we suppose, to the Government of this country, though what its nature is is not yet known. On its way the Nashville falls in with a Northern trading vessel, the Harvey Birch, going home in ballast from Havre to New-York; and the course the Nashville takes is, to bring the crew of the Harvey Birch on board the Nashville, to put them in irons, and then to burn and sink the ship. Now the maxim of war is well known, that one's business is to do the enemy as much harm and oneself as much good as possible. And, accordingly, when a war ship falls in with the enemy's traders, it is customary to take them and keep them, cargo and all; and ships of war roam the seas for this express purpose; but we do not remember hearing in warfare of any instance of a ship of war, expressly bound to a neutral country, to take there an official person, destroying the enemy's traders, when she can neither keep the ship or the cargo, if there be a cargo, nor make prisoners of the crew, being, by her very duty, obliged to go into the neutral port, where of course she could not be permitted to retain either ship, or cargo, or crew. Simply to destroy a vessel under such circumstances is a very unusual, and certainly seems a very wanton way of making war. With that, of course, we as Englishmen should have nothing to do, beyond having and expressing our opinion about it, if it in no way embroiled us. But we are as a neutral nation somewhat affected by the course taken by a war-ship of either of the belligerents, when she is coming into our ports on a mission to our Government, because that course may have a tendency to embrangle us with one or the other party. The Nashville, it seems, is some-what the worse for her passage, which has been a foul one, and is to go into one of the graving docks to be overhauled and refitted. Now, if she had come into our ports in a quiet way, merely bringing here the Confederate envoy and waiting to take him back again, and had received injury, we apprehend that the law of nations as regards neutral powers would not be very particular as to the extent and kind of assistance given in the neutral port to the disabled vessel. But it is a very different thing when she comes in red-handed, with prisoners in irons on board, whom she discharges in the neutral port. Under such circumstances everything beyond what is barely necessary to render her seaworthy may well be looked upon with jealousy by the belligerent power whose ship she has burned and destroyed, with no possible advantage to her own nation, except the destruction of an enemy's trading vessel.
lead_paragraph: Our American cousins have certainly the strangest method of making war that can well be imagined; and the affair of the Nashville, now lying at Southampton, and the Harvey Birch, now lying at the bottom of the sea, is not one of the least instances of the eccentricities of American warfare. Now the maxim of war is well known, that one's business is to do the enemy as much harm and oneself as much good as possible. And, accordingly, when a war ship falls in with the enemy's traders, it is customary to take them and keep them, cargo and all; and ships of war roam the seas for this express purpose; but we do not remember hearing in warfare of any instance of a ship of war, expressly bound to a neutral country, to take there an official person, destroying the enemy's traders, when she can neither keep the ship or the cargo, if there be a cargo, nor make prisoners of the crew, being, by her very duty, obliged to go into the neutral port, where of course she could not be permitted to retain either ship, or cargo, or crew. Simply to destroy a vessel under such circumstances is a very unusual, and certainly seems a very wanton way of making war. With that, of course, we as Englishmen should have nothing to do, beyond having and expressing our opinion about it, if it in no way embroiled us. But we are as a neutral nation somewhat affected by the course taken by a war-ship of either of the belligerents, when she is coming into our ports on a mission to our Government, because that course may have a tendency to embrangle us with one or the other party. The Nashville, it seems, is some-what the worse for her passage, which has been a foul one, and is to go into one of the graving docks to be overhauled and refitted. abstract: This battalion, the organization of which was commenced at Buffalo, some few weeks ago, arrived in this City, from Albany, on Sunday morning. The New World transported the men to this City. On landing they were marched to the Park Barracks, where they remained till yesterday afternoon, when they left by the Camden and Amboy route for Washington. In place of the customary field-piece, the battalion, which numbers 160 men, will, on its arrival at the Capital, be furnished with a newly-invented rocket-gun. The peculiarity of this weapon consists in its being breech-loading, and is capable of discharging ball, bombs and percussion shot. The rockets that will be fired from this gun are for the purpose of breaking up the enemy's cavalry, or of setting fire to any building that it is necessary to have destroyed. When the rocket balls are discharged, they will expand to the diameter of fifteen feet, and can be thrown the distance of 5,300 yards. Government has purchased the exclusive right of manufacturing these terrible instruments of destruction. Annexed are the names of the principal officers:

abstract: The Secretary of the Navy, in his report published in this journal on Wednesday last, says that the southward bound stone fleet is intended to obstruct the channels of Charleston Harbor and the Savannah River; and this, says he, "if effectually done, will prove the most satisfactory and economical method of interdicting commerce at these places." We give herewith a view of the points referred to, and their water approaches, from which a clear idea of the "rat-holes" to be stopped up can be obtained. One detachment of the fleet, consisting of twenty-five stone-laden old whalers, sailed four weeks ago, and it is supposed, has by this time operated on the Savannah River. The next detachment, consisting of twenty vessels of the same kind, is now leaving from different points, and is understood to be intended for the approaches to Charleston. The names and tonnage of the vessels, which have been purchased by the Navy Department for the present expedition, are as follows:

abstract: We do not share the apprehensions expressed in various quarters, of a serious difference of opinion among the Members of Congress, in regard to the conduct of the war -- still less of any factious opposition, on the part of any considerable number of them, to the policy and conduct of the Executive Department of the Government. The country has too much to lose by such dissensions, to permit any public man of ordinary discretion and patriotism to run the risk of creating them. There are, doubtless, rash and unthinking men in both Houses, whose conceit outweighs their judgment, and who are impatient of any policy that does not respond to their heated and reckless impulses. But they will case their minds by bar-room denunciations of the public men who are responsible for the conduct of the war, and will have the less temptation, as we trust they will have no encouragement, to embody their restless vanity in legislative forms. The mass of the members, we are confident, will fully realize the absolute necessity for the proper conduct of the war, of harmony between the several Departments of the Government, of mutual confidence and toleration among all who are connected with its administration, and of hearty unanimity on the part of the people in support of measures for the suppression of the rebellion.

The mass of the members, we are confident, will fully realize the absolute necessity for the proper conduct of the war, of harmony between the several Departments of the Government, of mutual confidence and toleration among all who are connected with its administration, and of hearty unanimity on the part of the people in support of measures for the suppression of the rebellion.
