abstract: The extensive scale upon which the managers of the Union Home School, with Mrs. Gen. ANDERSON as President, are engaged in getting up their first grand Fair, has delayed the opening a day or two. The donations are still coming in, and are marked with an appropriate adaptation to the design of the exhibition. The Home School has only been established since June, yet is already largely patronized by the little ones orphaned by the war. It was intended at first to admit only those who had lost their mother, and were left to charity by their fathers having fallen in battle; but so great was the number of applicants, that now they take all children whose fathers bring them to their care previous to assuming army duties. It is said, by one who has just returned from a visit of observation among the troops, that a strong disposition exists in the rank and file to contribute to the support of this noble enterprise; but the privates are often sadly plundered when pay-day comes round by sutlers and outside peddlers, who sell them bad liquor and induce them to forget home-lies and claims. It is proposed to establish an interest in the regiments for the aid of the Volunteer fund, which shall levy upon them but once a month, and that for the small sum of one dollar, or more if they wish to give it. The Garibaldi Guard have promised to give $800 a year, made up of small contributions from their monthly pay. Other regiments have given liberal promises, and the results of this Fair will show how far they will be seconded by our citizens, who, since they are made aware of the purpose of it, will no doubt look favorably upon the cause. The exact time of opening will be duly noticed, and those who are interested in assisting the decorations of the rooms will find the managers at No. 524 Broadway, opposite the Saint Nicholas Hotel.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, the usual number of petitions and resolutions were referred. Mr. HOWARD, Ex-Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, tendered his resignation as Sergeant-at-Arms of the Board, tendering his thanks for the uniform kindness and courtesy extended to him by all the members. The Comptroller presented his budget for 1862, (printed elsewhere in the TIMES,) which was referred to the Finance Committee, and 500 copies ordered to be printed. A preamble and resolution offered by Alderman CORNELL, having in view the repurchase of the Gansevoort-street property for market purposes, was introduced and concurred in. A resolution directing the Comptroller to examine into and report upon the title to the Fort Gansevoort property, was adopted. The bill of Mr. WIEGAND for removing bodies from a portion of the old Pottersfield came up in a majority and minority report, the latter being adverse to any payment, which was adopted by a vote of 12 to 11. The resolutions from the other Board, appointing A.V. STOUT, Esq., Treasurer for the disbursement of funds allowed by the City to the families of volunteers, were lost by the same vote, but were reconsidered and laid over. The application of the "Independent Telegraph Company," to set poles in the streets, they agreeing to do all the municipal telegraphing for the City as a compensation for the privilege, was recommitted. A large number of general orders were disposed of, and the Board adjourned.
lead_paragraph: At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, the usual number of petitions and resolutions were referred. Mr. HOWARD, Ex-Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, tendered his resignation as Sergeant-at-Arms of the Board, tendering his thanks for the uniform kindness and courtesy extended to him by all the members. The Comptroller presented his budget for 1862, (printed elsewhere in the TIMES,) which was referred to the Finance Committee, and 500 copies ordered to be printed. A preamble and resolution offered by Alderman CORNELL, having in view the repurchase of the Gansevoort-street property for market purposes, was introduced and concurred in. A resolution directing the Comptroller to examine into and report upon the title to the Fort Gansevoort property, was adopted. The bill of Mr. WIEGAND for removing bodies from a portion of the old Pottersfield came up in a majority and minority report, the latter being adverse to any payment, which was adopted by a vote of 12 to 11. The resolutions from the other Board, appointing A.V. STOUT, Esq., Treasurer for the disbursement of funds allowed by the City to the families of volunteers, were lost by the same vote, but were reconsidered and laid over. The application of the "Independent Telegraph Company," to set poles in the streets, they agreeing to do all the municipal telegraphing for the City as a compensation for the privilege, was recommitted. A large number of general orders were disposed of, and the Board adjourned.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, Recorder HOFFMAN presiding, James Gallagher, aged 30, native of Ireland, indicted for the murder of his wife, Mary, on the 28th of August last, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the fourth degree, and was remanded for sentence. The homicide was committed during a quarrel between Gallagher and his wife, and is said to have been accidental.

abstract: Yesterday, at Fort Schuyler, the Fourth and Fifth Regiments of the Irish Brigade were inspected by Maj. ALLCOCK, aid-de-camp to Gen. YATES. The different companies were well represented. Great credit is due to Acting Brig.-Gen. MLAGHER for his and untiring exertions in bringing the brigade to its present effective strength. Maj. ALLCOCK complimented the officers on the healthy and soldierly appearance of the men, and requested the officers to get their lady friends to supply their men with needle-cases, as those articles were the most useful souvenirs they could have. On Thursday a steamer will convey the men to Amboy on their way to Springfield, nine miles below Alexandria, where the other regiments of the brigade are stationed. All members of the brigade are requested to report themselves at Fort Schuyler to-morrow morning; if they do not they will be left behind.

abstract: Notwithstanding the statement in some of the papers, on Saturday, Gen. FREMONT remained very quietly within doors on Sunday, and did not attend service at Dr. CHEEVER's Church. Yesterday, the General received no visitors, but was busily occupied in preparing reports and examining letters relative to the conduct of the late campaign in Missouri, and the extensive business of a private nature in which he is elsewhere concerned. Capt. ZAGONYI, whose brilliant charge at the head of Gen. FREMONT's Body Guard upon the rebels at Springfield, has rendered the cavalry corps he commanded in Missouri as famous here as was the British Light Brigade in England, after the gallant, but disastrous demonstration at Balaklava, was, yesterday, the "observed of all observers" at the Astor House. The Captain was very reserved in his communications, and made no allusion whatever to military matters in the West. By the chances and changes of the campaign, he has been displaced from the position he lately held. The Body Guard have been disbanded as such.

abstract: We present this morning the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury, which has been awaited with an interest quite as great as that felt in reference to the Message of the President. No matter what may be the magnitude of the task in hand, the crushing of the rebellion, or what may be our relations with other countries, the public will clearly see its way out of all our difficulties, provided everything is sound in the department of "ways and means." In the predicament we are in, abundance of money is always success. So far there has been no lack, and with a vigorous and successful prosecution of the war, and a wise administration of the National finances, there need be no apprehension for the future.

abstract: In the Senate, a number of petitions and memorials were presented -- among them those of the Legislature of Connecticut, asking the repeal of so much of the act for the increase of the revenue as imposes an income tax, or to have the amount apportioned among special States, which shall be allowed to raise the amount in their own way. The Marshal of the District of Columbia was requested to inform the Senate by what authority he keeps slaves in jail because they are refractory. Mr. HALE's resolution, asking the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the propriety ofabolishing the old Supreme Court and establishing another one, was debated, and finally a substitute was adopted, which refers the whole matter, including the portions of the President's Message relating to the Judiciary, to the Judiciary Committee. The other portions of the Message were also appropriately referred. The resolution of inquiry into the causes of the disasters to our array it Bull Run, Ball's Bluff, etc., was then taken up, and occupied attention until the adjournment. It was finally amended so as to provide for the appointment of a Joint Committee, consisting of three members of the Senate and four of the House, to inquire into the general conduct of the war, and in this shape passed with only three dissenting votes.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, a number of petitions and memorials were presented -- among them those of the Legislature of Connecticut, asking the repeal of so much of the act for the increase of the revenue as imposes an income tax, or to have the amount apportioned among special States, which shall be allowed to raise the amount in their own way. abstract: There has been a skirmish on the Upper Potomac, which resulted disastrously to the rebels. On Saturday afternoon last a rebel force, consisting of a battery of six pieces and about four hundred infantry and two hundred cavalry, made their appearance on the Virginia side at Dam No. 5, and commenced shelling the dam and the houses on the Maryland shore. A company of the Thirteenth Massachusetts were on picket duty there, but having only smooth-bore guns, they could effect nothing against the enemy, who continued their fire all day. During the night, however, another company of the Thirteenth arrived, armed with Enfield rifles, and when the enemy opened fire again in the morning, they were replied to with such effect that a considerable number of them were placed hors de combat, and they were forced to abandon their battery. It was removed by them, however, on Sunday night -- the National force not being sufficient to cross the river to effect its capture. The skirmishing was still continued at last accounts.
lead_paragraph: There has been a skirmish on the Upper Potomac, which resulted disastrously to the rebels. abstract: Lieut. PEGRAM has succeeded in making his name famous. He has even gone further, and made it infamous. His wanton destruction of a merchant vessel on the high seas is an act unheard of in modern warfare. Such a barbarous outrage on the rights of commerce carries us back to an earlier civilization and a more savage epoch. It befits the character of a PAUL JONES, a Gulf pirate, or an Algerine corsair, rather than that of a man who for thirty-two years has enjoyed the distinction, and received the pay, of a United States officer.

abstract: The People ex. rel. Jas. S. Brownson et. al. vs. The Marine Court and Samuel W. Slocum. This was a motion for writs of prohibition to issue out of this Court, to restrain the Marine Court from trying three causes, brought by respondent Slocum, against the relators, upon three several promissory notes. The relators contend that the Marine Court has no jurisdiction to try the causes.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen held a regular meeting, last evening, at which a great number of papers were disposed of. A special Committee (to act in concert with one from the Board of Aldermen) was appointed to examine and report upon a suitable location for market purposes, on the North River, south of Fourteenth-street, and north of Canal-street. The following is a comparative statement of the amounts raised in each year since 1860, prepared by Mr. WARREN, Deputy Comptroller, from which it will be seen that the amount to be raised this year is nearly one million dollars less than 1861, and by reference to the Budget for 1862, presented to the Councilman last evening, it will be perceived that the Comptroller thinks that even this amount may be very materially diminished, and he strongly urges the Common Council to a judicious economy in all their expenditures. In some instances the Comptroller has not inserted the full amount called for by the heads of Departments:

abstract: The latest exploit of HOLLINS and his "ram," "turtle", or "what is it?" is still mom extraordinary than all its previous extraordinary exploits. According to the Savannah Republican, the "Manassas passed through Memphis, on the 4th inst., for Columbus, Ky." It is not recorded whether, in its passage, it rifted that Egyptian town in twain, or whether it only broke its own nose, as it did when it undertook to run against one of our men-of-war below New-Orleans. We need hardly say that we await with an intense anxiety the sequel of this latest and most astounding of HOLLINS' exploits.

abstract: The subject of an exchange of prisoners between the Government and the rebel authorities attracts a great deal of public discussion, and has engaged the earnest and solicitous attention of the Administration at Washington. The President and his Secretaries are naturally desirous to do everything in their power to alleviate the sufferings of those of our soldiers whom the fortunes of war have thrown into the hands of the rebels, as well as to mitigate, so far as possible, the sufferings of all who are in any way involved in the calamities which war brings in its train. But they have been forced to make a such considerations yield to the paramount duty of not compromising, in any way or to any extent, directly or by implication, the attitude of this Government, as absolutely sovereign, towards those who are in open rebellion against its authority. As our rebellion against Great Britain furnished a case in some respects analogous to the present war, the precedents of the Revolution on this point have a good deal of interest and importance. We shall present, therefore, a running history of the practice of the belligerents in that instance, as well as of the various attempts that were made to establish by agreement some general rule of action on the subject:

abstract: The silly story of Mr. OPDYKE losing his election, through errors in the original count, is rapidly vanishing before the labors of the Canvassers. The hundreds of ballots upon which the name of Mr. GUNTHER was only partially given, and which the poll officers consequently declined to enumerate, are already proved to be creatures of the excited fancy of some ward politician about whom the fumes of Tammany whisky were floating for a day or two after the election. The nine Wards already canvassed have not materially reduced the first stated majority of OPDYKE. The reduction, such as it is, is found not to be due in any degree to the cause so confidently alleged; but simply to clerical errors, or errors of enumeration. It may, of course, be counterbalanced by errors on the other side discoverable in the returns for the remaining thirteen Wards; so that it is even possible that a larger majority will have to be credited to the successful candidate, than has been claimed by his friends.
lead_paragraph: The silly story of Mr. OPDYKE losing his election, through errors in the original count, is rapidly vanishing before the labors of the Canvassers. It may, of course, be counterbalanced by errors on the other side discoverable in the returns for the remaining thirteen Wards; so that it is even possible that a larger majority will have to be credited to the successful candidate, than has been claimed by his friends.

abstract: The schooners Wide World, John L. Rodner, Benjamin Strong and Herschell, now lying at the Government dock foot of Murray-street. North River, are at loading provisions for Locust Point. The United States steam transports Jersey Blue, Commerce and W.P. Clyde, lying at Pier No. 9 North River, are also loading provisions and ammunition for the same place. They will probably all sail to-day.

abstract: Among the passengers from Boston to this city yesterday was Hon. CHARLES J. FAULKNER, late United States Minister in Paris, who has been released on parole from his imprisonment in Fort Warren by the General Government. He is on his way to Norfolk and Richmond, where he is to procure the release of Hon. ALFRED ELY, member of Congress from this State, now held as a prisoner of war by the Confederates. Failing in this, he is to return to the custody of the Washington authorities.
lead_paragraph: Among the passengers from Boston to this city yesterday was Hon. CHARLES J. abstract: Mr. GOODRICH, special bearer of important dispatches from our Ministers in Europe, arrived here this morning, and laid the documents before the Secretary of State. Mr. GOODRICH has been travelling for some time in Europe, and has had frequent interviews with the leading men throughout that country. The sympathy is almost universal with the Federal Government, and against the rebels.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Dec. 10.

abstract: GARRETT DAVIS, who has just been elected by the Legislature of Kentucky to fill the place in the United States Senate lately occupied by the expelled traitor BRECKINRIDGE, is one of the ablest public men in Kentucky. He is a native of that State, 58 years old, is a lawyer by profession and has acquired great distinction at the bar, and a very lucrative practice. He was a Representative in Congress from the Bourbon District in Kentucky for eight years, from 1839 to 1847. His residence is Paris, the county seat of Bourbon, one of the wealthiest "blue grass" counties in the State. When he left the public service, so high had he risen as a forensic debater and a skillfull parliamentary tactician, that he was justly regarded as one of the very foremost of the Whig leaders. His health forced him out of congressional life. But ever since his retirement he has had a loading part in shaping the State policy, and no important movement has been made without consulting him.
lead_paragraph: GARRETT DAVIS, who has just been elected by the Legislature of Kentucky to fill the place in the United States Senate lately occupied by the expelled traitor BRECKINRIDGE, is one of the ablest public men in Kentucky. abstract: SIR: Your dispatch of May 22 (No. 5) has been received. abstract: The Twenty-fourth Massachusetts Regiment Col. THOMAS G. STEVENSON, which has been encamped at Readville for some time past, left Boston on Monday evening for this city, on its way to Annapolis, at which place it will be attached to Gen. BURNSIDE'S Division. The regiment numbers 1,020 men, all of whom are thoroughly uniformed and equipped, and armed with the Enfield rifle. On landing at Twentythird-street the men were marched down Broadway to the Park Barracks.
lead_paragraph: The Twenty-fourth Massachusetts Regiment Col. THOMAS G. STEVENSON, which has been encamped at Readville for some time past, left Boston on Monday evening for this city, on its way to Annapolis, at which place it will be attached to Gen. BURNSIDE's Division. The regiment numbers 1,020 men, all of whom are thoroughly uniformed and equipped, and armed with the Enfield rifle. On landing at Twentythird-street the men were marched down Broadway to the Park Barracks. Along the route the men were loudly cheered and received high encomiums for the manner in which they marched. By invitation of the Sons of Massachusetts, the officers of the Twenty-fourth breakfasted at the Astor House, after which the men were again formed into line and marched to the foot of Canal-street, where they embarked on board the steamers Admiral and Eastern City, to be convoyed to their destination.

abstract: Farmerel al. vs. Bank of Fox Lake.--This action was brought to take up a draft given by the defendants in payment of a former one. On the trial below, the case resulted in favor of the plaintiffs, the defendants setting up as a defence first, that the check was obtained by fraud; and, secondly, that the giving of the check, in any event, was a payment.
lead_paragraph: Farmer et al. vs. Bank of Fox Lake. -- This action was brought to take up a draft given by the defendants in payment of a former one. On the trial below, the case resulted in favor of the plaintiffs, the defendants setting up as a defence first, that the check was obtained by fraud; and, secondly, that the giving of the check, in any event, was a payment.

abstract: Capt. Wilkes, U.S.N., commanding San Jacinto:  SIR: We desire to communicate to you, by this memorandum, the facts attending our arrest yesterday, on board the British mail steamer Trent, by your order, and our transfer to this ship.
lead_paragraph: U.S. STEAMER SAN JACINTO AT SEA, Nov. 9.
headline: {'main': 'THE CASE OF THE REBEL ENVOYS.; THE PROTEST OF MASON AND SLIDELL', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CASE OF THE REBEL ENVOYS.; THE PROTEST OF MASON AND SLIDELL', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is more than probable that with the present day all suspense in regard to the first impression made upon John Bull, by the exploit of Capt. WILKES, will be terminated. The La Plata, which connected with the Trent at St. Thomas, and carried forward the mails, passengers and news of that steamer, was expected at Southampton on the 29th ultimo, but was no doubt anticipated by the City of New-York, which left this port on the 16th ultimo, with intelligence of the capture of the two Envoys; and being one of the swiftest of transatlantic steamers, doubtless gave the tidings to the British public by the 26th, the day before the Kangaroo left Liverpool, and the Hansa left Southampton, for this port. The Kangaroo, calling at Queenstown on the 28th, and the Anglo-Saxon, for Portland, calling at Londonderry on the 29th, and the Europa, which will bring advices to Dec. 1, are now fully due at American ports; and it is scarcely possible that twenty-four hours can pass without one of this coming squadron making its report. To that portion of the public which is laboring with the painfullest apprehensions as to the temper with which our irascible progenitor will receive the news of the doings of his audacious descendant, the announcement of so early a solution of its doubts and fears must be received with a sense of grateful relief.
lead_paragraph: It is more than probable that with the present day all suspense in regard to the first impression made upon John Bull, by the exploit of Capt. WILKES, will be terminated. The La Plata, which connected with the Trent at St. Thomas, and carried forward the mails, passengers and news of that steamer, was expected at Southampton on the 29th ultimo, but was no doubt anticipated by the City of New-York, which left this port on the 16th ultimo, with intelligence of the capture of the two Envoys; and being one of the swiftest of transatlantic steamers, doubtless gave the tidings to the British public by the 26th, the day before the Kangaroo left Liverpool, and the Hansa left Southampton, for this port. The Kangaroo, calling at Queenstown on the 28th, and the Anglo-Saxon, for Portland, calling at Londonderry on the 29th, and the Europa, which will bring advices to Dec. 1, are now fully due at American ports; and it is scarcely possible that twenty-four hours can pass without one of this coming squadron making its report. To that portion of the public which is laboring with the painfullest apprehensions as to the temper with which our irascible progenitor will receive the news of the doings of his audacious descendant, the announcement of so early a solution of its doubts and fears must be received with a sense of grateful relief.

abstract: The delay which we have experienced in receiving reliable reports of the recent National victory at Fort Pickens,--for the rebels themselves virtually acknowledge that this was the result of the engagement,--furnishes another proof of the positive necessity of organizing some more regular and frequent system of communication with the ports held by our forces on the Southern coast.
lead_paragraph: The delay which we have experienced in receiving reliable reports of the recent National victory at Fort Pickens, -- for the rebels themselves virtually acknowledge that this was the result of the engagement, -- furnishes another proof of the positive necessity of organizing some more regular and frequent system of communication with the ports held by our forces on the Southern coast. BRAGG assaulted WILSON's Zouaves on the night of Oct. 9, and HOLLINS attacked the fleet, at the mouth of the Mississippi, three days subsequently, yet we were obliged to wait until Oct. 24 to learn that the rebels had suffered a disastrous repulse at Santa Rosa, and that the famous New-Orleans steam-ram had done little more than put its nose out of joint. This experience of waiting sixteen days to receive intelligence which might easily be brought to us in one-third that time, is repeating itself with some aggravations. The fight at Fort Pickens, which was undoubtedly more severe than any which has yet occurred south of Port Royal, commenced two weeks ago, and we are yet looking for the Connecticut, which, we are told, is to bring us the National version of the affair.

abstract: It was a good fortune to the person himself and to the world, that just before this terrible convulsion a candid, observing traveler and experienced agriculturist traveled the whole Southern country and carefully observed the effects of Slavery upon agriculture, upon manners, morals and social life. The same field will never be open again. Mr. OLMSTED has it all to himself. Whatever be the result of the rebellion, there can be no future opportunity for a dispassionate traveler to calmly watch and trace the features of a social system which belongs already to the past, and which the events of each day are rapidly changing. American Slavery can never be again altogether as it has been; it may even now be in the pangs of dissolution. However that may be, the future historian must seek in such pages as these of the well-known traveler and impartial observer, for the true characteristics and workings of the system. We have here traced by the hand not of an artist, but rather of a minute copyist, all those elements in the Southern population and their institutions which have burst forth in or have stimulated this gigantic and desperate outbreak. There is no apparent prejudice in OLMSTED's statements -- no even ordinary excitement, or enthusiasm in the expression of his conclusions. He gives us the clear simple daguerreotype of Southern life, and then leaves us to draw our own inferences. Sometimes the most fearful scenes are depicted with a sang froid which almost shocks one, until we see the intellectual object of this reserve. We behold in his sketches the shiftless, careless, lazy habits which Slavery naturally breeds; we stop at the dreary houses of the middle-class planters -- eat of the everlasting dyspepsia-giving hot bread and fat pork; talk with the surly women and the usually reticent men, whose conversation when excited becomes exuberant with oaths; we feel gradually, without ever being in so many words informed of it, the inherent ferocity and barbarity of society. The advantages also -- few though they be -- of the Southern system of labor are as faithfully given; the use of arms and the habits of command for which a class of masters or superiors to a servile class are naturally inclined, and the thoroughly disciplined and efficient "organization of labor" on some of the large cotton and sugar plantations, which perhaps could hardly be obtained without involuntary labor. The slave, too, is pictured with equal faithfulness -- perhaps some will think with too little sympathy, yet, no doubt, with perfect justice. His cost, his labor, his habits and diseases, his conversations and his spasmodic seasons of religious excitement and sentiment are most dramatically and closely described. Mr. OLMSTED has a certain nack of hearing and recording all the characteristic and droll stories, whether of white or black, which could meet a traveler at the South, while he gives certain conversations with a most vivid, life-like power. The result is that the book, apart from its great value as a book of information, is one of the most readable of the day.

abstract: Rev. Dr. BUTLER, of Washington, in a lecture at Cincinnati a few evenings ago, gave his audiences a few instances of the amiable disposition of young ladies of secession persuasion. In Alexandria, a gallant young artillery officer was spit upon by two young ladies, a few days before the battle of Bull Run. He immediately inquired their names and ascertained their residences, and on that same evening, with a number of his comrades, serenaded them for three hours, singing the most sentimental songs in praise of the loveliness and gentleness of women.

abstract: Although we have nothing as yet  direct from the Stone squadron, the "sixteen vessels looking like whalers," descried by the Savannah journals, inside the bar, answer so nearly to the description, that they may fairly be put down as the moiety of the famous rat-hole fleet, the other score having gone to pay their attentions to Charleston har- bor.
lead_paragraph: Although we have nothing as yet direct from the Stone squadron, the "sixteen vessels looking like whalers," descried by the Savannah journals, inside the bar, answer so nearly to the description, that they may fairly be put down as the moiety of the famous rat-hole fleet, the other score having gone to pay their attentions to Charleston harbor. There is one result of this sealing operation which was not contemplated in planning the measure, but which nevertheless will be one of its indirect effects. It will end forever the long-standing jealousies and bickerings of Charleston and Savannah with regard to the advantages of their respective harbors. The blockade, it is true, has for the present relieved them from the necessity of establishing invidious comparisons; but in former years they illustrated the beauties of Southern affection between State and State by the most scandalous railings. In an old copy of the Savannah Republican of May 18, 1859, we find an article of the kind, which as a home view of a subject that now interests us, is both suggestive and prophetic. Here are a few sentences worth resuscitating:

abstract: JOHN VERNAM, of Mount Morris, well known throughout the State, died in that village on Friday last, after a protracted illness. Mr. VERNAM was many years ago Sheriff off Saratoga County, and conspicuous in the politics of that part of the State. He removed thence to Livingston County, and was long connected with the construction and administration of our public works. He was one time Democratic candidate for Canal Commissioner.

abstract: A GANG OF SWINDLERS CAUGHT. -- Officer CROSBY, of the Lower Police Court, yesterday arrested three men, who gave their names as JOB EDWARDS, WM. H. LEONARD, and -- MILLER. They are charged by JOHN ONIONS, of No. 133 Liberty-street, with having swindled him out of $250, in the following manner. They advertised in the Herald for a partner having the above sum in cash; stating that they were engaged in the grocery business at No. 457 Macdougal-street. Mr. ONIONS answered their advertisement, and had an interview with the trio. They showed him large piles of boxes, which, it was alleged, were filled with groceries of all kinds. They stated they had been in business there about ten months; had done, and were doing a large and flourishing trade, and that the goods in the store were worth $1,000. Mr. ONIONS demanded that a legal agreement should be drawn up by an attorney. One of the firm was therefore put forward as a lawyer, the writings were drawn up, duly executed, and the money paid over. ONIONS was to be an active partner, and it seems that he soon became altogether too active to suit the designs of his copartners. An examination of the boxes in the store showed that they were empty, except a few filled with stones. The value of everything there did not exceed a few dollars. They had been there only a week or two, and had never paid any rent. Complainant, therefore, alleged that they were swindlers. Justice BRENNAN held the accused for examination.

abstract: ONE MAN INSTANTLY KILLED. -- Between 4 and 5 o'clock on Monday morning, an alcohol still exploded in the distillery of Messrs. FURMAN & Co., on the block bounded by First and Second, North Fourth and North Fifth streets, by which one man, named FRANK TEAGUE, who had charge of the still, was almost instantly killed, and the premises set on fire. The explosion is described by those who heard it as most terrific. The walls of the building where the explosion took place, were blown out, and the whole premises were apparently wrapped in one sheet of fire. The loss of Messrs. FURMAN & Co. is estimated at $20,000, which amount is covered by insurance in several New-York and Brooklyn offices.

abstract: We publish elsewhere an interesting letter from Capt. WILKES to the Secretary of the Navy, on his arrest of MASON and SLIDELL. It gives an inside view of the affair, showing under what light, and with what views he performed the act. The public generally had been led to believe, from a remark which Capt. WILKES was reported to have made after he had taken the step -- to the effect that he "could only be court-martialed for it" -- that he was in doubts as to the legality of the act; and not a little of the popular satisfaction arose from the fact that he had dared "to take the responsibility." But Captain WILKES waives all claims to this stroke of inspiration. On first getting wind of the whereabouts of the rebel Ambassadors, far from acting with unauthorized precipitancy, he retired to his cabin and squared his elbows to a vigorous inquisition of the lights of international law. "I carefully examined," says he,"KENT, WHEATON, VATTELL, besides various decisions of Sir WILLIAM SCOTT, and other Judges of the Admiralty Court of Great Britain, which bore upon the rights of neutrals and their responsibilities."
lead_paragraph: We publish elsewhere an interesting letter from Capt. WILKES to the Secretary of the Navy, on his arrest of MASON and SLIDELL. It gives an inside view of the affair, showing under what light, and with what views he performed the act. The public generally had been led to believe, from a remark which Capt. WILKES was reported to have made after he had taken the step -- to the effect that he "could only be court-martialed for it" -- that he was in doubts as to the legality of the act; and not a little of the popular satisfaction arose from the fact that he had dared "to take the responsibility." But Captain WILKES waives all claims to this stroke of inspiration. On first getting wind of the whereabouts of the rebel Ambassadors, far from acting with unauthorized precipitancy, he retired to his cabin and squared his elbows to a vigorous inquisition of the lights of international law. "I carefully examined," says he,"KENT, WHEATON, VATTELL, besides various decisions of Sir WILLIAM SCOTT, and other Judges of the Admiralty Court of Great Britain, which bore upon the rights of neutrals and their responsibilities."

abstract: Very little business of public importance was done by Congress yesterday, the day being principally devoted to eulogies of a dead Senator. In the Senate, petitions for the emancipation of slaves under the war power were presented by Messrs. FESSENDEN, of Maine, and SUMNER, of Massachusetts. A resolution for the expulsion of WALDO P. JOHNSON, member of the Senate, from Missouri, was presented by Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, and laid over.
lead_paragraph: Very little business of public importance was done by Congress yesterday, the day being principally devoted to eulogies of a dead Senator. In the Senate, petitions for the emancipation of slaves under the war power were presented by Messrs. FESSENDEN, of Maine, and SUMNER, of Massachusetts. A resolution for the expulsion of WALDO P. JOHNSON, member of the Senate, from Missouri, was presented by Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, and laid over. A bill authorizing the President to acquire territory for the settlement of free persons of African descent was introduced by Mr. HARLAN, of Iowa, and referred to the Committee on Public Lands. Senator WILSON's bill for the reorganization of the Medical Department of the Army was referred to the Military Committee. The resolution offered by Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the expediency of abolishing and reestablishing the Supreme Court was agreed to. The death of Mr. BINGHAM, Senator from Michigan, was then announced.

abstract: There has been considerable disappointment felt that the landing of our troops on the coast of North and South Carolina has not produced that diversion of the rebel troops before Washington which was anticipated. The expected rush homeward of the Carolina rebels to defend their own States has not taken place; and, consequently, MCCLELLAN has as strong an enemy in his front now to fight as he had before we landed twenty thousand men at Hatteras and Port Royal.

abstract: SIR: You receive the President's instructions for the discharge of your very important mission at a moment when a domestic crisis, long apprehended with deep solicitude, is actually reached. For the first time since the foundations of this Federal Republic were laid, with such pious care and consummate wisdom, an insurrection has developed itself, and assumed the organization and attitude of a separate political power.
lead_paragraph: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, No. 2.] WASHINGTON, April 27, 1861.

abstract: Rev. Dr. STORRS last evening delivered a lecture at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, choosing for his subject the war in which the nation is now engaged, and the results likely to accrue from it to the people of this generation and their posterity. The lecturer having been introduced to a large and highly respectable audience, commenced his address with a general reference to history. He said that history is the biography of nations.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. STORRS last evening delivered a lecture at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, choosing for his subject the war in which the nation is now engaged, and the results likely to accrue from it to the people of this generation and their posterity. The lecturer having been introduced to a large and highly respectable audience, commenced his address with a general reference to history. He said that history is the biography of nations. It presents to us the vicissitudes of fortune through which nations have passed to greatness or decay. Each nation expects for itself a career of unexampled prosperity, and thinks it will somehow be exempted from the reverses that have befallen other nations. But all are liable to the same changes. These changes sometimes come unexpectedly, as in the case of this country at the present crisis. This country has suddenly awakened from the sunniest, softest dream of steadfast peace to find itself involved in a terrible war. Some sinking of heart may follow the sudden shock of this awakening. Still, as a resolute man will dominate in the midst of opposing forces, so will a nation, if of generous stock, rise superior to disaster. Thunderstorms, volcanic eruptions, are desolating phases of nature, that precede quietude and fruitful development; so, out of war, a people that manfully bears itself, sees brighter vistas in the future. This has been true of other nations. It will be so of ours. A just war, wisely waged, becomes a great improving, regenerating agent in the State. It is not the case with all wars; but will be the result of a war waged for a good cause, in a spirit of conscientious devotion. The lecturer cursorily touched upon the characteristics of wars, as usually precipitated and conducted, and deprecated the evils that they inevitably caused. Nevertheless, he contended that even the worst of wars had redeeming features. They draw forth from the rightful side striking examples of patriotism and self-sacrifice. They produced instances of that loyal spirit of self-defence that Christ himself imposed upon his followers. Some wars were a sharp and wide-spread administration of justice. They take on a judicial aspect; there is the crimson outside, but the lining is of purest ermine. The record of time has significance when such a war as the present marks its progress. Its effects upon our material interests must also be regarded. The waste of war is frightful, no matter how righteous the cause in which it is waged. It destroys men, and men are the producing agents from whom general prosperity accrues. Even brute animals can be made to produce more than they consume; so can slaves; how much more free, educated citizens. Yet the destructive influences of war have counterbalancing benefits. So far as expenditure goes, we have not approached many European nations in the amount of our pecuniary outgoings. We have not begun to rival the magnitude of the English national debt. In times of comparative peace we have spent $2,000,000,000 in movements against England, Algiers, Mexico and the Indians; surely we can bear some strain upon our resources in such a war as this. War does not involve annihilation, it merely causes redistribution. It is not always so disastrous as it at first appears to be. Many nations have achieved the highest pitch of prosperity in the very midst of continuous war. War impresses upon us many useful lessons. It teaches us a wise economy; it stimulates invention, shows us those deep reserves of power before unthought of, which always start into life under the spur of emergency. It opens up new schemes of remunerative enterprise. The lecturer proved how some of the most useful inventions and grandest progressive movements of former and contemporary nations followed upon periods of seemingly exhaustive war. Dr. STORRS then made the conventional contrast between the inhabitants of luxurious plains and those who breathed a more invigorative atmosphere, spoke of the elasticity and recuperative energies of the latter, as compared with the spasmodic passion of the former, and drew the inference which the peculiar geographical qualities of the North and South would naturally suggest. He went on to say that the trials we are called upon to undergo will make better men of us and our posterity. When the reaction consequent on reestablished peace comes, every species of prosperous enterprise will expand to more imposing proportions than ever. Like the fabled giant, we shall arise all the stronger for the touch of our mother earth that we received in the moment of temporary prostration. Dr. STORRS proceeded to expatiate at length on the moral aspects of the war. The war will educate and inspire us. It is a great thing for a nation to come to a knowledge of its own martial strength. A greater sense of responsibility -- a more even-tempered magnanimity are thereby created. We are made more patient -- less petulant. The lecturer spoke at length on the better submission to discipline which the war will produce. It will render us more subordinate -- more ready to yield obedience where obedience is due. A Republic gains greatness by the strength of the Government it imposes on itself, and the readiness of its obedience to such delegated authority. The volunteer army, when it disbands, will diffuse this spirit of subordination amongst all classes. The war will knit together all sections of the community. The voice that rolls along the battle's edge is just as musical, whether German or American; there is no distinction now between Hungarian and Huguenot: the green flag, shamrock and all, floats nobly beside the Stars and Stripes. Great good will be derived from instances of individual heroism. We shall take a more exalted view of things. The lecturer, in a fine strain of eloquence, referred to the heroic sacrifice of Gen. BAKER, and to various cases of glorious personal achievement that have obtained historic fame, and declared that they had all had their share in the improvement of the race. War will bring our foremost men to the front. It will give power to the best and greatest. It will deliver us from insidious foes who seek to undermine our rights and liberties, and, viewed in that light, must be regarded as a blessing. It will teach us to call things by their right names -- American Slavery amongst the rest. The final peace, the immortal serenity that we all look for comes to us through the august travail of ages; so may the ordeal through which we are now passing soon bring us a foretaste of that peace. Dr. STORRS was warmly applauded throughout, and that by listeners of more than usual discrimination.

abstract: DEAR PARENTS: I wrote you a line or two by the mail accompanying Dr. HAGADORN, whom you have seen ere this. Dr. B. expressed great gratification at H.'s well-being. He has many friends here, and any attentions shown the prisoners in the neighborhood of New-York by its citizens can but have a beneficial effect upon the prisoners here. Nevertheless, I cannot but regret that some of the money and attentions bestowed on them should not have caused thought toward doing the like toward us. Why not send a batch of clothing to the unfortunates here? Government must know that their slop-shop duds can't last forever. And here we are, with the same rage upon us that adorned us upon our exit from Washington four months ago. Torn by bullets and saturated with blood on the field of Manassas though they were, we still hang to them as our only wardrobe. The Confederates have of late given us cover-lids, which, of course, don't supply the part of clothing.

abstract: With the cessation of active hostilities in the trans-Alleghanian portion of Virginia, the seat of war in that State is now confined to the Eastern section, designated as "The Old Dominion," an appellation often given, improperly, to the whole Commonwealth. Of this portion of Virginia we furnish the readers of the TIMES this morning, two large and admirably-executed Maps, drawn with sedulous regard to topographical accuracy, and representing the entire region stretching from Harper's Ferry to Norfolk. Hostile armies, numbering in the aggregate a half million of men are encamped or intrenched, or enwalled within these limits. Troops and supply trains constantly traverse every mile of it; its waters swarm with armed vessels; the cultivation of the soil is neglected; the Summer's harvest is but a crop of bayonets. So thoroughly indeed has the field been cleared for the bloody tournament to which the nation has been bidden, that no industrial pursuit, or other unbecoming relic of peace and tranqui, prosperity, disturbs the horrid level of this great battle plain.

abstract: Amid the blatant proclamations of confidence in the cause of secession in which the rebels indulge -- all the more blatant as they are conscious of a coming collapse -- there now and then comes out a fact which, with striking emphasis, gives the lie to their loud mouthings. Here is one. Paper money at the South is at thirty-five per cent. discount for gold: United States Treasury notes, or demand notes, are freely taken at par! This is the kind of test that tells. They talk loud, but they trust only Uncle Sam as their banker. While Confederate bonds are in many places literally thrown away as worthless, United States Treasury notes are eagerly sought for at par! They have, after all, not such erroneous ideas of the relative prospects of stability for the two Governments, those fellows.

abstract: Our neighbor of the Herald fights hard against the blow our offer to test his veracity on the subject of circulation has given him. But he fights like a man whose wind is gone, and whose "peepers" are closed. He hits wild and very low. He sees a dozen antagonists where there is but one, and seems generally confused and dazed by the turn things are taking. His profession of religious scruples against betting, speaks volumes concerning the condition to which he has been reduced.

abstract: A regular weekly meeting of this body was held Monday evening. A communication was received from the Mayor, relative to the Sinking Fund. He says the accountant employed upon the hooks of the Sinking Fund, to separate each loan, has completed his labors. From the investigations had, it appears that the amount of indebtedness for the whole of the city loan is $6,913,582,37; that the availables held and to the credit of the fund are $487,774,40. Both amounts agree with the last annual report of the Comptroller. Neither the sewerage bonds nor those issued for local improvements, and to be paid for by local assessment, are included in the above. The City Hall loan shows a not inconsiderable deficiency, which, however large balances have accrued, will continue to accrue to the credit of several of the other loans, mainly in consequence of the peculiar language of the laws authorizing these loans to be made. This, however, will not effect the general result. The Mayor annexes a statement to the communication, showing the various amounts necessary to be raised annually hereafter upon the city at large, and the several parts thereof, for principal and interest due on the different loans, and recommends that it be printed. The Mayor also recommends that the Finance Committee be authorized to examine the same, and, on receiving their approval, the statement be filed, and that the Comptroller be directed to have the accounts continued in like manner in future.

abstract: The Little Rock State Journal, of Nov. 29, notices the arrival at that city of twenty-seven prisoners, members of a secret Lincoln organization, from Van Buren County. They were lodged in jail for safe keeping, until tried by the civil authorities. Forty others were said to be on the way, and the names of the whole clan known, also their secret signs and pass-words, which were divulged by a young man who was ignorantly initiated into the order.

abstract: It is reported that several regi  ments on the Potomac are putting up commodious cabins for holding meetings for intellectual improvement and discussion during the Winter evenings. We don't remember that history records any spectacle exactly like that --a huge army coolly resolving itself into a debating society in front of the enemy.
lead_paragraph: It is reported that several regiments on the Potomac are putting up commodious cabins for holding meetings for intellectual improvement and discussion during the Winter evenings. We don't remember that history records any spectacle exactly like that -- a huge army coolly resolving itself into a debating society in front of the enemy. Nothing, however, could be more characteristic of the versatile Yankee nature; and we don't know but that, if the army be really going into Winter-quarters, it is the best thing our boys could do with their evenings.

abstract: Further information has been received relative to Mr. SIGISMUND FELLNER, the German whose body was found a few weaks since, floating in the water, in the vicinity of this City. The Police authorities have just received a communication from Mr. FELLNER's relatives in Germany. They state that he left his home there without the knowledge of his family; that he has a young wife and one child in that country, who are plunged into the deepest distress on account of the unfortunate and untimely death of the husband and father. They state further that when he left Europe he took with him a sum of money exceeding $100,000, besides a large amount of jewelry and other valuables. They offer the sum of $2,000 reward, in addition to that already made public, for the arrest and conviction of RADETSKY, the man who is believed to have committed the murder. They also offer the reward of one half of all the money and valuables belonging to FELLNER, which may be recovered. There is now the sum of $3,000 offered for the apprehension and conviction of the murderer. It is believed by the authorities of this City, that if RADETSKY has not already gone beyond the limits of the Union States, he will soon be taken into custody.
lead_paragraph: Further information has been received relative to Mr. SIGISMUND FELLNER, the German whose body was found a few weaks since, floating in the water, in the vicinity of this City. The Police authorities have just received a communication from Mr. FELLNER's relatives in Germany. They state that he left his home there without the knowledge of his family; that he has a young wife and one child in that country, who are plunged into the deepest distress on account of the unfortunate and untimely death of the husband and father. They state further that when he left Europe he took with him a sum of money exceeding $100,000, besides a large amount of jewelry and other valuables. They offer the sum of $2,000 reward, in addition to that already made public, for the arrest and conviction of RADETSKY, the man who is believed to have committed the murder. They also offer the reward of one half of all the money and valuables belonging to FELLNER, which may be recovered. There is now the sum of $3,000 offered for the apprehension and conviction of the murderer. It is believed by the authorities of this City, that if RADETSKY has not already gone beyond the limits of the Union States, he will soon be taken into custody.

abstract: In another part of this morning's TIMES we have given a careful history of the Exchange of Prisoners, as practiced between the British and Americans during the war of the Revolution. This will be found to be of special interest just now in view of the discussions concerning the exchange of prisoners between our Government and the rebel authorities. Every one is naturally desirous that such an exchange should be effected. It seems very hard that some thousands of our brave soldiers should He in Southern dungeons, and be subjected to all the sufferings and hardships of Southern captivity. Not only the prisoners themselves and their immediate friends, but all who sympathize with suffering, or have compassion for misfortune, take this view of the subject, and are extremely anxious that something should be done to establish a regular exchange of prisoners on both sides.

abstract: Our advices from the rebels, by way of Fortress Monroe, are important. The Norfolk Day Book, of Monday, a copy of which was brought down by a flag of truce, states that a battle is expected immediately on the Potomac, as the sutlers are engaged in removing their stores. This indicates that the "On to Washington" policy has at last fully prevailed in the rebel councils, and that we may expect a great, and perhaps a decisive battle, in a short time. This is further rendered probable by a statement contained in our Washington dispatches. Two regiments of rebel infantry, and one of cavalry, made their appearance in front of Gen. BLENKER's Division on Monday night, and a considerable force also took possession of Springfield, a place which was abandoned by them some time ago. It appears that the rebels have been advancing quietly in the direction of our lines for several days, and at various points.

abstract: On Monday morning, at about 9 o'clock, this regiment, which has been encamped at Readville, Mass., for some time past, struck tents, preparatory to its departure for the seat of war. Previous to its de parture, at the roll-call, 1,020 officers and men answered to their names. In the evening the men left, by the Stonington route, for New-York, and arrived here at about noon yesterday. The steamer Cornelius Vanderbilt was chartered to convey them to this City.

abstract: We devote a large portion of our space today to the publication of the diplomatic correspondence connected with the rebellion, -especially of the letters in which our Ministers at the several European Courts were instructed as to the light in which they were to present this incident to the various Governments to which they were accredited. Although the general subject has lost something of its novelty to American readers, they will find it presented in a fresh and most interesting light in this correspondence. By far the most masterly presentation of this whole subject, from the American point of view, which has yet been made will be found embodied in these letters of the Secretary of State. No abler public documents have ever emanated from that Department than those which Mr. SEWARD has produced, with so much profuseness, during the few short months that have intervened since the rebellion broke out. They are marked at once by the clearest insight into the philosophy of the movement, and the motives of its actors -- the most distinct perception of the means to be employed in its suppression, and the firmest and most unswerving determination to suffer no foreign Power, under any circumstances; to interfere in any way with the adjustment of our internal differences.

abstract: -- Within the last six or eight months a class of nuisances has been growing up in some of our principal streets, which demand the immediate and rigorous attention of our police authorities. We refer to the concert saloons, as they are called, which abound in Broadway, and which, under gaise of singing, and selling lager beer, are really the lowest and most infamous houses of prostitution, in which thousands of young men and boys congregate, every night, and plunge info the worst excesses of ruinous and disgraceful debauchery. Some of them have licenses for theatrical performances, and resort to petty plays, gymnastic feats, dancing, &c. &c., as an additional means of enticing visitors. The Herold, (especially its Sunday morning edition) is the recognised medium of advertising for these establishments, which brazen in large staring capitals their "pretty waiter girls" as among the special attractions of the place. These waiter-girls are simply street-walkers, who and greater facilities for thus prosecuting their trade indoors than in the open thoroughfare.
lead_paragraph: -- Within the last six or eight months a class of nuisances has been growing up in some of our principal streets, which demand the immediate and rigorous attention of our police authorities. We refer to the concert saloons, as they are called, which abound in Broadway, and which, under gaise of singing, and selling lager beer, are really the lowest and most infamous houses of prostitution, in which thousands of young men and boys congregate, every night, and plunge info the worst excesses of ruinous and disgraceful debauchery. Some of them have licenses for theatrical performances, and resort to petty plays, gymnastic feats, dancing, &c. &c., as an additional means of enticing visitors. The Herold, (especially its Sunday morning edition) is the recognised medium of advertising for these establishments, which brazen in large staring capitals their "pretty waiter girls" as among the special attractions of the place. These waiter-girls are simply street-walkers, who and greater facilities for thus prosecuting their trade indoors than in the open thoroughfare.

abstract: The intelligence which we publish to-day from Hilton Head warrants an outlook for coming business in South Carolina. Gen. SHERMAN has at length determined to occupy Beaufort; and at the Sailing of the latest steamer had dispatched an advance guard of one thousand men to hold that point. Addi
lead_paragraph: The intelligence which we publish to-day from Hilton Head warrants an outlook for coming business in South Carolina. Gen. SHERMAN has at length determined to occupy Beaufort; and at the Sailing of the latest steamer had dispatched an advance guard of one thousand men to hold that point. Additional forces would immediately follow, and from private advices we are able to announce that half of SHERMAN's whole division is now or soon will be concentrated at Beaufort. The proportions of the new move give assurance that it will not be a mere reconnoissance, as before, but an occupancy en permanence.

abstract: In the Senate, the Committee on Military Affairs was instructed to inquire and report what reduction may be made in the expenses of the Army. An inquiry was also directed as to the possibility of furnishing greater facilities to soldiers for sending home their pay. Resolutions...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the Committee on Military Affairs was instructed to inquire and report what reduction may be made in the expenses of the Army. An inquiry was also directed as to the possibility of furnishing greater facilities to soldiers for sending home their pay. Resolutions were presented from the Legislature of Kentucky, asking Congress to afford some relief to the suffering people in Ireland. It was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs. A memorial was presented from the New-York Chamber of Commerce, relative to the establishment of a mail line between San Francisco and China. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of appointing a Joint Committee of the two houses of Congress, who shall have power to retire improper officers of the Army and Navy. A bill establishing a new military and mail route between Washington and Baltimore, was referred to the Military Committee, as was a bill to increase the number of cadets at West Point. The death of Col. BALSER was then announced, and the rest of the session was devoted to fitting eulogies of his life and character.

abstract: Important reconnoissances were yesterday made along our lines of the Potomac, to ascertain the positions and strength of the rebels. One, made in a balloon by Prof. LA MOUNTAIN, establishes the facts that the rebel force at Fairfax Courthouse is very light; that between that point and Vienna there is an increase of strength, and that all along the line very considerable additions have been made to the scouts of cavalry and infantry.
lead_paragraph: Important reconnoissances were yesterday made along our lines of the Potomac, to ascertain the positions and strength of the rebels. One, made in a balloon by Prof. LA MOUNTAIN, establishes the facts that the rebel force at Fairfax Court-house is very light; that between that point and Vienna there is an increase of strength, and that all along the line very considerable additions have been made to the scouts of cavalry and infantry.

abstract: The steamship Columbia arrived at this port yesterday, from Havana, which port she left on the 6th inst. Nothing of importance had occurred at Havana since the date of previous advices. ANDERSON, who recently succeeded in escaping from the rebels in Texas.

abstract: We took occasion, last week, to speak in terms of earnest commendation of that portion of Secretary CAMERON's report which suggested an enlargement of the railroad facilities between Washington and Baltimore. No need is more urgent, and no occasion more appropriate. But the measure, nevertheless, falls
lead_paragraph: We took occasion, last week, to speak in terms of earnest commendation of that portion of Secretary CAMERON's report which suggested an enlargement of the railroad facilities between Washington and Baltimore. No need is more urgent, and no occasion more appropriate. But the measure, nevertheless, falls very far short of the standard which, with more comprehensive views, Congress will probably adopt, -- bills having already been noticed to that end, and petitions from the New-York Chamber of Commerce, and other influential bodies, having urged the passage of these bills with a number of powerful considerations. We allude to the creation of a National Post Railroad between this City and the Federal Capital.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, Frederick Hug, a German, 35 years of age, was tried and convicted of assaulting Thomas McKenna with a dangerous weapon, and remanded for sentence. Ann Flannagan, 33 years, born in Ireland, pleaded guilty to defrauding the disbursers of the fund for the relief of families of volunteers out of $3 1/2 per week for twelve weeks, by falsely representing that she was the wife of Christopher Flannagan, a private in Co. K, 9th N.Y.V., whereas in truth she was merely the wife of Michael Flannagan, who never went to the war. Fined $5.

abstract: We publish, this morning, some additional extracts from our diplomatic correspondence with England, which relate to the neutral position assumed by England, and to the questions that arose in connection with the subject of privateering. We have already given the dispatch of Secretary SEWARD, in which he rehearsed the successive steps of the attempted negotiation, -- but these extracts will still further illustrates the feeling which governed the action of the, British Government in the matter. While they professed the greatest anxiety to secure the adhesion of the United States to this important provision, they were determined, at all events, to hold themselves free from any obligation to enforce it against the Southern States. It was this determination on their part, and the evident impossibility on ours of conceding the exception required, which broke off all negotiations upon the subject.

abstract: -- Some operator, whose boldness is only equaled by that of the prestidigitateur himself, succeeded in abstracting from a show-case in Boston several of Hermann's trophies; -- the diamond buttons and studs presented to him by the Emperor of Austria, valued at $1,200. The robbery was committed while the case was surrounded by some fifteen or twenty persons, who were examining its rich contents, and it is supposed the rogue must have played the part of being a clerk in attendance, to ward off suspicion of his operations.

abstract: This regiment, formerly known as DURYEE's Zouaves, have opened a recruiting depot under the direct supervision of Lieut.-Col. DURYEE and Capt. WINSLOW, at No. 545 Broadway. Owing to the many promotions from the ranks to commissions in their own and other regiments, vacancies have been created which will give an opportunity to 40 first-class men to enroll themselves in this well-disciplined corps, now stationed on Federal Hill, Baltimore. Quarters, nations and clothing are provided at once, and the men will be [???] on to join the regiment on Monday of next week.

abstract: -- Our neighbor of the Herald is suddenly becoming sensible of the value and importance of foreign criticisms on the America Press. He has discovered an article in the London Saturday Review, in which the NEW-YORK TIMES is spoken of disrespectfully, and he exults over it as if he had received the personal indorsement of the entire world of British journalism. In the very article referred to, the Saturday Review speaks of the Herald as "in no sense fairly representing the cultivated mind and intelligence of the citizens of New-York," -- but as being "addressed to the vulgar herd of noisy politicians." And the hardest thing it says of the TIMES is, that it is a "somewhat more respectable journal" than the Herald. Our neighbor considers this a compliment!
lead_paragraph: -- Our neighbor of the Herald is suddenly becoming sensible of the value and importance of foreign criticisms on the America Press. abstract: The Herald prints an advertisement of THE TRIBUNE copied from our columns, for which it pretends that we pay it half-price. The pretence is utterly false; we never employed, nor authorized, nor in any manner solicited, the insertion of our advertisement by the Herald, any more than we ever entreated its forbearance, or did any other of a thousand discreditable acts which that mendacious journal has from time to time attributed to us.
lead_paragraph: From the Daily Tribune, Dec. 5, 1861.

abstract: The Big Whippoorwill is a stream seven miles west of Russellville, Logan County, Ky., and the Memphis Branch of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad crosses it about seven miles north of the Tennessee line. It is southwest of Bowling Green, where the main body of the rebel army in Kentucky, under BUCKNER, is stationed; and if the bridge is effectually destoyed, and the other bridge over Blk Fork, five miles further west, is also demolished, BUCKNER's direct railroad communication with Memphis, as well as with Columbus and Hickman, is cut off. Bowling Green is situated at the point where the Memphis Branch joins the Louisville and Nashville Road, and its strategic importance depends in a great measure upon its railroad connections.

abstract: With the WEEKLY TIMES, issued THIS MORNING, we furnish two large and admirably executed maps, drawn with sedulous regard to topographical accuracy, and representing that entire region of Virginia known as "The Old Dominion," stretching form Harper's Ferry to Norfolk, Hostile armies, numbering in the aggregate a half million of men, are encamped, or intrenched, or enwalled in these limits.
lead_paragraph: With the WEEKLY TIMES, issued THIS MORNING, we furnish two large and admirably executed maps, drawn with sedulous regard to topographical accuracy, and representing that entire region of Virginia known as "The Old Dominion," stretching form Harper's Ferry to Norfolk, Hostile armies, numbering in the aggregate a half million of men, are encamped, or intrenched, or enwalled in these limits. By the aid of these maps, the reader most distant from the theatre of operations can obtain as clear and comprehensive an idea of the campaign as those who participate in it, and trace out to his own satisfaction the numerous strategical points held by the opposing armies. In future, we design to issue these supplementary maps with the SEMI-WEEKLY and WEEKLY TIMES, as often as may be necessary to afford our readers an adequate idea of the movements made and contemplated by the forces in the field. Papers, containing the supplementary maps and in wrappers ready for mailing, may be had at the counter of the Publication Office at the usual price. In addition, the WEEKLY TIMES of this morning contains:

lead_paragraph: The few words of intelligence which reach us from Port Pickens, through a channel not entirely under rebel control, shows that Gen. BRAGG, in his recent interchange of countrsits with Col. BROWN, earne by the worse. His batteries were silenced, and he only escaped a more thorough drubbing because the National commander was yet lacking the necessary force to render a landing safe or practicable. The fort was, therefore, not breached -- the vessels disabled -- the position exposed to capture by assault at the will of the rebels. Such victory as there was belonged to the soldiers of the Union -- who, in not staking their success upon an ill-advised conflict with an enemy tenfold in number, and strongly intrenched, proved that to valor they added a wholesome discretion.

abstract: Mary Johnson vs. Susan Dixion. In this case the plaintiff hired a stall in the defendant's stable, at $2.50 per month, in which to keep a horse. Under the floor of the stall was an excavation, as appeared from the evidence, some ten feet deep, which was not known to the plaintiff at the time she rented it.
lead_paragraph: Mary Johnson vs. Susan Dixion. -- In this case the plaintiff hired a stall in the defendant's stable, at $2 50 per month, in which to keep a horse. Under the floor of the stall was an excavation, as appeared from the evidence, some ten feet deep, which was not known to the plaintiff at the time she rented it. Subsequently, the floor of the stall was discovered by the plaintiff's son to be in a dangerous condition, and he mentioned it to the defendant's agent, who, as shown, promised to attend to it, but did not have it repaired as it was understood would be done. In consequence of the neglect to repair, the plaintiff's horse fell through the floor, and was so injured that it died. This action was the result -- which, upon the trial, was determined in favor of the plaintiff.

abstract: The accident which occurred on the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad near Gray's Ferry Bridge, on Friday night, resulted in the destruction of several cars, injury to locomotives, and some narrow escapes.
lead_paragraph: The accident which occurred on the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad near Gray's Ferry Bridge, on Friday night, resulted in the destruction of several cars, injury to locomotives, and some narrow escapes. The train due at the ferry about 11 o'clock, was processing towards the bridge at a very slow rate of speed, the night being so foggy that the engineer could not see very far. The train going south was advancing with much greater speed, it having started a flew minutes late from the depot, Broad and Washington streets. The two locomotives came together on the curve a short distance beyond the bridge, and with sufficient force to smash cow-catchers, lamps, and injure the machinery of both locomotives, but not to any great extent. Both trains being long and heavily laden, great damage was done to the cars nearest the locomotives by the momentum of those behind them. The baggage-car and the mail-car of the up train were completely demolished, one of them having been removed from the trucks and pushed into the other like a telescope, within eight or ten feet of the end. The cars being at a slight angle to each other, by their position on the curve, one side of the mail-car was carried away. The Express baggage-master, Mr. SAMUEL BENNER, had his coat caught between the trucks in such a way that he had to be cut loose from it. The mall agent, Mr. TRAIL, had to be taken from the top of the car. The injuries of both of these persons were very slight. The platforms and draw-bars of some of the cars on this train were broken. The Adams' Express car, on the train going South, was perfectly wrecked, and its contents strewn upon the ground. Some of the soldiers from a camp near by laid in a large supply of turkies, chickens, eggs, &c., which were on the way to soldiers near Washington. Some of the platforms of the cars on this train were also broken. The damage to the company will not be very heavy, as the running gear of the cars injured were not damaged. The accident, it appears, was caused by the rule of the company, requiring trains going South to stop at the bridge a certain length of time having been violated.

abstract: The latest intelligence from Europe will by no means decrease the anxiety of the public with reference to impregnable ships, for coast and harbor defence, especially in view of the favorable report of the Committee appointed by Congress to examine that subject, and in view of the acknowledged success of the English mailed frigate, the Warrior.
lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from Europe will by no means decrease the anxiety of the public with reference to impregnable ships, for coast and harbor defence, especially in view of the favorable report of the Committee appointed by Congress to examine that subject, and in view of the acknowledged success of the English mailed frigate, the Warrior. We are spending many millions for vessels-of-war, and the people are beginning to throw aside old notions and prejudices, to admit that great progress has been made in the art of constructing shot-proof structures, and to inquire very seriously into the propriety of keeping behind the naval knowledge and naval practice of European Powers, in view of possible complications with them.

abstract: -The World objectsto our poking fun at Brother BENNETT concerning his Munchausenisms about the circulation of his Herald. The World considers it exceedingly undignified. That is a new idea. We regret the World did not mention it sooner. We might possibly have refrained from wounding its dignified and delicate sensibilities, if we had known in advance how dignified and delicate they were. We will bear the thing in mind hereafter, and will poke no more fun at the Herald, without stopping first to consider what the World will think of it. We don't care much for Mrs. Grundy's opinion, but the World's is another thing altogether, in everything except sex. The World, by the way, declares it can see no wit in our little performance. Well, who supposed it would? They had the same difficulty in the Express office and in the other Idiot Asylum at Syracuse.

abstract: By the screw-steamer Hansa, which arrived here yesterday morning, we have the first report of British opinion on the MASON and SLIDELL capture. The first news of the affair received in England was by the British West India mail steamer La Plata; and the account seems to have been tolerably fair, excepting a few exaggerated details thrown in for effect.
lead_paragraph: By the screw-steamer Hansa, which arrived here yesterday morning, we have the first report of British opinion on the MASON and SLIDELL capture. The first news of the affair received in England was by the British West India mail steamer La Plata; and the account seems to have been tolerably fair, excepting a few exaggerated details thrown in for effect. It produced considerable excitement in London, Liverpool and elsewhere; though not as much as had been anticipated by some people here. The Times discusses the legal rights and precedents in the case, but says that it requires a strong effort of self-restraint to do so. It says that the legal course; for the American naval officer would have been to take the Trent into port, and have the case adjudicated in a Court of Admiralty. It hopes that the British people will not meet this provocation with an outburst of passion, or rush to resentment without full consideration of all the bearings of the case. The Star says that the opinion of the law officers of the Crown had been taken on the subject, and that it is in favor of the right assumed by the United States Government. It urges coolness and temperance, and trusts in American justice. The purser of the Trent publishes a statement of the case which is somewhat mendacious and dramatic. The dispatches of MASON and SLIDELL, which escaped the vigilance of Capt. WILKES, had been received in London by the La Plata. The Times' City Article gives a high coloring to the British excitement, and says that English funds fell one per cent., from which there was afterward a rally of a half per cent., while at Lloyd's war risks of five guineas were demanded on vessels from New-York.
