abstract: In the Senate, after the usual presentation of petitions and memorials, Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, offered a resolution, which was agreed to, that the Naval Committee be instructed to inquire into the expediency of appointing pupils in the Naval Academy, according to merit. A bill, introduced by Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, authorizing the President to fill up the corps of Cadets at West Point, was referred to the Military Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, after the usual presentation of petitions and memorials, Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, offered a resolution, which was agreed to, that the Naval Committee be instructed to inquire into the expediency of appointing pupils in the Naval Academy, according to merit. A bill, introduced by Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, authorizing the President to fill up the corps of Cadets at West Point, was referred to the Military Committee. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, offered a resolution,which was adopted, directing the Inspector-General, the Quartermaster-General and the Commissary-General to inform the Sen. ate what articles ought to be sold by the sutlers to volunteers, and such as best would secure their efficiency. The Eouse resolution in reference to Gen. LYON was referred to the Military Committee, and the joint resolution in regard to the exchange of prisoners look the same direction. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, offered his resolution that the Military Committee be instructed to inquire into the expediency of appointing a Committee of both Houses to retire, improper officers from the army. A substitute was adopted, which directs the Military Committee to inquire into the expediency of providing a more efficient mode of retiring officers. Senator FOOT's resolution for the expulsion of JOHNSON, of Missouri, was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The bill to promote the efficiency of the navy, providing for the retirement of officers, for promotions, and for rewarding gallantry, was taken up and passed; also the bill relative to courts-martial in the army. After an Executive session the Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: At 11 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the confectionary store occupied by EDWARD SMITH, at No. 154 Greenwich-street. The stock was damaged to the extent of $200. abstract: Extensive preparations have been going on for some time at the various ship-yards and iron-works in this City, in altering, repairing and fitting out vessels which are to form a part of Gen. BURNSIDE'S Expedition. These vessels consist of steamers, barks, schooners, ferry-boats and barges, many of which are finished, and are now receiving their stores and ammunition.
lead_paragraph: Extensive preparations have been going on for some time at the various ship-yards and iron-works in this City, in altering, repairing and fitting out vessels which are to form a part of Gen. BURNSIDE'S Expedition. These vessels consist of steamers, barks, schooners, ferry-boats and barges, many of which are finished, and are now receiving their stores and ammunition. A large number of rifled and smooth-bore cannon, of heavy calibre, will be used in this expedition. Thus far, about fifty vessels have been attached to the fleet, and others are to be added. It is expected that the expedition will leave this port in a few days. It will proceed to Fortress Monroe and there be reinforced.

abstract: MR. HANLON'S GREAT GYMNASTIC FEAT. In the absence of opera the one thing which the arts have to regret this winter it is not unreasonable that the stockholders of the Academy of Music should lease their handsome edifice for some other species of performance requiring lineal space and a vast auditorium.
lead_paragraph: MR. HANLON'S GREAT GYMNASTIC FEAT. -- In the absence of opera -- the one thing which the arts have to regret this winter -- it is not unreasonable that the stockholders of the Academy of Music should lease their handsome edifice for some other species of performance requiring lineal space and a vast auditorium. Taxes must be paid even if the arts do languish. Theoretically, one would prefer that such a building, so filled with pleasant associations and exquisite memories, should come down easily, and not as it were flop to the physical after having been devoted almost exclusively to the intellectual. But in times of war these little matters cannot be arranged with nicety, and so the leaping business, inaugurated by Sappho as a matter of love, comes to be perpetuated by Mr. WILLIAM HANLON in a purely bread-and-butter and commercial point of view.

abstract: -Dr. FISHER, whose lecture on Gunpowder, Cannon and Projectiles, was recently delivered. In New-Haven, upon the invitation of the President and Professors of Yale College, and excited great attention, has consented to repeat the same at the Cooper Institute this evening, for the benefit of the fund of the Sanitary Commission. The whole subject of guns, rifled cannon, howitzers, mortars, and their projectiles of shells, &c, will be demonstrated by the aid of chemical experiments, large models, and diagrams.

abstract: By virtue of a written order from Superintendent KENNEDY, Sergeants WILSON and WADE, of the Eighth Precinct Police, made a descent upon a gambling house, on Wednesday night. The establishment is situated on the northeast corner of Spring and Mercer streets, and was kept by a man named WILLIAM ALLEN, but more generally known by the name of "Butt Allen."
lead_paragraph: By virtue of a written order from Superintendent KENNEDY, Sergeants WILSON and WADE, of the Eighth Precinct Police, made a descent upon a gambling house, on Wednesday night. The establishment is situated on the northeast corner of Spring and Mercer streets, and was kept by a man named WILLIAM ALLEN, but more generally known by the name of "Butt Allen." The arrest was made in consequence of a complaint by JOHN HINGHAM, of No. 130 Greene-street, in the city of Albany, who, about a week since, entered Mr. ALLEN's gambling saloon, and engaged in the game of "faro." He played about two hours; at the end of which time he had lost the sum of $510. The next day he returned, and with a view of winning back the money which he had lost the evening before, he again engaged in the play. He lost about $13 upon this occasion. He then went before a Police Justice and made an affidavit, setting forth the particulars of his loss, and signed his name JOHN HINES, NO. 130 Greene-street, Albany. The Police authorities thereupon investigated the case, and became satisfied that the house in question was one of those which should be broken up. They, therefore, sent word to Mr. HINES to come to New-York, and give his testimony in the case. In the meantime the officers entered the house, an above stated; arrested WM. ALLEN, the proprietor, and RICHARD WOLF, an employe, whose business it was to deal the cards and take the money in the establishment. The officers also took possession of, and conveyed to Police Headquarters, all the furniture, tools and implements found in the house, consisting of faro tables, cue boards, dealing boxes, card racks, chess boards, lay-outs, &c. amounting in value to over $1,000. When the Albany gentleman arrived here yesterday, he stated that his name was not "Hines," but HINGHAM, and that thereason of his giving it as Hines was because he did not wish to have his friends know how he had been swindled. Mr. HINGHAM made an affidavit before Justice QUACKENBUSH, upon which the accused parties were held to bail in the sum of $500 each. Mr. HINGHAM, the complainant, not being able to give ball, was sent to the House of Detention.

abstract: By way of Washington, we have a important information from Tybee Island and vicinity which has not been furnished by any direct arrival at this port. On the 5th inst., before daylight, Commander RODGERS left Tybee Roads with three gunboats, and proceeded to Warsaw Island, the fort upon which was found to be entirely deserted.
lead_paragraph: By way of Washington, we have a important information from Tybee Island and vicinity which has not been furnished by any direct arrival at this port. On the 5th inst., before daylight, Commander RODGERS left Tybee Roads with three gunboats, and proceeded to Warsaw Island, the fort upon which was found to be entirely deserted. It consisted of an inclosed octagonal work, with platforms for eight guns on the water laces. The guns had been removed, and the magazine blown up. Another battery, however, still in possession of the rebels, was discovered about three miles up on the Wilmington River, (a creek,) which runs parallel with the Savannah River, leading up from the rear of Little Tybee. The highest point to which Commander RODGERS penetrated, was eight miles from Warsaw Bar and ten miles from Savannah. This reconnaissance was probably preliminary to the investment of Fort Pulaski in the rear.

abstract: It is affirmed that the Government will at last yield to the pressure brought to bear against it by public opinion and advice of Gen. MCCLELLAN,and will make proposals for the exchange of prisoners. Without imputing to the North or South any inhumanity, it must be said, if what I am told and read be true, theprisoners are not well treated on either side. The Rev. Dr. BELLOWS, of the Sanitary Commission -- a man not likely to use strong words in reference to the conduct of the war on the Union side -- in a report to Government on the condition of the prisoners he visited in the New-York prisons, declares that "it was very trying, almost inhuman;" but it must be added, in justice, that he proceeds to state the wants and privations to which they were exposed, and which were disgraceful to the State, had been relieved, and that they had nothing to complain of except severe diseased and sickness. However, they had been for some weeks in that state of suffering before he saw them, and political prisoners who are not in the possession of funds have full reason to lament their hard fate. A Mr. MAURY, and Englishman, brother of the young gentleman who was arrested the other day for carrying correspondence directed to persons in the South, was seized in the State Department the day before yesterday, as he was inquiring after a portmanteau which had been detained at Cleveland, but for the release of which he had received the order of the Secretary of State, and he was placed in a room, as I am informed, without a table, fuel, or even a bed, where he passed the night, having been refused permission to communicate with his friends, or any explanation of the grounds of his arrest.

abstract: Letters from Gonaives to November 13, state that an insurrection there against the Government had been suppressed. All other parts of the Island are quiet. An unusually large portion of the coffee crop was going to Europe. From St. Domingo we learn that the inhabitants remained quiet under the Spanish rule.

abstract: CHARLES W. JEWELLwas last evening robbed of his watch on the corner of Hudson and Laight streets. The robber was a woman named MARGARET NICHOLS. She asked Mr. JEWELL what time it was, and he pulled out his watch to inform her, when she suddenly caught hold of it and ran. He immediately gave the alarm, and Officer STEVENSON soon after arrested her, but she had passed the watch to a confederate. Justice BRENNAN committed her to the Tombs.

abstract: Eugene Sullivan vs. James Fannin and others. -- In June, 1858, James Fannin entered into a contract, as appeared on this trial, with the executors of the late Anson G. Phelps, whereby the executors agreed to convey to James Fannin, or to such other responsible persons as he might designate, eight lots of land on the northerly side of Thirty-third-street, between Second and Third avenues, for the sum of $16,450, and to loan and advance by instalments, at times agreed on, $20,350 for the purpose of building eight dwelling-houses on the lots, Fannin agreeing to purchase the lots and erect the houses, and upon receiving the deeds of conveyance, to give eight bonds and mortgages upon the lots, covering in all the sum of $36,000.

abstract: GOVERNMENT DISPATCHES FROM FORT PICKENS. The Government has received dispatches from  Fort Pickens, stating that Gen. BROWN had silenced Fort McRae, destroyed the Navy-yard, and burned the town of Warrenton, and that the bombardment was a complete success. Our loss in the engagement was one man killed and five wounded.

abstract: At last the destination of the Federal fleet is known. On the 7th of the present month it entered Port Royal harbor, in South Carolina, engaged the forts, and, after a fight which lasted four hour, forced the enemy to abandon them. The next day the troop's, to the number of 15,000, were landed at Beaufort' which, we are told, they found totally destroyed, together with the neighboring plantations.
lead_paragraph: At last the destination of the Federal fleet is known. On the 7th of the present month it entered Port Royal harbor, in South Carolina, engaged the forts, and, after a fight which lasted four hour, forced the enemy to abandon them. The next day the troop's, to the number of 15,000, were landed at Beaufort' which, we are told, they found totally destroyed, together with the neighboring plantations. As we now know the point against which the Federal operations are directed, and have learnt their first success, there will be necessarily much speculation as to this subsidiary campaign, and the designs of the Government in sending an army to the coast of the Atlantic cotton States. In the first place, we must do justice to the energy of the Federal Government. Whatever may be the plans of its military men, and whatever may be the result of the expedition, it must be said that the fleet was well fitted out and skillfully handled. Even with the command of the sea, it is not an easy thing to land a large force on an enemy's ground, on a coast very dangerous at all times, and now deprived of every guide to the seaman in the shape of lighthouses or buoys. But, in spite of a succession of very heavy gales, and in spite of the resistance of the Confederates, who seem to have been not unprepared for a visit, the Federals have established themselves on another spot of Southern ground, and have a base from which to carry on any future operations which they may think advisable. The first more has been a success. Beyond the loss of two, or perhaps four vessels, in the storm, the Northern forces have met with no disaster, and they have now avenged the fall of Sumter, by hauling down a rebel flag on the soil of the most rebellious State.

abstract: The effect of the MASON and SLIDELL affair on England receives the fullest illustration in the extracts which will be found in this morning's issue. lead_paragraph: The effect of the MASON and SLIDELL affair on England receives the fullest illustration in the extracts which will be found in this morning's issue. If dilletantism were not barred on so grave a theme, it would be interesting to look oil the news simply as a study of "effects" on a large scale. When, a month ago, Capt. WILKES performed the public service of seizing the persons of the rebel envoys on board the British steamer, the feeling which immediately followed that of perfect satisfaction at the act was: "How will England take it?" To be sure we had the gratification to know that we had the law on our side, and were rectus in curia: but who does not know that, in such matters, human nature is governed not so much by the principles of pure reason as by local sentiments and patriotic prejudices? It was impossible to say how these would show themselves in this case, and this very element of uncertainty exercised the same effect on the public mind as skillfully managed suspense does in the hands of the dramatist. One followed, in anticipation, the steamer that conveyed the intelligence to England as a chemist might watch the working of a new and hazardous experiment. It bore to Britain what might act as an electric spark to touch the clouds of prejudice and passion, and evoke thence the thunders of a nation's wrath.

lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning, Nov. 24, a building of seven stories, in High-street, Edinburgh, suddenly fell, burying nearly the whole of the inmates in the ruins. The house was several centuries old; the whole gave way at once, collapsing inwards; 22 bodies have been taken out dead, and about 12 injured. The immense block of building was densely populated, and it is estimated that not less than 100 people must have dwelt in it.

abstract: We have at last got the truth about the affair which opened at Fort Pickens three weeks ago to-day, concerning which the rebels in the meantime, have so awfully bamboozled us.
lead_paragraph: We have at last got the truth about the affair which opened at Fort Pickens three weeks ago to-day, concerning which the rebels in the meantime, have so awfully bamboozled us. It now appears, as we suspected it would appear, that BRAGG never breached the Fort, never captured it -- never stormed it, engaging BROWN in front and attacking him in the rear -- all of which things we were told he had done; and that if, as the Pensacola Observer thought, BROWN and all his Yankees were drunk, they were at least sober enough to chastise pretty effectually the rebel braggarts and stun them into silence.
headline: {'main': 'The Truth About Fort Pickens', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Truth About Fort Pickens', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Claims are one thing, and rights another. A man may claim your house, land, wife, servant or horse without the slightest right to them. Shylock's bond was a legal claim, but its fulfillment proved a violation of the higher aw of humanity as well as that of the State of Venice.
lead_paragraph: Claims are one thing, and rights another. A man may claim your house, land, wife, servant or horse without the slightest right to them. Shylock's bond was a legal claim, but its fulfillment proved a violation of the higher aw of humanity as well as that of the State of Venice. The European nations about to invade Mexico may have legal claims on that country; but the question whether they have not forfeited all equitable rights therein, and run up a heavy balance against themselves, is well worth examination.

abstract: At a regular meeting of this Board last evening, Alderman CORNELL in the Chair, the ordinance for the relief of families of volunteers, as amended by the Board of Councilmen, was taken up out of the regular order, and several amendments proposed and adopted, after which the ordinance, as it came from the Councilmen, was adopted. abstract: Hon. CALEB CUSHING has written a letter to Mayor WOOD fully sustaining the act of Capt. WILKES in seizing the rebel Ambassadors, SLIDELL and MASON, on board the British steamer Trent. abstract: It will be remembered that, in the early part of last April, Fort Pickens was suddenly discovered to be in imminent danger of capture at the hands of BRAXTON BRAGG and his new army of Confederate warriors.
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that, in the early part of last April, Fort Pickens was suddenly discovered to be in imminent danger of capture at the hands of BRAXTON BRAGG and his new army of Confederate warriors. The National force in that vicinity was divided between Forts Pickens, McRae and Barancas, all three of which places, with their inefficient garrisons, would have fallen an easy prey, in detail to the rebel arms. But one night, Lieut. SLEMMER, Capt. VODGES and the other loyal officers in command, put their heads together, and the next morning BRAGG lifted up his eyes and beheld the two latter strongholds evacuated, their late occupants find most of the stores and moveable artillery they contained having been, between sunset and dawn, cautiously transferred to Pickens, which their concentration made a rather awkward nut to crack. BRAGG foamed in impotent rage. At first, he could not imagine through what source his enemy had been warned in time, and authorized to take so decisive a measure of defence; but the idea suddenly occurred to him that, the previous day, April 11th, he had granted a pass to one Lieut. WORDEN, of the United States Navy, permitting him to go aboard the sloop-of-war St. Louis, there to have communication with Captain ADAMS. Lieut. WORDEN had fulfilled his mission, had returned by way of Pensacola, and was on his journey back to Washington, when this luminous revelation burst on BRAGG's benighted mind. On the instant, BRAGG set the telegraph in motion, and before Lieut. WORDEN reached Montgomery, he found himself in rebel limbo -- the first prisoner of war that had been made on either side since the commencement of hostilities.

abstract: INTERESTING TO THE FRIENDS OF PRISONERS AT RICHMOND. -- Hon. MOSES F. ODELL has succeeded in obtaining from Government the money due the following-named soldiers, now prisoners in the hands of the rebels: Wm. N. Baldwin, Wm. T. Williamson, Herman W. Bristol, Wm. H. Van Home, Henry Holmes, Simon Richardson, Robert Bold, Wm. Darwin, Isaac De Graff, Patrick McManus, Augustus Thiery, Wm. Stewart. The other applications for pay of persons which have been made will be obtained as soon as the papers are corrected.

abstract: The congregation of this Church, who were so unfortunate as to have their church edifice blown down three years ago, just as it approached completion, are now engaged in raising funds for the erection of another, which is in progress on Fifty-fourth-street. For this purpose they are holding a Fair at No. 758 Broadway, where they have conspicuously asserted their loyalty to both Church and State, by exhibiting the Union Jack, festooned in unison with the Stars and Stripes at the entrance. The articles exposed for sale range from a pincushion to a piano-forte; and after the usual collection of those designed for utility, such as bed-quilts, toilet furnishing, luxurious creations in silk and wool crochet, besides plenty of good things to cat.

abstract: A PICKPOCKET CAUGHT. -- WILLIAM SHERMAN was yesterday arrested by Officer MOORE, charged with picking the pocket of DANIEL MARLEY and taking therefrom a gold watch and chain valued at $100. The parties were riding up Broadway in a stage, and the complainant feeling something pulling very strongly at his vest pocket, at once felt for his watch, and found it gone. Just at this moment the prisoner left the stage. MARLEY gave the alarm, and after the culprit had run a short distance he was caught by the officer, who found the stolen watch upon him. Justice QUACKENBUSH committed him for examination.

abstract: The Louisville Journal has rendered the Union cause most noble service by sustaining the Administration in its efforts to suppress rebellion. It seems likely now to do it serious injury by a captions and utterly unreasonable denunciation of the President, on account of what he does not say in his Message concerning Slavery.
lead_paragraph: The Louisville Journal has rendered the Union cause most noble service by sustaining the Administration in its efforts to suppress rebellion. It seems likely now to do it serious injury by a captions and utterly unreasonable denunciation of the President, on account of what he does not say in his Message concerning Slavery. It began by assailing him on thestrength of the spurious report of the Secretary of War, which contained a long paragraph on the employment of slaves in the army, not one word of which was contained in the genuine document. It continues its attack after this imposition has been thoroughly exposed, -- and does all in its power to create distrust of the Administration in the minds of loyal men in the Border States. This course is quite as impolitic for the Journal and its friends, as it is unjust to the President and the country.

abstract: It requires a strong effort of self-restraint to discuss with coolness the intelligence we publish today. An English mail steamer, sailing under the British flag, and carrying letters and passengers from a Spanish port to England, has been stopped on the high seas and overhauled. Four of the passengers have been taken out and carried off as prisoners, claiming, and vainly claiming, as they were being forced away, the protection of the flag of Great Britain. These are the naked facts. We put out of sight the accidents that the four gentlemen thus kidnapped were accredited with a diplomatic mission from the Confederate States of America to the Courts of Europe, and also the peremptory manner in which the Federal frigate acted in making her seizure. The intention of the Federal Government evidently was to act upon their strict right, and to do so in as little ceremonious a manner as might be. If they are justified by their rights as belligerents in what they have done the manner of doing it is a mere question of good or bad taste. If a rude fellow claims his rights coarsely we must yet give him his rights; and if we would not find ourselves in the wrong we must not quarrel with him on account of his ill manners.
lead_paragraph: It requires a strong effort of self-restraint to discuss with coolness the intelligence we publish today. These are the naked facts. We put out of sight the accidents that the four gentlemen thus kidnapped were accredited with a diplomatic mission from the Confederate States of America to the Courts of Europe, and also the peremptory manner in which the Federal frigate acted in making her seizure. The intention of the Federal Government evidently was to act upon their strict right, and to do so in as little ceremonious a manner as might be. If they are justified by their rights as belligerents in what they have done the manner of doing it is a mere question of good or bad taste. abstract: The officers of the Trent and La Plata, from whom the English Press and public received their accounts of the capture of SLIDELL and MASON, accredited emissaries of rebeldom, took pains that the case should lose none of its irritating points, through the non-use of their gifts of aggravation. Even the American reader rises from the perusal of their reports with a vexatious suspicion that the af fair was not managed with that delicacy ...
lead_paragraph: The officers of the Trent and La Plata, from whom the English Press and public received their accounts of the capture of SLIDELL and MASON, accredited emissaries of rebeldom, took pains that the case should lose none of its irritating points, through the non-use of their gifts of aggravation. Even the American reader rises from the perusal of their reports with a vexatious suspicion that the af fair was not managed with that delicacy, which we have been ascribing to it, and that possibly the self-respect of John Bull has been wantonly wounded. Yet nothing could be more unjust. A reexamination of what said "the Purser of the Trent, at sea," and what the officers of the Plata ashore, shows that beyond an unverified and improbable story of Capt. WILKES having, after the seizure, ordered Capt. MOIR, of the Trent, to go aboard the San Jacinto, and lay his vessel closer to that audacious man-of-war, there is no distinct allegation that the right of search was not exercised with the utmost conceivable delicacy. And it is enough to disprove the single charge referred to, that almost in the same breath with which Lieut. FAIRFAX is said to have communicated the arbitrary commands of his superior, that officer is stated by the same report to have authorized Capt. MOIR to proceed upon his voyage -- a liberty he could not have exercised, had he been charged with the preceding but apocryphal instructions.
headline: {'main': 'The Search of the Trent No Outrage.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Search of the Trent No Outrage.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. GORDON GRANT, an esteemed citizen of Troy, died in that city a few days since. He was born in Stonington, Conn., in 1789, and when he went to Troy, fifty-five years ago, was glad to get employment as cook on board a sloop plying between that city and Waterford. Subsequently he became master of a sloop plying to New-York, and gradually worked his way into a large produce and shipping business, by which be accumulated a large fortune. He used his means liberally in advancing the interests of the charitable institutions in Troy.

abstract: A startling report was yesterday received in Washington, brought by a deserter from the rebel army, to the effect that the rebels were advancing against our lines at three points. He stated that 75,000 men had been furnished with rations for four days, and were to move in three columns from Centreville. Heavy detachments of our troops were immediately sent out in the direction of Fairfax, but they returned last evening, and reported that they could discover no unusual movement. Other detachments were sent out, however, and the truth or falsity of the report would be ascertained.

abstract: A brig lately arrived from Rio Janeiro, via St. Thomas, brings a very singular report of the movements of the United States gunboat Iroquois. It will be remembered that the Iroquois was detailed some time since to watch the Sumter, and, if within the bounds of naval possibility, capture her. Previous accounts led us to believe that this consummation, so devoutly to be wished for, would be brought about -- indeed, the probabilities of the capture seemed so strong that it was assumed as having actually occurred. Happy dispatches assured us that the Sumter lay in the harbor of Port Royal, Martinique, while the Iroquois patrolled outside, to catch her immediately if she attempted to escape. The harbor of Port Royal is land-locked, and the entrance a narrow one; there lay the Sumter, seemingly, like the nephew of Gil Perez, "caught like a rat in a trap." There seemed no possibility of her escape without the connivance of the Captain of the Iroquois. This connivance, according to the report brought by the brig referred to, has occurred.
lead_paragraph: A brig lately arrived from Rio Janeiro, via St. Thomas, brings a very singular report of the movements of the United States gunboat Iroquois. Previous accounts led us to believe that this consummation, so devoutly to be wished for, would be brought about -- indeed, the probabilities of the capture seemed so strong that it was assumed as having actually occurred. Happy dispatches assured us that the Sumter lay in the harbor of Port Royal, Martinique, while the Iroquois patrolled outside, to catch her immediately if she attempted to escape. The harbor of Port Royal is land-locked, and the entrance a narrow one; there lay the Sumter, seemingly, like the nephew of Gil Perez, "caught like a rat in a trap." There seemed no possibility of her escape without the connivance of the Captain of the Iroquois. This connivance, according to the report brought by the brig referred to, has occurred.

abstract: A correspondent, writing from Abingdon, Southwestern Virginia, to the Richmond Dispatch, says that the burned bridges in East Tennessee will be repaired in a few weeks; that the Virginia Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Regiments were then in Abingdon, on the way to join Gen. HUMPHREY MARSHALL, in Russell County, Va. The regiment of Col. MOORE, raised just there, were to march with them on the next day. These troops, those at his camp, and those at Pound Gap, were to form a junction, and, with them, obese HUMPHREY was soon to march into Eastern Kentucky, to fire the Kentucky heart. He was to be in supporting distance of ZOLLICOPPER, and was expected "greatly to stiffen" the Confederate cause in that quarter.

abstract: Westerlo vs. Delbitt. -- This case was stated in the TIMES of yesterday. It will be remembered that the question to be determined was whether or not a certain certificate of deposit had been duly delivered to the plaintiff as a bequest, by one Mrs. Clinton, immediately before the death of the latter, and whether, if so delivered, the mere delivery was a sufficient transfer of the certificate to enable the plaintiff to collect in her own name and of her own right.

abstract: Most of our readers will remember the famous Keller troupe, whose beautiful tableaux, in which beautiful women and attractive children were displayed in most voluptuous semi-nudity, were at one time the great attractions in the principal theatres of the United States. Everyone went to see their thrilling "Battle of the Amazons;" and their "Shower of Gold," and "Bower of Flora," were pronounced triumphs of scenic art; and where the religious feeling of the community was not strong, their tableau of the "Crucifixion," in which Mr. KELLER appeared as Christ, met with unbounded applause. Somethinghas just come to light, which, if as true as it appears to be, will create the very general impression the the opposite would have been a far more appropriate character for Mr. KELLER than the one he was so much admired in, and, instead of the joyous bower of Flora, in which the lovely members of his troupe appeared, their real situation had decidedly more of the infernal in its associations. Lights and shadows, we all know, are often in most painful contrast on the stage, the real and mimic lives of those who tread it  are often, all know, painfully different, but revelations of atrocities like those of which we have heard in this case have but seldom to be made.
lead_paragraph: Most of our readers will remember the famous Keller troupe, whose beautiful tableaux, in which beautiful women and attractive children were displayed in most voluptuous semi-nudity, were at one time the great attractions in the principal theatres of the United States. Everyone went to see their thrilling "Battle of the Amazons;" and their "Shower of Gold," and "Bower of Flora," were pronounced triumphs of scenic art; and where the religious feeling of the community was not strong, their tableau of the "Crucifixion," in which Mr. KELLER appeared as Christ, met with unbounded applause. Somethinghas just come to light, which, if as true as it appears to be, will create the very general impression the the opposite would have been a far more appropriate character for Mr. KELLER than the one he was so much admired in, and, instead of the joyous bower of Flora, in which the lovely members of his troupe appeared, their real situation had decidedly more of the infernal in its associations. Lights and shadows, we all know, are often in most painful contrast on the stage, the real and mimic lives of those who tread it are often, all know, painfully different, but revelations of atrocities like those of which we have heard in this case have but seldom to be made.

abstract: The District Attorney has caused a medical examination to be held in the case of THOMAS A. MCGILL. who killed his mother, on Sunday last, by throwing her out of the fifth-story window of a house in  the First-avenue. The medical gentlemen appointed to perform this duty were Dr. MOSES H. RANNEY and Dr. BENJAMIN OGDEN. They made their report yesterday to Mr. WATERBURY, the District Attorney. They state that MCGILL is at present insane -- in fact, a maniac of the most dangerous description. That from his statements and appearance they conclude that his insanity is either mania recurrens -- a form in which the paroxysms of violence and lucid intervals again and again succeed each other -- or an attack of acute mania, or the result of a debauch. A knowledge of his previous history would afford the means of determining the precise form. They further say that the public safety seems to require some form of legal action to prevent his immediate discharge from an asylum. If placed in an asylum under an ordinary commitment for insanity, he would, at anytime, be discharged at the request of his friends. If the form of insanity be paroxysmal, whenever a lucid interval occurred, it would be the duty of the Superintendent to discharge him, even if no application were made. On the patients of an ordinary asylum, the reception of a homicide produces an injurious effect, and the rooms of such a building are not properly constructed for the safekeeping of such a patient. Acting on these facts, they say the State should make special provisions for the detention of criminal lunatics.

On the patients of an ordinary asylum, the reception of a homicide produces an injurious effect, and the rooms of such a building are not properly constructed for the safekeeping of such a patient. Acting on these facts, they say the State should make special provisions for the detention of criminal lunatics.

abstract: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning Capt. PETER MILLER was attacked in Fourteenth-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, by three young men, named JAMES WOOD, JOHN FERGUSON and EDWARD SCRIVEN. He was knocked down, and very severely beaten about the head and face. His lower jaw was terribly lacerated, and he was otherwise wounded to such an extent as to render him unable to leave his bed. The injuries, however, are not believed to be of a dangerous character. After the ruffians had beaten him until he was helpless, they proceeded to rifle his pockets. They took a gold hunting-casewatch, valued at $100, also his pocket-book The latter contained very little money, but was filled with valuable papers, such as promissory notes, manifests, &c. As soon as the Captain was able to walk, after the thieves had left him, he made his way to Mr. GILLESPIE's saloon, on the corner of Tenth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. The blood wasstreaming from his face and head, his clothes were torn and covered with blood. Mr. GILLESPIE did what he could for his relief. The wounded man related the story of his being waylaid and robbed, and described he parties as well as he could to Mr. G., who immediately said that he knew them -- that they had been into his place that evening. He proposed to Capt. MILLER to set out at once in pursuit of them, which he accordingly did. They were known to frequent a place in the vicinity of Eighth-avenue and Twenty-fifth-street, and when Mr. G. arrived there, he spied the three men standing on the corner.

abstract: One of the boats of the great naval river expedition, now nearly ready at Cairo, has a flag-staff erected on its upper deck, from the top of which floats the American flag, while on the bottom is nailed a sign, "For Memphis and New-Orleans." The impression generally prevails in our Western Army, as well as among the river rebels, that the grand flotilla will shortly cut its moorings at Cairo, and start on this perilous voyage down the Mississippi among the innumerable river batteries and river rebels -- flanked on the land sides by fifty or a hundred thousand Union soldiers. Whether the belief is correct that it wil certainly go down the Mississippi, in preference to any of the other streams in the vicinity, a short time now will tell. But the fact that we have a choice of navigable rivers near by, which penetrate into the very heart of the South, may well keep the rebels in a terrible state of perturbation as to where the blow will be struck. For fear it should start down the Mississippi one of these fine Winter mornings, however, we give a map of the course and windings of that river, from Cairo to Memphis, indicating also the towns, forts, and other natural and artificial points of defence between these two plates.

abstract: The position of affairs in Northeastern Kentucky, on the line to Cumberland Gap, is as follows: The two East Tennessee regiments remain at Camp Calvert, near London, just where they halted when the pursuit of ZOLLICOFFER was abandoned. ZOLLICOFFER has come back into the State, but by another road, taking the turnpike through Whitely and Wayne counties to the north bank of Cumberland River, below Somerset. This place, the present headquarters of Gen. SCHOEPF's command, is about thirty miles east of London. ZOLLICOFFER has all the way from 9,000 to 12,000 troops. He was evidently heading for Bowling Green when the advance of our troops threatened his rear. Gen. SCHOEPF has now, at Somerset, (or had at last accounts,) the following troops, with more, probably, to come.

abstract: The Commercial says; "We had, yesterday, a very interesting interview with two Union refugees from Louisiana, who succeeded in making their way from New-Orleans to Nashville, through the rebel lines, to the Ohio River. They confirm the report of the utter stugnation of business in New-Orleans, and constant apprehensions of attack, and scarcity of all the necessaries of life. All men between the ages of eighteen and forty five were being impressed into service.

abstract: The Richmond Examiner says: "An almost general stampede of slaves on the Eastern Shore is said to have taken place, in consequence of the enemy's invasion into Accomac and Northampton. It is estimated that there are about 10,000 slaves in these two counties -- out-numbering, as they do, the whites in Northampton -- and this large amount of property is, of course, at the entire mercy of the enemy. The slaves are escaping from their masters with the permission and connivance of the enemy, who have made no attempts whatever to arrest or check their exodus to Delaware and other portions of the hospitable North."

abstract: The Government has recently caused to be erected, at East New-York, barracks for the accommodation of troops preparing for active service in the field, and they were duly inaugurated on Thursday night by the contractors, Messrs. KNIFFEN & WALKER and the officers of the Ninetieth Regiment, by a grand ball, which passed off very pleasantly. These barracks are built of wood, in the form of a hollow square, inclosing about two acres of ground. On one front of the square are the apartments of the field and staff officers, on the next the Quartermaster has his department, and also the officers of the line, and the remainder of the barracks is arranged for the accommodation of the rank and file. The Ninetieth Regiment, which is now occupying these barracks, is under orders to proceed to Washington on Monday next, stopping on the way at the City Hall to receive a stand of colors ordered for them by the City Government. Annexed is a full list of officers connected with the Ninetieth Regiment (McClellan Chasseurs) New-York State Volunteers:

abstract: A bill has been passed authorizing the State to assume the war tax authorized by the Confederate Congress. Other important measures of finance, relief, etc., reported in a series of bills a few days since, are also being considered. The bill "to reduce the salaries, pay and perquisites of office of the several civil officers of this State, during the continuance of the war," is also being considered. It provides that "the annual salary of all persons holding office under the authority of this State, the pay and universe of members of the General Assembly, and the fees and perquisites of all persons holding office under the authority of this State, whose fees may may be fixed by any law of the State, shall be reduced twenty-five percent, on the amount thereof as now fixed by law." Its passage is considered doubtful.
lead_paragraph: A bill has been passed authorizing the State to assume the war tax authorized by the Confederate Congress. abstract: Among our Washington dispatches this morning will be found two orders, issued by Gen. WOOL, at Fortress Monroe, some weeks since, which touch precisely the most important question with which we have to deal in regard to Slavery. Gen. WOOL found some thousands of negroes collected about his camp, -- some of them abandoned by their masters, others fugitives from them, -- all practically enfranchised by the simple presence of a Union army in their neighborhood, -- all destitute, without employment or relations of any kind to society and the State.
lead_paragraph: Among our Washington dispatches this morning will be found two orders, issued by Gen. WOOL, at Fortress Monroe, some weeks since, which touch precisely the most important question with which we have to deal in regard to Slavery. Gen. WOOL found some thousands of negroes collected about his camp, -- some of them abandoned by their masters, others fugitives from them, -- all practically enfranchised by the simple presence of a Union army in their neighborhood, -- all destitute, without employment or relations of any kind to society and the State.

abstract: The inquest on the body of a man whose name is supposed to be BENJAMIN J. BURTON, who was found lying insensible on the pier foot of Morris-street, Jersey City, and died two days afterwards at the Almshouse hospital, was held yesterday by Coroner GAFFNEY. The Coroner had previously telegraphed to some relatives of deceased at Trenton to know what disposition he should make of the body, and received a reply from two nieces that he would have to do what he thought best, as deceased had no claims upon them. The jury rendered a verdict of death from disease of the heart and exposure.
lead_paragraph: The inquest on the body of a man whose name is supposed to be BENJAMIN J. abstract: ARREST OF A NOTORIOUS COUNTERFEITER. -- HENRY COLE, alias JOHNSON, was arrested yesterday afternoon upon the charge of counterfeiting. In August last, the accused and three other men -- all of whom are connected with a gang of counterfeiters, who for months have been prowling throughout the country -- visited Albany, and there presented a large number of $5 and $10 bills to the Albany banks. They purported to be genuine issues of the Prescott Bank, at Lowell, Mass. So well executed were they that the banks took them without hesitation, and paid gold in exchange. Very soon, however, the billswere ascertained to be bogus. No clue could be obtained until yesterday, as to the whereabouts of the guilty parties. COLE was arrested by Detective SLOWEY, in Grand-street. One hundred and sixty dollars in gold were found upon the prisoner. He was taken to Police Headquarters, and there detained for a short time. He immediately employed Ex-Judge STEWART, who obtained a writ of habeas corpus, upon which he was taken before Judge MCCUNN, at the City Hall, late in the afternoon. Here, however, he was met by Deputy-Sheriff GRATTAN, of Albany, who exhibited a warrant directing him to take and convey the prisoner to Albany for trial. The accused was therefore handed over to the Albany officer, who left town last evening with the accused.

abstract: A dispatch from Louisville last night informs us that Gen. BUELL's army (which, on the direct Louisville and Nashville line, is not less than sixty thousand strong) is moving forward to Green River. The remarkable quietude of this army for so long a period renders this movement more significant. That a general advance is in progresses is further indicated by the marching from Louisville, on Monday, of the Second, Thirty-first, Twenty-fourth, Sixth, Ninth, Tenth, Twenty-first and Thirty-third Ohio regiments' Gen. MCCLELLAN's plan is well understood to be that a simultaneous advance shall take place -- on the Mississippi, against Columbus, Ky.; in Central Kentucky, upon Bowling Green; from Romney, upon Winchester; from the Potomac, into Eastern Virginia; from Fortress Monroe, upon Yorktown or Norfolk; and that Butler's, Burnside's and Sherman's coast expeditions shall make demonstrations at the same time. If this be the case -- and we do not profess to have either official or semi-official information -- movements at all important points may be expected when one takes place; and the forward movement in Kentucky is the signal of a general advance.

abstract: The ruin which Charleston has invoked upon the country seems now to have overtaken herself. It is impossible to form an accurate idea of the origin or limits of the conflagration, from the dispatches which have reached us up to this morning. The telegraph is evidently unacquainted with the topography of Charleston; it mixes up buildings and...
lead_paragraph: The ruin which Charleston has invoked upon the country seems now to have overtaken herself. It is impossible to form an accurate idea of the origin or limits of the conflagration, from the dispatches which have reached us up to this morning. The telegraph is evidently unacquainted with the topography of Charleston; it mixes up buildings and streets, and locates edifices in quarters which, at all events up to secession times, they did not occupy. But the different buildings mentioned as being burnt, indicate a fire terrible and of great extent, including in its sweep nearly all the principal public edifices and the main part of the business section of the city. If what seems to be involved in the telegrams be true, that the line of flame stretched from the eastern end of Broad-street well across to the western lines of the city, and from thence swept northward up King and other parallel streets, as high as and beyond the old theatre, those who know the city will see how completely Old Charleston has been gutted. The latest dispatch -- up to Thursday night -- says that the fire was still raging, and that it had then crossed Broadstreet, and was sweeping furiously on. If that means that it had leapt to the south side of that street, and if it runs from thence across the few streets, down to the battery, Charleston may as well be blotted from the map of America, and the salt be sown on the spot upon which it stood.

abstract: -- It is said that Dr. Hagadorn owes his release as a prisoner from Richmond to a Northern Woman Mrs. Ogden, of Bath, Steuben County. Her husband was a classmate of Jeff. Davis, and the latter was indebted to her for relief, and attentions during a dangerous illness. So soon as she learned of Dr. Hagadorn's imprisonment, she wrote a letter to Jeff. Davis, requesting his release, which was promptly complied with. Of course the Doctor feels grateful to a lady to whom he is indebted for release from a long and cruel confinement.

abstract: By a gentleman who left Sedalia yesterday, we learn that PRICE had moved from Osccola to a point five miles distant, with a portion of his force, and made that place his headquarters. RAINS remained at Osceola, and was in command of that place. On Monday last a train of fifty wagons passed from Lexington, between Warrensburgh and Sedalia, to PRICE'S army. They were laden with supplies, and encountered no molestation.

abstract: The work on the various vessels that are to comprise, in part, Gen. BURNSIDE's Expedition, is progressing with great rapidity. Within a few days four vessels have been put into commission at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and will probably form a portion of the fleet. They are the gunboat Winona, carrying two thirty-two pounders, one eleven-inch culumbiad, and one rifled Parrott gun; the gunboat Chippewa, mounting the same armament as the Winona; the steamer Quaker City, with eight thirty-two pounders and one rifled Parrott gun; and the schooner Hope, which will be used as a dispatch boat. Several gunboats have recently sailed from this port for Annapolis, and others are lying in the stream awaiting orders.
lead_paragraph: The work on the various vessels that are to comprise, in part, Gen. BURNSIDE's Expedition, is progressing with great rapidity. abstract: MAKING CHEESE. The process of making cheese in Hermiker County, New-York, is admirable for its simplicity and dispatch, as compared with that practiced in Cheshire and other districts in England. The night's milk is placed in the cheese-vat, and kept as cool as possible. After the morning's milk is added, the whole is raised to the proper temperature either by heating...
lead_paragraph: MAKING CHEESE. -- The process of making cheese in Hermiker County, New-York, is admirable for its simplicity and dispatch, as compared with that practiced in Cheshire and other districts in England. The night's milk is placed in the cheese-vat, and kept as cool as possible. After the morning's milk is added, the whole is raised to the proper temperature -- either by heating a portion of the morning's milk, or, what is better, by applying steam to the bottom of the tin milk-vat. Sufficient rennet is then added to set the cheese in about forty minutes. When the cheese is set, the coagulated curd is cut into small pieces with a long four-bladed steel knife, which crushes the curd much less than the old-fashioned breakers, and is thus not so liable to press out the butter. The curd is then "scalded ed." This is done either by beating a portion of the whey, (which should not be heated to the boiling point,) and pouring it into the vat till the whole is raised to the desired temperature; or, when steam can be applied to the vat, it is heated in this way. The temperature varies somewhat in different dairies, from 102 to 108 degrees. After the scalding, the curd is allowed to stand in the heated whey about forty minutes, and the whey and curd is then poured on to a cloth placed on a shallow wooden vessel, with a hole in the bottom, which allows the strained whey to run off. The curd is then broken up fine and salted to suit the taste -- say a teacupful to each ten or twelve cows. The curd is then placed in the vat and put under the press, where it remains till the next morning. Those acquainted with the English method of making cheese will see in what respect the two processes differ. The method so imperfectly and inadequately described above, is not half as much labor as the Cheshire or Gloucestershire process. The method of heating the milk by the application of steam to the cheese-vat is a great improvement. Then the method of separating the curd from the whey by straining it through a cloth is much more expeditious. In Cheshire the whey is removed by pressing down a flat-bottomed pan gently on the curd in the cheese-tub, and allowing it to fill. When the curd is thus partially freed from the whey, the curd is again gently broken and allowed to settle and separate, and the whey ia baled out slowly, the curd being placed on one side of the tub, which is slightly raised, and a board is placed on the curd, with heavy weights on top to press out the whey. The curd is then cu. into pieces six or eight inches square, and again pressed with heavier weights.

abstract: The precedents to which the London Times makes an indirect allusion when it says that Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, could not be arrested because they were not officers of the army or navy, are very likely drawn ultimately from certain clauses contained in treaties...
lead_paragraph: The precedents to which the London Times makes an indirect allusion when it says that Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, could not be arrested because they were not officers of the army or navy, are very likely drawn ultimately from certain clauses contained in treaties between European nations, of which the treaty of Utrecht furnishes the most complete exemplar. It is said in this document that all men engaged in the army or navy (hommes de guerre) are contraband of war, and can be arrested. This doctrine, though disregarded by England in her war with France, was supported by the majority of writers on international rights during the last century. But modern publicists have improved upon it. They do not limit the right of seizure to military men alone, but apply it to all men engaged in the service of the enemy. Thus, D'HAUTEFEUILLE, an extreme advocate of the rights of neutrals, says on this subject, that by military men, we must not understand officers, soldiers and recruits alone, but all men who have contracted with the belligerent the engagement of serving it during the war. When such men as these are found on board of neutrals, the belligerent has an uncontrovertible right to look upon them as enemies perpetrating acts of hostility, and to treat them as such. According to this writer's opinion, the name homme de guerre does not apply simply to the profession of the man, but to the nature and character of his services. Accordingly, a minister of the Gospel, a lawyer, a merchant, may be as much an object of contraband of war as an admiral, or a general -- an opinion which leaves no doubt upon the arrest of Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL. The Times is then in fault when it professes not to know of any authority which will show them to be contraband of war. Aware as that paper is of the character of these gentlemen and of the nature of their mission, it might have declared their arrest justified as well on the ground of English precedents and "antiquated law," as on the ground of the opinions enunciated by living publicists and writers.

abstract: Gen. H. HENRY BAXTER, of Rutland, Vermont, aid to Gov. HOLBROOK, of that State, is at the Astor House, having come to this City to commission Col. FRANK E. HOWE as Military Agent for Vermont, and to arrange with the latter for the transportation of the First Cavalry Regiment, Col. L.B. PLATT, through this City, on its way to Washington. This regiment will reach here early this morning, in 141 cars, with their horses, equipments, tents and full camp equipage. They will land at the Thirty-first-street Railroad station, and will quarter in that vicinity till to-morrow to rest the horses. To-morrow morning the regiment will march down Broadway, and embark for Washington. The personnel of this regiment is unsurpassed by any in the service, being wholly composed of property-holders, bona fide patriots of the Green Mountain State. Their equipments are of a superior order, and everything pertaining to the regiment is of the best material. The horses are of the celebrated Morgan stock, sleek, well-cared for, know their masters, and are excellently well-drilled. The regiment numbers 1,030 men, and over 1,100 horses. It requires seven tons of hay and 400 bushels of oats to feed the horses of this regiment daily. Gov. HOLBROOK arrived here yesterday to attend the embarkation of the regiment, and many of the Sons of Verment will form a cavalcade to-morrow morning to escort their brothers-in-arms through the City. The parade of this regiment will make a brilliant and imposing display.

abstract: The "Vesper service," introduced into the Unitarian Church, by Rev. SAMUEL LONGFELLOW, in 1858, while pastor of the Second Unitarian Church of Brooklyn, seems destined to win wide favor. It was some time since adopted by several of the leading churches of that faith in New-England, and has recently been introduced into Rev. Dr. OSGOOD'S Church,...
lead_paragraph: The "Vesper service," introduced into the Unitarian Church, by Rev. SAMUEL LONGFELLOW, in 1858, while pastor of the Second Unitarian Church of Brooklyn, seems destined to win wide favor. It was some time since adopted by several of the leading churches of that faith in New-England, and has recently been introduced into Rev. Dr. OSGOOD's Church, of this City; Dr. FARLEY's, of Brooklyn; Dr. ELLIOTT's, of St. Louis; at Alton and Quincy, Illinois, and is welcomed with great heartiness by the Unitarians of old England. The new church at Yonkers, in this State, have also just adopted it. A recent correspondent of the Christian Register says "It seems to most of its friends the most impressive of all orders of worship, and what is remarkable, it interests persons of the most opposite creeds and tempers, from the High Churchman to the Methodist, from the Presbyterian to the Transcendentalists. Yet it is a very simple matter, and all its materials are to be found in the Bible and the Hymn Book. "It has filled the churches to overflowing wherever it has been adopted, and the interest in it continues unabated. Mr. LONGFELLOW's health having failed about a year and a half since, he resigned his charge, which the church very reluctantly granted, as the congregation were much attached to him. He went immediately to Europe, where he still is, and will spend the Winter at Berlin. The church have recently settled Rev. Mr. STAPLES under the most favorable auspices, as his successor 'who bears a remarkable personal resemblance to Mr.' LONGFELLOW, and possesses many of his characteristics in manner and spirit.
headline: {'main': "Longfellow's Vespers.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Longfellow's Vespers.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: MR. PRESIDENT: Several years ago, in my own home, one of the most brilliant tributes to the talented dead I ever heard, fell from the lips of him whose memory we to-day unite to honor. After a feeling review of the eloquence and genial nature of the gifted FERGUSON, Col. BAKER suddenly paused, and with a sadness of tone that was a fitting echo to the thought,...
lead_paragraph: MR. PRESIDENT: Several years ago, in my own home, one of the most brilliant tributes to the talented dead I ever heard, fell from the lips of him whose memory we to-day unite to honor. After a feeling review of the eloquence and genial nature of the gifted FERGUSON, Col. BAKER suddenly paused, and with a sadness of tone that was a fitting echo to the thought, exclaimed: "Who will thus speak of me when I am dead?" The desire then expressed, but no doubt soon forgotten, is more than fulfilled in the just tribute we must all pay to the eloquent BAKER.

abstract: The Western Press devotes itself to the discussion of the issue between Gens. ROSECRANS and BENHAM, in regard to which of those officers is responsible for the escape of FLOYD from Cotton Hill. ROSECRANS...
lead_paragraph: The Western Press devotes itself to the discussion of the issue between Gens. ROSECRANS and BENHAM, in regard to which of those officers is responsible for the escape of FLOYD from Cotton Hill. ROSECRANS charges that BENHAM failed to catch the runaway felon, through tardiness in executing his orders; while the friends of BENHAM allege that he besought in vain permission to attack, although his force was less than half that of the rebel chief; and that he was recalled from the pursuit of the fugitive at the moment he was on the eve of seizing his baggage train Capt. STEIN, who was Adjutant-General to Brig.-Gen. MORRIS, of the Indiana Volunteers, who commanded in some of the earlier movements in Western Virginia, takes up the controversy warmly in behalf of BENHAM, writing a long and eloquent letter on the subject to the Lafayette (ind.) Journal. After referring to Gen. BENHAM, "as an old officer, who in his capacity as engineer, reconnoitered the ground and planned the battle of Buena Vista, in which he personally participated as a member of Gen. TAYLOR's Staff;" and alluding to some disparaging references to the standing of the General among the "three months' volunteers," he says:

lead_paragraph: Although Gen. HUNTER's sphere of usefulness was somewhat circumscribed by his transfer to the Department of Kansas, he seems disposed to show no mercy to the rebels still left within his reach. For weeks past, Sr. GORDON and a band of marauders have amused themselves by making raids into Kansas, plundering and maltreating all loyalists who happened to be beyond the protection of the National forces. These robbers have made Platte County, Missouri, their headquarters, and, on Dec. 2, Gen. HUNTER addressed a note, bearing upon the matter, to the Trustees of Platte City. The following is the essential portion of this epistle, which was quite as amiable in tone as was required by the circumstances of the case:

abstract: - We hear a great deal about this and that port being inefficiently blockaded, and it can be readily understood that one vessel running the blockade will provoke a great deal move comment and gossip than the capture of a dozen by the ships of our squadron. The truth of this is demonstrated by the published statement of the Secretary of the Navy concerning vessels seized since the commencement of the war. Besides other services performed, the blockading squadron has captured over 160 of the enemy's vessels, and their seizure, while it establishes the general vigilance of our cruisers, amply atones for any damage that our commerce has sustained at the hands of the enemy. Forty-two of our war ships have succeeded in making prizes. The Minnesota, at Hampton Roads, has made the most captures; next to her, the South Carolina, stationed off Galveston and the mouths of the Mississippi, is able to show the largest number of rebel prizes.

abstract: It must be conceded  to the English newspaper Press, that the territorial acquisitions of Gen. SHERMAN are not important as a question of acres; but there is no doubt the capture of Port Royal has exerted a prodigious moral effect within the bounds of rebeldom, and done more than seemed possible...
lead_paragraph: It must be conceded to the English newspaper Press, that the territorial acquisitions of Gen. SHERMAN are not important as a question of acres; but there is no doubt the capture of Port Royal has exerted a prodigious moral effect within the bounds of rebeldom, and done more than seemed possible toward dissipating that vainglorious self-confidence with which the cockerels of the South strutted their improvised ramparts, mounted with stolen thunder, and defied the world. They have found their entrenchments wholly at the mercy of any belligerent comer. There are so many shells to be exploded by the legions of LINCOLN, and all these tremendous products of rebel engineery are to be evacuated, and given over to the tenancy of the Northern invader. Port Royal has demonstrated so much; and there is alarm behind every perch of defensive masonry on the Southern coast.

abstract: One cry impulsively leaped to the lips of Englishmen as the news was told of the search of the Trent a cry for the vindication of the "honor of the British flag." The act, seen through the distorted medium of the partisan reports first carried over, seemed to them a wanton wound to English honor.
lead_paragraph: One cry impulsively leaped to the lips of Englishmen as the news was told of the search of the Trent -- a cry for the vindication of the "honor of the British flag." The act, seen through the distorted medium of the partisan reports first carried over, seemed to them a wanton wound to English honor. There was no stopping to take the cue from PUFFENDORF or VATTEL -- they fell strongly and they spoke strongly. Public journals and public meetings united in one passionate vow that no insult should fall unredressed on the British flag. The Government was petitioned to see to it that honor was sacredly upheld.

abstract: ANOTHER SLICE FROM THE CITY HALL PARK. -Workmen were engaged throughout Friday in setting posts and putting up a high board fence in the Park, commencing at the western boundary of the grounds taken for the new City Hall, and running along Chambers-street to within about twenty feet of Broadway, with a depth of about 150 feet. Many supposed that ground was to be broken for a new engine-house, which had been petitioned for in that location, and which the Common Council at one time seemed disposed to grant. It has, however, been ascertained that the inclosure, which was to be sheltered by a temporary roof, is for the accommodation of the marble cutters for the new Court-house, who will soon commence work, and who will be employed all Winter. The weather has been so favorable, thus far, the Commissioners have been enabled to push on the work beyond their expectations, and the amount of labor already performed shows how much can be accomplished by many hands judiciously employed.
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER SLICE FROM THE CITY HALL PARK. -Workmen were engaged throughout Friday in setting posts and putting up a high board fence in the Park, commencing at the western boundary of the grounds taken for the new City Hall, and running along Chambers-street to within about twenty feet of Broadway, with a depth of about 150 feet. abstract: To-morrow morning the Fourth and Fifth Regiments of the brigade will arrive in this City from their quarters at Fort Schuyler, and proceed via the New-Jersey Railroad to Washington, and thence immediately to encamp beside the other regiments of the organization in the division of Gen. SUMNER, in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: To-morrow morning the Fourth and Fifth Regiments of the brigade will arrive in this City from their quarters at Fort Schuyler, and proceed via the New-Jersey Railroad to Washington, and thence immediately to encamp beside the other regiments of the organization in the division of Gen. SUMNER, in Virginia. The Fourth Regiment is commanded by Col. HENRY M. BAKER, an experienced and accomplished soldier, who was Colonel of the New-Jersey Second Militia Regiment during its three months' service. Four batteries of the Fifth Flying Artillery, numbering some five hundred men, will also depart under the command of Major THOMAS O'NEILL, who served with distinction through the Mexican war. These batteries are commanded by Captains HOGAN, MCMAHON, MITCHELL and O'DONOHUE. Our readers will remember the narrative we published some weeks ago of the escape of Capt. O'DONOHUE from Richmond. He was attached to MEAGHER's Zouaves, of the Sixty-ninth, fought gallantly, and was captured at Bull Run, and taken to the capital of Virginia, from which he made his escape under circumstances sufficient to test the courage, daring and endurance of the boldest. Returned home and obtaining the proper authority, he enlisted his battery, and is now once more off to the wars, under his old chieftain. The other officers are well-known to this community. Capt. MCMAHON has been fighting round the world since his boyhood -- from Europe to South America, whither he accompanied WALKER in his expeditions to that region. Capt. HOGAN formerly commanded the Napper Tandy Artillery Company of Brooklyn.

abstract: Our dispatches from California give an account of a great flood which has occurred in that State, owing to a heavy rain storm, which lasted for several days. The City of Sacramento was almost submerged, the water in the houses standing from two to twelve feet deep. The losses in that city alone will probably amount to half a million of dollars. At last accounts the weather had become more settled, and the waters were slowly subsiding.

abstract: If there was one thing on which all agreed at the outbreak of the war, it was that we should have to look forward to a season of general distress in our cities, this Winter, as the result of the social convulsion. Six months ago, the canvas of the future was not...
lead_paragraph: If there was one thing on which all agreed at the outbreak of the war, it was that we should have to look forward to a season of general distress in our cities, this Winter, as the result of the social convulsion. Six months ago, the canvas of the future was not only red with the colors of war, but black with the anticipations of suffering and starvation. Whether proclaimed with blatant exultation by rebels South or rebel sympathizers North, or felt by the loyal and true as an ominous shadow darkening the future -- it is a matter of history that the one general conviction was that the coming Winter was big with social and industrial disaster. The Secessionists gloatingly prophesied that infuriate mobs would go howling "bread or blood" through our streets; and nobody needs to be reminded what New-York journal gave these diabolisms daily expression. Europeans -- out of whose heads it seems to be impossible to get the idea that class-interests are somehow mixed up with this war -- told us we should soon have "dangerous socialistic upheavals, and the terrible cry of the French Revolution reechoed by the masses whom the war will plunge into poverty."

abstract: The first report of the Commissioner appointed by the Anglo-Indian Government to inquire into the cotton-growing capacity of the great Oriental Peninsula, and the progress of cotton cultivation therein, has been recently published. It is a most able and valuable document; and though it relates only to the region...
lead_paragraph: The first report of the Commissioner appointed by the Anglo-Indian Government to inquire into the cotton-growing capacity of the great Oriental Peninsula, and the progress of cotton cultivation therein, has been recently published. It is a most able and valuable document; and though it relates only to the region called the Doab, or the territory between the Jumna and the Ganges, it conclusively demonstrates why the culture of the cotton plant is not extending in India so widely as stay-at-home Britons are led to suppose.

abstract: We publish this morning most important news from Charleston, coupled with rumors of the most startling character. Nearly the whole of that pestilent city has been destroyed by an incendiary fire, the torch being applied by a negro a free negro, the dispatches state.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning most important news from Charleston, coupled with rumors of the most startling character. Nearly the whole of that pestilent city has been destroyed by an incendiary fire, the torch being applied by a negro -- a free negro, the dispatches state. The fire broke out in a sash-factory on Hazel-street, and communicated to buildings on the opposite side, when, under the impulse of a stiff breeze, the conflagration soon assumed a formidable character -- aided, perhaps, (though the dispatches do not so state,) by the incendiaries. The business portion of the City appears to have been almost entirely swept away, including the Institute and St. Andrew's Halls, the Theatre, the Catholic Cathedral and the Circular Church -- and last, though not least, the Mercury and Courier offices. Our latest advices are to the afternoon of Thursday, when the fire was still raging, as it had been since 9 o'clock on the previous evening. Thousands of houseless persons were huddled in the streets, and supplies for their relief were being sent in from the surrounding country. But the most important announcement in connection with this conflagration is that it was intended as only one scene in the horrible tragedy of a slave insurrection. The plot is said to have been disclosed by the body-servant of a military officer, and the discoveries which had followed had created the greatest consternation. Families were closing and barring their windows, and taking other measures to secure themselves. There are rumors, also, that insurrections had broken out in the interior of the State two days before the fire, and at last accounts were still raging unchecked.

abstract: The British Gov  ernment has pointed out numberless evidences of its amicable feeling toward this country, as an offset to as many outrages it has suffered at our hands. Its catalogue will receive an appropriate addition by inserting the case of the Nashville.
lead_paragraph: The British Government has pointed out numberless evidences of its amicable feeling toward this country, as an offset to as many outrages it has suffered at our hands. Its catalogue will receive an appropriate addition by inserting the case of the Nashville. The Northern States are engaged in peaceful commerce with England, carrying to her shores the bread without which her millions and the millions of Ireland will go nigh to perishing. Our shipping engaged in this munificent errand whitens the seas about the British Islands. Southern insurgents and incendiaries turn loose among these pacific squadrons a pirate, using a stolen ship, to burn, destroy, sink, and plunder at his own malevolent will; and how does England take occasion to demonstrate at once her good will and her impartial neutrality? By furnishing the Nashville, when it reaches the Bermudas, with the supplies, without which it would have been unable to reach the intended theatre of its devastations; and when it enters a British port red-handed from the commission of an outrage, the wantonness of which was but an illustrative prelude to its future performances, by renewing its supplies, and giving more absolute perfection to its means of hunting down and destroying American merchantmen. The Nashville when she emerges, (if she is to emerge, for there is still doubt.) from Southampton waters on her piratical business, will be to all intents and purposes a British, privateer, furnished forth by the British Government for the destruction of a friendly commerce.

abstract: Yesterday, about 10 o'clock A.M., an Exchange Broker, named BERNARD LEVY, one of the firm of L. B. LEVY  SON, of No. 146 Canal-street, under the Citizens' Bank, was found in his own office with his throat cut in a most horrible manner. Life was extinct when he was discovered, though the body was still warm.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, about 10 o'clock A.M., an Exchange Broker, named BERNARD LEVY, one of the firm of L.B. LEVY & SON, of No. 146 Canal-street, under the Citizens' Bank, was found in his own office with his throat cut in a most horrible manner. Life was extinct when he was discovered, though the body was still warm. He lay on the floor behind the counter, stretched out at full length, with one hand extended out at full length, and the other resting upon his breast. The body lay in a large pool of blood, and all his clothes were completely saturated with the vital fluid. On the counter was found the knife with which the deed is supposed to have been committed. The police were immediately notified of the affair, and Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinct Police, with a squad of men, proceeded to the place, and took charge of the establishment. About the same time. Coroner JACKMAN and Superintendent KENNEDY were notified of the occurrence, and they also attended, and took prompt measures to investigate the facts and circumstances which led to the fearful tragedy. Great crowds of people in the meantime thronged the street in front of the office where the body was found, and for a short time great excitement prevailed throughout all the vicinity. The scene of the occurrence is in Canal-street, three doors from the Bowery, and is one of four offices situated in the large brown stone building which takes in the corner, and nearly one-fourth of the block. The office where the body was found is about twenty feet long by fourteen feet wide, and as we have stated, was used as an exchange broker's office. The space between the counter and wall, where the body was found, is about four feet wide, and the counter was of such a height' that a person walking into the room could not naturally see anything lying on the floor behind the counter, without leaning forward. Nothing was found to have been disarranged in the office, and large quantities of bills and coin were in the show window and on the shelves back of the counter, at the time the body was discovered.

abstract: The lady managers of the Nursery and Child's Hospital state that in consequence of the fact that large numbers of persons were disappointed in obtaining admission to the amateur concert given by them in aid of that Institution, on Thursday evening, it will be repeated on Tuesday evening. Dec. 17. In order to give to those who purchased tickets and were deterred from using them by the crowd, an opportunity to do so, tickets not then presented, of which were returned, will be received. A limited number of new tickets will also be issued, which may be purchased as before from any of the managers.
