abstract: The Times adverts to Mr. SEWARD's recent instructions to the people near the Canadian frontier. The only inference was that he was about to force a quarrel with England. The Times says the wisest course for Canada will be to prepare; let her at once discipline her militia and emulate the mother country by drilling a volunteer army. Montreal only wants stout hearts and zealous hands to be safe until the Spring returns, when we can make it secure. The danger to Montreal or to any other point of the frontier is less. Canada should not rely too much on us and too little upon herself.

abstract: This regiment, numbering over a thousand men, with horses, arrived in this City yesterday, by way of Troy, from Burlington, Vt., at which place it had been encamped for the last nine weeks. On landing from the cars -- over 130 being engaged in transporting the men and horses -- the horses were taken to Bull's Head stables, in Twenty-fourth-street, near Third-avenue, where they were quartered, One man, a member of Company B, had the misfortune to slip from the platform of the car upon which he was standing and broke both of his arms. He was brought to the City, and conveyed to the Hospital, where he is being properly cared for.

abstract: The reports that have thus far reached us concerning the escape of the privateer Sumter from the United States steamer Iroquois, involved the very severest censure of Capt. PALMER, whose failure to seize her certainly stands in need of explanation. Simple justice, however, demands that he should no be condemned unheard.
lead_paragraph: The reports that have thus far reached us concerning the escape of the privateer Sumter from the United States steamer Iroquois, involved the very severest censure of Capt. PALMER, whose failure to seize her certainly stands in need of explanation. Simple justice, however, demands that he should no be condemned unheard. He has been known from the beginning of this rebellion one of the staunchest and most loyal defenders of the flag of the country, and has, by his personal remonstrances, prevented some of his brother officers of the Navy from throwing up their commissions and joining the South. He is well known in this City, where he has many family connections and friends.

abstract: CORONERS' INQUESTS.--At 6 o'clock yesterday morning, the body of MATTHEW KING, a native of Ireland, 40 years of age, was found on the sidewalk in First-avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth streets.
lead_paragraph: CORONERS' INQUESTS. -- At 6 o'clock yesterday morning, the body of MATTHEW KING, a native of Ireland, 40 years of age, was found on the sidewalk in First-avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth streets. From the appearance of the body he could not have been dead very long. Some papers were found on the person of deceased which indicated that he had been in the employ of EDWARD S. JAFFRAY, of the firm of JAFFRAY & SONS, No. 350 Broadway, as a groom. The cause of his death is unknown. He was conveyed to the Seventeenth Precinct Station-house by the police, and the Coroner duly notified. ....A lad named SAMUEL CLOBURG, while flying a kite, late on Saturday afternoon, on the top of house No. 315 Stanton-street, fell through the skylight to a floor below, and was injured so seriously that he died a few hours afterward. The body was conveyed to his home, No. 88 Lewis-street, and the Coroner notified to hold an inquest....At 12 1/2 o'clock on Saturday night, a man named JOHN BROCELIN was found dead at the foot of a flight of stone steps leading to the basement of No. 378 Broome-street. He was a man of intemperate habits, and it is supposed that he accidentally fell down the steps while intoxicated. Officer GORMAN, of the Fourteenth Precinct, removed the body to the Station-house. Deceased resided in Mott-street, near Grand.....Late on Saturday night, the body of an unknown man was found in the forecastle of the ship Julia Lawrence, lying at Pier No. 48 East River. Deceased was light complexioned, with hair and beard partially gray; he was dressed in a Russian cap, flannel undershirt, gauze undershirt, and a cotton shirt over both; black pants, blue vest, and wore a belt around his waist; he appeared to be about 50 years of age. The body was conveyed to the Seventh Precinct Station-house, and the Coroner notified. ....The body of an unknown man was found, yesterday, floating in the water at the foot of Clarkson-street, North River. He was dressed in blue overalls and a knit shirt. It is judged that he was about 40 years of age. The body was taken to the dead-house to await the Coroner's investigation....Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest, yesterday, upon the body of a lad, eight years of age, named JOHN CLIFFORD, who was found in the dock at the foot of Delancey-street, East River. The body had been in the water but a few hours. The lad's residence could not be ascertained.

abstract: According to the London Times, the arrangements for increasing the force in Canada are not yet complete, but in a very few hours everything will be settled. In the meantime, a large ship, the Melbourne, has been taken up, and is now being loaded with Armstrong guns, some 80,000 Enfield rifles, ammunition and other stores at Woolwich. It is not impossible that this vessel will be escorted by one or two ships of war. The rifles are intended for the Canadian military, and strong reinforcements of field artillery will be dispatched forthwith.

abstract: It is not to be denied that, during the past six months, many of Mr. SEWARD'S most devoted friends and warmest admirers have felt that there was something lacking in his public career. With, perhaps, a too ready distrust, they have listened to the little expressions circulating in society, quoted often incorrectly from his conversation, which indicated a want of proper appreciation of the dangers before the country.
lead_paragraph: It is not to be denied that, during the past six months, many of Mr. SEWARD's most devoted friends and warmest admirers have felt that there was something lacking in his public career. With, perhaps, a too ready distrust, they have listened to the little expressions circulating in society, quoted often incorrectly from his conversation, which indicated a want of proper appreciation of the dangers before the country. They have yielded somewhat to the representation that he was one of those philosophic, contemplative statesmen, suited to times of peace, and the intellectual discussions of the forum, but lacking that firmness of will and boldness of purpose requisite for the storms which have now burst upon the Republic. Forgetting the voice which, for so many years, amid obloquy and opposition, had rung out for Principle, when there were few to support it, some even went so far as to suspect their old leader of now urging disgraceful compromises with Slavery and rebellion. It was often currently whispered that Mr. SEWARD was not heartily with the Free States in their struggle, and many who had followed his banner so long, lost a little of their old enthusiasm for him. Beside these suspicions, the whole English Press and a clique of his enemies have labored to spread abroad the idea that his diplomacy was unconciliatory and hectoring, and that his aim was to unite parties at home by a war with England.

abstract: It is without a single rising of vindictive joy that a rightminded man will learn the tragic tidings of what has befallen Charleston. At the same time, if the catastrophe be one of the outworkings of the train of consequences which the inhabitants of that rebellious city instituted in spurning the beneficent protection of the Government of their fathers,--what can be said other than that it is just?
lead_paragraph: It is without a single rising of vindictive joy that a rightminded man will learn the tragic tidings of what has befallen Charleston. At the same time, if the catastrophe be one of the outworkings of the train of consequences which the inhabitants of that rebellious city instituted in spurning the beneficent protection of the Government of their fathers, -- what can be said other than that it is just? There are events in which God's logic does so show itself that one can but stand by and see the fulfillment of the decree of Fate.

abstract: The Thirty-fifth Anniversary of the New-York  City Tract Society, (and the twenty-ninth of the female branch,) was held last evening at the Church of Rev. Dr. ADAMS, on Madison-square.
lead_paragraph: The Thirty-fifth Anniversary of the New-York City Tract Society, (and the twenty-ninth of the female branch,) was held last evening at the Church of Rev. Dr. ADAMS, on Madison-square. The church was densely crowded with an interested assemblage. The chair was occupied by Rev. Dr. DEWITT, President of the Society, and the exercises of the evening were opened with prayer and the singing of the cxxxvith Psalm. The Treasurer's report was read by WM. WALKER, Esq., from which it appeared that the collections and donations during the year amounted to $16,066 22, and the expenditures to $16,396 27, leaving a small balance due the Treasurer.

abstract: Dispatches from California, published yesterday, gave an account of a great flood which has occurred in that State, owing to a heavy rain storm. The City of Sacramento was almost submerged, the water in the houses standing from two to twelve feet deep. The losses in that city alone will probably amount to half a million of dollars. At last accounts the weather had become more settled, and the waters were slowly subsiding.

abstract: The London Observer, a Ministerial organ, says in its issue of Saturday Evening, Nov. 30: A special Messenger of the Foreign Office has been ordered to carry our demands to Lord LYONS, and will proceed by the packet from Queenstown to-day. The public will be satisfied to know that these demands are for an apology, and to insist on the restitution to the protection of the British flag of those who were violently and illegally torn from that sacred asylum.

abstract: Recruiting, both for general service and for regiments, continues very inactive. No favorable change may be expected until greater inducements than now exist are offered to recruits. Not more than twelve men and boys were enlisted here last week, and only two men and six boys were sent to Governor's Island. Three recruiting parties were sent from the island last week to recruit for general service, and others will be sent to recruit for the Eighth Infantry, which is making very slow progress, there not being more than twelve or fourteen men at the headquarters, Fort Hamilton.

lead_paragraph: We published, yesterday, the report of the Coroner's inquest in this case, and some further details will be found in this morning's paper. The verdict of the jury has failed to satisfy the public mind; and the conviction that a barbarous murder has been committee seems to be gaining strength. Certainly the interests of justice demand that further invesgations should be made; and the police of the City will be guilty of a gross neglect of duty if they fail to search out every fact, and to watch closely every witness, that may contribute to disperse the darkness and suspicion which enshrouds this horrid drama of death.

abstract: --To remind us of certain dues which fall about Christmas time, JAMES MILLER publishes in royal quarto form a sumptuous volume--Lyra Germanica--a selection of hymns from Chevalier BUNSEN'S comprehensive collection, Versuch eines Allgemeinen Gesang and Gebetbuchs, translated from the original by CATHARINE WINKWORTH. The German language, in its wealth of sacred poetry, is rivaled by no other.
lead_paragraph: -- To remind us of certain dues which fall about Christmas time, JAMES MILLER publishes in royal quarto form a sumptuous volume -- Lyra Germanica -- a selection of hymns from Chevalier BUNSEN's comprehensive collection, Versuch eines Allgemeinen Gesang and Gebetbuchs, translated from the original by CATHARINE WINKWORTH. The German language, in its wealth of sacred poetry, is rivaled by no other. It abounds with rare old hymns, the compositions of such masters as LUTHER, ANGELUS and PAUL GERHARDT, which move the soul like organ notes. The wealth of the Germans in this respect may be traced to the fact that with them the singing of hymns is considered quite as actual a part of public worship as prayer. In our church it is customary for choirs to perform for the edification of the congregation, and because the services would not be considered as quite complete without the opening and closing hymns. But in the German Church the whole congregation unites in an anthem of praise, sending up their song as prayer. This demand for good hymns naturally produces them. The collection of Chevalier BUNSEN, before alluded to, contains something more than nine hundred sacred lyrics, and scarce a feeble one can be selected from them all. The German mind views the hymn as a vehicle of worship, and aims in it rather at the expression of a devotional feeling than the paying of common-place compliments in regular metro, to the Deity. Accordingly we find the German Hymn full of fire and strength, replete with clear Christian faith, and expressing a brave joyful trust. The difference in structure of the two languages makes the rendering into English verse a most difficult task, but in the vollume before us, the spirit of the compositions is faithfully preserved, and the slight alterations of text which occur were rendered necessary by the exigencies of poetical translation.

abstract: Great excitement was created in Washington yesterday on the reception of the news from Europe, which was forwarded in advance of its publication in this City. It was discussed universally in the streets and hotels, and the universal sentiment, according to our correspondent, appeared to be one of defiance. There was a disposition, however, to doubt the reliability of the news.
lead_paragraph: Great excitement was created in Washington yesterday on the reception of the news from Europe, which was forwarded in advance of its publication in this City. It was discussed universally in the streets and hotels, and the universal sentiment, according to our correspondent, appeared to be one of defiance. There was a disposition, however, to doubt the reliability of the news. Congress is expected to adjourn on Thursday day next for two weeks, to enable the members to pass the holidays at home, -- consequently no important legislation is expected immediately.

abstract: The map mania continues without showing any visible signs of abatement. Perhaps we should have said map passion, as it is scarcely fair to characterize as disease that which is only a natural demand, stimulated by the exciting events of the day. The term was as badly chosen as though we should say "war-fever," when alluding to the present natural throbbing of the patriotic pulse of our people.
lead_paragraph: The map mania continues without showing any visible signs of abatement. Perhaps we should have said map passion, as it is scarcely fair to characterize as disease that which is only a natural demand, stimulated by the exciting events of the day. The term was as badly chosen as though we should say "war-fever," when alluding to the present natural throbbing of the patriotic pulse of our people. Certain it is that if any one has not an accurate notion of every battle-ground and important point in the rapidly-shifting theatre of operations, the fault is theirs alone, and not that there are no maps in market.

abstract: Our news from England this morning will give the public a startling and most unwelcome surprise. In spite of the evident exaggerations contained in our report, enough remains that is unquestionably true to show that we are on the brink of war with Englad, and that nothing but the highest and the steadiest statesmanship at the helm, and the cordial confidence of the public in the wisdom and patriotism of the Government, can save us from that direst of calamities. We maysay at the outset, however, that dark as the prospect appears, it is by no means hopeless: -- the peril may and will be averted, if that wisdom and public confidence are not withheld.

abstract: The three classes of reserve comprise eight line-of-battle ships, six frigates, five corvettes and twelve sloops, mounting a grand total of 1,861 guns. The steam gunboats attached are not included, which are 21 in number, with 42 guns. This, however, does not include the gunboats and mortar vessels laid up. The list is confined entirely to effective vessels at present, or could be rendered so with little delay. The ships in commission for service at Portsmouth mount 342 guns. The total number of guns in the ships enumerated before is 225, while Admiral MILNES' fleet, on the North American station, amounts to 873 guns.

abstract: --We but pay the Atlantic for January a deserved compliment when we rank it as the best number that has appeared in the history of the magazine. It is always the custom of magazine proprietors to make the initial number of the year an extraordinarily good one.
lead_paragraph: -- We but pay the Atlantic for January a deserved compliment when we rank it as the best number that has appeared in the history of the magazine. It is always the custom of magazine proprietors to make the initial number of the year an extraordinarily good one. In this instance, the gentlemen who guide the destinies of the Atlantic have achieved an eminent success. If the same standard of excellence which distinguishes the January number could be maintained throughout the year, we should have a magazine to be proud of, and a ready answer to the taunt that, though our country produces many remarkable dailies, it cannot get up one respectable and readable monthly. Every one will hail with pleasure the reappearance of Rev. HOMER WILBUR, with his neat classical allusions and quotations. He introduces our old friend, Birdofredum Sawin, Esq., who favors us, by means of a letter to Mr. Hosea Biglow, with a versified account of his experience in the South. It is in LOWELL's best vein, and fully equals the best of the Biglow Papers. The leading article, "Methods of Study in Natural History," is by Prof. AGASSIZ. Dr. WINDSHIP -- why isn't he called Steamship? the name would be more suggestive of strength -- gives us "Autobiographical Sketches of a Strength Seeker." According to his story, the Doctor has been enabled to raise his enormous weights by adopting the principle of the man who by lifting a calf everyday, was finally enabled to shoulder it when it grew to an ox. He first determined to practice litting until he could raise a weight of twelve hundred pounds. Having attained that development of muscle some time since, he now intends to rest satisfied when he can lift three thousand. Thus it seems that the attainment of strength is somewhat like that of wealth -- the votary is never satisfied, but marks out a fresh endeavor as soon as he attains the sum of his first ambition. And why do not those wise ones who advise against the accumulation of riches have a word to say against this gathering of muscular power? The same argument would hold good in both cases, for a man can no more carry muscle out of the world with him then he can money. "Jefferson and Slavery," a clear and admirable article, is by Prof. WHITE. RALPH WALDO EMERSON contributes a delightful essay, "Old Age," and NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE a charming account of a "Pilgrimage to Old Boston." "Fremont's Hundred Days in Missouri," is a semi-defence of the "Pathfinder," by WM. DORSHEIMER. The author disdains any intention of appearing as an apologist, but gives a graphic sketch of what FREMONT did do in the hundred days of his command. This is perfectly fair, as multitudinous mouths have been opened to tell what he did not. In addition we have a tale, "Love on Skates," by the late THEODORE WINTHROP; "Light Literature," by Rev. D.A. WASSON; "Per Tenebras Lumina," a poem, by Mrs. H.D.T. WHITNEY; another poem, "The True Heroine;" an appreciative article on JAMES FENIMORE COOPER, by GEO. S. HILLIARD, a continuation of Mrs. STOVE's "Agnes of Sorrento;" further chapters of "A Story of To-day," by the author of "Life in the Iron Mills," and the usual reviews and literary notices.

abstract: The advices brought by the Europa, and confirmed by the City of Washington, convey the startling intelligence that the English Government, after submitting the case of the Trent to the law officers of the Crown, has decided to regard the seizure of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON as a violation of international law, and to demand of the American Government an apology for the act, and a restoration of the rebel envoys to the shelter of the British flag. A Queen's messenger, bearing dispatches to Lord LYONS, conveying this demand, is on board the Europa and arriving at Boston to-morrow night, will reach Washington by Wednesday. In the meantime, the most energetic preparations for war are making in England. Every dock-yard is active, and steamers are taken up by the Government to carry troops, arms and artillery, heavy and light, to Canada, while it is understood that the first cruise of the mailed monster, the Warrior, will, in the event of a rejection of an English ultimatum, be made in American waters. A royal proclamation has forbidden the exportation of arms, of gunpowder, and of any material used in the manufacture of that explosive. The popular excitement was intense. Mr. BRIGHT had made a speech at Rochdale, in which he referred in the friendliest terms to the cause in which the North is engaged, and expressed a hope that a rupture might still be avoided. Mr. COBDEN had written a letter, moderate in tone, invoking a suspension of judgment. But the entire drift of opinion appeared to be in the direction of war, the Ministerial Press fanning the popular flame by promising to clear the sea of the American navy in a month; acknowledge the Southern Confederacy; and, by breaking the blockade, letting out cotton, and letting in British manufactures. A blockade of the Northern ports is also on the war programme. The London Observer, the more intimate mouth-piece of the Ministers, declares it would be not only proper, but easy, to cause SLIDELL and MASON to be delivered to a British frigate, anchored in front of Washington, with twelve other royal men-of-war attending as witnesses of the humiliating spectacle. The tone of the Press generally is violent and uncompromising; and little hope is expressed that the United States will make concessions. The London Times, indeed, declares a war to be sought by Mr. SEWARD through this transaction; and a remark said to have been made by Gen. SCOTT since his arrival at Paris, is cited as showing the insult to have been deliberately planned by the Washington Cabinet.

abstract: The Constitution left Ship Island Roads Dec. 7. Five lady passengers, the wives of the chief officers of the Twenty-sixth and Ninth Regiments, who had accompanied their husbands, returning in the ship. We made a quick run to Key West, where it was necessary to call for coal, but owing to the delay which would occur, in consequence of several other vessels, viz., the United States steamers Connecticut and Water Witch, and the sloop-of-war Richmond, being ahead of us, it was decided to proceed to Havana. Here we were detained part of two days, and sailed again on the 12th, arriving at Fortress Monroe on Sunday afternoon. A heavy northeast gale prevailed during two days of the trip. The representatives of the Press here left the steamer for New-York, in order to report the results of the expedition. The ship would receive two hundred tons of coal, and sail immediately for Boston, where Maj.-Gen. BUTLER will join the second expedition with the Twelfth Maine Regiment, and a large body of other troops.

abstract: Much of our space in the present issue is surrendered to accounts, furnished by our own Reporter, of the voyage of Gen. PHELPS' brigade, and its landing at Ship Island, near the mouths of the Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: Much of our space in the present issue is surrendered to accounts, furnished by our own Reporter, of the voyage of Gen. PHELPS' brigade, and its landing at Ship Island, near the mouths of the Mississippi. The expedition seems to have run an uneventful course. Without detention by the way, after leaving Fortress Monroe, the steamer that bore the troops proceeded to its destination, where the little army effected an undisputed landing. Ship Island was found to be provided with a fortification, erected by marines detached from the blockading squadron. A certain number of heavy guns were in position, while others were daily expected from Fort Pickens, where Col. BROWN has, it seems, discovered himself to be in possession of more gun-metal than the leaguer of Gen. BRAGG seems to' require. The troops, at the departure of our correspondent, were settled contentedly in their quarters, their only solicitude relating to the exact period when they should be called to those active operations of which Ship Island is no more than the radiating centre.

abstract: ASPINWALL, Saturday, Dec. 7 12 M. The victory of Gen. MITRE, of Buenos Ayres,  over URQUIZA, of the Argentine Confederation, was complete. MITRE occupies Rosario. He took 2,500 prisoners, who have joined his forces; 28 cannon, 5,000 horses,  The dates from Mendoza are to Nov. 2. From Chili the dates are to Nov, 18. The Republic was tranquil. Business improving.

abstract: The Sanitary Commission has just issued a circular, stating the general objects and results of its organization, and appealing for additional contributions for their prosecution.
lead_paragraph: The Sanitary Commission has just issued a circular, stating the general objects and results of its organization, and appealing for additional contributions for their prosecution. The financial statement shows that they have received over $28,000 in money, of which according to the latest report, about $18,000 have been expended in salaries and traveling expenses, printing, hospital supplies, &c, the latter item, including nurses, amounting to $2,696. The amount still on hand is about $10,000, -- the monthly expenses of the Commission averaging about $5,000 a month, -- "a trifle," as the report justly says, "compared with what the private charity of the country can afford to contribute toward saving the lives of our soldiers," -- and a trifle, it might have been added, compared with what it will contribute, if satisfied that the process is at once the most effective and economical. Of the amount thus far contributed, one-third has been derived from various Life Insurance Companies, one of these institutions having given the munificent donation of $4,000, another $3,000, and three others $1,000 each.

abstract: The United States steamer transport Constitution, Capt. A.T. FLETCHER, arrived at Fortress Monroe on Sunday afternoon, where she called for orders, on her return from Ship Island, Mississippi Sound, having safely landed at the latter...
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer transport Constitution, Capt. A.T. FLETCHER, arrived at Fortress Monroe on Sunday afternoon, where she called for orders, on her return from Ship Island, Mississippi Sound, having safely landed at the latter place, Dec. 4, the two regiments, (Twenty-sixth Massachusetts, and Ninth Connecticut,) which embarked on her at Boston, the 18th and 21st of November. In this southward expedition, after proceeding to Portland for the Twelfth Regiment of Maine, which did not embark on her, the Constitution proceeded to Fortress Monroe, Nov. 23, where she arrived on the 26th. She coaled, and left on the 28th, and, after a very pleasant passage, arrived at Ship Island, Mississippi Sound, Dec. 3. Her arrival here was as gratifying as it was unexpected by the little fleet and small garrison which have been holding the place against constant threats, and occasional attacks from the rebels. By the assistance of two large river steamers, which had been captured in Mississippi Sound only a short time previous to her arrival the troops and material of war, and subsistence stores, were landed between the 4th and 8th of December -- a single accident only occurring, by which one of the steel rifled guns belonging to Capt. MANNING's Light Battery was lost overboard. The two regiments were comfortably encamped on the island, near the lighthouse, and the Salem Battery near the fortification. On the 6th the last of the cargo was landed on the beach, and was taken charge of by Commissary BUTLER, brother of Maj.-Gen. BUTLER, who will probably join the expedition in a short time with a large accession to the force. The Constitution left at Ship Island her splendid rifled long-range guns, and also six fine life-boats, of the Francis and Raymond patterns, for the use of the command. During the day on which the Constitution sailed from Ship Island, a naval engagement took place within sight, and quite near the island, between the United States gunboat New-London and the steamer De Soto, and two rebel armed vessels -- the Pamlico and California -- which were attempting to run the gauntlet from New-Orleans to Mobile. "Nobody was hurt" on either side. The Constitution sailed from Ship Island Saturday, Dec. 7, at 5 P.M., and arrived at Key West on the 9th, where she put in to obtain coal, but not being able to obtain it there with dispatch she proceeded to Havana, arriving on the 10th. Here she coaled, and again left on the 12th, at 8 o'clock A.M., and arrived at Fortress Monroe on Sunday, at 3 1/2 o'clock P.M. Two hundred tons of coal would be put on board, and she would sail on Monday for Boston, where she will be due on Wednesday.

abstract: In the Senate, a number of petitions tonching upon the Slavery question were presented. Mr,  TEN EYCK, of New-York, offered a resolution against radicalism in any sense, which was laid over. The Committee on Military Affairs, on motion of Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, was in  structed to inquire into the expediency of providing a uniform manner in which to deal with the slaves of rebels.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, a number of petitions touching upon the Slavery question were presented. Mr. TEN EYCK, of New-York, offered a resolution against radicalism in any sense, which was laid over. The Committee on Military Affairs, on motion of Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, was instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing a uniform manner in which to deal with the slaves of rebels. The Committee on the Judiciary were instructed to prepare a law to prevent the aiders and abettors of treason from bringing suits for the collection of debts in the United States Courts. Mr. WILKINSON, of Minnesota, offered a preamble and resolution for the expulsion of Senator BRIGHT, of Indiana. Mr. BRIGHT made a brief speech, denying the truth of the charges brought against him, and the subject was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The resolution making inquiries of the Secretary of State in reference to the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus, presented by Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, was then called up by that gentleman, and was discussed during the rest of the session. It was finally referred to the Judiciary Committee, 25 to 17, and the Senate, after an Executive Session, adjourned.

abstract: The steamship Champion, from Aspinwall, with specie from California to the amount of $979,000, arrived here yesterday. She reports that when in lat. 31 30, Ion. 76 , she was chased for an hour by a propeller, supposed to be a privateer, which finally hoisted the English, colors; but the propeller did not succeed in overtaking the treasureship.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Champion, from Aspinwall, with specie from California to the amount of $979,000, arrived here yesterday. She reports that when in lat. 31 30, lon. 76, she was chased for an hour by a propeller, supposed to be a privateer, which finally hoisted the English, colors; but the propeller did not succeed in overtaking the treasureship. From South America, we learn that Gen. MITEE, of Buenos Ayres, had gained a victory over URQUIZA, the commander of the forces of the Argentine Confederation, and had taken a large number of prisoners and munitions of war, and occupied Rosario. The late massacre at La Paz, Bolivia, is said to have been instigated by Gen. FERNANDEZ, who is plotting to be President. Dr. CORPANCHO is on his way to Washington as Peruvian Minister. From Bogota (United States of Colombia,) we learn that the church difficulties had reached a climax, and MOSQUERA had cut the gordion knot by exiling the Archbishop and the refractory monastic crew. The civil difficulties also continue, with a prospect of peace. From other points there is nothing of great importance.

abstract: This regiment, Col. KINGSBURY, will arrive in this city this morning, en route for the seat of war. abstract: The first complete regiment of cavalry that has passed through the streets of New-York since the present war began, marched along Broadway to the Battery, yesterday, preparatory to its final departure for the scene of conflict. The First Regiment of Vermont Cavalry arrived in this City on Sunday, and on Monday morning notice of its organization. strength, appearance and efficiency was published in the NEW-YORK TIMES. At the same time, mention was made of the Colonel, LEMUEL B. PLATT, of Colchester, Chittenden County, Vt.

abstract: We shall have the Europa's mails to-morrow, and then, perhaps, we can test a little more accurately the precise import and value of the news which yesterday threw Wallstreet into such a paroxysm of alarm, and created so much excitement in the City at large.
lead_paragraph: We shall have the Europa's mails to-morrow, and then, perhaps, we can test a little more accurately the precise import and value of the news which yesterday threw Wallstreet into such a paroxysm of alarm, and created so much excitement in the City at large. Meantime it may give us somewhat more of peace for the intervening day, to reflect that nine-tenths of the European bluster and menace which filled our newspapers yesterday morning, was the work of the excited English Press, and not at all the utterance of the English Government. Indeed the only official intelligence we have on the subject is, that England has instructed her minister here to demand an apology and reparation for the insult offered to the British flag in the affair of the Trent.

abstract: Henry Dexter vs. Richard J. Clark. This was an action commenced in the Marine Court, to recover $50 for one quarter's rent of a house belonging to the plaintiff, and occupied by the defendant; also to recover $68.75, upon a claim for prior rent of the same house, due from the defendant to Messrs. Weeks  De Forest, and by them assigned to the plaintiff. The complaint was dismissed by Judge THOMPSON.
lead_paragraph: Henry Dexter vs. Richard J. Clark. -- This was an action commenced in the Marine Court, to recover $50 for one quarter's rent of a house belonging to the plaintiff, and occupied by the defendant; also to recover $68 75, upon a claim for prior rent of the same house, due from the defendant to Messrs. Weeks & De Forest, and by them assigned to the plaintiff. The complaint was dismissed by Judge THOMPSON.

abstract: LOUISA BRIEDSBRACH and GEORGE WEILER were arrested last night about 10 1/2 o'clock, by Captain DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinct, aided by Sergeant JOURDAN and Officer GOLDEN. From the evidence of DAVID LEVY, given upon the inquest, on Saturday last, it is believed the parties under arrest may have had some connection with the death of BERNARD LEVY, the Canal-street broker. Since Saturday, Captain DOWLING and his assistants have been unremitting in their efforts to ferret out the residence of the persons in question. They traced them through the city from one house to another, until finally they found a house in Norfolk-street, from which they removed on the same day that LEVY came to his sad end. From there they found it very difficult to trace them; and it was only by resorting to ways and means known only to policemen that they were enabled at last to find their residence. They were found at No. 1 Allen-street, and taken to the Sixth Precinct Station-house, where they now are. The woman is about thirty-five years of age. She is a German by birth, and speaks the English language very imperfectly. Her appearance is that of a woman of nerve and determination. WEILER is her paramour, and is the man referred to in the evidence of DAVID LEVY as having been brought by the woman to deceased's office, upon a certain occasion, when she pointed out deceased to him, at the same time making threats against his life. He is a quiet, inoffensive-looking man, about forty years of age.

abstract: This regiment, Col. MORGAN, which has been encamped at East New-York for some time past, left its quarters yesterday and proceeded to Governor's Island, where it will remain till its departure for the seat of war. At the City Hall, Brooklyn, a stand of colors was presented to the regiment by Gen. COOKE, on behalf of the Mayor and Common Council. After the presentation, the regiment crossed the Fulton Ferry, marched up Broadway, and paraded through several of our principal streets. The regiment is uniformed, armed and equipped. Only two companies have, however, the Enfield rifle, the remainder being supplied with the old flint-lock musket, altered to the percussion cap, a weapon that is almost worse than useless.

abstract: In addition to the large map of Ship Island and its surroundings, which we published yesterday, we give herewith another diagram, exhibiting the depth of water in the vicinity of the Island, and between the Island and the mainland showing what an admirable water-way for inland navigation the rebels here possessed, and how admirably we close it up by the possession of this narrow strip of land.
lead_paragraph: In addition to the large map of Ship Island and its surroundings, which we published yesterday, we give herewith another diagram, exhibiting the depth of water in the vicinity of the Island, and between the Island and the mainland showing what an admirable water-way for inland navigation the rebels here possessed, and how admirably we close it up by the possession of this narrow strip of land. From the Island to Mississippi City on the main is a distance of ten miles; and it is along this passage that the rebel steamers between New-Orleans, Mobile and other points have been plying. It was impossible for our heavy blockaders to pursue them through these intricate and often shallow windings; and consequently the coastwise traffic along here has been kept up with the greatest impunity. By the aid of our batteries and rifled cannon on Ship Island, and a few well-armed light-draft gunboats cruising in Mississippi Sound, it will be impossible for even a rebel cockleshell to sail now almost anywhere on the Gulf coast.

abstract: Four companies of Col. WILLICK's German Indiana regiment were attacked this afternoon, on the south side of Green River, opposite Mumfordsville, by Col. TERRY'S regiment of Texan Rangers, two regiments of infantry and six pieces of artillery. Col. WILLICK, on being reinforced, drove the rebels back, with a loss of 33 killed, including Col. TERRY, and 50 wounded. The National loss was 8 privates and 1 Lieutenant killed, and 16 wounded.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Tuesday, Dec. 17.

abstract: The steamship Europa did not reach Boston until late last evening, and her mails were not forwarded by the express train. They will reach this City this morning. The British sloop-of-war Rinaldo, which was in Boston harbor, started half an hour after the Europa's arrival, to deliver a message to the British Admiral at Bermuda, and special messengers from the Queen and from Mr. ADAMS, our Minister, started for Washington by the Shore Line road.

abstract: The news of the appropriation of $500,000 (to be raised by the sale of bonds) by the Common Council has spread with wonderful rapidity among those most interested. It was only on Monday the certified copy of the ordinance reached the Comptroller, but yesterday that officer was favored with many calls from wives of volunteers, whom he was, of course, compelled to put off until he can advertise and dispose of the bonds to be issued in accordance with the ordinance. It is not probable that any money can be raised until after January, which, hard as it may operate upon many families, is unavoidable.

abstract: The Herald wants to know what motive it can possibly have for stirring up public passion and plunging this country into war with England. It is not for us to judge its motives, it is sufficient to point out the inevitable consequences of its conduct. But the Herald has over and over again boasted that it prospered most in the midst of public calamities.
lead_paragraph: -- The Herald wants to know what motive it can possibly have for stirring up public passion and plunging this country into war with England. It is not for us to judge its motives, -- it is sufficient to point out the inevitable consequences of its conduct. But the Herald has over and over again boasted that it prospered most in the midst of public calamities. Its columns, within the last three or four months, have been filled with braggart vaunts, that while all other departments of business were suffering, it was never so prosperous as now; -- that its circulation had been immensely increased, -- that its advertising was never so large nor so lucrative, -- that the more servants were out of place, the more were its columns crowded with their notices, -- and, in short, that it prospered most on the ruins of every other interest.

abstract: During the past year very extensive improvements have been completed in Central Park. Considering the fact that the number of laborers employed has been much less, and the expenses only about one-half those of last year, it is believed that the management has been good, and the money judiciously expended.
lead_paragraph: During the past year very extensive improvements have been completed in Central Park. Considering the fact that the number of laborers employed has been much less, and the expenses only about one-half those of last year, it is believed that the management has been good, and the money judiciously expended. The Park-drive has been extended from fifty-ninth-street to One Hundred and Fourth-street, making in all more than seven miles of as fine a road for driving as can be found in this country. Much labor has also been expended in the preparation of the skating ponds, the construction of refreshment saloons and other necessary buildings. These buildings will be rented to parties desiring to furnish refreshments to the visitors at the Park, and the income thereof is to be applied to the adorning of the grounds and the improvement of the ponds. Mr. C.G. WHITE, of Brooklyn, has presented to the Superintendent a couple of cranes. They are objects of much interest to those visiting the Park. A pair of deer have also been placed in an inclosure near the Mall, where all may have an opportunity of seeing them. Mrs. CRAWFORD, the widow of the celebrated sculptor of that name, has caused to be placed in the Park a copy of each of her husband's works in plaster. They make a very fine appearance. A great amount of shrubbery and large numbers of trees have been transplanted within the last year, with great succees. Several new avenues have been opened, and five archways, of great architectural beauty, have been constructed in different parts of the Park. Several wealthy parties in the upper part of the City are now making arrangements to erect a glass conservatory at their own expense. If the plan is carried into execution it will be one of the most beautiful structures of the kind in the country. It will be two hundred feet in length, by forty feet in width, and two stories in height. If is to be situated near Fifth-avenue and Seventy-fourth-street, and will front an artificial pond five hundred feet in length, by two hundred and fifty in breadth. The location selected for this building is one of the most beautiful and picturesque in the Park, and when completed according to the design of its projectors will add greatly to the attractions of the Central Park.

abstract: Returning here after a three weeks' absence, I am surprised at the wonderful change which has been effected in the appearance of the place. Evidences of indomitable Yankee energy are abundant. A single rickety plantation residence, with its halfdozen straggling outhouses, and a frame hut near the fort, erected by the rebels as a make-shift barrack, were the only buildings on Hilton Head when our army took possession.
lead_paragraph: Special Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: In the Senate, the House bill authorizing the raising of a volunteer force in Kentucky was referred to the Military Committee. A bill to increase the number of cadets at West Point was reported from the same Committee by Mr. WILSON.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the House bill authorizing the raising of a volunteer force in Kentucky was referred to the Military Committee. A bill to increase the number of cadets at West Point was reported from the same Committee by Mr. WILSON. A call was made upon the Secretary of War for copies of all the correspondence between Gen. SCOTT and Gen. PATTERSON. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, then called up his resolution that the Secretary of War be requested to furnish the Senate with copies of the orders for the erection of barracks for the Kansas troops, and proceeded with a lengthy speech, deprecating inaction on the part of the military authorities during the Winter months, and urging a vigorous prosecution of the war. After considerable debate the resolution was laid on the table. The Committee, on the part of the Senate, to investigate the conduct of the war, was announced to consist of Messrs. WADE of Ohio, CHANDLER of Michigan, and JOHNSON of Tennessee. The House resolution, adjourning over from Thursday until the 6th of January, was laid on the table, and after an Executive Session the Senate adjourned.

abstract: A correspondent of the Memphis Appeal, writing from Feliciana, Graves County, Ky., says: "Yesterday a lady from Padueah was arrested near our camp, and upon her person was found a large package of letters written to our boys at home. They had been intercepted somewhere in transit, and had, no Joubt, either been or were intended to be taken to Padneah. This fact plainly shows that LINCOLN has emissaries fingering our mail."

abstract: The Jonesboro' (Eastern Tennessee) Union of Nov. 23 says: "During the present week the barn of JOSEPH A. CONLEY, the Clerk of the County Court of this county, was consumed by fire -- supposed to be done by an incendiary. Loss $300. This is the third barn burnt in this county; DAVID J. CARR'S having been consumed about three weeks ago, and URIAH HUNT's some two months ago. We advise our farmers to have a special care of their barns, for their burnings are becoming too frequent."

abstract: The United States steam-sloop Dacotah arrived off the Battery, fourteen days from St. Thomas, at 4 P.M., Monday. She experienced very heavy weather, in a succession of northeast gales. Her boilers are leaking badly, and she will need many repairs. The Dacotah was ordered home from the East India Squadron, and left Hong Kong for the United States Aug. 6.
lead_paragraph: The United States steam-sloop Dacotah arrived off the Battery, fourteen days from St. Thomas, at 4 P.M., Monday. The Dacotah was ordered home from the East India Squadron, and left Hong Kong for the United States Aug. 6.

abstract: One evening last Summer, soon after the warspirit had been touched to a more vivid flame by the disaster at Manassas, I was standing near the office of the Congressional Globe, in that magnificent Pennsylvania-avenue which is one of the features of Washington. abstract: The Board of Canvassers met on Monday afternoon, and proceeded to foot up the returns as previously canvassed. Each Alderman added the returns from his district, and the whole was found correct, according to the footings of the clerks. After a brief recess, the Deputy Clerk, Mr. TOUMEY, read the formal declaration of the result, naming the candidates as elected, and as heretofore announced in the TIMES, which, on motion of Alderman BOOLE, was confirmed. On motion of Alderman GENET, the result was published in the TIMES, Atlas, Leader, State Zeitung, Herald, Metropolitan Record, Transcript, and Irish American.

abstract: There are signs in what we hear from the rebellious States that they are beginning to realize their situation in some measure, and that, as a consequence, alarm is seizing them. It is not surprising that it should be so. Let us reverse the situation of things, in our imaginations, and strive to picture to ourselves how such prospects would seem to us.

abstract: -We rehearsed,  a few days since, certain circumstances of the Canal-street homicide, which in our judgment utterly negatived the idea that the deceased committed suicide. The Coroner's jury returned a verdict of suicide, and the Police apparently concurred in its justice. The fact that no robbery appeared to have been committed, was held to constitute a very strong pesumption against the idea that he had been murdered.

abstract: The London Times regrets that the Administration of Mr. LINCOLN will hardly be able to release itself sufficiently from popular influences to take a manly and proper course in regard to the Trent. There is too much reason to believe that a remark of the same kind applies to the position assumed by the British Government.
lead_paragraph: The London Times regrets that the Administration of Mr. LINCOLN will hardly be able to release itself sufficiently from popular influences to take a manly and proper course in regard to the Trent. There is too much reason to believe that a remark of the same kind applies to the position assumed by the British Government. For some months past the approaching session of Parliament has been looked to as destined to decide whether the Palmerston Party was to have a perpetual lease of power, or whether the "outs," whose numbers, by a well-known political law have been steadily growing, should take their turn in disbursing the magnificent things, which it is the vocation of Cabinet Ministers to dispense. The Tory opposition needed only a "cry," with which to enlist the country, to make a successful assault upon an administration, which, through a long term of power, has not distinguished itself by any positive policy, and which has been singularly regardless of the pledges as to reform, -- and other conspicuous topics, on the strength of which it attained office. The outbreak of the American insurrection gave the Tories this "cry."

abstract: The American navy may be said to have been reconstructed since the fall of Sumter. In July last the regular naval force, either fitting out or in commission on the Southern coasts did not exceed forty vessels nor amount to over 700 guns. Day by day, however, the blockading fleet continued to receive additions from vessels ordered home from foreign stations. Of a fleet of eighteen ships-of-war that carried the American flag in foreign waters, thirteen have returned home. Six gunboats and sloops, carrying 88 guns, have been left on the Pacific coast -- one, the Saratoga, (18,) on the Coast of Africa, and one, the Pulaski, (I,) on the Coast of Brazil. Thus the efficient force of the old navy of the United States -- efficient, that is to say, for the blockade and the purposes of the rebellion -- is equal (omitting receiving-ships and ships-of-the-line that have been on the stocks for fifty years) to about seventy vessels of all rates, carrying between 1,200 and 1,300 guns.
lead_paragraph: The American navy may be said to have been reconstructed since the fall of Sumter. Thus the efficient force of the old navy of the United States -- efficient, that is to say, for the blockade and the purposes of the rebellion -- is equal (omitting receiving-ships and ships-of-the-line that have been on the stocks for fifty years) to about seventy vessels of all rates, carrying between 1,200 and 1,300 guns.

abstract: The Eleventh Regiment of Connecticut Volunteers, which has been quartered for several weeks past at Camp Lincoln, near West Hartford, in that State, arrived in this City yesterday morning by the steamer City of Hartford. As the troops landed, their officers were met by a Committee of the Sons of Connecticut, and formally notified of the hospitalities awaiting them.
lead_paragraph: The Eleventh Regiment of Connecticut Volunteers, which has been quartered for several weeks past at Camp Lincoln, near West Hartford, in that State, arrived in this City yesterday morning by the steamer City of Hartford. As the troops landed, their officers were met by a Committee of the Sons of Connecticut, and formally notified of the hospitalities awaiting them. A number of gentlemen, wearing badges of the same organization, were in attendance at Pier No. 3, and as the regiment fell into marching order, led the line to Broadway, preceded by sixteen performers of DODWORTH's Band.

abstract: The Panama Railroad Company's steamer California, chartered in place of the Guatemala, which broke her shaft near Punta Arenas de Costa Rica, arrived at Panama on the 4th, having the Guatemala in tow. The dates from Guatemala and Salvador are to the 24th and 26th, from Nicaragua to the 28th, and from Costa Rica to Dec. 1. There is nothing important from Guatemala, Nicaragua or Costa Rica. Salvador, as well as New-Granada, is the theatre of Church excitement. Sometime since, the Bishop of Salvador demanded the punishment of one of President BARRIOS' Ministers, for having rather freely commented --but in general terms -- on the abuses of the Church. This demand led to a sharp correspondence, in which the Bishop was plainly told that he would not be allowed to meddle in State affairs. Since then affairs have been getting worse and worse between the civil and Church dignitaries, till BARRIOS has been compelled to exile the Bishop, who has gone to Guatemala. Another high churchman has fled to Panama, and the priests all over the country are packing up to make tracks. Salvador has always been a good deal priest-ridden, and there would be considerable danger of a revolution were it not that BARRIOS is a military man, and flatters his soldiers and officers, and pays them before anybody else is paid.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMANN, James Killery, an Irishman, about 40 years of age, was put on trial for the murder of his wife, Margaret, by beating her with a stick, at the corner of Eighty-first-street and Eighth-avenue, on the 1st of October last. The victim died on the 13th of October at the Bellevue Hospital, from a premature delivery, said to have been produced by injuries inflicted by the accused. The case occupied the entire day, and will be resumed this morning.

The case occupied the entire day, and will be resumed this morning.

abstract: As the details of the conflagration at Charleston begin to reach us, we are able to form some idea of how complete is the ruin that has fallen on that rebellious city. Five hundred and seventy-six buildings, representing a property of seven million dollars, are reported as having been destroyed on Wednesday alone.
lead_paragraph: As the details of the conflagration at Charleston begin to reach us, we are able to form some idea of how complete is the ruin that has fallen on that rebellious city. Five hundred and seventy-six buildings, representing a property of seven million dollars, are reported as having been destroyed on Wednesday alone. And as on the following night, whetherIllinois passed Charleston, the fire was still raging, the imagination does not so much take the direction of asking what has been consumed, as what can have been left unconsumedamid the general conflagration.

abstract: The Connecticut combines with her capacity as a transport ship strength and staunchness enough to make her quite formidable as a vessel of war. She is pierced for six guns, and is, therefore, fully able to relieve the monotony of her peaceful carrying avocation with occasional dashes after prizes, or a brush now and then with a rebel privateer.
lead_paragraph: The Connecticut combines with her capacity as a transport ship strength and staunchness enough to make her quite formidable as a vessel of war. She is pierced for six guns, and is, therefore, fully able to relieve the monotony of her peaceful carrying avocation with occasional dashes after prizes, or a brush now and then with a rebel privateer. During her late cruise she did not chance to meet with any of the latter kind of customers, but she fell in with prizes, and must, by their capture, have earned plenty of spending money for her officers and crew. She overhauled altogether fourteen suspicious-looking craft, some of which she warned, driving off others, and laying violent hands on two, the Adelaide and Zealand, taking them into Key West, where the Adelaide, on unquestionable evidence, was of course condemned. Both vessels were sailing under British colors, and were caught in the act of trying to run the blockade. The Adelaide had a valuable cargo, consisting of a great quantity of sugar, some thirty tons of coffee and some small arms, mostly sabres. The Zealand seemed to be only in ballast, but it was shrewdly suspected, by Capt. WOODHULL and the Prize Commissioners, that she had, when she found herself in peril of capture, dumped overboard everything of any worth that she had aboard. It was impossible, under the circumstances, to bring forward enough legal evidence to insure her confiscation, and the Commissioners had to discharge her.

abstract: By the Constitution, which touched at Havana en route to Boston, we receive our files of Havana papers and highly important corrrespondence from Mexico. The news from Havana is destitute of importance. From Mexico we learn that the ulti
lead_paragraph: By the Constitution, which touched at Havana en route to Boston, we receive our files of Havana papers and highly important corrrespondence from Mexico. The news from Havana is destitute of importance. From Mexico we learn that the ultimatums of France and England had been presented to the Mexican Government, and on the 21st ult. a treaty had been celebrated conceding the English demands. On the 22d this treaty was sent to Congress for ratification, where it was rejected by a decided vote; the objection turning to the requirement common to both the French and English ultimatums, that the Custom Houses should be placed in charge of Foreign Commissioners. It was feared this demand would be fatal to negotiation, it being considered as opening a fatal door to the destruction of Mexican independence. To show a disposition to comply in other respects, Congress at once authorized the President to lower the rate of duties, an authority he alone exercised; and also abolished the obnoxious law of July 17, thereby placing the foreign debts in course of immediate payment. On the 24th, Sir CHARLES WYKE sent in his ultimatum, upon the rejection of which he was to withdraw and leave the Mexican Government to the consequences of its obstinacy, but up to the close of our correspondent's letter, the final answer of the JUAREZ Cabinet had not been received. The French Minister had already terminated his negotiations. Against Spain the National resentment was fearful. Gen. URAGA had been placed in command of the region between the capital and Vera Cruz, and was about to leave with his army for Jalapa. Gen. ORTEGA would probably be commissioned, and sent to hold the lower road, by way of Orizaba, while Gen. TAPIA was instructed to put the neighborhood of Tampico in a state of defence. The Mexican Extraordinary reports that outrages against resident Spaniards were of constant occurrence. Mr. CORWIN was recovering from his late illness, and was using every energy to maintain peace. An agent of the Southern Confederacy was imprisoned at the capital for assaulting a loyal citizen of the United States.

abstract: The United States vs. One Case marked U.H.B.D., containing watches. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the goods on the ground of undervaluation with intent to evade the payment of duties. The goods were imported in October, 1860, on board the Vanderbilt, by the claimant, Bernard Daws. The Government gave testimony to show that the watches were undervalued in the invoice some 330 francs, or over ten per cent. The claimant gave evidence tending to show the accuracy of the invoice. The amount of difference in the duty between the invoice value and that put upon the goods by the Appraisers, was less than five dollars.

abstract: As the transport steamer New-Brunswick, having on board the Eleventh Connecticut Regiment, was proceeding down the harbor last Tuesday night' on her way to Annapolis, the Revenue cutter fired a blank shot to bring her to. This warning was not heeded by the pilot, whereupon the cutter sent up signal rockets, and when the steamer had reached the Narrows, a shot was fired from Fort Hamilton, strik-...
lead_paragraph: As the transport steamer New-Brunswick, having on board the Eleventh Connecticut Regiment, was proceeding down the harbor last Tuesday night' on her way to Annapolis, the Revenue cutter fired a blank shot to bring her to. This warning was not heeded by the pilot, whereupon the cutter sent up signal rockets, and when the steamer had reached the Narrows, a shot was fired from Fort Hamilton, striking the supports of the steamer's walking-beam, and, in the rebound, falling into a state-room, which, fortunately, was not occupied at the time. The soldiers were at a loss to undesrtand the import of the iron messenger, and were much surprised that the first gun should be from a United States fort. No damage was done to the machinery of the vessel. The Captain is a stranger to this port, and was not aware of the Revenue cutter's mission, but certainly no excuse can be offered on the part of the pilot for not immediately attending to the signal.

abstract: A Cabinet meeting was held to-day, at which the English question was discussed of course informally, as the nature of the dispatches brought by the Royal messenger have not been divulged.
lead_paragraph: A Cabinet meeting was held to-day, at which the English question was discussed -- of course informally, as the nature of the dispatches brought by the Royal messenger have not been divulged. There was but one sentiment prevalent, and that was that no quarrel with England must be permitted to interfere at this moment to stay the reduction of the Southern rebels. The Government is probably satisfied that the clamor for a war with England originates with, and is propagated by, sympathizers with the Southern rebellion. It knows that nothing would so gratify the rebels; would so restore their vanishing confidence, and reinvigorate them to redoubled efforts at defence, as the news that England is to be permitted to come to their rescue. It believes it has no right to give new life to the rebellion by entering upon another and vaster quarrel, which would at the same time increase tenfold the burdens upon the people of the North; and it naturally hesitates to adopt a policy which would carry joy to every traitor in the country, and weigh down to poverty the loyal and law-observing citizen. But whether these or other considerations govern in the matter, I have the best authority for saying the demands of England will be met in a spirit of conciliation, which will at once refute the calumny that Mr. SEWARD or any other member of the Cabinet has been eager to provoke a foreign war. The intelligence received by the Jura, that the dispatches with which SLIDELL and MASON were intrusted reached England, notwithstanding their arrest, renders the question as to the disposition of the persons of the rebel envoys one of secondary moment, and a most inadequate one on which to base a great international struggle. It will be borne in mind that the Administration is still uncommitted on the Trent business. The subject was not mentioned in the President's Message: and the language of Secretary WELLES, in his report and his letter to Capt. WILKES, are rather professional and personal than diplomatic, and in no degree bind the State Department. Of one thing the public may rest assured, the subject will not be settled without an important curtailment of the English pretensions to enforce a right of search, which she finds it so unpalatable to concede to other Powers.

abstract: In the Senate, after the presentations of petitions amoug which were the usual number relating to the question of Slavery Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, offered a resolution, which was laid over, asking by what authority Gen. PHELPS' proclamation to the people of the Southwest was issued. A bill for the collection of direct taxes in the rebellious States was introduced by Mr. DOOLITTLE of Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, after the presentations of petitions -- among which were the usual number relating to the question of Slavery -- Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, offered a resolution, which was laid over, asking by what authority Gen. PHELPS' proclamation to the people of the Southwest was issued. A bill for the collection of direct taxes in the rebellious States was introduced by Mr. DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin. It provides for the seizure and sale of lands. Mr. SUMNER introduced a resolution for the expulsion of Senator POLK, of Missouri, which was referred to the Judiciary Committee. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into the condition of the military hospitals. The Kansas contested-election case was taken up, but, after some debate, was recommitted to the Judiciary Committee, in order that additional testimony might be taken. Senator LANE was yesterday confirmed as Brigadier-General, and it is understood that he will enter upon his military duties as soon as his case is disposed of finally. The resolution offered by Mr. SUMNER, that the soldiers shall not be used as slave-catchers, was taken up, and agreed to after some discussion. Mr. LATHAM's resolution, inquiring why passports were required to be taken out by passengers to California, was also passed.

lead_paragraph: We have an intimation from Washington this morning of the policy which will probably be pursued by our Government in the Trent affair. A Cabinet meeting was held yesterday, at which the whole matter was discussed, though informally, as neither the Queen's Messenger nor the one from Minister ADAMS had arrived at the time the meeting was held. The sentiment prevalent is understood to have been that no quarrel with England must be permitted to interfere with putting down the rebellion. The demands of England, whatever they may be, will be met in a spirit of conciliation, in marked contrast to the precipitancy with which she has sought to make the seizure of the rebel envoys a casus belli.

abstract: By the Jura, which arrived at Portland yesterterday, we receive two days later European news. The excitement in regard to the Trent affair continues unabated throughout England. BRIGHT and COBDEN
lead_paragraph: By the Jura, which arrived at Portland yesterterday, we receive two days later European news. The excitement in regard to the Trent affair continues unabated throughout England. Large military and naval preparations are going on, and the exportation of arms and munitions of war to the United States has been prohibited. In the midst of the popular clamor, Messrs. BRIGHT and COBDEN have made an appeal for peace, but it seems to be disregarded. The French Press, acting, doubtless, under Imperial instruction, have become reserved on the subject of the dispute. They no longer openly coincide in the British view of the case. This, taken in conjunction with the fact that a number of French men-of-war have been ordered to be prepared immediately for sea, is somewhat significant. Some Paris correspondents are disposed to believe that France is not actuated by the friendliest motives for England; others think that the Emperor is willing to and mediator between England and America, and that he has fobidden all discussion of the matter by the Ministerial Press, in order that he may be able to assume hereafter the position of an impartial arbitrator.

abstract: WILKES has given the English an interpretation of their own principles of international law which they don't relish, that is no reason why they should murder his name whenever they have occasion to write it. All their journals, from the Times and Saturday Review to Punch, persist in writing it docked as to the e. thus -- WILKS! Now, besides that they have the orthography of the word in every American paper, it certainly argues themselves unknown not to be familiar with the name of the commander of one of the most successful of Exploring expeditions. We shall next have our Gallic friends sending it back to us in their curious spelling as VILKS! Now, we don't much care how thoroughly those people violate all their pretended neutrality. Do your worst; give aid and comfort to the enemy -- harbor their pirates; but don't, in the name of Cadmus, offend our eyes with such a villainous cacography as WILKS!

abstract: The work of the Secessionist precipitators seems to have been less thoroughly done in Tennessee than in some other quarters. From every part of that State indications of a strong Union sentiment not only existing but preparing to assert itself, reach us through unquestionable channels; and exhibit the probability ...
lead_paragraph: The work of the Secessionist precipitators seems to have been less thoroughly done in Tennessee than in some other quarters. From every part of that State indications of a strong Union sentiment not only existing but preparing to assert itself, reach us through unquestionable channels; and exhibit the probability of a reaction which, even without National aid, may sever that gallant State from the rebel confederation. That loyalty to the Union is the fashion in East Tennessee, we have had, first and last, sufficient evidence. The plans of DAVIS and his cabal found little favor there from the outset. Faithful to the traditions of JACKSON, the population cherished a veteran hatred of nullification and its posterity, and regarded South Carolina, always restless, ambitious and mischievous, with incurable aversion. These sentiments found expression through such newspapers as BROWNLOW's, and the oratory of JOHNSON, NELSON and MAYNARD. When, therefore, the engines of rebel terrorism were brought to bear upon the East Tennesseeans, in order to force them into a vote for the ordinance of secession, the machinery, so infallible elsewhere, was at fault. East Tennessee remained for the Union; and in the multitudes of refugees it has sent to the North; in the other multitudes it has contributed to the National army in Kentucky; and, above all, in the heroic labors of BROWNLOW and his band, upon whose success at Morristown doubt has very unjustly been cast, we may see how inextinguishable is the zeal of these consistent patriots.

abstract: The recent Mumfordsville engagement, considering the disproportion of numbers, proves the most brilliant National victory yet achieved. Four companies, of about 350 men, of Col. WALLACH'S regiment, led by the Lieutenant-Colonel, drove back over 3,000 rebel cavalry, artillery and infantry. They were first attacked by a regiment of Texas cavalry, whom they repulsed and followed, when they were drawn into ambush, and fired at from all sides by rebel infantry.

abstract: The very important news from Mexico which, together with the projected Convention between Her Britannic Majesty and the Mexican Republic, we published in this journal, exclusively, yesterday, shows that the President and Congress of Mexico are willing to do all in their power to satisfy the legitimate demands of France and England. Mr. WYKE, the English Minister, submitted to the Government of Mexico an ultimatum composed of three conditions -- two of which were at once agreed to by the Government, while on the third, relating to interference with the Custom-collections, no action had yet been taken, though concession on that point was regarded as a virtual surrender of independence. The French Minister's ultimatum embraced five points -- four of which the Mexican Government stood ready to concede. The fifth article, relating to "ample satisfaction for alleged insults offered to the Minister at a street squabble," could hardly be agreed to by Mexico; for the reason that previous legal investigation had shown that the Minister himself was really the offending party in the row. In regard to the preposterous demands of Spain, the Mexican Government would and could make no concessions. Mexico has thus done all in her power, in the desperate straits in which she is placed, to satisfy and conciliate England and France; while her old enemy, Spain, she knows to be irreconcilcable by any argument but force.

abstract: Col. MULLIGAN, the heroic defender of Lexington, received a warm welcome at the hands of the citizens of New-York yesterday. While at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, he was waited upon by many of our prominent public men and cordially greeted. About noon, he was escorted to the Governor's Room by a delegation of the Common Council, consisting of Aldermen CORNELL, BOOLE and DAYTON, and Councilmen HAZLETON, GROSS and RYAN, who had been appointed for that purpose. The Colonel was formally welcomed to the City by Mayor WOOD, who felicitously alluded to the distinguished services of the City's guest, on behalf of the Union cause in the West. Col. MULLIGAN responded, modestly expressing the hope that he should yet do something to compensate for the high honor paid him by the City of New-York, and the belief that the cause of the Union and the Constitution would yet be triumphant.

abstract: A MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE. -- BRIDGET HUGHES, a widow woman, left her home on the 6th inst., and has not since been seen by her family. She resided with a sister on Grand-avenue, near Myrtle-avenue, and left with the avowed intention of going to the Catholic Church in Jay-street.

abstract: The few hours' additional intelligence brought by the Jura shows a rapid subsidence of the popular excitement in England. The tone of the Press is less recklessly defiant, and such organs of the Liberal party as the London Daily News, the London Star, and the Mannchester Examiner, take a generous and conciliatory view of the cause of agitation. The News in its earlier article was unconditionally for war.
lead_paragraph: The few hours' additional intelligence brought by the Jura shows a rapid subsidence of the popular excitement in England. The tone of the Press is less recklessly defiant, and such organs of the Liberal party as the London Daily News, the London Star, and the Mannchester Examiner, take a generous and conciliatory view of the cause of agitation. The News in its earlier article was unconditionally for war. It is now reported as approving of the spirit and purport of a letter of Gen. SCOTT, wherein the veteran affirms the legality of the act of Capt. WILKES, but acquits the Washington authorities of having ordered it, and as expressing a belief that a collision may still be avoided, if the same spirit and purpose animate the Secretary of State. These changes of sentiment were to be expected. It must be kept in mind that the information upon which the first action of the British Government was founded was entirely one-sided, and stated so grossly to the disadvantage of the United States, that it would have been marvelous indeed if the resentment of the British people had not been provoked to the utmost limit. Every subsequent arrival from America has tended to correct these injurious impressions. The action of Capt. WILKES, it has been found, was taken upon his individual responsibility, and cannot therefore be ascribed to that wanton craving for a foreign war, which the London journals persist in ascribing to the administration of President LINCOLN. They have found the failure of Capt. WILKES to capture the steamer -- which when the dispatches now known to have been on board had been discovered, would have been a lawful prize, -- was due to his desire to exhibit every possible courtesy and favor to the ship, its officers and passengers. They have read the President's Message at the opening of Congress, and found that while the people universally commended Capt. WILKES, on the assumption that he had kept clearly within the law, the President carefully refrained from committing himself; so that there is no evidence that what the Administration did not order it has since approved. The knowledge of these points cannot fail to moderate very sensibly the first extreme ardor of English passion, and even before the response of our Government to the demands of Lord RUSSELL returns to England, we may confidently anticipate an entire disappearance there of the warlike fever which at first ran wild over the country. John Bull, proud, sensitive, irate, at the first impulse, recovers his love for fair play at the second.

abstract: The trial of CHARLES M. JEFFERDS for the murder of JOHN W. MATTHEWS, who, it will be recollected, was shot while pursuing the murderer of JOHN WALTON, on the night of June 30, 1860, was commenced in the Court of Sessions, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, On the trial of the Walton murder, in July last, JEFFERDS was acquitted, but new evidence having since come into the hands of the District Attorney, he was rearrested, and indicted for the murder of MATTHEWS. The evidence taken yesterday was substantially the same as on the Walton trial, but it is expected that new evidence will be introduced to-day.

abstract: most inopportune moment just now to bring up for settlement in Congress those incidental and abstract questions concerning Slavery and negroes, the practical solution of which must depend entirely upon the course of events, and which can be decided so much more wisely at a future time. One honorable Senator the other day not only presented a batch of petitions for the abolition of Slavery, but introduced a resolution of inquiry, whether any additional legislation is necessary to secure persons of African descent the right to take out patents. No one, surely, can object to an African patenting whatever he may invent; but it can hardly be possible that the inventive genius of that irrepressible race has suddenly burst forth with such vehemence as to demand that the Senate, at the present crisis should occupy itself in such discussions. Moreover, bringing up such questions as this, just now only irritates and annoys members from the Border Slave States, without the slightest good result. If members of Congress will only leave over the problem of African patent rights and other African rights and wrongs, till they meet next session, it is likely that events will have done much to make their solution clear and easy.
