abstract: The report of Col. HARVEY BROWN, representing the comparative uselessness of his smooth-bore guns as against the rifled guns of the rebels, in the late action at Fort Pickens, will, of course, receive the attention which it demands of the Ordnance Department. It was not necessary, however, to await the result of a battle in order to reach Col. BROWN'S conclusions.
lead_paragraph: The report of Col. HARVEY BROWN, representing the comparative uselessness of his smooth-bore guns as against the rifled guns of the rebels, in the late action at Fort Pickens, will, of course, receive the attention which it demands of the Ordnance Department. It was not necessary, however, to await the result of a battle in order to reach Col. BROWN's conclusions. The theory of the rifle projectile -- the perpetual correction of the deviation of the projectile, due to its irregularities of surface and weight, by revolving it on its own axis -- proclaims the fact, and all practice establishes the vastly superior range and accuracy of the rifled cannon.

abstract: The trial of Charles M. Jefferds for the murder of John W. Matthews commenced in the Court of Sessions, before Recorder HOFFMAN, yesterday, at noon. This is the second time that Jefferds has been put on trial in connection with this remarkable double murder, the first trial, which was for the murder of Walton, having taken place in July last, and resulted in a verdict of acquittal. As the prisoner is the only person who has ever been arrested for, or even suspected by the prosecuting authorities of the commission of the crime, the present trial will, doubtless, clear up the mystery that has hung about the case, or else consign it forever to the long catalogue of horrible murders, whose undiscovered and unpunished perpetrators are a living contradiction of the popular notion that "murder will out." Since the acquittal of Jefferds, in July last, for the murder of Walton, it is understood that new evidence has come into the hands of the District-Attorney tending to establish his guilt; but what the nature of the evidence is was not divulged yesterday, further than what was contained in an intimation of the District-Attorney, in opening the case, that it rested on the confessions of the prisoner himself. The evidence taken thus far is substantially the same as that given at the Coroner's inquest, and subsequently on the trial for the murder of Walton.

abstract: The London Times, in its latest article on the Trent affair, goes the length to assert that "that sort of irregularity has often formed the occasion of war." Probably this is only meant as a sounding piece of British bluster, for, as a historical statement, it...
lead_paragraph: The London Times, in its latest article on the Trent affair, goes the length to assert that "that sort of irregularity has often formed the occasion of war." Probably this is only meant as a sounding piece of British bluster, for, as a historical statement, it is rather too audacious for even that wanton journal to make. There are no instances in the history of enlightened nations in which a war has been originated by a single event -- a single demand in the form of an ultimatum. It is said, however, that England has sent such an ultimatum to the Government of the United States in the case of MASON and SLIDELL -- demanding the delivery to British protection of the persons of the rebel emissaries, or -- war! Certainly, whatever be the nature of the instructions which the Queen's messenger has conveyed to Her Britannic Majesty's representative at Washington, the English journals have not scrupled to flaunt this defiant ultimatum in the face of America, and have gone on to discuss how, in the event of our refusal to comply with a demand for the surrender of the prisoners, our fleet is to be swept from the seas in a week, our blockade of the Southern ports raised, and our own ports blockaded.

abstract: Not one of the least remarkable events in our great contest with the rebellion was the accident of the seizure of Messrs. SLIDELL
lead_paragraph: Not one of the least remarkable events in our great contest with the rebellion was the accident of the seizure of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON from the deck of a British steamer from which act, in the active imaginations of some of our people, loomed up a war vastly greater in its proportions than the colossal one already in hand. In the opposite quarter of the heavens arose another cloud twice as portentous as that which had darkened the horizon. It is not to be wondered at that excessive alarm should, for a day or two, prevail; for no event has happened since the breaking out of the war, which has given the secession element, with which every pore of New-York society is saturated, such power for mischief. Every traitor among us was instantly converted into a flaming patriot, burning to maintain the honor of the country, and eager to defend the act of Capt. WILKES with the last drop of his blood. At the same instant, the inevitableness of the war, with its terrible consequences, was painted in the most frightful colors, and insinuated into the ears of the timid with all the cunning that the most devilish ingenuity and hate against the North could devise. From such arts, coupled with exaggerated rumors, upon the first arrivals of the late steamers, how set afloat we will not now inquire, and with the complications between the Banks and the Government, yesterday was altogether a blue day in our calendar.

abstract: The British ship Cheshire, of Liverpool, England, Capt. CRAIG, from Liverpool, Oct. 10, and Belfast 19th, vid Savannah Bar 6th inst., arrived at this port this morning, in charge of a prize crew, and in command of Prize-Master HEATH, of the United States steamer Augusta, Capt. PARROTT. The Cheshire was discovered on tho 6th inst. off Tybee Island, in six...
lead_paragraph: The British ship Cheshire, of Liverpool, England, Capt. CRAIG, from Liverpool, Oct. 10, and Belfast 19th, vid Savannah Bar 6th inst., arrived at this port this morning, in charge of a prize crew, and in command of Prize-Master HEATH, of the United States steamer Augusta, Capt. PARROTT. The Cheshire was discovered on tho 6th inst. off Tybee Island, in six fathoms water, and upon being boarded it was found that she had cleared for Nassau, N.P., and that her cargo consisted of coffee, salt and army blankets, which was deemed very suspicious. Upon questioning her captain as to why -- if he was bound to Nassau -- he should be found in that locality, he replied that he had received instructions at Liverpool to speak the blockading squadron, but for what purpose it was not made known. Not deeming it safe to allow her to proceed, and as the replies were not satisfactory, she was towed to Charleston by the United States steamer Augusta, Capt. PARROTT. The movements of this vessel were reported to the Navy Department some time since by the American Consul at Liverpool. She exchanged the American for the British flag in England. A letter from Commander PARROTT, of the Augusta, addressed to Commodore PAULDING, Commandant at the Navy-yard, says:

abstract: ness of Great Britain in forbidding, upon the first alarm of a war, the exportation of arms and the constituents of gunpowder, presents an example which it is advisable to imitate in this country. We are informed that the purchases of ship timber in the United States for the British Admiralty have been so heavy as nearly to clear the market; and vast quantities are actually stored here, awaiting transportation. Owing to the war, the supplies of live-oak timber, which came from the South, have been cut off. The Virginia sources have also been practically closed, and at this moment, when Congress is about to urge the most energetic measures for doubling the navy, it is almost impossible for the American shipbuilder to find material for a single vessel. To stop this exhaustion of our strength for the benefit of a foreign, and possibly a hostile Power, will not be the dictate of a retaliatory policy, but of a policy which looks to the safety of our own people before that of the stranger. The Government cannot act in the matter too early.

We are informed that the purchases of ship timber in the United States for the British Admiralty have been so heavy as nearly to clear the market; and vast quantities are actually stored here, awaiting transportation. Owing to the war, the supplies of live-oak timber, which came from the South, have been cut off. The Virginia sources have also been practically closed, and at this moment, when Congress is about to urge the most energetic measures for doubling the navy, it is almost impossible for the American shipbuilder to find material for a single vessel. To stop this exhaustion of our strength for the benefit of a foreign, and possibly a hostile Power, will not be the dictate of a retaliatory policy, but of a policy which looks to the safety of our own people before that of the stranger. The Government cannot act in the matter too early.

abstract: The Mexican intelligence which we published yesterday led us to hope that England, at least, was disposed to come to terms with the Republic. The appointment of Sir CHARLES WYKE to negotiate a treaty with the Juarez Administration, and the signing of that instrument by the British representative, certainly seemed fair indications of the amicable proclivities of the Palmerston Government, and fully justified the conclusion that the difficulties still pending would be ultimately surmounted. But an article whichwe have copied from the latest received number of the London Morning Post -- the Premier's pet organ -- constrains us to suspect that the Wyke diplomacy has not been undertaken in good faith, and that its real object is to throw Mexico off her guard! The article in question deals at length with the Mexican imbroglio, and enumerates carefully all England's causes of complaint against the ingrate commonwealth. "By Mexico," it says, "we have long been treated with the worst ingratitude. We succored her in her struggle for independence; we lent her money, to the extent of some ten millions sterling, to establish her Government; and she repaid us by a long suspension of the claims of British bondholders to dividends; by the deliberate robbery of their money that lay under the seal of our Legation, and by the ill-usage of British residents in her territory." Well, Mexico admits all these wrongs, and is ready to make ample reparation for them; but the journalist will not hear of an amicable arrangement. Timet Danaos et dona ferentes. He was aware, indeed, when he indited the article under consideration, that Sir CHARLES WYKE had been authorized to treat with Mexico, and that he had become a party to a Convention, which conceded all England's requirements -- yet what of that? Though England would have been bound in honor to abide by that Convention had it been ratified by the Mexican Congress, the redacteur of the Post would not have it so. This newspaper essayist has no respect for good faith or treaty obligations! "The attempt," exclaims he, "to stave off our active interference, and to separate us from our allies, is vain. We shall not accept the proffered satisfaction; and our fleet, with those of France and Spain, will proceed to seize upon the ports and custom duties of Mexico!"

abstract: That there should be a crowded audience, wherever and whenever the brilliant Boston orator is announced to speak, is to be expected; but that an assembly of the number and character that filled the Cooper Institute last evening, composed of the most respectable citizens of all parties -- many accompaniedby their wives and daughters -- should brave the anticipations of riot and disturbance, which the Herald has been so ready to announce, and eager to promote, was a compliment to Mr. PHILIPS' attractive eloquence, as significant, as proof of the low estimation in which the veracity or influence of that journal is held.

abstract: If the old mischief-maker of the Herald were capable of shame or abasement, he would be visited with daily pangs of that sort in view of his utter impotence to make mischief. He has labored zealously for days to excite a riot on the occasion of Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS addressing a popular audience on the war. Every incendiary appeal that could be made to the passions of the mob was uttered, and repeated in every issue. Mr. PHILLIPS accordingly made his speech last evening to a vast multitude, who only interrupted the speaker with outbursts of approval and applause; and the Herald has a new proof that its slanders are the highest indorsement of the purity of those it assails, and that even the mob systematically reverses its recommendations.

abstract: Judge HOLLINGSWORTH, a well-known and prominent citizen of Todd County, arrived here yesterday, having succeeded, after considerable difficulty, in getting through the rebel lines. Todd County is southwest of Bowling Green, and on the railroad  from that place to Memphis. The Judge has been there ever since the rebel forces entered Kentucky, and has had every opportunity for ascertaining the true state of affairs in that entire region.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFORT, Ky., Saturday, Dec. 14, 1861.

abstract: The Defence, 22,600 horse power, 3,668, tons, is still in dock at Chatham, but from the energy now shown in fitting her, and the number of hands employed about her, a very short time only will elaspe before she is ready for sea. Her crew will be sent to her immediately, and during the time the vessel is being completed they will be employed at Chatham in preparing the screw-frigate Galatea, 20,800 horse-power, for sea. The necessary provision is to be made at Chatham for their accommodation.

abstract: At 10 o'clock this morning, a rebel battery of three guns, flanked with about two hundred infantry, suddenly commenced shelling the encampment of Col. GEARY'S Pennsylvania Regiment. About twenty shells, well aimed, fell amidst the encampment, the first within a few feet of Lieut.-Col. DE KORPONAY, commanding. The six companies in camp were well deployed and intrenched.
lead_paragraph: POINT OF ROCKS, Thursday, Dec. 19.

abstract: In the Senate, Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, presented a number of petitions, numerously signed, for the emancipation of the slaves, loyal masters to be compensated. A petition was presented by Mr. WADE from citizens of Ohio, asking for the appointment of Gen. FREMONT as Lieutenant-General. Mr. WILLEY, of Virginia, offered a resolution, which he accompanied with a speech, that the war has been forced upon the country by the rebels without provocation, with the purpose of destroying the Union and the Constitution, and ultimately the democratic form of government. The resolution of the House to adjourn until the 6th of January was taken up, and debated until the Senate found itself without a quorum, when, of course, nothing was done with it.

abstract: IST. -- In the Independent, of the current week, is announced an important change in the editorial force of that paper. Messrs. BACON, THOMPSON, and STORRS, who have controlled it editorially from the outset, while they do not cease to contribute to its columns, surrender the editorial responsibility into the hands of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, who will be Editor-in-chief. Rev. JOSHUA LEAVITT, and Mr. THEODORE TILTON, whose indefatigable and valuable labors as assistants have effected so much for the prosperity of the journal, will continue their relations with it.

abstract: The terms and exact character of the instructions sent out to Lord LYONS are kept a close secret but we learn that amongst those persons in London likely to have the best means of judging, there is a general belief that the amount and form of the reparation which our Government has felt bound to demand are such as the American Government is not likely to concede. The most likely, or rather least unlikely, chance of an amicable settlement, so far as can at present be seen, is considered to be that the Senate, in which there is a majority strongly opposed to Mr. Seward, may, were it only to overthrow him, declare for redress and conciliation.

abstract: marked M. & Co. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the goods for an alleged undervaluation with intent to evade payment of duty. The Government gave testimony to show that the goods were imported by the firm of Macias & Cayonare, of this City, who presented an invoice of the goods, setting forth that they weighed 1,224 pounds, and were worth 20 cents a pound. They also showed that the goods, though worth only 20 cents a pound, actually weighed 1,800 pounds, thus making an undervaluation of the goods.

abstract: Taking Hilton Head for the base of operations, the army and navy are conjointly making a series of strategic moves which must, sooner or later, bring South Carolina and Georgia to their fealty. So soon as the foothold here was made secure Tybee Island was seized and held, and now other operations are in progress for a flank advance upon Savannah. Charleston, too, is receiving a share of attention.
lead_paragraph: HILTON HEAD, S.C., Friday, Dec. 13, 1861.

abstract: At every step of our naval operations, we get new demonstration of the immense utility of that great National undertaking, the United States Coast Survey. In the latest expedition, that to Ship Island, the only guides the commander had in the dangerous navigation off the Florida reefs, were the "day-marks" of beakons left by the of ficers of the Survey.
lead_paragraph: At every step of our naval operations, we get new demonstration of the immense utility of that great National undertaking, the United States Coast Survey. In the latest expedition, that to Ship Island, the only guides the commander had in the dangerous navigation off the Florida reefs, were the "day-marks" of beakons left by the of ficers of the Survey. The Port Royal Expedition owed its success in no slight degree to a gentleman attached to this corps, Capt. BOUTELLK, who brought to bear the profound knowledge of the region he had gained in the course of some years triangulation and hydrographic operations. And we can easily permit the rebels to do their worst in the way of removing buoys and destroying light-ships and light-houses, when we can send on our expeditions the very men who performed the original surveys.
headline: {'main': 'What the Coast Survey is Doing for Us.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What the Coast Survey is Doing for Us.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is noticeable, but not in the least strange, that those journals and men who have been most in sympathy with the rebels, should be most eager for war with England. They have all at once a terribly keen sense of national honor. They were exceedingly tolerant of in-...
lead_paragraph: It is noticeable, but not in the least strange, that those journals and men who have been most in sympathy with the rebels, should be most eager for war with England. They have all at once a terribly keen sense of national honor. They were exceedingly tolerant of insults to our flag when they came from Southern rebels, -- and when they involved merely the overthrow of the Constitution, the disruption of the Union, and the permanent destruction of our national integrity and life. But the slightest hint that England questions, in any particular, the perfect propriety of our proceedings, arouses all their courage, and demands an immediate declaration of war.

abstract: It is just a year ago to-day since the first State Ordinance of Secession was passed, and South Carolina declared the National Union forever dissolved. The day is to be commemorated in that State, and probably in other parts of the South, and it is hoped to make the 20th of December in the new Republic what the 4th of July has been in the old Republic Independence Day.
lead_paragraph: It is just a year ago to-day since the first State Ordinance of Secession was passed, and South Carolina declared the National Union forever dissolved. The day is to be commemorated in that State, and probably in other parts of the South, and it is hoped to make the 20th of December in the new Republic what the 4th of July has been in the old Republic--Independence Day. So far as South Carolina is concerned, the year's retrospect and the anniversary must be sufficiently melancholy. It has been for her, as for the whole country, a year of gloom and calamity; and it now looks as though for her it would be followed by a year of disaster and woe compared with which the disastrous record of the past is light and trivial. Could South Carolina a year ago have foreseen this anniversary as she now sees it, even she might have paused in her devilish career, and stayed the hand that cleft the Union in twain, and brought upon the nation war and its unnumbered woes. The day must seem to her but the first anniversary of her ruin.
headline: {'main': 'A Year of Secession.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Year of Secession.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: NANTUCKET, Dec. 17. -- The schr. Stella, of Halifax, N.S., from Boston for Halifax, with a cargo of cornmeal, ran on the Raps, to the westward of these Islands, beat over, and is now in our harbor, leaking some 600 strokes per hour. Will haul on the ways for repairs.

abstract: The ladies of this Society are now holding their fifth Annual Fair in the Lecture-room of their church, at the corner of Hammond-street and Waverley-place. The plan of their operations is to give work to the poor of their own parish at living prices, and Thursday being appointed for their meetings, upon which day many poor families are relieved, often becoming the recipient of the article which they have just completed. The proceeds of this Fair will be used to further such a plan of benevolence, and also to support the church, which is free, and numbers a large attendance. During the past Summer one thousand garments were made up and distributed to our volunteers by this society, independent of the home charities. Last year $500 were cleared, and the prospects are equally fair for this year's success. An Industrial School is kept up under the auspices of Rev. E.R.T. COOK, the pastor, assisted by several of his lady parishioners, and specimens of the improved condition of the little scholars are visible in the collection of substantial needle work, which is exhibited upon one of the tables, and in the appearance of large patchwork quills hung against the wall. Union lanterns are hung the whole length of the room, and the general effect is very brilliant, while the articles sell at reasonable prices.

abstract: The sloops of-war Macedonian and Constellation have been ordered to be refitted and cruise in foreign seas, for the protection of American commerce. The Constellation is a 22-gun sloop, rebuilt at Norfolk in 1854. She was last on duty on the Mediterranean Station in 1857-'58, under the command of Capt. CHAS. H. BELL. She should not require much refuting to make her sea-worthy. The Macedonian, also a 22-gun sloop, was rebuilt at Norfolk in 1836, and has been lying in ordinary at Boston for some time past. She will require a thorough overhauling.

abstract: The following is the weekly statement to theCommissioners of Charities and Corrections; Number on hand Dec. 7, 7,834; admitted since, 1,887; being a total of 9,721; of whom there died, 42; discharged, 1,400; sent to Blackwell's Island, 371; to Sing Sing, 8; total, 1,821; leaving still in charge, 7,900; an increase of 66 over last week. Out of 501 vagrants and disorderly persons committed from 6th to 19th of December 232 had been sent up ten times, 15 thirty times, 10 forty times, 6 fifty times, and 4 had been inmates of the institutions one hundred times.

abstract: LEAVENWORTH, Thursday, Dec. 12, 1861. Nothing more interesting than some drunken  shooting scrapes, among disorderly soldiers, two or three rumors of a fight in Platte County, and the close of a trial for murder, resulting in the conviction and condemnation of the accused parties, have occurred to break the monotonous stir of life here for the last week, until yesterday, when orders were issued placing most of the organized corps under marching orders.

abstract: WALLACK's THEATRE.--A new drama, called "Up at the Hills," was produced here on Thursday  night. It is from the pen of Mr. TOM TAYLOR, and illustrates a phase in East Indian life, in which the ...
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE.--A new drama, called "Up at the Hills," was produced here on Thursday night. It is from the pen of Mr. TOM TAYLOR, and illustrates a phase in East Indian life, in which the army officers of her Brittannic Majesty, in their social relations do not come in for a vast amount of glory. The principal character is a Major -- a blackleg of the better kind, who swindles the verdant cornets of his regiment, and falls even lower than that in a matter of love. Contrasted with this unenviable personality is a lady, Mrs. Col. McCunn, who outwits the polite sharper in all his little schemes, and in the end rescues the lady whom he has schemed to ensnare. The drama depends on these two characters, which are very well drawn, and is therefore somewhat scant in incident. Materials so slight indeed in feebler hands would be uninteresting; carpentered by Mr. TAYLOR they furnish a certain amount of intellectual pleasure to the watchful. The dialogue, without being brilliant, is easy and agreeable. It shows how two well-bred people can light a battle of life and death without a coarse display of temper. In the last act the hand of a master is clearly perceptible, all the nerves of the story being gathered up with surgical accuracy. So excellent is this, that the piece, which somewhat drags in the earlier stages, is completely redeemed, and leaves a favorable impression on the mind. Whether this result is due mainly to the author, or partly to the actors, we shall not now stop to inquire. It is certain that Mrs. HORT plays a very important role, with charming determination of purpose and admirable effect, and that Mr. FISHER has never been seen to greater advantage. Miss HENRIQUES has a spasmodically sentimental part, but succeeds by natural grace and modesty in rescuing it from insipidity. Mr. FLOYD, as Lieut. Greenway, is also excellent. The scenery and appointments we need scarcely add are all that could be desired.

abstract: We recently  chronicled the fact that HOLLINS' ram had gone "through Memphis." The ubiquitous marine Proteus now turns up at the scene of its old exploit, near the mouth of the Mississippi, the very place where erst it broke its nose.
lead_paragraph: We recently chronicled the fact that HOLLINS' ram had gone "through Memphis." The ubiquitous marine Proteus now turns up at the scene of its old exploit, near the mouth of the Mississippi, the very place where erst it broke its nose. The Fortress Monroe correspondent on the Philadelphia Enquirer, writing of an engagement which took place there on the 12th instant, says: "HOLLINS' Turtle or ram was disabled, and the Massachusetts made up the stream to capture her, but found her deserted aground and going to pieces." As we have heard nothing of this pretended engagement we sincerely hope the whole story is a mistake. It would pain us extremely to think that the "ram" should vanish from the world of being; and the thought of it "deserted, aground and going to pieces," would haunt our midnight vision. We have had so much genuine fun out of this marine monster, that in losing it we should lose the one comic element in the war. The country will hold HOLLINS to a severe account if, in allowing aught of harm to reach it, he dry up forever the source of many a side-shaking joke. Evehis Caesarem, said the Roman Emperor to the bark that bore him: so the Falstaffian Commodore, Evchis Hollins -- you bear HOLLINS, and in doing so you bear that in which the whole nation has an interest. We shall hold HOLLINS severely responsible for any damage that may befall the "ram."

abstract: The United States vs. Twelve Bales of Tobacco.--A witness in this case was brought up on an attachment issued against him for failing to appear as a witness in obedience to a subpoena.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Twelve Bales of Tobacco.--A witness in this case was brought up on an attachment issued against him for failing to appear as a witness in obedience to a subpoena. The fuels appeared to be that he was duly subpoenaed for the 17th, and attended on that day, when he was told to come on the 18th. He came on the morning of the 18th, but went away again on his own responsibility, because he thought the case would not be called. He was not subpoened again for the 18th, or paid his fees for that day.

abstract: Peter Lynch vs. Henry Bischoof.--The plaintiff brought his action to compel the defendant to deliver to him, plaintiff, a deed to the premises known as No. 46 Elm-street, in this City, pursuant to a contract, as alleged, made between the parties for the purchase thereof by the plaintiff.
lead_paragraph: Peter Lynch vs. Henry Bischoof.--The plaintiff brought his action to compel the defendant to deliver to him, plaintiff, a deed to the premises known as No. 46 Elm-street, in this City, pursuant to a contract, as alleged, made between the parties for the purchase thereof by the plaintiff. The plaintiff claimed that in September last he contracted with the defendant to make the purchase, for the sum of $6,000, and that, although ready to perform the contract on his part, the defendant refused to deliver a deed of the premises.

abstract: In the Senate, a number of petitions were presented--among them one for the removal of JESSE C. BRIGHT, and one for the establishment of a system of exchanging prisoners. A joint resolution from the Military Committee recognizing the ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, a number of petitions were presented--among them one for the removal of JESSE C. BRIGHT, and one for the establishment of a system of exchanging prisoners. A joint resolution from the Military Committee recognizing the services of the deceased Gen. LYON, was passed. The House bill for the relief of the owners of the British ship Perthshire, was temporarily laid on the table. The bill to abolish the United States Supreme Court was reported back from the Judiciary Committee, which was discharged from further consideration of the matter. A bill further to prohibit the sale of liquor to soldiers in the District of Columbia was passed. The resolution presented by Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, calling upon the Secretary of War for a copy of Gen. PHELPS' Proclamation, was taken up and discussed, and finally laid on the table. Mr. WILLEY, of Virginia, then resumed and concluded his speech, commenced on Thursday, and after an Executive session the Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: We are very glad to see  that the public scandal to which we lately called the attention of the authorities--the so-called "Concert Saloons" of Broadway-- was yesterday made the subject of a presentment by the Grand Jury.
lead_paragraph: We are very glad to see that the public scandal to which we lately called the attention of the authorities--the so-called "Concert Saloons" of Broadway-- was yesterday made the subject of a presentment by the Grand Jury. This document, which gives a forcible expose of the true character of these obscene dens, will go before the Legislature on its assembling, in January, with the request for legislation thereanent, for it seems that existing laws are inadequate for the suppression of these nuisances. The attempt made, some time ago, to extinguish them by imposing a heavy theatrical license, proved a failure, the extraordinary profits of these infamous resorts enabling them not only to stand this burden, but to pay large and in some cases enormous salaries to their "artistes." as they call them. The system of police descents in vogue a year or two, for a similar, though less shameless class of establishments, also proved utterly inadequate, and gave rise to abuses quite as bad as the evil it was intended to cure. The nuisance, in fact, is a novel one, and demands new and special laws. Such laws, and of the most stringent, we hope the Legislature will give us at the earliest moment, for public morality clamors for the prompt suppression of these vile dens.

abstract: A. and E. Scheillin vs. John G. Wyman.--The plaintiff, on behalf of themselves and others, creditors of the late firm of Mansfield  Wood, of San Francisco, allege that in August, 1859, the firm of Mansfield  Wood made and executed an assignment to the defendant, in ...
lead_paragraph: A. and E. Scheillin vs. John G. Wyman.--The plaintiff, on behalf of themselves and others, creditors of the late firm of Mansfield Wood, of San Francisco, allege that in August, 1859, the firm of Mansfield Wood made and executed an assignment to the defendant, in this City, for the benefit of their creditors here; by which instrument the defendant was preferred to the amount of $6,000 and one Breeden to the amount of $16,000, and that the remainder of the assigned property was to be distributed pro rata among the other creditors. They also allege that the defendant has paid the amounts preferred under the assignment, and that he refuses to distribute the balance among the remaining creditors. They ask that the defendant be compelled to account and distribute any balance in his hands.

abstract: The discussions with which the newspaper Press, in common with ourselves, indulged upon the seizure of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON on the steamer Trent, and the approval of the same, were all based upon the assumption that with the rebel emissaries ...
lead_paragraph: The discussions with which the newspaper Press, in common with ourselves, indulged upon the seizure of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON on the steamer Trent, and the approval of the same, were all based upon the assumption that with the rebel emissaries were captured their dispatches, which were to be our evidence to vindicate the act. We stated at the time that Capt. WILKES did not go far enough -- that with the rebels and their dispatches he should have brought in the ship convoying them, for adjudication in a Court of Admiralty. Unfortunately this was not done, and it now turns out that only the persons of the rebels were taken, while their dispatches went forward in the steamer. Capt. WILKES thus allowed both the subject matter of adjudication, with the proofs to be presented to secure it, escape. It may be entirely competent for an officer to visit and search; and in case articles contraband of war are found on a ship of a neutral nation, to bring her into port. But here his authority ends. He is the bailiff; not the court. His office is purely ministerial, not judicial. Did he not then, (from the best of motives, to be sure,) commit a grave oversight, leaving us no choice but to make the proper amends, whatever these may be? No Court has jurisdiction unless the subject matter to be passed upon is within its reach, so that its judgments can take effect either upon persons or property. The subject here was the steamer or some article contraband of war. Were the rebels such? Can they be adjudicated upon as contraband in a Court of Admiralty? Is not their offence of a nature entirely different? If, then, we have no competent proof with which to condemn the ship, and as she is out of our jurisdiction if we had, no judgment in the case can be passed. Are we not, then, bound to restore matters to their original status, which would involve the return of the rebel Ministers?

abstract: Detective FARLEY yesterday arrested Mr. GEORGE W. JONES, formerly a Senator of the United States, from the State of Iowa. During the Administration of Mr. BUCHANAN he was the United States Minister to Bogota, South America, where he has resided for the last three or four years.
lead_paragraph: Detective FARLEY yesterday arrested Mr. GEORGE W. JONES, formerly a Senator of the United States, from the State of Iowa. During the Administration of Mr. BUCHANAN he was the United States Minister to Bogota, South America, where he has resided for the last three or four years. He has recently left the latter place and come on to Washington to settle up his business with the Government. He had a protracted interview with Secretary SEWARD on Thursday, and left Washington on the afternoon train of that day for New-York.

abstract: Recent military movements in Kentucky seem to indicate the speedy opening of the campaign in that State, if, indeed, it may not be said to have already opened in the recent forward movements from two of the main points of action.
lead_paragraph: Recent military movements in Kentucky seem to indicate the speedy opening of the campaign in that State, if, indeed, it may not be said to have already opened in the recent forward movements from two of the main points of action. There are in Kentucky three distinct and fundamental points of military operation, both for the rebels and for the National forces -- an Eastern, a Central, and a Western. The Eastern base is on or near the Cumberland River; the Central, on and near the Green River; the Western, on the Mississippi. On the East we have Gen. SCHOEPF, at Somerset, opposed to ZOLLICOFFER on the other side of Green River, and to CRITTENDEN at Cumberland Gap. This, on our part, looks to the possession of the Gap, and the occupation of East Tennessee; while from here the rebels look to the possession of Lexington and the control of Eastern Kentucky. In the Centre we have the main body of the National Kentucky army on the line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, extending as far south as Munfordsville and the crossing of Green River; the advance of which is under Gen. MITCHELL, of astronomical fame. Opposed is the main body of the rebels at Bowling Green, under BUCKNER and ALBERT S. JOHNSTON. This, on our part, looks to the possession of Nashville and the control of the great system of railroads running eastward and westward; the rebels from here look to the possession of Louisville and to carrying the seat of war up to the banks of the Ohio. On the Mississippi we have the army at Paducah and the army and navy at Cairo, under various Generals, opposed to the rebel army at Columbus, and the rebel batteries on the river. This, on our part, looks to the occupation of Memphis and the control of the Father of Waters; the rebels here, probably, intend to remain simply on the defensive, and make the point a base for incursions into Kentucky and Missouri. The other detachments of rebels here and there throughout the State are simply small bodies of marauders and guerillas, acting without any design except the destruction of Kentucky.

abstract: We hear such  accounts of the character and eloquence of Mr. CHARLES ANDERSON, brother of Gen. ANDERSON, that we feel sure that the lecture he is to deliver this evening at the Cooper Institute will be something notably worth hearing.
lead_paragraph: -- We hear such accounts of the character and eloquence of Mr. CHARLES ANDERSON, brother of Gen. ANDERSON, that we feel sure that the lecture he is to deliver this evening at the Cooper Institute will be something notably worth hearing. It will be remembered that Mr. ANDERSON but lately escaped from imprisonment in Texas, where, faithful among the faithless, he was held in duress for his truth and loyalty to the Union. The narrative of his escape, even in the brief outline in which it appeared at the time in the public prints, was among the most moving and romantic episodes of the war. He will to-night give his personal experience in full, and his inside views of secession in Texas will be both attractive and instructive.

abstract: The Herald says that the TIMES "has fallen to puffing prodigiously, philosophically and piously those well-known institutions, the Broadway concert saloons." As a mere matter of fact, this statement is, of course, exactly the reverse of the truth.
lead_paragraph: The Herald says that the TIMES "has fallen to puffing prodigiously, philosophically and piously those well-known institutions, the Broadway concert saloons." As a mere matter of fact, this statement is, of course, exactly the reverse of the truth. We have denounced these saloons as pests and disgusting nuisances, and called upon the City authorities to suppress them. If the Herald, however, means that our denunciation of them only calls public attention to them, and thus has the same effect as a puff, it may possibly be true. The Herald undoubtedly believes it, -- else it would never denounce them, as it does occasionally in its editorial columns. Its object is to help them, -- to bring them into notice, -- to stimulate the curiosity of its readers, and induce them to visit these mysteriously wicked places, -- these "well-known institutions" as the Herald styles them, -- which make that paper their special organ, and rely upon its advertising columns, aided by an occasional editorial notice, for their support. We have not the slightest doubt that they find themselves abundantly repaid for the large sums of money which they thus pay the Herald for its support.
headline: {'main': 'The Herald as a Family Paper.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Herald as a Family Paper.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Among the passengers of the steamer City of Washington, which arrived yesterday, were CHARLES F. STEVENS, the first officer, and PAUL J. HOWELL, the carpenter of that vessel.
lead_paragraph: Among the passengers of the steamer City of Washington, which arrived yesterday, were CHARLES F. STEVENS, the first officer, and PAUL J. HOWELL, the carpenter of that vessel. They are both residents of Massachusetts, and have been for three or four years officers of the ship. They lost all their clothing, tools, instruments, &c., which they had on board, and are serious losers by the piratical act of the Nashville. Capt. NELSON will remain a short time longer in England. All the facts of the outrage were laid before the American Minister, and the chief particulars have already been made public. Mr. J.H. BROWER, the owner of the ship, has received no additional information from Capt. NELSON concerning the affair.

abstract: There is a curious, and, perhaps, not altogether meaningless, contrariety in the latest news from England, for while it tells that the Anti-American fever rages as fiercely as ever in the Saxon part of Her Majesty's dominion, it also brings us word that a strong Celtic current of sympathy sets toward the United States. There will be found in the telegraphic ...
lead_paragraph: There is a curious, and, perhaps, not altogether meaningless, contrariety in the latest news from England, for while it tells that the Anti-American fever rages as fiercely as ever in the Saxon part of Her Majesty's dominion, it also brings us word that a strong Celtic current of sympathy sets toward the United States. There will be found in the telegraphic summary of the America's news an abstract of a series of resolutions adopted at a mass meeting held in Dublin, for the purpose of taking into consideration the aspects and prospects of "Irish national affairs, in view of the present relations between England and America." These resolutions announce that, should any struggle break out between the two countries, Ireland would not be an indifferent spectator, and declare that the "events of the hour dictate to all Irishmen a forgetfulness of the past, and a united rally for the old cause of their country."

abstract: The Evansville, Ind., Journal has had an interview with a gentleman who, within the last week, has been in the rebel camps at Columbus, and who brought many interesting items of news relative to the forces there, their condition, and the defences of Columbus. The forces at Columbus consist of about forty regiments, none of them containing over 800 men, and at least 2,000 of this number are sick, leaving an available force of about 30,000 men. Very few of the regimentsare uniformed; a large majority of the soldiers are poorly clad, and some even without shoes. At least 100 guns are mounted on the earthworks about Columbus, many of them of the heavist calibre. The roads in every direction arc obstructed by fallen timber, and masked batteries have been planted in the woods back of the town. The men composing the rebel regiments are represented as the lowest and vilest of the "poor whites," undisciplined, and only kept under control by the promises daily made to them by the rebel leaders. Whisky is freely circulated among them by the commanding officers, and their courage is kept to the "sticking point" by this means. The black flag has been hoisted, and it is said in their camps that when the "Yankees" attack them, no quarter will be given and no prisoners taken. Among the troops is one company of Indian cavalry from Arkansas, and hundreds of negroes are armed and in the regiments with the whites. Two regiments, at least, who were in the battle of Bull Run are now at Columbus.
lead_paragraph: The Evansville, Ind., Journal has had an interview with a gentleman who, within the last week, has been in the rebel camps at Columbus, and who brought many interesting items of news relative to the forces there, their condition, and the defences of Columbus. The men composing the rebel regiments are represented as the lowest and vilest of the "poor whites," undisciplined, and only kept under control by the promises daily made to them by the rebel leaders. abstract: It will be seen by our Washington dispatches that brief notes on the subject of the Trent affair have passed between the British Minister and secretary SEWARD, though the merits of the question have not yet been discussed. Lord ...
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by our Washington dispatches that brief notes on the subject of the Trent affair have passed between the British Minister and secretary SEWARD, though the merits of the question have not yet been discussed. Lord LYONS' note was merely an inquiry as to whether our Government was ready to receive and consider the dispatches sent by the British Government, and Mr. SEWARD's reply was that he was not yet ready to give them the immediate and careful attention which the subject required -- at the same time assuring Lord LYONS that he would be in readiness in the shortest possible time. It is expected that the matter will stand thus until the arrival of the America's mails, which will be to-morrow or Tuesday.

abstract: The brilliant manoeuvres of Gen. POPE in Western Missouri are again attracting some attention to that unfortunate State. After ...
lead_paragraph: The brilliant manoeuvres of Gen. POPE in Western Missouri are again attracting some attention to that unfortunate State. After the termination of FREMONT's campaign and the withdrawal of our troops from Springfield and the Southern border, it seemed as though all that section of the State stretching from the Arkansas line to the Missouri River must soon again fall into the hands of the magniloquent PRICE, and the speedy advance of his ragged mob on the heels of our retreat gave strength to the impression. But the bulk of FREMONT's army was not moved out of the State nor even north of the river; it was only stationed at points where it could be used effectively against the rebels should they attempt to advance on St. Louis, Jefferson City, Lexington or Kansas. Of that extensive section of country stretching from the Osage River to the Missouri, and westward to the Kansas line, Gen. POPE was appointed military commandant, with a force of some twenty thousand troops. He at once got his soldiers into condition for action; and energetically prepared to rout the rebels out of the domain under his supervision. Gen. POPE issued no pronunciamiento, gave the rebels no notice of his plans, and indulged in no brag. He knew the field, knew his men, knew the enemy, knew his work, and was determined to do it. And almost every day during the past fortnight has given evidence that the work was steadily progressing; and that his field of operations would soon have to be extended beyond its original boundaries.

abstract: as those who note such things know, has for some time been performing the "Octoroon" at the Adelphi, London -- over the stage of which theatre the American flag was draped. When, however, the San Jacinto affair transformed all England into Secessionists, the wily DION, as we learn by the last steamer, displaced the Stars and Stripes and substituted the rebel Stars and Bars. This is certainly a new version of "London Assurance!" This same man, a few years, ago, came a penniless adventure to New-York, where, by the generality of our citizens, he made a great success and a great fortune and fell, and leaving the odor of sanctity behind him. Those who knew him most thoroughly will be least surprised at this latest piece of contemptible lickspittle toadyism.

abstract: BITION The London Enquirer, Mitchell's Steam-Shipping Journal, and other English engineering publications, have made the TIMES' proposition to send one of our Sound steamers to the World's Fair the subject of interesting editorials. They are disposed to ...
lead_paragraph: The London Enquirer, Mitchell's Steam-Shipping Journal, and other English engineering publications, have made the TIMES' proposition to send one of our Sound steamers to the World's Fair the subject of interesting editorials. They are disposed to acknowledge the advantages of these vessels for coast and channel service, in advance. The Enquirer also makes the TIMES' proposition to send over some Yankee locomotives, the text of an able discussion upon the advantages of the American machine. All this substantiates the conclusion we have repeatedly urged, that our ship and machine-builders would secure a large share of the world's orders, if they would only avail themselves of this grand opportunity to show the world's buyers what they can do. It may be urged that the English will copy the good features of our works, and so maintain their precedence. Of course, the practice of different countries becomes gradually assimilated, but the English have had ample opportunity to inspect our steamboats and locomotives for years, and have been aware of their merits, but they have not produced copies.

abstract: If there were any doubt as to the propriety of adequate sea-coast defence under all circumstances, it could not safely be shared by a people over whom impend complications with the proprietors of fast armor-clad war steamers. The grand question is, what constitutes adequate sea-coast defence? Is it ...
lead_paragraph: If there were any doubt as to the propriety of adequate sea-coast defence under all circumstances, it could not safely be shared by a people over whom impend complications with the proprietors of fast armor-clad war steamers. The grand question is, what constitutes adequate sea-coast defence? Is it forts alone, when the whole substance and character of menacing fleets has been changed? Can land batteries, designed to cope with wooden walls, dependent on the capricious wind for locomotion, as a matter of course, defend harbors against rapid mailed steamers, any more than the cuirass of the Middle Ages can resist gunpowder because it is proof against the power of a man's hand? We commend these considerations to the patriotic attention of those, officers of the army, who devote so much of their energy to ridiculing all means of harbor defence except forts; who omit no occasion to insist that shot-proof vessels, as aids to forts are simply a waste of money; who volunteer to Congressional Committees, appointed to decide upon the proper defences, their professional conclusion, that our fortified harbors are safe against all invading fleets, slow or fast, vulnerable or mailed. Heaven knows how they found it out.

abstract: The news by the America is only an elaboration of what had previously come to hand, with the exception, perhaps, of assertions attributed to French journals, that the Government of Great Britain had signified to the Manchester manufacturers that the Cotton ports would be opened by February. This is ...
lead_paragraph: The news by the America is only an elaboration of what had previously come to hand, with the exception, perhaps, of assertions attributed to French journals, that the Government of Great Britain had signified to the Manchester manufacturers that the Cotton ports would be opened by February. This is unquestionably a canard, very likely invented by parties in the rebel interest. The idea that the British Government should have definitely resolved to open the Cotton ports, or should have communicated such intention, if it entertained it, to French journalists, is too absurd for utterance. The invention accomplished one, and probably its only object -- to keep our people in a state of constant apprehension and alarm.

abstract: Hen. THOMAS S. WILLIAMS, Chief Justice of Connecticut, died in Hartford on Sunday, of pneumonia. He was born in Wethersfield, on June 23, 1777, and was the youngest but two of twelve children, all of whom he survived. Graduating at Vale Colleges in 1794, he was admitted to the bar of Windharn County in 1799, and in 1803 removed to Hartford, where he has since resided. For a number of terms between the years 1815 and 1820, he represented his district in Congress, and in the latter year was appointed an associate Judge of the Supreme Court of Errors. In 1834 he received the appointment of Chief Justice, and the honorary degree of LL. D. was conferred upon him in 1834 by his Alma Mater, Yale College. His Chief Justiceship he resigned in 1847, but while holding it, from 1831 to 1835, he acted as Mayor of Hartford. His legal reputation was very extensive and his decisions are widely quoted. Judge WILLIAMS was also very widely known as a philanthropist. Liberal of his own means, he took a prominent part in the benevolent enterprises of the day. For twenty years he was President of the American Asylum for the Deaf and Dumb, and Vice-President of the Retreat for the Insane, at Hartford, He was President for several years of the American Tract Society, and Vice-President of the American Board of Foreign Missions.
lead_paragraph: Hen. THOMAS S. WILLIAMS, Chief Justice of Connecticut, died in Hartford on Sunday, of pneumonia. He was born in Wethersfield, on June 23, 1777, and was the youngest but two of twelve children, all of whom he survived. In 1834 he received the appointment of Chief Justice, and the honorary degree of LL. D. was conferred upon him in 1834 by his Alma Mater, Yale College. His Chief Justiceship he resigned in 1847, but while holding it, from 1831 to 1835, he acted as Mayor of Hartford. His legal reputation was very extensive and his decisions are widely quoted. Judge WILLIAMS was also very widely known as a philanthropist. Liberal of his own means, he took a prominent part in the benevolent enterprises of the day. abstract: The first session of the Conference of the "Independent Methodist Churches in the United States was held in the St. John's Methodist Church, in this City, (Prof. MATTISON'S,) on Wednesday and Thursday last. About twenty delegates, lay and clerical, were in attendance, representing various Independent Methodist Churches in different parts of the country. Rev, M. STAPLE, of Brooklyn, was chosen President, Rev. H. MATTISON, of New-York, Secretary; and JAMES M. COBURN, Esq., of New-York, Treasurer.
lead_paragraph: The first session of the Conference of the "Independent Methodist Churches in the United States was held in the St. John's Methodist Church, in this City, (Prof. MATTISON'S,) on Wednesday and Thursday last. About twenty delegates, lay and clerical, were in attendance, representing various Independent Methodist Churches in different parts of the country. Rev, M. STAPLE, of Brooklyn, was chosen President, Rev. H. MATTISON, of New-York, Secretary; and JAMES M. COBURN, Esq., of New-York, Treasurer.

abstract: Yesterday morning, the Ninety-first Regiment, New-York Volunteers, Col. VAN ZANDT, arrived in this City from Albany, on the steamer Knickerbocker. The regiment, numbering nearly nine hundred men, proceeded at once to Governor's Island, where it will remain till its departure for the seat of war. Previous to the departure of the regiment from Albany, it paraded through the principal streets, and received quite a complete ovation. Mrs. Col. HARCOURT presented the regiment with a handsome stand of colors' which donation was received in an appropriate address by Col. VAN ZANDT, Maj. TARDELL, now in active service at the seat of war, was appointed Lieutenant-Colonel of the regiment, on Friday, by Gov. MORGAN. A few of the men were sick with the measles, and were sent to Bedloe's Island to be cared for until their recovery. Annexed is a list of the principal officers:

abstract: The probability of a war between the United States and Mother England, is exciting the wildest joy at the South. The story comes at the same time from Charleston, Memphis and New-Orleans. On the verge of ruin, with its ...
lead_paragraph: The probability of a war between the United States and Mother England, is exciting the wildest joy at the South. The story comes at the same time from Charleston, Memphis and New-Orleans. On the verge of ruin, with its supports on all sides giving way, the engagements of its framers about the forcible intervention of Foreign Powers to release the cotton unfulfilled, with Winter, bankruptcy and defeat facing it this chance of a British war is obviously the only salvation of the rebel Government, and hence the universal expression of satisfaction and relief as the prospect of such an event becomes imminent. If the Washington Government could be inspired by JEFF. DAVIS, of its policy there could he no doubt. It would meet the application of Lord RUSSELL with scorn and defiance. It would stand doggedly upon its view of international law. It would convert an accident into an insult; and invite the army and navy of Her Britannis Majesty to do their worst. To these extremes would rebeldom gladly commit the Federal Government, for in their necessary consequences would be the redemption of the lost cause of secession. In fact, the game of the rebels has from the start depended upon some European Power coming to its rescue. JEFF. DAVIS has been unable to effect this; he now asks President LINCOLN to effect it for him.

abstract: that upon the appearance of the Texans at Fort Stanton all the citizens in the vicinity of the Post fled to the settlements leaving their homes, crops and almost everything else they had, behind them. After the Texans abandoned the place the Apache Indians became masters of the situation, and had command of the whole country round about. In this condition of things the citizens did not return during the Summer to look after their forsaken homes and property. This Fall, however, a party of twenty men determined to revisit the neighborhood for the purpose of ascertaining whether anything could be obtained from the flourishing fields of growing crops they had left in the early Summer. The unfortunate party never returned. The whole number fell victims to the barbaric ferocity of the Apaches.

abstract: A correspondent writes to the Boston Journal: "The chess match between Messrs. Paulson and Kolisch was drawn by especial agreement, thus: After the score stood Paulsen 7, Kolisch 6, drawn 15, Mr. Kolisch proposed that if the next three games should be drawn, then the match should be considered drawn. This was acceded to by his adversary, and after three more games the score stood thus: Paulsen, 7; Kolisch, 6; drawn, 18. According to the original agreement, the first winner of nine games was to be declared the victor, which was overruled by the special agreement alluded to above. You will, therefore, see that the statement in yesterday's Journal was incorrect. Mr. Paulsen. however, won the honors, because he actually scored one more game than his opponent, and also played open games throughout, while his opponent played close games whenever he had the second more."

abstract: In London, with reference to the important question of the attitude likely to be assumed by France, the opinion continues to be that, however desirous the Emperor might be to give some employment to his navy, and to distract the public attention in France from the state of the French finances, he is not likely to do anything to cause a difference with the British Government, because serious results might follow in France, if distrust there should increase, and cause a further depression of trade.

abstract: The steamship America, with two days' later news from Europe having left Liverpool on the 7th inst., and Queenstown on the 8th put into Halifax yesterday morning, for the purpose of leaving dispatches for the Colonial Government. The war excitement continued unabated in England, and preparations for hostilities were proceeding rapidly. The new steel-plated frigate ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship America, with two days' later news from Europe--having left Liverpool on the 7th inst., and Queenstown on the 8th--put into Halifax yesterday morning, for the purpose of leaving dispatches for the Colonial Government. The war excitement continued unabated in England, and preparations for hostilities were proceeding rapidly. The new steel-plated frigate Warrior was taking in a large quantity of coal, preparatory to a cruise in American waters, and immense quantities of small arms and munitions of war were being prepared for shipment. A large number of engineers was also to be sent to Canada immediately.

abstract: England knows she is strong. This is our hour of weakness, and she may make it her opportunity to strike. She can now be arrogant and insulting, for now her arrogance and insult cannot be resented. The Northern coast is exposed to her large and powerful navy; our towns are not fortified, and she may bring desolation upon our people and our manufacturing interests.

abstract: The sinking of the Stone Squadron in the channel of Charleston harbor has been for so long a foregone conclusion, that the announcement this morning that the old whalers have actually done their work will hardly be news. The steamer Ericsson, which arrived at Fortress Monroe on Saturday, actually towed nine of them up to Charleston from Port Royal, and seven followed after, making sixteen in all, which were the next day sent to the bottom, to become the nuclei for the accumulation of the shifting sands and alluvial deposits. And there may they lie forever.
lead_paragraph: The sinking of the Stone Squadron in the channel of Charleston harbor has been for so long a foregone conclusion, that the announcement this morning that the old whalers have actually done their work will hardly be news. abstract: The recent collision at Drainesville is, for one or two reasons, especially valuable. In the earlier conflicts of the war, doubt was cast upon the prowess of Northern troops. Bull Run was regarded, in England at least, as settling the relative measure of courage between the combatants, and Ball's Bluff appeared to confirm the verdict upon Bull Run. In the West, to be sure, there were gigantic exploits, such as SIEGEL's at Carthage, LYONS' at Wilson Creek. MULLIGAN's at Lexington, SIGONYI's at Springfield. NELSON's at Piketon, BENHAM's at Carrick's Ford; but they belonged to those Western braves, whose fighting qualities were never in doubt, and who, we fear, looked with some degree of contempt at the heroes sent out from what they considered the effeminate civilization of the East. Let all these prejudices be cured by the story of the fight near Drainesville. Against a sheltered foe, superior in number, the Pennsylvania troops fought with unquestionable courage. The slaughterous fire of the enemy was received without flinching; and as steadily returned; and after a contest keenly disputed, the rebels fled beaten from the field. The ruth if our men have only lacked confidence in their leaders. Give them assurance that they are to be handled by skillful officers, and not sacrificed by stupidity and incapacity, and hey will show all the qualities necessary to win victories and final success. They were so handled on Friday, and we see the result.

abstract: The Government have lying at Quebec four strong steamers, the Victoria, Lady Head, Napoleon and Advance. The three first named are iron propellers, the last mentioned is a side wheel vessel of wood. Can they pass the canal locks? If so, they should be sent to Kingston at once. A few days ago the water was out of the Lachine Canal alone, the others were full, and us the cold weather had not set in, vessels might be sent through them to the lakes. If we cannot how get these boats, it will be well to put them in readiness to receive guns the day the war breaks out. There are also a number of propellers lying at various ports which might he fitted up in readiness for the contest if it must come. Of course they would make comparatively poor war vessels, but as everything depends upon the possession of the lakes, to that and our efforts must be directed. Most of them are large enough to carry a couple of sixty-eight pounders, and would thus be valuable auxiliaries to the English gunboats which will certainly be here.
lead_paragraph: The Government have lying at Quebec four strong steamers, the Victoria, Lady Head, Napoleon and Advance. The three first named are iron propellers, the last mentioned is a side wheel vessel of wood. Can they pass the canal locks? If so, they should be sent to Kingston at once. A few days ago the water was out of the Lachine Canal alone, the others were full, and us the cold weather had not set in, vessels might be sent through them to the lakes. If we cannot how get these boats, it will be well to put them in readiness to receive guns the day the war breaks out. There are also a number of propellers lying at various ports which might he fitted up in readiness for the contest if it must come. Of course they would make comparatively poor war vessels, but as everything depends upon the possession of the lakes, to that and our efforts must be directed. Most of them are large enough to carry a couple of sixty-eight pounders, and would thus be valuable auxiliaries to the English gunboats which will certainly be here.

abstract: The Monmouth, N.J., Democrat corrects some errors made in reference to Mrs. MARKS. It says that the statement that she made a confession, implicating RADETSKI, is without foundation. She has made no confession, but pleads entire ignorance of how FELLNER came to his end. The evidence before the jury, upon which the indictment was founded, came from other sources. Mrs. MARKS made another attempt to commit suicide, after her removal from New-York, but she has since been in a more cheerful frame of mind. A considerable amount of property belonging to her, which was about to fall into the hands of the "Sharks" at New-York, was recovered for her by Deputy Sheriff SMALLEY, through the intervention of CHARLES H. MITCHELL, Esq., of New-York. Mrs. MARKS has been discharged, from custody, no evidence appearing to justify the author ties in holding her, and she is now boarding with a private family in the village.

abstract: The United States steam transport Star of the South, Commander KEARNEY, arrived at this port yesterday morning from Port Royal, which port she left on the 18th inst., at 5 P.M., bringing one day later advices than the Atlantic. She brings no further news of moment, except that on the morning of the 18th heavy firing was heard in the direction of Tybee Island, and that the steamer Marion had proceeded with reinforcements to that place.

abstract: We are not of those, our readers will have discovered, who believe a war with England will grow out of the Mason and Slidell affair, but, even should such a calamity result from it, England has evidently no chance of drawing France into the quarrel, and must be content to bear the brunt of the contest alone. For a few days, indeed, after intelligence of the abduction of the rebel Commissioners from on board the Trent had reached Paris, the tone of the leading French journals was almost as excited and indignant as that of their British cotemporaries. Gradually, however, the Gallic effervescence subsided, and French redocteurs began to take a calmer and more rational view of the matter. Nor should it be forgotten that the official Moniteur itself, the special organ of the Imperial Government, was the first to adopt a pacific tone, and to put forth words of sense and soberness on this subject. It considered a peaceful solution of the difficulties not impossible, and counseled France to await the issue with calmnesss. Next followed the Debats which set the seal of its approbation to the opinions of the Moniteur, and even went so far as to visit the Trent with its censure, and justify the act of Capt. WILKES. "It is generally admitted," says this able journal "that neutrals ought not to mix either directly, or indirectly, in war operations," and "that they expose themselves to lawful seizure, when they carry for either of the belligerents, contraband of war, troops, known spies or other agents belonging to the service of the armies. * * The Trent is but a merchant vessel, and as it was not sufficiently removed from the American coast to escape all suspicion, the Federal cruiser had the right to stop it, and to examine what was on board" -- aye, and, as the legitimate conclusion from the Debats premises, to capture "all contraband of war," "spies" or "other events" found there! What more cogent defence of their case than this need Americans desire? The Opinione National is almost as explicit as the Journal des Debats in stating its views. Had a French vessel been in the place of the Trent, the Opinione considers that France, which has ever respected the rights of neutrals, would be fully justified in vindicating the dignity of its flag, but that Great Britain, which has always opposed those rights, is precluded, by her own antecedents, and by the Washington Government, not being bound by the Convention of 1856, from seeking redress vi et armis! Cold comfort, this, for England. It is, however, the leading newspaper of the Liverpool of France that gives her the unkindest cut of all. The Courrier du Havre, after telling England that she must, under penalty of falling from the rank which she occupies in the world, take up the matter with a high hand, and do justice to herself, adds, with provoking sang froid. "But this is, for her, wholly a personal affair, about which she has no need of consulting her friends or allies. The care of avenging her outraged honor concerns her alone!" In other words, the Havre writer, while laboring to incite her to hostilities, gives her very plainly to understand that, in such a quarrel she must not expect any aid or countenance from her French confederate.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  Since my communication of Nov. 30, I have seen several able arguments on the question I have again written about one in the Boston Courier, of Dec. 12, and especially one which occurs in an able and eloquent appeal on behalf of Constitutional Law against the "higher law," from the pen of Judge NICHOLAS, of Kentucky, in the Louisville Journal of the 11th December.

abstract: At 3  o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the five-story brick building No. 161 Broadway, which resulted in the total destruction of the building and contents. The lower part was occupied by HEGEMAN  Co., as a wholesale and retail drugstore. They are the greatest sufferers, although there are several other parties who have sustained damage to a large amount.
lead_paragraph: At 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the five-story brick building No. 161 Broadway, which resulted in the total destruction of the building and contents. The lower part was occupied by HEGEMAN Co., as a wholesale and retail drugstore. They are the greatest sufferers, although there are several other parties who have sustained damage to a large amount. The alarm was given immediately after the discovery of the fire, and the firemen were early on the ground; but such was the inflammable nature of the contents of the store, and the fire had gained such headway before the hose could be brought to bear upon it, that it soon became obvious that the entire structure would be demolished. The attention of the firemen was therefore mainly directed to the protection of the adjoining buildings. Within an hour after the fire was first seen, the whole of the building was a mass of smouldering ruins. Very little, if anything, of the contents of the drug-store was rescued from the flames. The upper stories were occupied by Messrs. ELLINGHAM & POLMYER, paperbox manufacturers. They had a large amount of stock on hand, which was totally destroyed. The estimated loss on the building and contents is $65,000. The buildings Nos. 157 and 159 are occupied on the lower floor by E.J. SCHENCK, auctioneer. His damage by water is considerable. He had a large quantity of furniture and other goods stored on the first floor and in the basement, and much of this its ruined by the flood of water with which the firemen deemed it nececessary to drench every part of the premises. His damage could not be definitely ascertained. DOUBLEDAY & STEWART occupied the upper floors of these buildings, and were damaged to the extent of $200, mostly by water. No. 163, on the other side of the burnt building, is occupied, on the first floor, by JOHN FOLEY, gold pen manufacturer; and on the floors above by Messrs. ROTHSCHILD & SANGER, dealers in furs. The stock of each of these is believed to be considerably damaged by water, but owing to the fact that the stores were closed yesterday, the loss could not be ascertained.

abstract: The troops to Canada will have to come overland from Halifax -- a task much less difficult than when it was performed on previous occasions. Railroads extend from over about one-third of the distance from Halifax to Quebec. There is now a passable stage road, on which the distance from Woodstock to Riviere du Loup is made in Summer in three days and three nights. This is the most difficult portion, because it passes through a new country, over which the road is of the most primitive description. On landing at Halifax, the troops can go by rail to Truro; thence, on a good stage road, a distance of some 80 miles to Muncton, at the head of that arm of the Bay of Fundy which stretches furthest to the east; from this point, they will reach St. John by rail. What course they will take from St. John we cannot say; but the probability is they will go up the St. John River, which will then be covered by ice, to Frederickton. They might go to St. Andrews and take the railroad to Woodstock; but in that case their starting-point would be close to the American frontier, and they would have sixty miles of stage-road from St. John to St. Andrews. They will have several advantages over any troops that ever traveled the same route, in Winter, before. Over two hundred miles of railroad will be at their service; and where the rail does not extend the road will be passable. It will not be difficult to obtain horses and sleighs, to convey them over those portions of the road where the rail has not been laid.

abstract: These two regiments are now stationed at East New-York, and are occupying the splendid "Union Barracks" in front of the Howard House, elected by Commissary WALKER. An addition of several hundred men was made to the regiments on Saturday evening last, by the railroad from the South Ferry. The barracks are large, comfortable and commodious, and so arranged as to make an inclosure of sufficient size for drilling purposes. Yesterday, notwithstanding the cold, the inclosed area was well filled with soldiers, who were being "put through" in military tactics.

abstract: Our Washington dispatches yesterdays stated that brief notes on the subject of the Trent affair had passed between the British Minister and Secretary SEWARD, though the merits of the question had not yet been discussed. Lord LYONS' note was merely an inquiry as to whether our Government was ready to receive and consider the dispatches sent by the British Government, and Mr. SEWARD's reply was that he was not yet ready to give them the immediate and careful attention which the subject required -- at the same time assuring Lord LYONS that he would be in readiness in the shortest possible time. It is expected that the matter will stand thus until the arrival of the America's mails, which will be to-day or to-morrow.
