abstract: -- TICKNOR & FIELDS are producing some books of which they have very good reason to be proud. One volume in particular, the Spare Hours of Dr. JOHN BROWN, of Edinburgh -- the best John Brown, by the way, that has yet figured in history -- does the Riverside Press lasting credit. It is too often the case with books as with men -- a prepossessing exterior is adopted as a sort of set-off against the astounding emptiness within. But not so with these Spare Hours, of which the judicious reader will incline to make many careful minutes. There is a charming vein of uncommon sense in these papers, together with a pathos and tenderness that is real -- not brought up like a stage heroine's tears from an artificial well by the bucket of premeditation. The Dr. is an inveterate hater of all shams. He can sympathize with affliction, but he has no bowels of compassion for imaginary ills. He delights in stripping off disguises, and getting at the actual anatomy of the fact with which he has to do. Once his diagnosis is made he proceeds accordingly. No hesitating treatment ensues at his hands. Immediately he fancies that he has found diseased flesh, his knife is at work without any preliminary flourishes. Occasionally in making these excisions he cuts a little deeper than is necessary, but the sufferer has ever the consolation of knowing that he is honest in his surgery, and has no venal end in view. He does'nt kill for the sake of being enabled to dissect the remains. But it does seem to us that he punctures the buoyant complacency of the very ingenious PHILIP JAMES BAILEY rather deeper than the exigencies of the case demand when he pins down the poem on which his reputation is chiefly founded, as "the somewhat tremendous, absurd, raw, loud and fuliginous 'Festus.'" Milder treatment would have answered. But the similie that follows is so delightful that even the author of "Festus" must perforce smile in his pain. "We would, we repeat, as much rather keep company with 'V.'" (the poems of another are under consideration, and he is pointing their merits by contrast,) "as we would prefer going to sea for pleasure in a trim little yacht, with its free motions, its quiet, its cleanliness, to taking a state berth in some Fire-king steamer of one thousand horse-power, with his mighty and troublesome throb, his smoke, his exasperated steam, his clangor and fire and fume, his oils and smells." There is much truth in this verdict of the Doctor's, but we apprehend that he pushes his conclusions slightly beyond truth, and this is quite as unfair as to stop half-way. But, without an occasional exhibition of intolerance, what would a Scotsman be? We might as well have a Dutchman at once. In this reprint of the Horoe Subsciroe, our Boston friends have given us one of the most charming volumes of light reading that ever came to enliven the horizon of dullness. The reader will very soon make up his mind that he cannot spare Spare Hours to his friends until he has given them a second reading. For, of a verity, these "Brown Studies" (as an Edinburgh wag calls them) are very pleasant to indulge in.
lead_paragraph: -- TICKNOR & FIELDS are producing some books of which they have very good reason to be proud. One volume in particular, the Spare Hours of Dr. JOHN BROWN, of Edinburgh -- the best John Brown, by the way, that has yet figured in history -- does the Riverside Press lasting credit. It is too often the case with books as with men -- a prepossessing exterior is adopted as a sort of set-off against the astounding emptiness within. But not so with these Spare Hours, of which the judicious reader will incline to make many careful minutes. There is a charming vein of uncommon sense in these papers, together with a pathos and tenderness that is real -- not brought up like a stage heroine's tears from an artificial well by the bucket of premeditation. The Dr. is an inveterate hater of all shams. He can sympathize with affliction, but he has no bowels of compassion for imaginary ills. He delights in stripping off disguises, and getting at the actual anatomy of the fact with which he has to do. Once his diagnosis is made he proceeds accordingly. No hesitating treatment ensues at his hands. Immediately he fancies that he has found diseased flesh, his knife is at work without any preliminary flourishes. Occasionally in making these excisions he cuts a little deeper than is necessary, but the sufferer has ever the consolation of knowing that he is honest in his surgery, and has no venal end in view. He does'nt kill for the sake of being enabled to dissect the remains. But it does seem to us that he punctures the buoyant complacency of the very ingenious PHILIP JAMES BAILEY rather deeper than the exigencies of the case demand when he pins down the poem on which his reputation is chiefly founded, as "the somewhat tremendous, absurd, raw, loud and fuliginous 'Festus.'" Milder treatment would have answered. But the similie that follows is so delightful that even the author of "Festus" must perforce smile in his pain. "We would, we repeat, as much rather keep company with 'V.'" (the poems of another are under consideration, and he is pointing their merits by contrast,) "as we would prefer going to sea for pleasure in a trim little yacht, with its free motions, its quiet, its cleanliness, to taking a state berth in some Fire-king steamer of one thousand horse-power, with his mighty and troublesome throb, his smoke, his exasperated steam, his clangor and fire and fume, his oils and smells." There is much truth in this verdict of the Doctor's, but we apprehend that he pushes his conclusions slightly beyond truth, and this is quite as unfair as to stop half-way. But, without an occasional exhibition of intolerance, what would a Scotsman be? We might as well have a Dutchman at once. In this reprint of the Horoe Subsciroe, our Boston friends have given us one of the most charming volumes of light reading that ever came to enliven the horizon of dullness. The reader will very soon make up his mind that he cannot spare Spare Hours to his friends until he has given them a second reading. For, of a verity, these "Brown Studies" (as an Edinburgh wag calls them) are very pleasant to indulge in.

abstract: The Government have called out one company of seventy-five men in each battalion of the Sedentary Militia. There are about five hundred battalions in Canada, Upper and Lower, and the call will produce between thirty and forty thousand men. The mere calling out of this number of militia involves a very large expenditure, and we are bound to believe that the step has not been taken lightly. We are entirely ignorant of the reasons which have produced it, and can only guess that instructions received by the Jura have caused the Government to regard the United States difficulty as more serious than they did before. Certain it is that communications from the Government a day or two ago did not indicate that they thought thirty or forty thousand men necessary for the defense of the Province. An intimation from England that the arming of the militia was advisable, and perhaps, also, that the Imperial Government would bear the expense, may have led to the change of policy.

abstract: Samuel S. Slater vs. Fernando Wood. -- This case is familiar, although tried some time since States was a Policeman under the Metropolitan Police act, and was injured while engaged with others in the memorable attempt to arrest Fernando Wood, during the Street Commissioner controversy of 1857. The action was brought to recover damages for the injury, and upon trial the plaintiff recovered $500. Upon appeal the General Term have now reversed the judgment, and granted a new trial.

abstract: In April, 1838, a great fire occurred in Charleston, S.C., probably very near the site of the present fire, as the theatre, principal hotel, and over 1,100 buildings were destroyed, the fire first commencing in a paint shop on King-street. Hundreds of families were rendered houseless, and contributions were raised for the sufferers in different parts of the country. In this city a public meeting was called at the City Hall, by a call signed by the Mayor, Luther Lawrence, Elisha Bartlett, Elisha Huntington, John Aiken, Eliphalet Case, James G. Carney, J.W. Mansur, John W. Graves, and others. The Mayor presided, and a committee was appointed to solicit subscriptions from the churches and citizens. What success attended their labors we have no means of knowing. It is hardly probable that a meeting will be called in Lowell at the present time, as the action of Charleston during the last year has not been such as to awaken much sympathy among our people.

Mansur, John W. Graves, and others. The Mayor presided, and a committee was appointed to solicit subscriptions from the churches and citizens. abstract: -- A Baltimore correspondent in this morning's TIMES suggests a very singular, if not original, method of making Slavery inure to the damage of the rebels. "How," asks he, "can Slavery be turned against the rebellion? By driving the slaves back upon their masters, who must for their own preservation maintain and feed them, while under the circumstances they can derive no possible return for their labor." He then mentions that it is now the Southern Winter, that pork there is forty-eight dollars a barrel, that there is no sale for cotton and consequently no money, and that, Cuffee's appetite being undiminished, he will first ruin and then devour his master. Now, if the master fed, or was compelled to feed Cuffee upon this high-priced article of pork, and if Cuffee spent his whole time in gormandizing, this argument would be conclusive for driving the slaves back upon their impoverished masters. But in the first place, the slaves will not be likely to be fed upon any such expensive luxury as prime mess pork at present; and next, the rebels do not stultify themselves by permitting the slaves to remain a negative power in the present war. If, for instance, there were ten thousand slaves at Port Royal and the adjacent sea-islands when Gen. SHERMAN landed his forces there, and if their masters and the rebel army succeeded in driving the majority of them inland, who believes that they were permitted to sit down leisurely on the other side of the rebel lines and devour pork at forty-eight dollars a barrels? On the contrary, is it not a great deal more likely -- as indeed we know was the case -- that the slaves got rations of Indian corn and rice, which are as cheap and plenty there as here, and were instantly put to work throwing up fortifications and digging trenches at Coosawhatchie, and working might and main at the defences of Charleston? It is in a military aspect we view the question at present. And it must be evident to everybody, that the force, the military force, represented by these ten thousand slaves, is of far greater gain to whichever side uses it, than the mere coarse rations they consume is loss. In fact the labor of every slave there, if he be put at the proper kind of work, and properly handled, is worth more than the labor of two white men; while our correspondent himself estimates the cost of the black man's sustenance at one-third less than that of the white. Our troops at Port Royal are now suffering very severely from sickness, brought on in great part by the extraordinary amount of hard manual labor that has devolved upon them since they were stationed there -- all of which should have been performed by the slaves who are now working on the other side. For this purpose they should be seized, captured and held in every way possible. And this no more means that the slaves are to be employed in cutting their masters' throats than the masters now employ them in cutting the throats of Unionists.

abstract: The more detailed telegraphic news, that comes to us by the Arago and Edinburgh, is as favorable as could be desired for a pacific solution of our differences with England. Cotton is firm, with an upward tendency, which would hardly be the case were there the least reliance placed upon the story that England was meditating the opening of the ports. By previous arrivals, cotton was reported dull and declining, in consequence of the story referred to. By the Arago and Edinburgh, turpentine and naval stores are reported to be higher and breadstuffs dull.Consols had advanced within a few days 1 per cent. In other words, commercial matters, the true index of the political horizon, unmistakably assure us that this is as clear of clouds as it has been since our troubles commenced. Were there any danger of a collision between this country and England the commercial news would be the exact reverse of what now comes to us.

abstract: It must be owing to the fact that the prophetic "E.M." has ceased to issue his daily bulletins advertising us of the "terms" and "cycles" of the weather, that we have allowed so important an astronomic event as the shortest day of the year to steal a march upon us unawares. Yet so it is: on the 21st of December the sun reached the utmost limit of his journey southward, and began, though with a movement so slight as to require our modern micrometric instruments for its detection, to move in the opposite direction. We have, therefore, reached the dead of Winter.
lead_paragraph: It must be owing to the fact that the prophetic "E.M." has ceased to issue his daily bulletins advertising us of the "terms" and "cycles" of the weather, that we have allowed so important an astronomic event as the shortest day of the year to steal a march upon us unawares. Yet so it is: on the 21st of December the sun reached the utmost limit of his journey southward, and began, though with a movement so slight as to require our modern micrometric instruments for its detection, to move in the opposite direction. We have, therefore, reached the dead of Winter.

abstract: The news of the advance of the enemy from Virginia on this section of the State is nothing but one tissue of misrepresentation and exaggeration. We were grossly deceived here as to the number of the enemy. The facts of the case are these: There are only several hundred of them, and no fear need be entertained of their doing much harm in this immediate section.

abstract: The steamship America, which left Liverpool on the 7th inst., and Queenstown on the 8th--put into Halifax on Saturday morning, for the purpose of leaving dispatches for the Colonial Government. The war excitement continued unabated in England, and preparations for hostilities were ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship America, which left Liverpool on the 7th inst., and Queenstown on the 8th--put into Halifax on Saturday morning, for the purpose of leaving dispatches for the Colonial Government. The war excitement continued unabated in England, and preparations for hostilities were proceeding rapidly. The new steel-plated frigate Warrior was taking in a large quantity of coal, preparatory to a cruise in American waters, and immense quantities of small arms and munitions of war were being prepared for shipment. A large number of engineers was also to be sent to Canada immediately.

abstract: Miss LAUEA KEENE's establishment will be closed to-night for the purpose of rehearsing the forthcoming novelties, two in number, and called "Little Tom; or, A Christmas Carol," and "Robinson Crusoe." These will be brought out to-morrow-night, in time for a double performance on Christmas and the young folk. Mr. BARNUM, too, although afflicted by the tragic mortality of whales, and embarrassed by the tranquil voracity of a Hippopotamus who consumes a barrel of turnips a day, is up and ready with a new holiday piece, called the "Bower of Beauty." It will be produced tonight, and played afternoon and evening until further notice. At the Bowery Theatre, the Irish pageant called "O'Donoghue; or, The White Horse of Killarney," has met with a great success, and will be played every night until Christmas. At the Academy of Music, Mr. WM. HANLON is the special attraction, and performs his swing trick before astounded crowds. The pantomime performances of the Fox company have greatly improved since the first night, and are now admirable. At Mr. WALLACK's Theatre, the new comedy by Mr. TOM TAYLOR, called "Up at the Hills," will be performed. At the Winter Garden, the successful spectacle drama called "The Lakes of Killarney," and two other pieces.

abstract: The rebel Congress has no such exhaustive preoccupation with its own troubles as to be all-forgetful of others. Maryland has still a strong hold upon its sympathies -- the stronger perhaps, in that it seems to fare so satisfactorily in the absence of the friendly coddling it would have received had the original plans of secession been accomplished. The loss of Maryland was indeed a sorry misadventure at the start; but to discover how their loss was the gain of that Commonwealth adds poignancy to a very natural sorrow. We are not surprised, therefore, to find the Richmond legislators passing resolutions of condolence with the suppressed rebels of Maryland, and promising at an early day to overrun the State, and make the condition of its people as blest as that of their neighbors in the Old Dominion.

abstract: INAUGURATION OF LAKE LINCOLN -- Lake Lincoln donned its winter garb on Friday night last, and since that time has been gradually adding to its coverings until its surface is sufficiently strong for the occupancy of skaters with safety. The lake will be thrown open to the public for the first time to-day (Monday,) and in the evening will be brilliantly lighted by means of four locomotive lamps, one placed at each corner. Suitable buildings have been erected for the accommodation of skaters and visiters. The ice is said to be in excellent condition, and in case of snow means have been provided for removing it. The lake is two miles from the Jersey City Ferry and is accessible by cars and stage from Jersey City.

abstract: THE ACCIDENT TO THE CROTON WATER MAIN. -- The break in the Croton main, at the corner of Fifth-avenue and Sixty-fourth-street, an account of which we published in yesterday's TIMES, is a pretty serious one, and will not probably be fully repaired for a day or two. The Chief Engineer is using great diligence toward the accomplishment of the work. As soon as the leak was discovered, the water was turned off from that main, and a gang of about forty men were set to work to take out the damaged pipe and replace it with a new one. The mains lie twenty feet below the surface, and the excavation must necessarily be slow. The Fifth avenue mains supply a portion of the eastern division, and citizens in that part of town will only be inconvenienced to the extent of nor being able to get water into the upper part of their houses. With this main taken out, there is very little more than enough to carry the water to the second floor of the houses situated above Canal-street. The mains in this avenue were laid down in 1841, and it is believed that many of them need repairing.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the London Times says that the official opinion of the British Foreign Minister on the outrage perpetrated on the Trent is most precise and positive, namely; that the violence committed by the Captain of the San Jacinto is indefensible; and that by regarding the Commissioners, Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, as contraband, Mr. LINCOLN and his Ministers contradict themselves, for they refused to admit they were aware of their presence. The correspondent adds that the Emperor NAPOLEON does not materially dissent from this view of the case.
lead_paragraph: The Paris correspondent of the London Times says that the official opinion of the British Foreign Minister on the outrage perpetrated on the Trent is most precise and positive, namely; that the violence committed by the Captain of the San Jacinto is indefensible; and that by regarding the Commissioners, Messrs. The correspondent adds that the Emperor NAPOLEON does not materially dissent from this view of the case.

abstract: Col. KIMBALL, of the Fourteenth Indiana Regiment, arrived in this City on Tuesday night, on his way home from Western Virginia. He left Phillippi, the headquarters of Gen. REYNOLDS and of his own regiment, on Sunday, and brings the first full and authentic account of the late battle between our troops under MILROY, and the rebels under JOHNSON, that has reached us.
lead_paragraph: Col. KIMBALL, of the Fourteenth Indiana Regiment, arrived in this City on Tuesday night, on his way home from Western Virginia. He left Phillippi, the headquarters of Gen. REYNOLDS and of his own regiment, on Sunday, and brings the first full and authentic account of the late battle between our troops under MILROY, and the rebels under JOHNSON, that has reached us. He was not present, but from the official report of Gen. MILROY, and the statements of officers engaged in the battle, has learned enough to give us a fair idea of its plan and result. The enemy were posted in an intrenched position near Yager's farm, about eleven miles directly east of the camp at Greenbriar, where Gen. REYNOLDS defeated them last October, and where by the way, as our men have learned beyond question, by the graves found in the camp, and from the reports of prisoners, we killed fully 500, and inflicted a total loss of about one thousand, in spite of the reports to the contrary, After the retreat of the enemy from that position, the main body scattered, probably joining other divisions, leaving about two thousand men at this Yager camp, to hold our forces in check. Here they had intrenched themselves strongly, and undoubtedly expected to stay all the Winter. These Entrenchments consisted of four lines of earthworks and ditches, placed at various distances behind each other, so as to afford four successive lines of defence. The attack was left entirely in the hands of Gen. MILROY, who commanded the Brigade at that point, and he selected for it the Ninth and Thirteenth Indiana Regiments, and portions of one Ohio and the Second Virginia Regiments. The column marched on the night of the 12th, so as to reach the enemy and begin the light at 6 o'clock on the morning of the 13th. A battalion of the Ninth Regiment, under Col. MOODY, was ordered to make a detour to the enemy's left, so as to reach and attack them in the flank at the some time that Gen. MILROY attacked them in front. Owing to the darkness, and the wretched mountain paths, or no paths, through which this division had to pass, it failed to arrive at the time, and MILROY, expecting it every moment and eager for a fight, began the attack without it. The battle was warm and doubtful. Our force was unprotected, the enemy was intrenched, and at least two to our one. Once there were signs of wavering, and portions of some of the regiments fell into disorder. In the nick of time, Maj. DOBBS, of the Thirteenth, came up with a portion of that regiment which had been left behind, and restored the fight. A little after 8 o'clock, Col. MOODY, with his division, came up, joined the attacking column, and then our men began the work of cleaning out the intrenchments in earnest. One after the other of the four lines of breastworks and ditches was carried, the enemy rallying in the next one behind as fast as the one in front was stormed, so that our troops had to make four separate and hard fights of it before they cleared the field, At last, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, after a scattering but bloody battle, lasting all day, our men drove the enemy from the last earthwork, and were masters of the position. In the last ditch young JOSEPH GORDON was killed, after having fought with extraordinary gallantry all day, and killed five of the enemy. He was shot through the head, and died instantly. A little earlier in the fight, Capt. MADDEN, of the Ninth, was killed, but how we do not know. After driving the enemy from the intrenchments which protected their camp, our troops retired, it being then dark, and slept on the field, to renew the fight next morning. But the enemy had had enough of it. Our scouts, as soon as it was light, saw that the redoubtable chivalry had burned everything that couldn't be carried off, and would burn, and had retreated nobody knew where. Col. KIMBALL is satisfied that the rebel force is utterly disorganized, and that five hundred men cannot be found together anywhere in Western Virginia. We lost thirty men killed, and rather more than that number wounded. Of the enemy over 150 dead bodies were found in the intrenchments by our men before Col. KIMBALL left. Among them was that of a Colonel, supposed to be that of Col. JOHNSON, who commanded. On Saturday night a party of Col. KIMBALL's scouts brought in nine prisoners, among whom was the noted Col. STERN or STORM, who has been one of the most active leaders of the guerilla bands in the country. Two Colonels, and probably five hundred men killed and wounded, with thirty prisoners, make up a very handsome victory, and the enemy confess it by burning up their camp and scattering in every way. We lost nine prisoners, of the Ninth Regiment, by their headlong disposition to get ahead of the rest of the regiment. Our total loss, we suppose, is about seventy, in killed, wounded and prisoners.

abstract: We have seen and conversed with several gentlemen who arrived last evening from Munfordsville, the scene of the skirmish on Tuesday, some particulars of which we have already given. Among those with whom we have conversed are the Surgeon of Gen. ROCSSEAU's Brigade (who was at the scene of the fight) and Mr. HENRY MEYERS, who participated in the fight, both of whom are gentlemen of unquestioned veracity. Their statements are both to the same effect, and present the skirmish of Tuesday as one of the most brilliant exploits of the campaign on the part of the Federal troops.
lead_paragraph: We have seen and conversed with several gentlemen who arrived last evening from Munfordsville, the scene of the skirmish on Tuesday, some particulars of which we have already given. abstract: The American papers take it for granted, if a war between England and the United States should occur, in consequence of the refusal of the latter to yield to the just demands of our mother country, that Canada would speedily and inevitably be "chawed up." We do not intend to wage a wordy war on the point. We are prepared to consider the dangers of our position, and to do all that lies in our view to triumph over them. And, with the assistance we shall receive from Great Britain, we know we shall succeed.
lead_paragraph: The American papers take it for granted, if a war between England and the United States should occur, in consequence of the refusal of the latter to yield to the just demands of our mother country, that Canada would speedily and inevitably be "chawed up." abstract: SOUTH FERRY ATLANTIC-STREET RAILROAD.  The entrances to the Atlantic-street Tunnel, at the South Ferry, have been closed, and the street, being one hundred and twenty feet wide, has been restored to its original grade. The consummation of this change makes a great improvement in the street, for which the owners of property can well afford to pay the assessment levied therefor.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH FERRY ATLANTIC-STREET RAILROAD.--The entrances to the Atlantic-street Tunnel, at the South Ferry, have been closed, and the street, being one hundred and twenty feet wide, has been restored to its original grade. The consummation of this change makes a great improvement in the street, for which the owners of property can well afford to pay the assessment levied therefor. The tunnel being closed and the street restored to an easy and beautiful grade, far better railroad facilities are given to the public by the Brooklyn and Jamaica Railroad Company for the transportation of passengers and freight from the South Ferry to any station on Long Island. Trains, for the Winter, will leave the South Ferry for Jamaica almost hourly, and for Hempstead, Syosset, Farmingdale, Deer Park, Riverhead and Greenport, morning and afternoon, connecting with the trains of the Long Island Railroad Company at Jamaica, on their arrival from James-slip, by the way of the Hunter's Point route.

abstract: -- On Saturday afternoon, an explosion took place at the Bridesburgh Arsenal, which resulted in injury to several of the employes. It occurred in a frame structure, in which eight men and boys were at work, driving fuses into bombshells. A fuse in the hands of a boy named KELLER took fire, and communicated to a number of fuses in a bag in the room. Being composed of sulphur and meal powder the fuses scattered like chasers in all directions about the room. The workmen fled from the building, and got out before an explosion took place, which was caused by one of the fuses falling into a half-barrel of meal powder. The building was entirely demolished, and WILLIAM COONEY, a resident of Bridesburgh, was slightly injured by a piece of lumber striking him on the leg; the lad KELLER was out about the body and legs, and GEORGE THOMPSON was struck in the head with a splinter, and received a scalp wound. Several of the workmen had their hands burned. The explosion of a fuse by friction is an unusual occurrence, one that had not before taken place at the Bridesburgh Arsenal. The wounded persons were conveyed to their homes. About $500 loss was sustained by the Government.

abstract: The condition of the Union prisoners at the South not only justifies the determination of the Government to effect an exchange, but urges the exchange to be accomplished with all possible speed. The misery of these men is represented as extreme. Provided by their jailers with no better food than is fed, in periods of scarcity, to the slaves; half covered only with the tattered garments they took with them from the battle field; and, worse than all, held in a condition of enforced idleness and vacancy at a time when men of energetic temperment are eager for action and the duties of the field, they realize a punishment as pitiless as can well be inflicted by one human being upon another. The prisoners detained at the North fare far less cruelly. They are certainly exposed to the rigors of a climate to which they have never been used ; but the Government has supplied them with abundant food; their sick have been looked after with the utmost tenderness; charity has furnished clothing and a variety of contributions to comfort; and they have been exposed to none of that official harshness, and popular contumely, which have added so greatly to the misery of our brave fellows in Richmond and Charleston. The argument for the exchange is all in favor of the North; and the more rapidly it is urged, the more important the discount from the sufferings of its imprisoned soldiers. The only fear is that the practice of releasing rebel prisoners upon their repeating the oath of allegiance, will leave us short of material for the redemption of all our unfortunates.

abstract: The nature of the propositions which Lord Lyons is charged to lay before Mr. SEWARD still eludes public curiosity. Of this suspense the organs of secession are disposed to make the best possible use in the way of exciting popular apprehension, particularly as the lapse of each succeeding day renders a war loss likely to result from the forthcoming negotiations.
lead_paragraph: The nature of the propositions which Lord Lyons is charged to lay before Mr. SEWARD still eludes public curiosity. Of this suspense the organs of secession are disposed to make the best possible use in the way of exciting popular apprehension, particularly as the lapse of each succeeding day renders a war loss likely to result from the forthcoming negotiations. These professional alarmists assert, indeed, that no negotiations are to take place. They repeat that the surrender of SLIDELL and MASON is required to precede any diplomatic correspondence, and that a refusal to concede this vital preliminary, will render all peaceful adjustment impracticable. The conspicuous absurdity of these stories need hardly be indicated. History furnishes no precedent for such violent displacement of diplomatic forms, even in cases where, the fact complained of has been outrageous and even intolerable, and where the offender has been as inaccessible to pacific influences as the Bey of Tripoli or the King of Dahomey. We may rest assured that in the present instance, where England so much needs the support of the public opinion of the world, its Government will not adopt a course which must necessarily expose it to the censure of having forced upon the United States an inevitable quarrel, upon a foundation no broader than a variance in the interpretation of a maritime rule.

abstract: By the Persia we have tidings of the death of His Royal Highness Prince ALBERT, confort of Queen VICTORIA, Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha,  The event took place in London, on the 15th inst., after a brief illness, which was not considered dangerous until two days before it resulted in death.
lead_paragraph: By the Persia we have tidings of the death of His Royal Highness Prince ALBERT, confort of Queen VICTORIA, Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, The event took place in London, on the 15th inst., after a brief illness, which was not considered dangerous until two days before it resulted in death. His disease was gastric fever. A profound grief will be felt throughout Great Britain for the loss of this good and distinguished man, who, by his domestic virtue, his works of charity, his labors for the benefit of the English people, and by his scientific and literary attainments, had made himself loved and respected by both the high and the low. Prince ALBERT was a Christian and a gentleman as well as a Prince, and was more illustrious by his virtues than by his position. For twenty-one years he was in the eye of the English nation, and in every respect he sustained himself as few men in his situation have ever done. We can give but the dry record of his life.

abstract: In the Senate, Mr. DAVIS the new Senator from Kentucky, appeared and took his seat. A memorial was presented from citizens of Boston, representing that the freedom of the Press had been bridged, and asking relief. The bill making an appropriation of $1,500,000 for the construction of ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Mr. DAVIS the new Senator from Kentucky, appeared and took his seat. A memorial was presented from citizens of Boston, representing that the freedom of the Press had been bridged, and asking relief. The bill making an appropriation of $1,500,000 for the construction of gunboats for operations on the Western rivers was reported from the Committee on Finance, and passed. Mr. KING, of New-York offered a resolution, which was laid over, requesting the President to institute law proceedings against persons held in custody by Executive authority. A resolution was passed providing for a Select Committee of three, to inquire into the expediency of connecting some of the military and naval stations on the coast by submarine telegraph. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, introduced a bill providing against the return of fugitive slaves by the army, and for the punishment of any officer ordering it. The bill to increase the number of Cadets at West Point from 170 to 350 was taken up and debated at considerable length, but was not definitely acted upon. It receives much opposition on the score of economy.

abstract: The brig St. Mary, Capt. BREVOOR, which left Pernambuco on Nov. 16, loaded with sugar, reports that on Dec. 4, latitude 29째, longitude 69째, she encountered a N.E. gale of most unusual violence, which caused her to lay to for six days. During the storm her sails were split, and her bulwarks stove in. On Dec. 10, latitude 28째 37', longitude 72째 40', she encountered a suspicious-looking schooner ahead, which stood on the wind, until about five points on the brig's weather how, when she wore around and endeavored to head the brig off. The brig kept off, and was followed in chase by the schooner, but after a smart run she was left astern, evidently doing her best to overtake the St. Mary.

abstract: Last evening the hero of Lexington, Col. MULLIGAN, gave his second lecture before a New-York audience. The subject was "The Slege of Lexington," and it was, as usual, full of interesting details of the noble and gallant defence of that place. Despite the inclemency of the weather, Cooper Institute, where the lecture was delivered, was quite respectably filled by a highly intelligent audience, who listened to Col. MULLIGAN with evident delight. During the delivery of the lecture, Col. MULLIGAN was often interrupted with outbursts of genuine applause.

abstract: Gen. HUNTER'S Department, as recently organized, embraces the State of Kansas and the four vast Territories to its north, south and west Dakota, Nebraska, Colorado, and the Indian domain.
lead_paragraph: Gen. HUNTER'S Department, as recently organized, embraces the State of Kansas and the four vast Territories to its north, south and west Dakota, Nebraska, Colorado, and the Indian domain. In geographical extent it is far the largest of any of the military departments. His command comprises now about sixteen thousand men, mostly stationed at Leavenworth and other points on the Missouri River border, at Fort Scott and other points on the western land line of Missouri, with detachments at Denver and elsewhere in the Territories, and some in Missouri. The work to be accomplished is to defend Kansas from PRICE, RAINS and MCCULLOCH's marauders; to keep in subjection the wild Indians of the Plains; to rescue the Indian domain west of Arkansas from the hands of the semi-civilized secession red men; to tickle the ribs of Arkansas itself; perhaps to trepan Texas; and may be, in certain events, to make a bold push southward even for the Gulf of Mexico. The first part of the work, the defence of Kansas, may almost be said to be accomplished already, by Gen. POPE's dashing operations last week in Western Missouri; for PRICE will never dare now to move west of his present position, where he might be suddenly cut off from retreat by POPE, and the rest of his ruffians be as neatly bagged as a couple of thousands of them have just been by that intrepid General. The Indian difficulty is now also likely to find a very easy solution, since delegations from the tribes have visited Washington, and been impressed by the fact that the National army was what they loftily designated a "big thing." The whole army of this Department will thus speedily be set free for a Winter campaign in the seceded States of the Southwest or somewhere else. The troops composing this column are of the very best material for campaigning in the whole army. They are mostly Westerners, hardy and self-helping, accustomed to exposure, expert with the rifle, and full of adventure and the spirit of war. Most of them, too, have seen service during the past Summer in Missouri, and are anxious again to meet the rebel foemen with whom they have already measured blades. The force in the Department will probably be increased ere long to twenty or twenty-five thousand men. Under a dashing and valorous leader, this column will assuredly do work this Winter that will make the Western sky glorious.

abstract: The whole country is watching with intense interest the movement of the National armies in the field. But a subject not one whit less in importance, is the movement of the National finances. Secretary CHASE is bearing as great a burden as Gen. McCAELLAN, for without the success of the Minister of finance, the best of Generals and the best of causes must fail.
lead_paragraph: The whole country is watching with intense interest the movement of the National armies in the field. But a subject not one whit less in importance, is the movement of the National finances. Secretary CHASE is bearing as great a burden as Gen. McCAELLAN, for without the success of the Minister of finance, the best of Generals and the best of causes must fail. Mr. Chase has presented a scheme in his annual report, for utilizing the entire capital of the country in support of the war, without oppressing, but, on the contrary, actually benefitting those who lend their means to the Government. It is the duty of Congress to put this great scheme into practice, if it shall meet the views of that body. The proper Committee is at work, trying to embody the suggestions of the Secretary in a bill, which shall at the same time be guarded and perfected by their own skill and experience. The following is the first draft of the work upon which the Committee is engaged, its National Importance justifies its publication, and by preserving it for reference, the public may keep pace with such modifications as it may be subjected to.
headline: {'main': 'THE NATIONAL SCHEME OF FINANCE.; How Secretary Chase Proposes to Meet the Financial Wants of the Country.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE NATIONAL SCHEME OF FINANCE.; How Secretary Chase Proposes to Meet the Financial Wants of the Country.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE INAUGURATION OF DRAMATIC PERFORMANCES IN THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The drama was fairly inaugurated last evening in the Academy of Music. The house was well filled throughout, the audience including many of our most wealthy and fashionable families. If the Academy can be filled on such a tempestuous night as the last, the drama in Brooklyn may be said to be a fixed fact, and the applause meted out to the principal actors evinced how gratified the people were. This was confined to no particular portion of the house. There was a unanimous feeling of satisfaction. The play -- "Hamlet" -- was put upon the stage with unusual care, and those who took part in it were most cordially welcomed. Mr. DAVENPORT as Hamlet, Mr. J.W. WALLACK as the Ghost, Mr. MARK SMITH as Polonius, and Mrs. BARROW as Ophelia, at once ingratiated themselves with the people of this city. To-night will be presented SHERIDAN's comedy entitled the "School for Scandal," in which all of the principal artists of the company will appear.

abstract: We had an interview yesterday with SAMUEL D. HURD, OF Bangor, Maine, Second Lieutenant in Company C, of the Second Regiment of Maine Volunteers, who was badly wounded and taken prisoner a the battle of Bull Run, and who reached this city yesterday, on his return from Charleston.
lead_paragraph: We had an interview yesterday with SAMUEL D. HURD, OF Bangor, Maine, Second Lieutenant in Company C, of the Second Regiment of Maine Volunteers, who was badly wounded and taken prisoner a the battle of Bull Run, and who reached this city yesterday, on his return from Charleston. He left that city on Thursday, the 12th inst., having been one of some three hundred prisoners who were confined in the City Jail, which was burned during the late conflagration -- the prisoners making their escape by jumping from a small window -- the only one which was not barred. Mr. HURD was shot through both legs at Bull Run, and also wounded in the side. He was taken to Manassas, where his wounds were dressed by a rebel surgeon, named MCWILLIAMS, from Maryland. They were afterwards removed to Richmond, and confined in EDWARDS' tobacco warehouse, from which they were taken to Charleston -- about four hundred of the whole number being confined in Castle Pinckney, and the remainder, about three hundred, being sent soon after to the City Jail.

abstract: The New-England Society celebrated its fifty-sixth aniversary festival, at the Astor House, yesterday evening. The hour fixed for the commencement of the banquet was six P.M., but the hall was not thrown open until nearly seven, long ere which time a very large assemblage of members and invited guests crowded the adjacent parlors. Among them were many citizens of eminence from New-York as well as from New-England, and no inconsiderable representation of both arms of the National service.

abstract: Gen. L.B. Swan died at Rochester on Friday last, in the 53d year of his age. He was born in Onondaga County, resided in Utica until his removal to Rochester, thirty years ago, where he engaged successfully in the business of manufacturing water pipe. In June, 1851, he was appointed Brigadier-General by Gov. Hunt, and at once assumed command of the Twenty-fifth Brigade, Seventh Division, a position which he held until his death.

abstract: Gen. Sir FENWICK W. WILLIAMS, of Kars, the commander of the forces in Canada, has been here again all day, in consultation with the military authorities. He came down from Montreal by special train, to hold a council of war. What warthereat determined, of course I cannot tell. But this I know, that heavy guns and shot and shell are daily going west, and that the Imperial Commissariat are preparing to receive more British troops.

abstract: William Tillman, William Stedding, Donald McLeod and Bryce MacKinnon, libelants, vs. The schooner S.J. Waring, her tackle, &c., and cargo. -- SHIPMAN, J. -- This is a libel in rem. against the schooner S.J. Waring, her tackle and cargo, by which Wm. Tillman, Wm. Stedding and Donald McLeod, seamen, and Bryce MacKinnon, passenger, seek to recover salvage for rescuing the vessel and her cargo from a so-called prize crew, and bringing them safely into the port of New York. The three first-named libelants joined in one libel, and the latter instituted a separate proceeding. The two libels were consolidated, and are therefore treated as a single cause.

abstract: BARNUM's MUSEUM. -- It is so long since the man of letters had anything to do with the scene painter  that the partnership -- which was never of a very hearty kind -- may be considered permanently dissolved. The business is now carried on exclusively by the latter, assisted by a humble scrub with a pen whose duty it is to make all the human characters as idiotic as possible -- a task which he performs admirably, and to the entire satisfaction of the public. At least, we are led to this conclusion by the success of Mr. BARNUM's new Christmas piece, called "Ondina," which certainly supplies a vast deal for the eye, and a very little for the mind. In a spectacular drama the characters talk for the benefit of the carpenters, to fill up the time, in fact, whilst a new "set" is being made. SPURGEON, with or without his Gorilla, would, under such circumstances, be dreary. Miss KEENE, who knows what a colloquial Sahara is and how to get across it, borrowed a lesson from Parliamentary usage, and made some of her members talk against time on every political topic. The trouble was that they talked non-sense, and perverted the theatre from its proper use as a place of amusement to a dull debating society, where suckling statesmen sang comic songs and flirted with the Ballerine. Mr. BARNUM's dramatist has avoided this Scylla, but he has tumbled upon the Charybdis of dullness instead. Were it not for the scenery, one would die of such a piece. And it is this reflection which brings us back to the fact that it is the artist and not the author who is to be considered, and so considered, "Ondina" deserves to be successful.
lead_paragraph: BARNUM's MUSEUM. -- It is so long since the man of letters had anything to do with the scene painter that the partnership -- which was never of a very hearty kind -- may be considered permanently dissolved. abstract: The steamship North Star, which arrived at this port last evening, brought the mails, passengers and treasure which left San Francisco by the steamer of the fifth. She left Aspinwall on the evening of the 14th.
lead_paragraph: The steamship North Star, which arrived at this port last evening, brought the mails, passengers and treasure which left San Francisco by the steamer of the fifth. She left Aspinwall on the evening of the 14th. The advices from the United States of Colombia by this arrival are important. From Bogota, the capital, the news is twelve days later. The State of Santander had at last been pacified, by the submission of the rebel leader, CANAL -- leaving only two States in which there are men in arms against the Mosquera Government, Antioquia and Cauca; and the latest intelligence from there renders it probable that soon they also will submit, and the war be thus entirely ended. A conspiracy against the Governor of Panama is said to have been discovered among the Carthagenians, growing out of dissatisfaction at his adhesion to the Mosquera cause. The news from the South Pacific States is not specially important.

abstract: The Persia brings the unexpected and unwelcome intelligence of the death of the Queen's Consort, Prince ALBERT. The event has doubtless caused the profoundest regret in England, where the deceased had appropriated no small degree of the loyal affection with which the people regard the Royal family; judiciously identifying himself with every progressive and enlightened enterprise of his period, and devoting his time and revenue to experiments designed to mitigate the condition of the poorer classes. His zeal in promoting the International Exhibition of 1851, and that contemplated for the approaching year, has given Prince ALBERT a world-wide reputation as a cultivator and friend of the industrial arts. By zealously laboring in these directions, and by studiously avoiding interference in domestic politics, the Prince acquired a firmer hold upon the liking of the British people, than any previous occupant of a similar position. For a moment, indeed, during the Crimean war, doubts as to his thorough loyalty to the allied cause, and a suspicion that he secretly sympathized with and even intrigued for Russia, engendered his prosperity; but these suspicions having been found unjust, happily did not darken the closing days of the Queen's husband.

abstract: The decision of Judge SLIPMAN, which we published yesterday, in the salvage case of the S.J. Waring, deserves some attention. The action, as will be remembered, was brought to recover salvage compensation for the services  rendered by the colored steward WILLIAM TILLMAN, and three others, for recovering the schooner from the hands of a prize crew, who had been put on board of her on her capture ...
lead_paragraph: The decision of Judge SLIPMAN, which we published yesterday, in the salvage case of the S.J. Waring, deserves some attention. The action, as will be remembered, was brought to recover salvage compensation for the services rendered by the colored steward WILLIAM TILLMAN, and three others, for recovering the schooner from the hands of a prize crew, who had been put on board of her on her capture by the privateer Jeff. Davis. They had succeeded in carrying her within one day's sail of a port in South Carolina, when TILLMAN and one of the crew named STEDDING, undertook and effected her recapture, in which they killed the prize-master and his two mates. After the recapture, they, with the assistance of another sailor and a passenger, navigated the vessel in safety to New-York, although not one of them was acquainted with navigation. TILLMAN was the chief actor in the recapture, and in the subsequent sailing of the vessel, in which he supplemented his own experience as a sailor, with extracts from BLUNT's Coast Pilot read to him by the passenger.

abstract: We have now full details of the America's news and letters from our correspondents in England and France. Our London correspondent says that the British Government is preparing for war with the utmost energy; that businessmen are getting ready for the storm, and that nearly the whole English nation, including the mob, is reveling in literal madness on account of the alleged insult to the English bunting.
lead_paragraph: We have now full details of the America's news and letters from our correspondents in England and France. Our London correspondent says that the British Government is preparing for war with the utmost energy; that businessmen are getting ready for the storm, and that nearly the whole English nation, including the mob, is reveling in literal madness on account of the alleged insult to the English bunting. The air was thick with canards of every conceivable kind. Nevertheless, a majority of the ministry and of the commercial classes are opposed to war, and if MASON and SLIDELL were returned, a rational reaction may be expected. That, however, is universally demanded as a preliminary to any negotiations whatever. The Secessionists in Europe are in raptures over the prospect, and expect that the English Government will presently be their avowed ally. The British Press, or at least a part of it, is more temperate in its comments than it was a fortnight before; the Times, however, is as malignant as ever. Gen. SCOTT's letter had produced a mollifying effect in some quarters. Several liberal members of Parliament, among others JOHN BRIGHT, had made efforts to calm the excitement, but apparently with little effect. We have a report of the anti-war meeting in Dublin, and the speech of T. O'DONOGHUE, which was received with bravos, yells, hisses and cheers. It appears, however, that the Irish malignity against England is strong as ever. The Shipping Gazette shows that England is not dependent on this country for Breadstuffs; and that in that respect a state of war will make little difference to her. The English secession Presses were feeding the people with daily doses of the most astonishing lies -- some of which we copy. The Queen's proclamation forbidding the export of war material, is working to the damage of the manufacturers of certain kinds of arms.

abstract: Wm. P. Kirkland et al. vs. The Bark Fame, &c. -- SHIPMAN, J. -- This libel seeks to recover damages for injuries to a cargo of coffee transported in the bark Fame from Rio Janeiro to the port of New-York. From the evidence before the Count, it appears that the cargo was considerably damaged on the passage. The answer alleges that this damage occurred, not from any cause for which the bark or her owners are responsible, but solely from "the dangers and accidents of the seas and navigation," in which terms, the exception in the bill of lading exempts the carriers from all liability. It is clear, from the evidence, that a portion of the injury was caused by rats gnawing the packages. This fact was anticipated by the answer, and the latter alleges that due care was exercised, two cats being kept on board from the time the coffee was laden at Rio until it was discharged at New-York. The claimants insist that, having exercised due care and diligence, the injury by rats is within the exceptions of the bill of lading; and is to be deemed one of the "dangers or accidents of the seas and navigation." On the other hand, the libelants maintain, as matter of law, that damage to a cago by being gnawed by rats is not a peril of the sea, within the meaning of that term or the terms used in the bill of lading; and that, therefore, the claimants cannot exempt themselves from liability by showing that they took certain precautions to prevent it.
lead_paragraph: Wm. P. Kirkland et al. vs. The Bark Fame, &c. -- SHIPMAN, J. -- This libel seeks to recover damages for injuries to a cargo of coffee transported in the bark Fame from Rio Janeiro to the port of New-York. It is clear, from the evidence, that a portion of the injury was caused by rats gnawing the packages. The claimants insist that, having exercised due care and diligence, the injury by rats is within the exceptions of the bill of lading; and is to be deemed one of the "dangers or accidents of the seas and navigation." On the other hand, the libelants maintain, as matter of law, that damage to a cago by being gnawed by rats is not a peril of the sea, within the meaning of that term or the terms used in the bill of lading; and that, therefore, the claimants cannot exempt themselves from liability by showing that they took certain precautions to prevent it.

abstract: New-Mexico, in his Message to the Territorial Legislature, which met at the beginning of this month, says that, "while the war tax is just and right in itself," he thinks "New-Mexico should be relieved from the payment of it." He gives as reason for this, that the Territory suffers from Indian depredations fifty thousand dollars a year and upwards; and he thinks that if this fact were presented to Congress, a law for the exemption of New-Mexico would be pasted. In contrast with these lugubrious statements when speaking of the war tax, the Governor in another part of his message, gives the rosiest view of the financial condition and general prosperity of the Territory. The receipts paid into the Treasury during the year considerably exceeded the expenditures. The public debt is only twenty-three hundred and four dollars, and there is money enough in the hands of the officers, he says, to pay every dime of that. The gold mines of the Territory are spoken of as the richest and most productive upon the continent of America, and the principal mine is only thirty miles from the capital at which the Governor pens his message. The copper, iron and coal mines yield abundance of ore; iron and leather abound; wool can be had for the clipping; and the Governor says,, that a "[???]-grown sheep can be raised at less cost than a Spring Chicken!" It is certainly veryshabby and beggarly, after this, for GOV. CONNELLY or the Territory to ask to be relieved from paying into the National Treasury the trifling war-tax of $63,000, which is the sum apportioned to New-Mexico.

abstract: Among the veracious reports on the health of our troops, with which it is the ambition of some of our cotemporaries to enrich their columns, one of the most original has recently appeared in the Tribune. That journal gravely stated on Saturday that three of our invalid soldiers at Port Royal had been "frozen to death" in their tents.
lead_paragraph: Among the veracious reports on the health of our troops, with which it is the ambition of some of our cotemporaries to enrich their columns, one of the most original has recently appeared in the Tribune. That journal gravely stated on Saturday that three of our invalid soldiers at Port Royal had been "frozen to death" in their tents. Now, no one who has ever traveled in Georgia or South Carolina at the present season of the year, can fail to know that, in the temperature which usually prevails in that district, such an event could not possibly have taken place. The statement is an obvious misrepresentation, and our too pliant cotemporary has been imposed upon by some one who has an interest in exciting the public mind by falsehood. The fact is the weather at Port Royal has been so mild during the present month that, as our special correspondent stated in the letter we published on Saturday, Summer garments were still being worn, and invariably, as is well known, the mean temperature throughout the brief Winter is considerably above the freezing point.

abstract: It may be that the awful drama that crowds the time, all but puts out of mind the sweet pastoral of Bethlehem, which comes down to us balmy and fragrant through these twenty centuries, and lives again in men's thought this Chrismas Day. " On earth, peace, good will to men," is the sentiment of the day. Alas! it is to us an aspiration; not an actuality.
lead_paragraph: It may be that the awful drama that crowds the time, all but puts out of mind the sweet pastoral of Bethlehem, which comes down to us balmy and fragrant through these twenty centuries, and lives again in men's thought this Chrismas Day. " On earth, peace, good will to men," is the sentiment of the day. Alas! it is to us an aspiration; not an actuality. For while the customary chimes peal out their silvery gladness on the air, the ear catches from afar the hoarse braying of the trumpet which summons brother to battle with brother. Even the Christmas tree cannot but, for many of us, cast a gloomy shadow; there are blank spaces on its branches, where eyes that we have loved have shone and smiled; eyes that now, on the far outpost, keep watch for the advancing foe; eyes, it may be, from which the light is forever departed.

abstract: At the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, the United States steamer Crusader and the bark Restless  were put into commission at 1 o'clock. The Crusader carries an armament of ten 32-pounders, a crew of about 200 men, and a Sergeant's guard of marines. The Restless has four 32-pounders and a crew of 60 men.
lead_paragraph: At the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, the United States steamer Crusader and the bark Restless were put into commission at 1 o'clock. abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- M. HERRMANN, the conjuror, commenced a short season at this establishment on Monday last. It is, we think, more suitable for his entertainment -- which gains by proximity to the operator -- than the Academy of Music, where sleight-of-hand became a mere mummery of perspective. In point of decoration, too, Niblo's Garden will suffer nothing by comparison with the up-town temple of the Muses. During the rather protracted recess which it has enjoyed, the painters and decorators have been busy with their brushes and hangings; the upholsterers, too, have revolutionized the benches and seats, turning them into arm chairs, after the Academy fashion, but with more neatness. Nothingcan well be brighter or more beautiful than the present appearance of the house. The ornamentation is in simple good taste, and thoroughly well done. On Monday night, when the winds howled outside, and the snow, and the sleet, and the slush combined to make the pursuit of amusement a very serious undertaking, it was like stepping into fairy-land to find oneself in its shining corridors, and Mr. HERMANN's magic did not tend to dispel the impression. The great conjuror performed some of his best tricks, and was received with the usual favor by an audience not over-crowded, but better than could have been expected under the circumstances. No nicer Christmas treat could have been provided for the young folk than a visit to the Garden of Magic.

abstract: Yesterday and to-day the rebel batteries on the Potomac have been wonderfully employed in wasting powder and ball. Probably $1,000 would not replace the ammunition consumed in their pyrotechnic displays of the past forty-eight hours. Not a vessel has been disabled out of the sixty which have run their blockade within the above time, not a soldier victimized or injured.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: It is perfectly evident, from the whole tenor of our foreign advices, that the English people were at the latest dates in a perfect paroxysm of rage and indignation. Every pretence of listening to the dictates of common sense had been abandoned. War with the United States was the popular and paramount passion.
lead_paragraph: It is perfectly evident, from the whole tenor of our foreign advices, that the English people were at the latest dates in a perfect paroxysm of rage and indignation. Every pretence of listening to the dictates of common sense had been abandoned. War with the United States was the popular and paramount passion. Everybody, high and low, rich and poor, was striving to outclamor everybody else in his fulminations of wrath and revenge against this country. There was not the slightest disposition to listen to explanations, or to wait for apologies. It was a foregone conclusion that they were forthwith to have war, and the whole fabric of English society was rocking and rolling on the waves of this swelling and surging tide.

abstract: The chances are against the probability of a war between England and North America. On Tuesday we stated, on authority that excluded doubt' that in diplomatic circles it was understood that a reference would be made to LOUIS NAPOLEON, and yesterday the telegram confirmed our statement. The Emperor of the French has already offered his services as mediator, and they are pretty sure to be accepted.

abstract: trial of this unfortunate young man for the murder of MATTHEWS has resulted in a verdict of guilty. The case has been one of profound interest, and as such, has elicited the utmost skill of the legal gentlemen employed; and after a protracted inquiry, has certainly presented as thorough an analysis of the testimony as unsparing examinations and cross-examinations could procure. The testimony is such as we always regret to see relied upon in a criminal prosecution. The disgusting story of the detective; the depths of licentiousness, dissipation, and all manner of filth, through which the official avenger of blood was forced to wade, in pursuit of the murderer's secret; and the too obvious participation of strong drink in the confessions upon which the case mainly depended, are not the sort of instrumentalities right-minded people care to use or see used in the pursuit of truth and the promotion of social morality. But the story, vile as it is, has been told, and the jury interprets it as convicting the prisoner. The verdict, of course, declares him guilty of two murder's. The same hand that struck down MATTHEWS was red from the slaughter of WALTON; and if JEFFERDS be answerable for the one fact, he is so also for the others and in his entire inability to prove an alibi a strong presumption of his guilt, independently of the case made by the Police, unquestionably exists. The counsel for the prisoner will no doubt move a new trial, and perhaps obtain it; but they will have undertaken a hopeless task, unless they come prepared to account for the whereabouts of the convict at the hour when the two homicides were perpetrated.
lead_paragraph: trial of this unfortunate young man for the murder of MATTHEWS has resulted in a verdict of guilty. The case has been one of profound interest, and as such, has elicited the utmost skill of the legal gentlemen employed; and after a protracted inquiry, has certainly presented as thorough an analysis of the testimony as unsparing examinations and cross-examinations could procure. The testimony is such as we always regret to see relied upon in a criminal prosecution. The disgusting story of the detective; the depths of licentiousness, dissipation, and all manner of filth, through which the official avenger of blood was forced to wade, in pursuit of the murderer's secret; and the too obvious participation of strong drink in the confessions upon which the case mainly depended, are not the sort of instrumentalities right-minded people care to use or see used in the pursuit of truth and the promotion of social morality. But the story, vile as it is, has been told, and the jury interprets it as convicting the prisoner. The verdict, of course, declares him guilty of two murder's. The same hand that struck down MATTHEWS was red from the slaughter of WALTON; and if JEFFERDS be answerable for the one fact, he is so also for the others and in his entire inability to prove an alibi a strong presumption of his guilt, independently of the case made by the Police, unquestionably exists. The counsel for the prisoner will no doubt move a new trial, and perhaps obtain it; but they will have undertaken a hopeless task, unless they come prepared to account for the whereabouts of the convict at the hour when the two homicides were perpetrated.

abstract: at its height in Canada. To read the provincial journals one would suppose the great empire of Canada had received some greivous insult which demanded the utter extirpations of her foes. It is a little amusing to reflect how perfectly quiet Canada was under the Trent "outrage," until she heard from England. It was not until the old lion growled that the whelps thought of whining. Canada looks abroad for her resentments, as well as for her opinions, Governors, and other luxuries.

abstract: Yesterday was thoroughly Christmas weather. Old Thor had it thoroughly his own way, and made us know that it was time, much as our pockets might object to it, to sally out and purchase some toy or token to gladden the hearts of the little ones at home. Notwithstanding the war, the stores presented as gay an appearance as ever. Articles of every description were displayed for sale in the windows, from a miniature baby that could say "ma-ma," and "pa-pa," to a hippopotamus, that almost rivaled BARNUM's in magnitude.

abstract: The Senate only was in session yesterday -- theHouse having adjourned until to-morrow Several petitions looking to the emancipation of slaves were presented. The Committee on Naval Affairs was instructed to inquire into the manner in which war vessels have been fitted out at the Navy-yards, rumors of great extravagance having obtained currency. A petition of citizens of Boston relative to the freedom of the Press, was presented by Mr. HALE. After an Executive Session, the Senate also adjourned until to-morrow.

abstract: CHARLES JEFFERDS was yesterday convicted of murder in the first degree for the killing of WALTON and MATTHEWS, on the 30th of June, 1860. The Court sat from 10 o'clock yesterday morning until nearly 11 at night, and was crowded the entire time. The jury were out an hour and a quarter. On the announcement of the verdict, JEFFERDS rose, and, in an unfaltering voice, facing the jury, said, "Gentlemen, you have convicted an innocent man."

abstract: The intelligence of the death of Prince ALBERT produced a profound impression in this City, particularly among the British residents. The Cunard, and all the other English steamers in port, yesterday displayed their flags at half-mast, and all the principal ships of the Liverpool and London lines also displayed their colors at half-mast. Mr. ARCHIBALD, the British Vice-Consul, took immediate steps to convence a meeting of the British residents of New-York, with a view of initiating suitable proceedings in commemoration of the sad event. Telegraphic information from the British Provinces shows that the event will be made the occasion of suitable observances throughout the Canadas and Nova Scotia.

lead_paragraph: Col. H. M. DAY, formerly Lieutenant-Colonel of the First Illinois Cavalry, is in the City, having recently been at Washington, where he succeded in having himself and regiment mustered again into the service. The Colonel, as Lieutenant-Colonel, was with his regiment in the fight at Lexington, with Col. MULLIGAN, and was badly wounded in the leg. He is still quite lame, but expects to take his command, which numbers 1,140 men, into active service in a very short time.

abstract: --A remarkable collection of small  oil paintings, the work of an amateur artist of this City, will be sold by auction to-day at LEEDS  Co.'s rooms in Nassau-street. The pieces are mostly studies from nature--studies in landscape and waterscape, in foliage, in sky and cloud; and there are ...
lead_paragraph: -- A remarkable collection of small oil paintings, the work of an amateur artist of this City, will be sold by auction to-day at LEEDS Co.'s rooms in Nassau-street. The pieces are mostly studies from nature--studies in landscape and waterscape, in foliage, in sky and cloud; and there are also in the collection admirable sketches of foreign scenery and life. Some of these little gems are exquisite bits of coloring, exhibiting the touch and taste of a fine American genius; and they ought all to find eager purchasers and appreciators in these Holiday times. There is no better evidence of the general growth of American taste in art matters than the fact that such a collection is offered at public sale.

abstract: It is believed that the demands of the British Govermnent in regard to the Trent affair have been made known by Lord LYONS to our Government, and that these demands have been correctly foreshadowed by the British Press--an apology for the transaction, and the restitution of MASON and SLIDELL.
lead_paragraph: It is believed that the demands of the British Govermnent in regard to the Trent affair have been made known by Lord LYONS to our Government, and that these demands have been correctly foreshadowed by the British Press--an apology for the transaction, and the restitution of MASON and SLIDELL. An extraordinary cabinet meeting is reported to have been held yesterday, in reference to these demands the result of which was a determination to disavow the act of Capt. WILKES, and to give up the captive rebels, should this prove the only course through which to escape a war with England; but at the same time, it is alleged, our Government will require Great Britain to concede this as a definite settlement of the question of the right of search, and also that no interference shall be made by her at any time in behalf of the rebellion.

abstract: Lieut.-Col. HORACE BINNEY SARGENT, AND Mr. L. W. KNIGHT, Quartermaster of the First Massachusetts Cavalry Regiment, arrived here yesterday morning, and made arrangements with Col. FRANK ...
lead_paragraph: Lieut.-Col. HORACE BINNEY SARGENT, AND Mr. L. W. KNIGHT, Quartermaster of the First Massachusetts Cavalry Regiment, arrived here yesterday morning, and made arrangements with Col. FRANK E. HOWE, for putting the first battalion of this regiment, under command of S. GREELLY CURTIS, through the City to-day. This command numbers over 400 men and horses, and was to leave Boston yesterday, at 1 o'clock, by the Providence route, via New-Haven. The battalion will reach Twenty-ninth street and Fourth-avenue about 8 o'clock this morning, and without any formal reception, will march to the foot of Cortlandt-street, to take the boat to Jersey City and thence proceed to Annapolis.

abstract: --The an  nouncement that Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT has taken passage for this City in the Arago, which left Havre on the llth, and may be expected today or to-morrow, has occasioned considerable remark. It was understood when he left home that he intended to be absent for some ...
lead_paragraph: The an nouncement that Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT has taken passage for this City in the Arago, which left Havre on the llth, and may be expected today or to-morrow, has occasioned considerable remark. It was understood when he left home that he intended to be absent for some months, -- and his sudden return is therefore not unreasonably supposed to have some connection with the condition of public affairs. Our latest Paris correspondence stated that he had had a long interview with Prince NAPOLEON previous to his departure, and intimations have already been made in the Paris journals that the Emperor would gladly offer his mediation between England and the United States, if it should be found impossible otherwise to settle amicably the differences pending between them. It is by no means unlikely, if such a purpose is entertained by the Emperor, that Gen. SCOTT should have been selected as the medium of making it known to our Government. As the affair of the Trent has not yet been made the subject of diplomatic discussion, the Emperor could not suggest mediation through the ordinary channels of national intercourse. If England should assent to such a mode of settlement, we presume that our Government would not object to it. In our judgment, however, such a resort will not be found necessary.
headline: {'main': "GEN. SCOTT'S SUDDEN RETURN", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "GEN. SCOTT'S SUDDEN RETURN", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The London Saturday Review, of Dec. 7, comes to us literally overflowing with malignant abuse of the United States. It contains no less than eight articles upon the relations of the two countries,--and the evident purpose of each one of them is to excite among the ...
lead_paragraph: The London Saturday Review, of Dec. 7, comes to us literally overflowing with malignant abuse of the United States. It contains no less than eight articles upon the relations of the two countries,--and the evident purpose of each one of them is to excite among the English people, the greatest possible amount of hatred and detestation of the institutions, the Government and the people of this country. One of these articles only makes the least pretence of examining the main question at issue between the two nations on the ground of law and common sense; all the rest are bald and shameless appeals to the basest passions of an excited community. The one which forms the exception discusses the seizure of the rebel agents on board the Trent, and is worthy of some attention, although it prefaces its argument by the assumption that we have been guilty of a gross aggression, and that England might have at once declared war upon us, "raised the blockade and been hailed as a benefactor by her own citizens, and by every maritime State." It discusses the law of the case, and goes over the authorities which have been cited, in a much more judicial as well as judicious way, than any other article which we have seen in the English papers.

abstract: STEAMSHIP CAHAWBA, OFF CHARLESTON,  Saturday, Dec. 21, l86l.  The main channel of approach to Charleston harbor has been destroyed. abstract: We  are requested by a gentleman whose official position at the time enabled him to know all the facts, to contradict a calumny recently transmitted to a notorious New-York press by one of those letter writers here ...
lead_paragraph: --We are requested by a gentleman whose official position at the time enabled him to know all the facts, to contradict a calumny recently transmitted to a notorious New-York press by one of those letter writers here whose unscrupulous missives are well calculated to bring discredit on the whole fraternity. This gentleman denies that the Prince of Wales ever presented to President BUCHANAN any pictures of the royal family for the Presidential mansion or for any other purpose. The Prince, shortly before he embarked for England, sent to Miss LANE as a token of personal regard six loose sheets, containing likenesses of the Queen, Prince ALBERT, and four of their royal children. She had them plainly framed at her own expense, and hung up in the family sitting-room, until she should return to Wheatland.
