abstract: We learn from the Houston Telegraph of the 2d inst., that a council of war was held at Galveston on the Wednesday previous, the result of which has not definitely transpired. "It is rumored, however, ...
lead_paragraph: We learn from the Houston Telegraph of the 2d inst., that a council of war was held at Galveston on the Wednesday previous, the result of which has not definitely transpired. "It is rumored, however, that the conclusion arrived at, is that Galveston is untenable. In support of this rumor, the batteries on the bench have been removed, the powder and other munitions of war on the island have been taken to a place of greater security; a portion of the public records have been removed, and a building has been rented in this city to be used as a hospital, to which the sick in the Galveston hospital have been removed. So much for the action of the public authorities? Private parties are also migrating to a place of greater security, a number of whom came up to this city on the train Saturday. The Galveston News has rented an office in this city, and will soon remove here? All these things point to one direction, and leave but little room for doubt or conjecture. We must say that it is a little singular that our Galveston cotemporaries have not mentioned one word of these things. They must think to keep the enemy in ignorance by their silence, but experience has taught us that when a thing has become 'town talk,' the enemy find it out without the aid of newspapers. We believe in letting our people know what is transpiring affecting their interests, when the knowledge can serve them more than it will benefit the enemy, even at the risk of informing the enemy of it through our columns which in this instance we do not think at all likely."

They came in flying the secession flag. It was rumored that the authorities would not allow the Gladiator to land her firearms.

abstract: The Richmond Examiner, of Dec. 11, states that a bill had been passed in secret session of Congress granting a bounty of fifty dollars to privatesand non-commissioned officers who shall serve continuously three years or during the war, to be paid at the ...
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Examiner, of Dec. 11, states that a bill had been passed in secret session of Congress granting a bounty of fifty dollars to privatesand non-commissioned officers who shall serve continuously three years or during the war, to be paid at the end of their first term to those reenlisting for the next two years. The bill also provides for sixty days' furloughs, with transportation home and back, to twelve month men, who reenlist for the war, or two years longer. It is understood that the bill provides that troops reenlisted shall, at the end of the present service, have power to organize themselves into companies and elect their officers, and said companies will be allowed to organize themselves into battalions or regiments, and elect their field-officers.

abstract: A bill has passed the Legislature of Mississippi, authorizing an advance of treasury notes--not to exceed the sum of $5,000,000--to the planters of the State, upon the hypothecation of cotton valued at $25 a bale. The Senate proposed to pledge the faith of the State for their redemption--a feature which was stricken out by amendments on the bill going to the lower house.
lead_paragraph: A bill has passed the Legislature of Mississippi, authorizing an advance of treasury notes--not to exceed the sum of $5,000,000--to the planters of the State, upon the hypothecation of cotton valued at $25 a bale. The Senate proposed to pledge the faith of the State for their redemption--a feature which was stricken out by amendments on the bill going to the lower house. These notes are to be received in payment of all State taxes and dues, and it is contemplated to obtain the consent of the Congress for the Confederate collector to take them in payment of the national war tax, which the State has determined to assume. Another measure has passed, proposing to relieve the indigent families of volunteers, by levying thirty per cent. in addition to the regular State tax, which is to be distributed to the various counties in proportion to the number of soldiers they have furnished for the service.

abstract: --The  community was startled, this morning, by the tidings that Hon. SOLOMON G. HAVEN, one of our oldest and best-known citizens, was dead.
lead_paragraph: --The community was startled, this morning, by the tidings that Hon. SOLOMON G. HAVEN, one of our oldest and best-known citizens, was dead. We learn that the sad event was the result of a paralytic stroke. As a prominent member of the Bar, the law partner of Mr. FILLMORE, and the former Representative of this District in Congress, Mr. HAVEN was generally known, and everywhere favorably. Time denies to us, to-day, the preparation of a proper tribute to our departed fellow-citizen. We can only say, further, that his loss will be deeply and fervently regretted. -- Buffalo Commercial, 25th.

abstract: We have one most excellent symptom in connection with the English quarrel:--the public mind in this country is essentially calm and self-possessed. Our people have been entirely free from that insane frenzy which seemed at the latest dates to have absolute ...
lead_paragraph: We have one most excellent symptom in connection with the English quarrel:--the public mind in this country is essentially calm and self-possessed. Our people have been entirely free from that insane frenzy which seemed at the latest dates to have absolute control of public sentiment in England, and are prepared to look at the question in the light of common sense, and to act upon it from considerations of justice and of prudence. When the news of the Trent affair first reached this country, it naturally created some excitement. But the feeling did not partake in the least of hostility against England, or of any desire to insult the British flag: -- it was simple exultation that we had arrested two of the most prominent and most odious of the conspirators against our Government, and had them safely in our possession. Naturally enough, we went to work to convince ourselves, if possible, that no wrong had been done to England, -- that we had law as well as feeling on our side, and that England would probably acquiesce in that view of the case. We do not think that any of our people were prepared for so violent and insane an outbreak of popular passion, as occurred upon the receipt of the news in Great Britain. But even this has not had the effect of goading us into a similar insanity.

abstract: "An expedition on a large scale is being fitted out at Norfolk to proceed against Hatteras Inlet, and retake what was captured from them by Commodore STRINGHAM. The fleet will consist of eleven large ...
lead_paragraph: "An expedition on a large scale is being fitted out at Norfolk to proceed against Hatteras Inlet, and retake what was captured from them by Commodore STRINGHAM. The fleet will consist of eleven large >side-wheel steamboats and propellers, and a number of ship's launches, taken from the Norfolk Navy-yard. It is expected to rendezvous at Roanoke Island, and when joined by the gunboats now fitting out at the navy-yard and iron works at Norfolk, will at once proceed to the coast of North Carolina.

abstract: We are strongly inclined to doubt the authenticity of the statement published in the TIMES of Tuesday, from a soldier who claimed to have just returned from Charleston, concerning the alleged escape of Col. CORCORAN.
lead_paragraph: We are strongly inclined to doubt the authenticity of the statement published in the TIMES of Tuesday, from a soldier who claimed to have just returned from Charleston, concerning the alleged escape of Col. CORCORAN. There are very many points in the narrative which are open to suspicion. The Union prisoners, according to previous reports, were confined in the new prison, which was not within the district destroyed by the fire; and it certainly does not seem likely that three or four hundred of them would be left in an open room, from which they could so easily make their escape as they were represented to have done in this narrative. We have hitherto understood, also, that it was not the wounded among our prisoners who were removed to Charleston, but those who were best able to bear the removal. There are other features of the case which incline us to the belief that Lieut. HURD was indulging in some flights of fancy in the report which he made of his adventures in Charleston, and that he has really been no further South than Richmond.

abstract: --Our correspondent  who accompanied the famous stone-laden squadron from Port Royal to Charleston, gives a most interesting account of the sinking of the sixteen old whalers in the main entrance to Charleston Harbor.
lead_paragraph: -- Our correspondent who accompanied the famous stone-laden squadron from Port Royal to Charleston, gives a most interesting account of the sinking of the sixteen old whalers in the main entrance to Charleston Harbor. Some doubt had been entertained as to the efficiency of the plan, from the fact that the attempt to destroy the channel at Ocracoke, on the North Carolina coast, was a total failure -- a still wider channel having been presently formed by the shifting sands at the side of the old one. Capt. DAVIS, however, took this hydrographic difficulty into consideration, and by an ingenious arrangement of the old hulks, checkerwise, cuts up the passage into an intricate series of whirling eddies, which are utterly incapable of being navigated. The plan will no doubt be entirely effectual, and give JEFF. DAVIS what his soul has so long been yearning for -- a perfect blockade.

abstract: -- Hon. W.P. Sheffield, of Rhode Island, is a most unfortunate man. Some time ago, while in this City, he fell and fractured his leg in such a way that he was laid up for months. Just now he is attending to his duties as member of Congress, and a few days since, while alighting from an omnibus in front of the Interior Department, a sudden start of the vehicle threw him to the ground. Some severe bruises, from which his injured limb was not exempt, were the result.

lead_paragraph: CORONERS' INQUESTS.--MICHAEL LYNCH died very suddenly on Tuesday evening, at the lodginghouse of CORNELIUS MALONEY, No. 37 Park-street. Deceased was a native of Ireland, 50 years of age. The Coroner will hold an inquest to-day .... ELIZABETH McGUIRE, living at No. 90 Tenth-avenue, died suddenly on Tuesday night. The Coroner was notified. ....EDWARD THOMPSON, a soldier in the Fifteenth Regiment New-York Volunteers, Col. MCLEOD MURPHY had been in the City on a furlough, and was returning to his regiment on the 18th inst. He had arrived in Baltimore, when by some means he struck his head against the sharp portion of a railroad car, and fractured his skull, from the effects of which he died on Tuesday in the latter city. His remains were brought on here yesterday, and the Coroner notified. Deceased was a native of Ireland, 32 years of age, and resided at No. 653 Seventh-avenue....The body of an unknown man was found yesterday in the North River, at the foot of Thirty-seventh-street. It was taken to the dead-house of Bellevue Hospital, and the Coroner notified....An unknown man was found dead yesterday in the cellar of a new building in West-street, one door below Jay-street.

abstract: In the show-room of the Ames Manufacturing Company at Chicopee, near Springfield, Mass., hang two remarkable specimens of cavalry sabres, the history of which is thus given: Some two years ago the manufacture of swords was commenced at the Richmond Armory.
lead_paragraph: In the show-room of the Ames Manufacturing Company at Chicopee, near Springfield, Mass., hang two remarkable specimens of cavalry sabres, the history of which is thus given: Some two years ago the manufacture of swords was commenced at the Richmond Armory. To this armory at Richmond the stolen machinery from Harper's Ferry has since been added. A couple of thousand of these pruning-hooks were turned out, and then scabbards were wanted for them. But the chivalry had hammered out the blades into as many different shapes as there were swords, and no two alike. A scabbard made for one would not interchange with any others! So they shipped them to the Ames Company, with a request to have them fitted to scabbards, or rather (in order to have the symmetry of their shape) to have scabbards fitted to them! A job of this nature would have non-plussed almost any one else, but Yankee ingenuity prevailed over the stupidity of the Hotspurs; the swords were provided with scabbards, and two of them preserved as mementoes of the ingenuity of the age.

abstract: --It is a very curious  fact that scarce a day passes without an announcement from Washington of some wedding in the army. Generals, majors, lieutenants, captains, corporals and high privates, all seem to be busy marrying and giving in marriage.
lead_paragraph: --It is a very curious fact that scarce a day passes without an announcement from Washington of some wedding in the army. Generals, majors, lieutenants, captains, corporals and high privates, all seem to be busy marrying and giving in marriage. The only difference appears to be that the privates wed not singly but in battalions. At least there was, the other day, an account of the marriage of forty soldiers in the grand army of the Potomac. If the matrimonial mania goes on at this rate, it is more than likely that the chaplains will find it an economy of labor to perform the interesting ceremony -- say, by platoons! And on this point, if we are not able to cite an exact precedent, there is, at least, on record an acconnt of baptism having been performed in this wholesale style. The story is told of a Polish Bishop, who, being called upon to perform the ceremony on a heathenish and unchristened army, summoned them by battalions, and, waving a huge besom over them, baptised the first as collective Peter; second, Paul, etc. Why should not some such plan he inaugurated in what is, in more senses than one, our grand Union army?

abstract: TIGHT BARNS.--The Massachusetts Ploughman has the following eminently sensible remarks on a very important subject: "Cattle must have air, or they die. Hay must have air, or it becomes musty. Corn must have air in the crib, or it rots.
lead_paragraph: TIGHT BARNS.--The Massachusetts Ploughman has the following eminently sensible remarks on a very important subject: "Cattle must have air, or they die. Hay must have air, or it becomes musty. Corn must have air in the crib, or it vote. Many farmers seem not to understand this; and they inclose their barns as tight as double-boarding will permit -- making it necessary to give their hay two or three hours more sunning than it would need in barns that admit some air between the boards. It is an universal law that all living animals require air. Even fish in the ponds die very soon when deprived of air. They inhale a small quantity through their gills; and, by closing those gills tight with twine, they die in their own element. Some animals require much more than others. Those living under water require the least, while the fowls of the air require the greatest quantity, and their blood is warmer than that of cattle. But the blood of fishes is comparatively cold. The alarming fever among cattle, which prevailed here last year, was generally supposed to have come from Holland, whence Mr. Chenery, of Belmont, imported his cows. Different opinions were given on this point; but most of the papers on fanning were filled with accounts of fevers that had often prevailed in Germany, England and France. And they had not the least doubt that Mr. Chenery had imported the German fever with the German cows. But we are now confirmed in the opinions heretofore expressed by us -- for Mr. Chenery himself told us, last week, that he had no doubt the fever among his cattle was caused by their being confined closely in his very tight barn. His agent, also, who has the care of his cattle, stated to us explicitly that the want of free air was the sole cause of the fever. And now for tight barns. Why will practical farmers continue to throw away their money in buildings barns so tight that the cattle cannot breathe in them -- so tight that the hay becomes musty, and the horses become diseased with the heaves? We have been recently informed that a gentleman in Walpole has been building a barn so costly that but few farmers could think of imitating it. The cost was $6,000. Well, it was filled with hay last Summer, but it could not hold hay. Soon after haying was over the owner went into his barn, and declared that the hay was on fire. It actually smoked so much that he thought spontaneous combustion must take place. He ordered the mows to be overhauled, and the side-boards to be opened to let in air. His hay, of course, was nearly spoiled, and would be worthless without removal. It is cruel to keep cattle tied up in cold barns, as many have done, where drafts of air pass through, and the frost freezes hard the manure behind them. But the poorest farmer can prevent all this, if he has ingenuity enough to place his principal haymow on the cold sides of his barn, to stop all draft of air through it. The hay maybe dealt out in Winter in such a way as to leave that portion of the mow on the cold side or sides untouched till mild weather comes. A hay-cutter will leave the mow in good trim. The wall boards of barns should not be jointed. It is loss of labor and of lumber to make the edges straight by planing or jointing. Good barn boards will come together quits close enough by merely pressing them together by means of a small iron bar. Boards put on in this way will keep the snow out, and let a little air in -- enough to keep hay from spoiling and cattle from catching fevers."

abstract: For reasons but too evident to the sense of every citizen, the high festival of the Christian Church, sacred forever to a fallen race, was not cele  brated yesterday with that boisterous and exuberant hilarity which has for a generation past distinguished its recurrence in this City.
lead_paragraph: For reasons but too evident to the sense of every citizen, the high festival of the Christian Church, sacred forever to a fallen race, was not cele brated yesterday with that boisterous and exuberant hilarity which has for a generation past distinguished its recurrence in this City. Christmas to our people has been the gala day of our tenderest associations the very jubilee of every kindliest and purest thought. In comparison with all other days of the whole year -- working days and festive ones alike -- we have made it what the charmed circle of home is, contrasted with the dullness or turbulence of the outer world. From infancy to manhood, the anniversary of the Saviour's birth has been the heaven of memory. Dedicated to God by the laws and observances of our religious faith, it has been continually sanctified in our hearts by the traditions of family and home. It is with the Christmas times of by-gone years that most of us associate the pleasantest and fondest recollections that are left to us of all that we have loved and lost; or with the hope of its return, bearing wealth and honors to our hearths, that we connect the inmost longings of the future. Because then Christmas among us belongs to the fireside where parent and child, sister and brother, have been wont, each year, to reassemble for the renewal of fond pledges, and the sharing of innocent joys, it was outwardly less gay with us here than for half a lifetime gone. Too many were far away, exposed to privation, wounds and death; too many had already paid the debt of patriotism in the sacrifice of their lives, and still too many more were groaning on beds of sickness or mutilation, not to leave the public heart full of sober reflection, sometimes of heavy grief. But even this changed mood gave in the minds of most a higher significance to the day. The glow of the national purification rested on the popular gaze, and where, here and there, the battle-cloud obscured a spot of the horizon, it seemed but to enhance the splendor of the morning close at hand for our country and the system she defends. In this spirit, a vast portion of our people went heartily to work in the celebration of the merry Yule-tide. A grand body of irrepressibles, and among them the Celt and the Teuton loomed up largely, and defying pestilence, famine and death, in the pursuit of their native humor, gave full vent to jollity in a Metropolis where no one of the terrors indicated existed beyond the realm and sway they always claim in any hive of human beings.

abstract: "J.W. BUTLER, formerly a member of the Fusiliers," says the Boston Journal, "has recently received the appointment of pilot and guide for the coast of the Gulf of Mexico. He is now in this city, waiting conveyance to the Gulf. Mr. BUTLER was in command of a schooner which was trading in the Gulf of Mexico when the rebellion broke out.
lead_paragraph: "J.W. BUTLER, formerly a member of the Fusiliers," says the Boston Journal, "has recently received the appointment of pilot and guide for the coast of the Gulf of Mexico. He is now in this city, waiting conveyance to the Gulf. Mr. BUTLER was in command of a schooner which was trading in the Gulf of Mexico when the rebellion broke out. He remained at Pensacola until August, when he effected his escape, bringing with him several other Union men and three or four ladies. He was enabled to give to Col. BROWN, in command at Fort Pickens, much valuable information as to the rebel defences, and brought away a series of not far from fifty photographic views of the defensive works in and about Pensacola, which were taken for Gen. BRAGG. Some of these he still has with him, but most of them have been detained by Col. BROWN, and by the authorities at Washington, to whom they are of great value. Mr. BUTLER says there are many Union men in Florida, but they are watched by a Committee of Safety, and are completely intimidated. His rate partner was hung shortly after he left, on suspicion of being a party to his escape."

abstract: The memory of man extendeth not back to the time when the weather was more propitious for a holiday than yesterday, and right well was it im  proved by all. All business throughout the city was suspended, and even the bar-rooms--an unusual occurence--were very generally closed. In many of the churches there was the usual service or a festival.
lead_paragraph: The memory of man extendeth not back to the time when the weather was more propitious for a holiday than yesterday, and right well was it im proved by all. All business throughout the city was suspended, and even the bar-rooms--an unusual occurence--were very generally closed. In many of the churches there was the usual service or a festival. At an early hour in the morning the usual Mass was sung in the Catholic churches, which were appropriately decorated for the occasion, as were the Episcopal, Universalist and some of the Unitarian and Presbyterian Churches. Those who sought pleasure in out-door sports, found it. The skating-ponds were particular objects of attraction. From an early hour until late every skating-pond within the city limits presented an animated scene, as it was the first opportunity for skating the present season. Constitutional Engine Company No. 7 took occasion to bring home their new steam-engine, manufactured by the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company of Manchester, N.H., at the expense of $3,700. This engine is one of the best yet made, and is finished and mounted in the best style. The "boys" of No. 7 are as pleased with it as a child with a new doll, and well they may be, for, besides being useful, it is a beautiful thing to look upon. The Company received the machine in New-York in the morning, and, preceded by a band of music, crossed to this city, and, after marching through some of the principal thoroughfares, drew up in front of their house, on Front, near Bridgestreet. The house of Engine Company No. 7 has just been completed at a cost of $3,400. The building is 50x25 feet, and is constructed of brick, with brownstone facings, and is three stories high. The lower story is the engine-room, and the two upper stories are used for other company purposes. The old and young, everywhere, seemed bent upon enjoyment, and nothing occurred to mar the festivities of the occasion.

abstract: --We beg leave to  suggest to the editor of the Albion, whether he would not serve the cause of his own country more effectively, by seeking to allay, rather than inflame, the hostility of Englishmen resident here against the Government of the United States.
lead_paragraph: -- We beg leave to suggest to the editor of the Albion, whether he would not serve the cause of his own country more effectively, by seeking to allay, rather than inflame, the hostility of Englishmen resident here against the Government of the United States. His laborious attempts to prove that the Secretary of State has pursued a policy and held a tone intentionally insulting and offensive to England can certainly do nothing toward preserving peace, even if they were ten times as successful as they are. We appreciate fully the delicacy of the Albion's position, and have frequently borne testimony to the tact and discretion which have marked the editor's usual treatment of controverted questions that now and then arise between the two countries. An English newspaper, in New-York, ought to be thoroughly and entirely in the interest of peace; and whenever its editor makes up his mind that the interest or honor of the country which he more immediately represents demand war, he should also decide to advocate that policy on his own soil and under his own flag. We should be sorry to believe that the editor of the Albion has arrived at any such conclusion, but the general tone of his paper does not seem calculated to promote the preservation of peace.

abstract: We  thought we had become tolerably familiar, from reading the Herald, with the acts of which unprincipled and unscrupulous demagogues feed the angry passions of a sensitive and excited community.
lead_paragraph: We thought we had become tolerably familiar, from reading the Herald, with the acts of which unprincipled and unscrupulous demagogues feed the angry passions of a sensitive and excited community. But even the Herald may learn something in this line from the London newspapers. There seems to be nothing too monstrous for their use, -- no falsehood too palpable, no invention too transparent, if it only panders to the malignant passions of the English people.

abstract: One of the most striking results, so far, of the war, is the complete change it has wrought in the financial condition of our Government. A year or two ago, with only one important source of revenue, impost duties, we could hardly make way with the immense amount ...
lead_paragraph: One of the most striking results, so far, of the war, is the complete change it has wrought in the financial condition of our Government. A year or two ago, with only one important source of revenue, impost duties, we could hardly make way with the immense amount of money it produced. We were the envy of other nations, while our complacency at our fortunate position scarcely knew any bounds. But we have left behind us, and we fear forever, the happy age in which every want, apparently without any effort of our own, was more than supplied. Henceforth our ingenuity will be racked to the utmost to make both ends meet. We are poring over the elaborate systems that bring such countless sums into the exchequers of France and England. In our necessities, we have changed places with these countries. They, not ourselves, are the happy nations in possessing systems of taxation so thoroughly digested as to produce annually, without apparent hardship, sums equal to that which we find difficult to raise, both by taxation and loans. We have equal wants but unluckily are not only unused to the burdens they impose, but are puzzled beyond measure to adopt them to our own shoulders, so as to be borne without really weakening us, or what is equally to be avoided, without dissatisfaction and complaint.

abstract: Col. C.F. TRIGG, of East Tennessee, arrived in Cincinnati on Thursday evening, from Knoxville. The Colonel left that city two weeks ago, with his son and six gentlemen, and, after a hazardous and fatiguing travel over the mountains, reached London, Ky., a few days since, where he left his party, and reached Cincinnati alone.
lead_paragraph: Col. C.F. TRIGG, of East Tennessee, arrived in Cincinnati on Thursday evening, from Knoxville. The Colonel left that city two weeks ago, with his son and six gentlemen, and, after a hazardous and fatiguing travel over the mountains, reached London, Ky., a few days since, where he left his party, and reached Cincinnati alone. He represents the condition of affairs in East Tennessee as desperate. The Union men, although compelled to remain silent and undemonstrative, are firm as rocks and true as steel to the good old Government, but their fidelity daily costs them dear.

abstract: It is thus seen that, in the present case, there is only an embarrassment, resulting from the similar designs of the two Governments to reach one common object by different courses, without knowledge of each other's dispositions in that respect.
lead_paragraph: * * * It is thus seen that, in the present case, there is only an embarrassment, resulting from the similar designs of the two Governments to reach one common object by different courses, without knowledge of each other's dispositions in that respect. There is nothing more. We propose, as a nation at peace, to give to Great Britain as a friend what she as a neutral demands of us, a nation at war. We rejoice that it happens so. We are anxious to avoid all causes of misunderstanding with Great Britain; to draw closer, instead of breaking, the existing bonds of amity and friendship. There is nothing good or great which both nations may not expect to attain or effect if they may remain friends. It would be a hazardous day for both the branches of the British race when they should determine to try how much harm each could do the other.

abstract: The sixteen ships of the stone fleet which have gone to their final moorings on Charleston bar, and around which the heavy masses of sand are now settling, will effectually close all passage into or out of the original secession city by that line. They will effectually blockade the port so far as the main ship channel is concerned, and will relieve our regular blockading fleet from duty in that direction.

abstract: The British schooner Jane Campbell, of Liverpool, formerly the Herndon, of Washington, N.C. was yesterday afternoon brought into this port as a prize, by Acting Master JOHN BAKER, of the bark Brazilian. She was taken by the steamer State of Georgia, off Beaufort. She was from Liverpool for Havana, and has a cargo of salt and some flannel. She had been lying off Beaufort for some days, and was seized by order of the Commodore of the fleet. She was towed to the Navy-yard.

abstract: Gen. SCOTT arrived in this City by the steamer Arago yesterday. When coming up the Narrows the steamer was boarded by a number of gentlemen, among whom was Surveyor ANDREWS, who entered the cabin and congratulated the General on his safe return home. As the Arago neared her dock a salute of four guns was fired from the deck of the vessel lying at the pier. About two hundred citizens were assembled on the pier, and when the General had reached, with some assistance, the end of the plank, he was greeted with three hearty cheers. He immediately stepped into a carriage which was in waiting, and accompanied by Mr. HOYT, his son-in-law, was driven to the Brevoort House, where he will remain for the present. He sent several dispatches to Washington last evening.
lead_paragraph: Gen. SCOTT arrived in this City by the steamer Arago yesterday. abstract: The corner-stone of  the new City Hall was laid yesterday with extensive ceremonies, which will be found in detail in another part of thi, morning's TIMES. Several addresses were delivered, devoted mainly to historical reminiscences.
lead_paragraph: The corner-stone of the new City Hall was laid yesterday with extensive ceremonies, which will be found in detail in another part of thi, morning's TIMES. Several addresses were delivered, devoted mainly to historical reminiscences. We do not see in any one of them any very satisfactory explanation of the reasons for throwing upon the City this enormous additional burden just at the present time, nor any estimate of the rate of taxation which our citizens will be required to submit to within the next few years, according to present appearances. The rate was two per cent. this year, and will pretty certainly be three next year. Probably a steady increase of one per cent. per annum may be anticipated for some time to come, unless the Legislature steps in to arrest some of the many projects by which our City authorities are inclined to spend the public money and test the public patience. Unless we are greatly mistaken we shall soon see a movement for effectual financial reform in our City affairs.

abstract: Before the daring exploit of Capt. WILKES became known in England, the London News was distinguished for its generous and steadfast advocacy of the Northern cause.
lead_paragraph: Before the daring exploit of Capt. WILKES became known in England, the London News was distinguished for its generous and steadfast advocacy of the Northern cause. It not only championed the National Government against the London Times, the Herald, the Saturday Review, and other revilers and contemners of the American people, but became the medium through which loyal Americans in Europe might file their answers to the misrepresentations of those papers. But the cartel of the "Purser of the Trent," put the News fairly to the right about. No Tory organ was more thoroughly out of temper, and given over to more revengeful appetite. The demand for redress, which Ministers were assumed to be drafting, was required to take the form of an ultimatum. The steamer waiting to carry it out was to be followed by the entire available navy. Armies were to be forthwith launched upon Canada; the Empire was to be placed upon a war footing -- not so much by way of intimidation, as of precaution against the supposed hostile animus dictating the policy, of which Capt. WILKES was the instructed agent. It was in fact the worst feature of the first English intelligence after the fact, that the steadiest friend our people was known to have in the English Press should turn thus fiercely against us, excelling, indeed, in its ferocity, the attitude of the Times itself. And from the intensity of the attendant popular demonstrations it was only too clear that the News represented the English opinion of the moment more faithfully than did its more cautious cotemporary of Printing-House-square.

abstract: The steamship Arago, with mails, reached this port yesterday, and a synopsis of the Niagara's news two days later, was transmitted to us from Cape Race. Gen. SCOTT is a passenger by the Arago, and he returns in greatly improved health. Twelve hundred more troops, besides military slaves, sledges, etc., had arrived at Hali ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Arago, with mails, reached this port yesterday, and a synopsis of the Niagara's news two days later, was transmitted to us from Cape Race. Gen. SCOTT is a passenger by the Arago, and he returns in greatly improved health. Twelve hundred more troops, besides military staves, sledges, etc., had arrived at Halifax. On the 28th of last month, the pirate Sumter had captured an American ship in the West Indies, but released her on the Captain promising to pay $26,000 three months after peace was declared. A British war-steamer had arrived off St. Thomas to protect British vessels. The London Press are rivaling Punch in the absurdities of their stories about United States affairs. On the question of peace or war they are still quite belligerent. The News, however, advises arbitration, which the Morning Herald opposes. In some of the journals there are evidences of returning reason. At a United Prayer Meeting, Hon. BAPTIST NOEL and others fervently prayed for peace. Lord SHAFTESBURY thought this a rebuke to the Government, and that it would be better to pray privately for peace. Various religious bodies, together with the Peace Society, were deprecating hostilities. The Bight Honorable J.K. MOWBRAY thought the Trent outrage "quite unparalleled," and announced his intention to support "the honor of the Queen." The Times is very severe on JEFF. DAVIS and his Confederacy, as well as on the Union States; it criticises terribly DAVIS' late message. We copy the main articles.

abstract: The first reception of the Brooklyn Art Association (second season) took place last evening at the Academy of Music, and attracted a brilliant assemblage of the fashion and beauty of the sister city.
lead_paragraph: The first reception of the Brooklyn Art Association (second season) took place last evening at the Academy of Music, and attracted a brilliant assemblage of the fashion and beauty of the sister city. One hundred and thirty-nine pictures were exhibited in the Gothic concert-room of the establishment, many of them from the easels of our best-known artists. We can do no more than barely mention the names of the most prominent exhibitors: KENSETT; (very good) GIGNOWX; (several excellent compositions and many studies;) COLEMAN, (the "Banks of the Guadalquiver," very fine) CARMIENCKE; RITCHIE, HALL, DE HAAS; GIFFORD (a sunset of Windsor Castle, remarkable for boldness of color,) HALL, EDWIN WHITE, (the best genre picture in the exhibition,) WM. HART, HUBBAHD, BIERSTADT, (a vivid and thoroughly effective representation of the first bivouac of the Seventh Regiment in Virginia; one of the best pictures the war has given us;) LOUIS LANG (No. 9 good; No. 75 the other way) and Rev. A.A. WILLETTS, (a piece called "Sheep.") We give the names as they occur in the catalogue. There are many poor paintings, but the lovers of the quiet and unpretentious will find sufficient good ones to interest them.

abstract: The three transports the Persia, Australasian and Melbourne Conveying the British troops to Canada, are reported in the St. Lawrence, and were, at last tidings, momentarily ...
lead_paragraph: The three transports -- the Persia, Australasian, and Melbourne -- conveying the British troops to Canada, are reported in the St. Lawrence, and were, at last tidings, momentarily expected at Quebec. If this were not an exceptional season, this would have been impossible; for, not for a score of Winters, has the navigation of the St. Lawrence been open at this date. They will not do more than reach Quebec, however, for, a week ago, the ice had already begun forming at that part of the river, and would presently, if it has not done so already, interpose its cold infrangible blockade against Britain's belligerent preparations.

abstract: We have had skirmishes every day, for a week, culminating yesterday in an affair of some magnitude. The first engagement in which we sustained any loss took place on Sunday, the 15th. About ten o'clock on that day, a body of thirteen Texan rangers made a sudden dash at our advanced picket post, a mile beyong Green River, on the railroad.
lead_paragraph: CAMP WOOD, at Munfordsville, Ky., Wednesday, Dec. 18, 1861.

abstract: The United States transport steamer Baltic, J. J. COMSTOCK, Commander, which left New-York on Dec. 6, at 1 P.M., with the Seventy-fifth Regiment New-York Volunteers, returned to this port yesterday morning. She arrived at Fort Pickens on Dec. 13, at 5 P.M., and after landing the troops and cargo left her anchorage at 1 A.M. on the 19th. She arrived at Key West at 5 P.M. on the 20th, and having taken in coal sailed on the 22d, at 6 A.M., arriving at Sandy Hook Dec. 25, at 12 o'clock M.

abstract: At a regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen held yesterday, an ordinance was presented, prohibiting the burning of lights on board vessels lying at the City wharves, unless enclosed in glass globes or ...
lead_paragraph: At a regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen held yesterday, an ordinance was presented, prohibiting the burning of lights on board vessels lying at the City wharves, unless enclosed in glass globes or lanterns, under a penalty of $25 for each offence, and prohibiting also the use of camphene, burning fluid, &c., under the same penalty. It was laid over. The Comptroller was directed to report whether the Supervisors have legally acquired title to the land taken for the new Court-house, and what provision has been made for the payment of the same. [This is in consequence of the Commissioners having recently inclosed [???] additional space for a stone yard.]

abstract: -The Anti-AmericanAmerican frenzy runs so high in Montreal, that the intended celebration of the anniversary of the Landing of the Pilgrims by the New-England Society was abandoned. Extensive arrangements had been made for the occasion and our Consul, Mr. GIDDINGS, was to have delivered an address; -- but the apprehension of some disturbance led to the abandonment of both address and dinner. Our provincial neighbors are evidently "on the rampage."

abstract: Captain and brevet Maj. JOSEPH A. HASKINS' Company (D) of the First Artillery, arrived on Tuesday from Fort Washington, Md., en route to Fort Taylor, Key West, Fla. They are at the Park Barracks, and expect to remain there until the steamer General McClellan leaves for Fort Pickens and Key West. They have been stationed at Fort Washington for the last eight months, and have had full employment in placing that fort in proper order, mounting guns, &c.

abstract: In the Senate, after the usual presentation of petitions. Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, offered a resolution calling upon the President to transmit to the Senate copies of all dispatches which have passed between our Government and that of Great Britain relative to the seizure of MASON and SLIDELL.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, after the usual presentation of petitions. Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, offered a resolution calling upon the President to transmit to the Senate copies of all dispatches which have passed between our Government and that of Great Britain relative to the seizure of MASON and SLIDELL. Mr. SUMNER objected to its consideration. Mr. HALE advocated its passage in a speech of considerable length, in which he opposed the restitution of the rebel envoys, and advocated in preference a war with Great Britain. The resolution was laid over under the rule. Mr. GARRETT DAVIS, the new Senator from Kentucky, gave notice of his intention to introduce a bill confiscating every species of property of all persons who have had any connection with the rebellion, either in a civil, military or naval capacity. Mr. HARLAN, of Iowa, introduced a bill to establish a Provisional Government in all the seceded States. The Senate soon afterward adjourned until Monday.

abstract: No new developments relative to the Trent affair reach us from Washington. abstract: The London Times publishes a letter from THURLOW WEED, the main object of which is to defend the American Government, and Mr. SEWARD in particular, from alleged hostile intentions toward England.
lead_paragraph: The London Times publishes a letter from THURLOW WEED, the main object of which is to defend the American Government, and Mr. SEWARD in particular, from alleged hostile intentions toward England. He disclaims, on behalf of Mr. SEWARD, anyunfriendly feelings or intentions toward England, and says that the threat of insulting England which Mr. SEWARD made to the Duke of Newastle, was merely idle talk and badinage. Mr. WEED says he believes if England's dispatch to Lord LYONS is peremptory in tone, it will meet with peremptory refusal. He appeals for moderate counsels on both sides as the only method of avoiding a collision.

abstract: We suppose it to be pretty well understood that the Banks will go no further with their loans to Government than the third $50,000,000, three instalments of which have already been paid. They will then have on hand $110,000,000 of the loan, a sum very nearly equal to their capitals.
lead_paragraph: We suppose it to be pretty well understood that the Banks will go no further with their loans to Government than the third $50,000,000, three instalments of which have already been paid. They will then have on hand $110,000,000 of the loan, a sum very nearly equal to their capitals. They should go no further, if they could. They should retain means enough to afford all needful accommodations to the mercantile community. In a little over four months they will have furnished something over a million dollars per day. It is not probable that sales of Government bonds can be made for the future at an equal rate. As its wants are steadily increasing, it must seek other sources of supply. Mr. CHASE proposes to make up the anticipated deficit by establishing a uniform system of free banking, with United States stocks as security for the redemption of its bills. By making the law compulsory, he assumes that a market equal to $200,000,000 would be created for such securities. This plan, which could not fail, if attempted to be put into immediate operation, to force three-quarters of the Banks into liquidation and bankrupt the whole community, receives, as far as we can learn, no response whatever from the public, and will not, we presume, be seriously entertained by Congress. A free banking law may be passed, without any compulsory clause, which will remain a silent letter upon the statute book.

abstract: A prisoner who escaped from the rebel camp at Hermanville last Saturday, reports that when the news that Gen. POPE'S cavalry had driven in Gen. RAINS' pickets at Johnson, was received by Gen. PRICE'S army, the greatest confusion pervaded the rebel camp. The cavalry, artillery, infantry, and raw, ragged, unarmed recruits were mixed up in inextricable conusion, and many hours elapsed before anything like order was restored.

abstract: The files brought from England by the Edinburgh exhibit an unexpected improvement in the tone of the British Press. In another column we produce a series of extracts from journals collectively of vast circulation and influence, which unite in deprecating a war...
lead_paragraph: The files brought from England by the Edinburgh exhibit an unexpected improvement in the tone of the British Press. In another column we produce a series of extracts from journals collectively of vast circulation and influence, which unite in deprecating a war upon a ground so frivolous as the search of the Trent, and concur in recommending a reference of the case to arbitration, and a submission to whatever award an impartial tribunal may make. When the first tidings of the transaction reached England no such voice was raised. The rush of popular indignation carried the entire Press along with it. The London Star and Manchester Examiner called indeed for a suspension of judgment until the American representation of the affair should arrive; and doubted whether a belligerent motive had prompted the instructions under which Capt. WILKES was presumed to act, but they went no further. To-day we find a score of influential newspapers sturdily combating any resort to war; and a few of them going so far as to justify the action of the American Captain by appeal to British precedents. The change is striking and gratifying. When the Ministerial Press shall have sufficiently out-vapored and out-thundered the Conservatives to render moderation possible without risking a Parliamentary defeat, it too may be expected to join in the cry for peace, and show all readiness to meet half way the pacific dispositions of the American Government.

abstract: We have reason to believe that our Government has made a reply to the representations of the British Government in regard to the violation of the British flag in the case of the Trent, which is considered satisfactory by the British Minister, -- and that no further differences need be apprehended between the two Governments in connection with this affair. Of the terms of this arrangement, we are not prepared to speak: it is needless to say, however, that they are perfectly honorable to the country, and such as, we have not the slightest doubt, the people will fully and heartily approve.

abstract: To those who retain a taste for primitive customs, the apple-paring which commenced on Thursday night, in the old-fashioned New-England kitchen connected with the Fair for Volunteers' Children now progressing on Broadway, will afford a memorable Christmas pastime. Seven members of an apparently...
lead_paragraph: To those who retain a taste for primitive customs, the apple-paring which commenced on Thursday night, in the old-fashioned New-England kitchen connected with the Fair for Volunteers' Children now progressing on Broadway, will afford a memorable Christmas pastime. Seven members of an apparently regularly constituted Down East family, dressed in strictest Puritan garb, do the honors --" Jerusha," the bound girl, making herself particularly conspicuous in her attentions to the demands of visitors who are inclined to partake of her tempting array of pumpkin pies and apple sass. A gentleman, while allowing her to make his cup of coffee, suggested thepropriety of her pouring in "more milk." She caused, looked hard at him a minute, and, drawing a long breath, exclaimed: "Dew tell! morn milk? Why, to tell the truth, we've got eleven keews, all told, but there ain't but one on 'em givin' milk neow. Dun no what on airth's the reason. The baby keeps gettin' fits, tew, and we gin him goose-grease in in'ardly and out'ardly, but tain't no use." All this is sung out as near in one breath as possible, and in the conventional Yankee nasal twang.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- LAST NIGHT OF WILLIAM HANLON. -- This evening is positively the last performance of WM. HANLON at the Academy of Music, and in addition is given for the benefit of Mr. G.L. FOX. When we mention that Mr. G.L. FOX is decidedly the best pantomimist in the country since the RAVELS have departed from us, and that he is one of the two enterprising managers who undertook the task of presenting WM. HANLON to the public, in his present great gymnastic feat, we feel certain that he will achieve the main end of benefits -- a crowded house. There will be no matinee to-day, it being decided late last night to forego it, on account of a slight accident to Mr. HANLON.

abstract: The Albany Evening Journal suggests a reason or two for believing the conversation which Mr. SEWARD is reported by a London journal to have had with the Duke of Newcastle, in regard to a war with England to be a wholesale fabrication.
lead_paragraph: The Albany Evening Journal suggests a reason or two for believing the conversation which Mr. SEWARD is reported by a London journal to have had with the Duke of Newcastle, in regard to a war with England to be a wholesale fabrication. The conversation is said to have taken place in September, 1860, and Mr. SEWARD is represented as saying, "My Lord Duke, either Mr. LINCOLN or myself will be next President of the United States," at a time when Mr. LINCOLN having been nominated by the Republican Party, it was morally certain that Mr. SEWARD could not be the next President. And moreover, Mr. SEWARD was upon his Western tour at the time indicated, so that his first encounter with the Duke of Newcastle was at New-York toward the close of October. Perhaps, after these evidences of untruth in material points, the whole story may be permitted to pass as a falsehood.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Joseph Nimmo, native of Ireland, 29 years of age, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the fourth degree, in having caused the death of Christopher Colwell at No. 306 Mulberry-street, on the night of the 9th of November, l861.
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Joseph Nimmo, native of Ireland, 29 years of age, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the fourth degree, in having caused the death of Christopher Colwell at No. 306 Mulberry-street, on the night of the 9th of November, 1861. The accused threw a [???] at deceased during a quarrel, which was commenced by deceased without provocation, and the injuries inflicted terminated in abscess of the brain which resulted fatally some three weeks after. Remanded for sentence.

abstract: J.W. ZACHARIE, one of the rebel agents captured on board a British schooner, and at present confined in Fort Lafayette, is one of the wealthiest merchants of New-Orleans. His warehouse in that city, located on Custom-House-street, will be remembered by many of our shipmasters as an immense establishment. Mr. ZACHARIE has three children, a daughter aged about 19, and two sons, now in the hardware business on New-Levee-street. His appearance is somewhat repulsive, on account of a certain amount of hauteur, which, however, he will probably lose before the United States is ready to part with him. His correspondents in this City included some of our heaviest Broad and South-street houses. With Mexico his business was immense, he chartering every year hundreds of coasters for the trade. Great efforts will no doubt be made to obtain his release.

abstract: Gen. SCOTT makes no secret of the real motive of his hasty return from Europe. He desires it to be understood that he came clothed with no mission and charged with no message whatever, from any foreign prince or power; that he had no interview either with the Emperor NAPOLEON or with M. THOUVENEL, ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. SCOTT makes no secret of the real motive of his hasty return from Europe. He desires it to be understood that he came clothed with no mission and charged with no message whatever, from any foreign prince or power; -- that he had no interview either with the Emperor NAPOLEON or with M. THOUVENEL, his Minister of Foreign Affairs; and that his reason for coining home was the apprehension of immediate hostilities between England and the United States, and the fear that, if he did not embrace this opportunity of returning, he could not return at all. The only high personage with whom Gen. SCOTT had any political conversation in France was Prince NAPOLEON -- and to him he expressed his confident belief that, if foreign nations did not interfere, the rebellion would be effectually suppressed by midsummer, and that before that time cotton for the supply of the immediate necessities of other nations would be supplied through the Southern ports of which our troops are taking possession. Gen. SCOTT states that the feeling in England and France was universal that war is inevitable. He shared it himself to the fullest extent until he reached this City. What he has since seen of public sentiment on this side the Atlantic has, however, very materially modified this opinion. The cause of the extraordinary anger of England, Gen. SCOTT believes, is the conviction on the part of the great body of the English people that the United States are resolved upon war, to punish England for her concession of belligerent rights to the rebel States. The affair of the Trent is regarded as having been made the occasion for manifesting this feeling toward Great Britain; and not one man in a thousand believed that the Government of the United States would disavow the act, or make for it the slightest reparation or apology, -- no matter how clear might be their conviction that it was in manifest violation of the principles of international law. Gen. SCOTT is satisfied, as every person in this country must be, that this assumption is utterly unfounded, -that this Government has not the slightest wish or willingness to insult Great Britain, and that any reparation consistent with National honor, for any wrong that may have been done, will be promptly and cheerfully afforded. And this, he believes, will be quite sufficient to prevent a war.

abstract: The approach of Winter in exceeding stern and inclement reality, is exciting in certain quarters complaints of the inactivity, and in fact lethargy, which are thought to have settled upon the great Union army. We are told that the unusually favorable weather of the Fall has been permitted to escape without...
lead_paragraph: The approach of Winter in exceeding stern and inclement reality, is exciting in certain quarters complaints of the inactivity, and in fact lethargy, which are thought to have settled upon the great Union army. We are told that the unusually favorable weather of the Fall has been permitted to escape without that military improvement which it seemed to invite; and that even now when retirement to Winter quarters would appear to be the dictate of humanity and prudence, we are left without any means of judging whether there is to be a winter campaign, or a suspension of hostilities until Spring, with its genial weather, shall make the path to glory smoother and easier. The assertion herein is that little or nothing has been accomplished, and the inference, that our military leaders are without any definite plans, and are in reality waiting upon the movements of the enemy.

abstract: ANOTHER RAILROAD WAR?THE POLICE ARE CALLED OUT TO KEEP THE PEACE.?The right of way through the streets of Brooklyn is considered so valuable that every new Railroad Company, after acquiring this right, has a long opposition of some rival interest to encounter, before being able to proceed to business, involving a loss of time, money and temper.
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER RAILROAD WAR -- THE POLICE ARE CALLED OUT TO KEEP THE PEACE. -- The right of way through the streets of Brooklyn is considered so valuable that every new Railroad Company, after acquiring this right, has a long opposition of some rival interest to encounter, before being able to proceed to business, involving a loss of time, money and temper. The City and Central Railroad Companies had a long and expensive contest about which had the best right to the use of Furman-street, and, after a year's wrangling, and the expenditure of a vast amount of money, they made a compromise. The Newtown Railroad Company and the Coney Island Railroad Company have been set by the ears through the secret machinations of another Company, it is believed, interested in having the operating of these roads delayed. The ostensible difficulty is about the approach to Fulton Ferry through Water-street -- both claiming exclusive privileges on this street. The Coney Island Company, seizing upon a favorable opportunity got their track down first, when the other company also attempted to lay another track on the same street, but were restrained by an injunction. Several injunctions have been granted on both sides, and amended and annulled so often that the parties in interest hardly know now where they do stand. At all events the Newtown Company resolved yesterday morning to tear up the track of the Coney Island Company, and at 11 1/2 o'clock commenced the work, when they were stopped by a posse of Police by direction of Superintendent KENNEDY, who also gave instructions not to permit either company to do anything in the disputed district until the legal questions involved shall nave been decided.

abstract: The condition of our relations with Mexico, at present, renders it probable that no effort will be made by our Government to interfere in any manner, either for or against the proposed tripartite schemes in that country. Mr. CORWIN, our Minister...
lead_paragraph: The condition of our relations with Mexico, at present, renders it probable that no effort will be made by our Government to interfere in any manner, either for or against the proposed tripartite schemes in that country. Mr. CORWIN, our Minister to Mexico, has made no treaty with the Mexican Government, as has been supposed, and he has appealed to the State Department for instructions as to his future course, in view of the momentous issues involved in the European interference. His papers, however, have been referred to the Senate, where it is likely they will remain without action. The allies will thus be allowed to carry out their purposes, with no obstacles except such as may arise from complications among themselves. It is believed that a scheme is on foot for placing MIRAMON at the head of the old Church Party in Mexico, for cooperation with the Spanish forces.

abstract: The redoubtable PRICE and his army are now retreating through Western Missouri toward Arkansas for the third time. When LYON was after him, he ran very swiftly; when FREMONT pursued, he made fair time; and now he flees from the advancing shadow of POPE.
lead_paragraph: The redoubtable PRICE and his army are now retreating through Western Missouri toward Arkansas for the third time. When LYON was after him, he ran very swiftly; when FREMONT pursued, he made fair time; and now he flees from the advancing shadow of POPE. For a month past, he has stood shivering by the south shore of the Osage River, looking across with longing eyes to the green fields and pastures new of Jackson, Lafayette and Saline Counties, yet fearing to launch his bark away. And now, at last, instead of boldly moving forward and confronting the Canaanites, he again skulks backward in his own tracks to the desert region that sweeps around the Ozark Mountains. Those of his men who did cross over the river were suddenly devoured by that son of Anak, Gen. POPE. And why should those still on the safe side of the stream venture over, when they know it will only be to exchange the free airs of the desert for the cadaverous atmosphere of the "St. Louis Medical College?"

abstract: Our Government has surrendered the four persons taken from the British steamer Trent, and has tendered, an apology to the Government for the violence offered to her flag. This is not the first time in which a similar proceeding has taken place.
lead_paragraph: Our Government has surrendered the four persons taken from the British steamer Trent, and has tendered, an apology to the Government for the violence offered to her flag. This is not the first time in which a similar proceeding has taken place. One of the incidents which preceded the War of 1812 was of a somewhat similar character, though not quite parallel in all respects. In 1808 a British man-of-war sent on board the American frigate Chesapeake and took from her four persons, who were claimed to be English subjects, without any other warrant or authority than the will of the officer commanding the vessel by which the outrage was perpetrated. Our Government at once demanded redress, and after a long correspondence and delay, the British Minister at Washington transmitted to the Secretary of State the following letter:

abstract: It was intimated in the TIMES yesterday morning, that the affair of the Trent had been adjusted on a basis which would probrbly prove satisfactory to both Great Britain and the United States. We this morning publish the diplomatic correspondence between the Governments of France and England on the one hand, and that of the United States on the other, concerning the question of in  ternational law, involved in the seizure of the rebel Commissioners.
lead_paragraph: It was intimated in the TIMES yesterday morning, that the affair of the Trent had been adjusted on a basis which would probrbly prove satisfactory to both Great Britain and the United States. We this morning publish the diplomatic correspondence between the Governments of France and England on the one hand, and that of the United States on the other, concerning the question of in ternational law, involved in the seizure of the rebel Commissioners. The first document is a note from Mr. SEWARD to Mr. ADAMS, in which the case is briefly mentioned, and in which Mr. SEWARD says that the action of Capt. WILKES was without any instructions from the Government, and he trusted that the British Government would consider the subject in a friendly temper. Then follows a note from Earl RUSSELL to Lord LYONS, dated Nov. 30, reciting the English version of the case -- declaring that the act of Capt. WILKES was an affront to the British flag, and a violation of international law; and announcing that the "liberation of the four gentlemen named, and their delivery to your lordship," together with a suitable apology for the aggression, alone could satisfy the British nation. To this Mr. SEWARD responds in a paper, addressed to Lord LYONS, under date of the 26th inst., in which he analyzes at great length the principles of public law involved in the case, and arrives at the conclusion that the Government of the United States would be wrong in refusing to comply with the British demand, so far as relates to the disposition that shall be made of the persons captured. He closes by saying that the "four persons in question" will be cheerfully liberated; and your lordship will please indicate a time and place for receiving them." No "apology," however, is offered, because no offence was intended. To this Lord LYONS responds by announcing that he will forward the communication to Her Majesty's Government, and will immediately make arrangements to place the "four gentlemen" again "under the protection of the British flag." Beside these documents on the Trent case, there is a dispatch from M. THOUVENEL, the French Minister for Foreign Affairs, to M. MERCIER, the "Minister of the Emperor at Washington," in which THOUVENEL pronounces the conduct of the American cruiser unjustifiable, but hopes for a pacific solution of the difficulty. To this Mr. SEWARD responds in a note to M. MERCIER, in which he corrects an error of the Minister of Foreign Affairs, refers him to his correspondence with the British Government, and exchanges assurances of friendship. The whole correspondence will doubtless be universally perused.

abstract: The mails by the Nova Scotian, which came to hand yesterday, are one day later than before received, though the news is not so late as received by the Niagara. We make a variety of extracts, showing the temper of the Press and people of Great Britain on the Trent question. Prominent among them are the utterances of members of Parliament to their constituents.
lead_paragraph: The mails by the Nova Scotian, which came to hand yesterday, are one day later than before received, though the news is not so late as received by the Niagara. We make a variety of extracts, showing the temper of the Press and people of Great Britain on the Trent question. Prominent among them are the utterances of members of Parliament to their constituents. Mr. HORSMAN made a speech at Stroud on the 10th, in which he declared his belief that there would be no war, though he contended that the interests and sympathies of Englishmen were with the South. The London Times, in commenting upon this speech, commends its sentiments. Mr. SEYMOUR FITZGERALD made a speech at Bury on the 11th, in which he deprecated a war with the United States, and hoped it would be averted. Mr. FREDERICK PEEL also made a speech on the 11th, in which he counseled moderation in regard to the Trent affair. He likewise gave his views relative to the struggle between the United States Government and the rebellion, in which he expressed his belief that the North was fighting for dominion as well as for union, and that the South was fighting for self-government as well as for Slavery. Mr. H. BRAND, at Lewes, on the 10th, insisted that England regarded with the most friendly feeling the people of the United States, and looked upon war with them as a great calamity to be averted, if possible, without loss of National honor. Mr. MILLER, at Leith on the 10th, denounced the affair of the Trent as a gross insult to England, the culmination of a series of offences for which America ought to be punished. A short blockade of the Northern ports would decide the question of separation between the North and South, when England would be pretty sure of compensation for all the expenses incurred through a largely increased trade with the South.

abstract: The Globe says the following troops have been ordered to Canada in the Persia, Australasian, and Melbourne: Two battalions of infantry of the line, two batteries of artillery; and one company of Royal Engineers. The Melbourne has already sailed.
lead_paragraph: The Globe says the following troops have been ordered to Canada in the Persia, Australasian, and Melbourne: Two battalions of infantry of the line, two batteries of artillery; and one company of Royal Engineers. The Melbourne has already sailed. Arrangements are being made for forwarding to British North America two battalions of guards, four battalions of infantry of the line, three batteries of field artillery, five batteries of garrison artillery, two battalions of the military train, and two companies of the Royal Engineers. The two battalions of guards under orders are the first battalion Grenadier Guards now at the Tower, and the second battalion Scots Fusilier Guards now at the Wellington Barracks. The Rifle Brigade and first battalion of the Sixteenth are in course of embarkation, and the following battalions are held in readiness, viz.: The first of the Fifteenth and Ninety-sixth, and the second of the Sixteenth Regiment.

abstract: The prize schooner Charity, captured off Hatteras Inlet, the 17th of December, by the steamer Stars and Stripes, and placed in charge of GEORGE ASHBURY, master of the same, to be taken to this port, was wrecked off Hempstead Beach, last Tuesday morning. She was laden with a cargo of salt, sugar, coffee, clothing, boots and shoes, &c. She was wrecked about two miles from the beach.

abstract: If any European has a right to address words of counsel to the people of the United States, it is certainly that noble French Protestant whose book on America is the one just and generous judgment that has yet been rendered on our cause.
lead_paragraph: If any European has a right to address words of counsel to the people of the United States, it is certainly that noble French Protestant whose book on America is the one just and generous judgment that has yet been rendered on our cause. We mean, of course, Count AGENOR DE GASPARIN, author of the Uprising of a Great People. In the last number of the leading Parisian paper -- the Journal des Debats -- we find a long letter from his pen on the international difficulty that so lately darkened our horizon with war-clouds. It is a word of peace and of impartiality -- addressed to England and to the United States -- and breathes that same spirit of calm faith and candor that pervades his book on America. As the affair that, at the time of his writing, seemed so threatening has already been happily settled, there is no need nor interest now to enter into the line of argument which he uses in order to show Englishmen what limitations the case presents to the absolute judgment pronounced upon it, to disentangle the act of Capt. WILKES from the falsities that adhered to it, and to allay the passionate effervescence of the British public. Accordingly, we confine ourselves to translating a few remarkable sentences from his counsel to Americans, that acquire a peculiar significance in view of the events of the past day or two:

abstract: The diplomatic correspondence which the affair of the Trent has called forth between the French Government and our own, though of subsidiary importance, as compared with...
lead_paragraph: The diplomatic correspondence which the affair of the Trent has called forth between the French Government and our own, though of subsidiary importance, as compared with the great argument between the two Powers directly involved, yet possesses some features of remarkable interest; and the lucid dispatch from M. THOUVENEL to the French Minister at Washington may be read with advantage by those who would learn the varying aspects the case presents when seen in the light of the public law of different nations.

lead_paragraph: CORONERS' INQUESTS. -- Coroner SCHIRMER on Friday held an inquest on the body of MARY E. WALLACE, a child aged 6 years, who died from burns accidentally received on Christmas day, at No. 326 West Forty-seventh-street....An unknown man was found dead in the upper part of a building on the corner of Catharine-slip and South-street, Friday afternoon. The cause of his death is believed to have been intemperance. The Coroner was Dotified....A child named HANNAH TWOMEY, was accidentally burned to death Friday at No. 140 Cherry-street. Its mother had left the child alone in the room for a few minutes, and when she returned found it in flames. It died soon after. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest GEORGE FAULKNER died at the New-York Hospital Friday from injuries received by falling through the hatchway of WILSON's bakery, No. 73 Fulton-street, where he was employed. He was a native of Ireland, aged 32 years.... WILSON WELLS died Friday at the New-York Hospital from the effects of a fall which occurred while at work at the new building corner of Fifth-avenue and Fourteenth-street.... MARGARET CASSERLY was scalded to death on Friday at No. 648 Second-avenue, by falling into a kettle of boiling water. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest upon the body.

abstract: The correspondence to which we give place this morning quiets apprehension of war arising out of the seizure of MASON and SLIDELL. So far, indeed, as these documents...
lead_paragraph: The correspondence to which we give place this morning quiets apprehension of war arising out of the seizure of MASON and SLIDELL. So far, indeed, as these documents throw light upon the matter, no grounds of apprehension have at any time existed; for nothing can be more calm and reasonable than the dispatch of Lord RUSSELL requiring satisfaction, and nothing more evident than that the President has from the first been convinced of the defects in the American case, and prepared to discuss the topic without dogmatic adherence to an ex parte opinion.

abstract: While Americans are rejoicing, as they have heartfelt reason to rejoice, at the capture of two deliberate, designing traitors, Englishmen are roaring "like mad" about the insult to their flag. And here, even among our early allies and England's hereditary enemies, the public feeling is against us! This, while I am informed by some of the causes, is nevertheless unaccountable. The loyal Americans have set themselves earnestly at work to correct this perverse sentiment.

abstract: - The Legislature of Mississippi enjoys a unique reputation for financial successes. Witness its happy method of honoring the bonds issued to the Planters' Bank, and other clever devices for postponing indefinitely and otherwise the payment of its debts. The latest exhibition of its skill in this direction is a resolution now pending for advancing to the planters twenty-five dollars for each bale of cotton they hold. The boldness of the scheme consists in this, that the Legislature is elected by and composed of planters, who either propose to raise the necessary funds by taxing themselves or by taxing others. In the former case they only take money from one pocket to place in the other; in the latter case, they vote the property of others as distressed as themselves into their private pockets. But this juggle is not the only curiosity of the business. The cotton has been bought and paid for by the rebel Government in Confederate bonds. It is simply in the custody of the planters, the most of it not yet baled and roped. It requires all the license of Mississippi legislation to justify the Indemnification of a class of sufferers who have already been indemnified in full by a gratuity from the public treasury. But the planting interest is supreme in Mississippi; how can bankers, professional men, shopkeepers and mechanics help themselves?
