abstract: Mr. HORSMAN, M. P., addressed his constituents at Stroud, on the 10th. The right honorable gentle man referred to the principal questions discussed during the past session, and expressed his approval of the policy of non-intervention pursued by the Government with respect to the affairs of foreign nations.
lead_paragraph: Mr. HORSMAN, M.P., addressed his constituents at Stroud, on the 10th. The right honorable gentle man referred to the principal questions discussed during the past session, and expressed his approval of the policy of non-intervention pursued by the Government with respect to the affairs of foreign nations. With respect to the Hungarian question, he said: "I have no hesitation in expressing the opinion, which the friends of Austria ought to regard, that unless Austria does by some means or other conciliate her Hungarian subjects, the first shot fired in Europe may bring about such a state of circumstances that any man, a few years hence, looking at the map of Europe for the empire of Austria, may haply look in vain." Passing on to the affairs of America, he expressed his conviction that the truth with regard to the latter was as stated by Earl RUSSELL -- "that the North were fighting for empire and the South for independence." He continued: We know that the Northerns have been swelling almost to bursting with the contemplation of the future grandeur of the great American republic embracing one whole continent, with a population so vast, and so compact in its structure, that it would give the law to all the other nations of the world. I have never met with an American, with any traveler or writer who could give any assignable limit to an American's vision of the future grandeur of his country. He has looked upon it in commerce, in arts, in arms, in everything that promotes civilization, as the future government and guide of the whole world. On the other hand, the Southerns say that they desire immediate independence, and that they prefer independence to the yoke of partnership in future grandeur. They say that they are strong enough and large enough to maintain themselves. They argue that they lose more than they gain by their connection with the North, and that, in abandoning the North, they are merely giving effect to the same principle which the founders of the republic established when they repudiated their connection with England. [Hear, hear.] The war proceeds, and in a short time it is shown that the English Government were right in their estimate of the power and the prospects of the contending parties. The South has proved itself able to hold its own, and the North has shown not only military failures, but a complete break-down of civil government. There is not a security that was established for liberty of speech, writing, or motion, which has not been swept away; and there is not amongst the most despotic Governments of Europe one spot on the earth in which every constitutional right has been so entirely suspended, and in which the freedom of individuals is so utterly destroyed, as in the States of North America. [Hear, hear.] An opinion has been expressed that Democracy in America has failed. I am not desirous of going into that question now, but I may say that the result of what has been going on shows that the military enterprise of the North has so far proved a failure, and that its civil Administration is at this moment utterly disorganized, and has completely broken down. [Hear, hear.] The Cabinet of the North are in a state of great difficulty and embarrassment. The population have been so harrassed that they are almost in a state of desperation. They admit the war must be a long one. And then the question occurs, what is it for? It is obvious that the Union is not easily to be restored; and even if it could, we all know that a Union cemented by blood will not be the old Union founded by the original fathers of the Republic It is not, therefore, the question of the restoration of the Union. It is rather a question as to the terms of separation, as to the boundary to be established. That is a question for arbitration that could be more easily carried out before more blood is shed, before more exasperation is caused, than after a long, pernicious and calamitons war. [Hear, hear.] He next came to the affair of the Trent. The Law-Officers of the Crown have advised Her Majesty that the act complained of is a breach of international law, and, according to some semi-official statements which have been published, the Government have sent a dispatch to Lord LYONS, laying down the terms on which he is instructed to demand reparation from the Cabinet at Washington; and I believe there are two characteristics of that message which are generally acceptable to Europe. The first is, that the demand is said to have been made with great firmness; and the second is, that it is said to be couched in terms the most conciliatory, so as to give the American Government every possible opening to recede with honor, and not imposing upon them the slightest humiliation. [Hear, hear.] I believe that the proceedings of the Government have been approved of from one end of the kingdom to the other, and I believe it is the consciousness of the people that the right course has been pursued and steadily persisted in, that has produced the calm which pervades the whole community. [Hear.] So far as our interests and sympathies are concerned, they would go with the South. When the war first broke out, all our sympathies were ready to enlist themselves with the North, because they believed the cause of the North was that of emancipation; and it was only when we found that they were ready to compound with Slavery, to perpetuate Slavery, to combine all the profits of Slavery with all the advantages of professed abolition, that the reaction took place, and that the English public determined to observe that strict neutrality which to this moment has never been departed from. There was a danger, in the event of war breaking out, that we should be made participators in much we should disapprove, but his sympathies must go with the party that is most moderate, and the most ready for the conclusion of an early peace. [Cheers.] There is one plea the force of which we must all admit: the weakness of the North is not admitted; on the contrary, they are ready to push at the South, dispose of England, and help themselves to Canada. [Laughter.] We must remember that the abuse of England -- the menacing of England, has not only been a habit but a profitable trade in America. The newspapers are sold by it, the members of Congress get their elections by it, the Secretaries of State are raised to office by it, the Presidents mount the highest steps in the ladder by it. It is the whole political capital on which men thrive -- perpetually reviling and challenging England. We have disregarded it, as we could well afford to do: but it is our duty, in the interests of America, as well as in the interests of Europe, to see that she is brought to her senses, and we must teach her that if she wishes to be respected, that respect must be founded on her own regard for international obligations, her own respect for civilized law, and that she is not to be respected in proportion to her own menacing and bluster. [Cheers.] It is my ardent and sincere belief that there will be no war. In the first place, it is not the interest of the Northern States to go to war. What are they to do if they go to war? At present they are occupied altogether in the South. But they say, "We are dealing with the South. We may lose territory there, but we shall compensate ourselves by taking Canada. But what do the Canadians say to that? They say they live in too great a proximity to the great Republic, and have formed a very correct notion of the value of its connection. They think the English, monarchy is far more respectable. And there is another argument. If the Americans are unwise enough to show themselves over the frontiers of Canada, they may probably meet with rather a hot reception; and they will soon find some difference between a war with Canada and a war with the Southern States. After an engagement with Canadian regiments, when the Northern heroes run away, they will be followed over the frontier; and, instead of the States annexing Canada,it may happen that Canada may annex a goodly portion of the States themselves. [Cheers.] Well, then, what are they to do by sea? In the last war the American privateer was a very dangerous element to be considered, and people say you will have the American privateers again. But where are they to sail from? The whole South seaboard of the States, which were their great harbors both of exit and refuge, will be closed against them. No Northern privateers can sail from these harbors, and if one enters it will be captured. The whole of the ports of the European Powers are closed against privateers, and there are only two or three harbors which the Americans have, which can be easily blockaded, so that any attempt at privateering would be checkmated. [Hear.] I believe that when it is not the interest of America to go to war with us, it may also be shown to them that it is consistent with their character and honor to remain at peace. [Hear, hear.] I believe that these two motives combined will make them ready to meet half way the judicious concessions asked by England. But whether there was peace or war, he believed there was an end of the Union, and the separation would not only deal a death blow to Slavery, by rendering Fugitive Slave Laws impossible, but would also give strength to the Northern States. They would start up a new empire. The disasters of the present day having opened their eyes to the unsafe parts of the Constitution, they would form a stronger Government, when the few would govern and the many obey, instead of every man governing and no man obeying. [Hear, hear.] If war, he concluded, is to decide these painful and unhappy difficulties, there never was a time when England was in such a condition as to make the results of that war both brief and certain. Commercially, our position is sound. Financially it is so good, that while other nations are endeavoring to extricate themselves from the prospect of bankruptcy, the only quarrel with the House of Commons is, whether the Chancellor of the Exchequer shall put on or take off another million of taxes.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen, last evening, appropriated $500 each, to the Presidents of the Aldermen and Councilmen, for services as Health Commissioners. An appropriation passed to provide a...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen, last evening, appropriated $500 each, to the Presidents of the Aldermen and Councilmen, for services as Health Commissioners. An appropriation passed to provide a drill-room for the new Thirty-seventh Regiment, State Militia. JAMES F. MURRAY, was reimbursed $113 for damage done to his house by a mob, on the night of election. The sum of $250 was granted the reader for extra services. The Board concurred in the Railroad bill of the Councilmen. The Board of Councilmen held a regular meeting and rushed through a series of resolutions, confirming the grant, as conveyed in the "Gridiron" Railroad bill. It was violently opposed by Messrs. KEECH, LENT, ORTON and PINCKNEY, but as all proposed amendments were voted down by a distinct vote, the opponents were forced to yield, and the measure was finally adopted -- Ayes 13, Noes 10. An injunction having been served on some of the members, in the matter of the purchase of the "Fort Gansevoort" property, it was referred to the Corporation Counsel, with a request to report at the next meeting. The NEW YORK TIMES and World were made Corporation papers.

abstract: This regiment, Col. NELSON CONVERSE, arrived in this City Thursday, from Keene, Cheshire County, N.H., where it has been encamped since the 15th of last November. The steamer Connecticut was chartered to convey them here. Previous to leaving the encampment a handsome stand of colors was presented to the regiment by Gov. BERRY. Col. CONVERSE received the gift, on behalf of his men, in a neat and appropriate speech.
lead_paragraph: This regiment, Col. NELSON CONVERSE, arrived in this City Thursday, from Keene, Cheshire County, N.H., where it has been encamped since the 15th of last November. The steamer Connecticut was chartered to convey them here. Previous to leaving the encampment a handsome stand of colors was presented to the regiment by Gov. BERRY. Col. CONVERSE received the gift, on behalf of his men, in a neat and appropriate speech. The regiment has its maximum number, and such was the desire to join that upwards of two hundred men who presented themselves for enlistment had to be refused. Lieut.-Col. GRIFFIN was formerly a Captain in the Second New-Hampshire Regiment. Many of the other officers have also seen active service. All of the men are fully uniformed and equipped, but are not armed. Weapons -- Sharpe's rifles -- will be provided them in Washington. The men were landed at Pier No. 1, North River. During the afternoon they again embarked and proceeded to Amboy, by which route they will be conveyed to the capital. Subjoined is a list of the officers:

abstract: The mails of the steamship Niagara reached this City yesterday morning -- two days later than those by the Nova Scotian. An extended summary of her news has already been published, but we give elsewhere correspondence and extracts of interest touching the affair of the Trent. The tone of the British Press and people continues much the same -- with a rather more decided leaning toward peace. It was understood that Her Majesty, Queen VICTORIA, was much averse to a war with the United States, and even went so far as to have the first dispatch to Lord LYONS, as originally framed, modified into a more pacific form. Among our extracts will be found the letter of THURLOW WEED to the London Times, together with the ill-natured comments of that paper, and the speech of Commander WILLIAMS, of the Trent, detailing the part taken by him on the occasion of the seizure of MASON and SLIDELL.
lead_paragraph: The mails of the steamship Niagara reached this City yesterday morning -- two days later than those by the Nova Scotian. abstract: The heat edifice, just completed, for the St. John's Independent Methodist Church, in Forty-first-street, near the corner of Sixth-avenue, was dedicated yesterday with appropriate exercises. The Society was formed about three years since, commencing with eleven members and seventeen Sabbath School scholars. There are now eighty-eight members and over a hundred scholars. They worshipped in the Hall corner of Thirty-ninth-street and Broadway from June, 1858, until the completion of the present building. They differ from the Methodist Episcopal denomination in being independent of the Conference or Bishop, and choosing their own pastor for such time as to the Church shall seem most desirable. They own their church property, have no presiding elder, do not enforce attendance upon class-meetings as a condition of membership, and make their own code of laws instead of being governed solely by the ministry.
lead_paragraph: The heat edifice, just completed, for the St. John's Independent Methodist Church, in Forty-first-street, near the corner of Sixth-avenue, was dedicated yesterday with appropriate exercises. abstract: A MAN SERIOUSLY STABBED ON A JERSEY CITY FERRYBOAT.--About 12 % o'clock on Saturday night, a man named YOUNG, was seriously stabbed in the head just as he was leaving the ferryboat at Jersey City, Mr. YOUNG is an employe on board the Cunard Steamship America.
lead_paragraph: A MAN SERIOUSLY STABBED ON A JERSEY CITY FERRYBOAT. -- About 12 1/2 o'clock on Saturday night, a man named YOUNG, was seriously stabbed in the head just as he was leaving the ferryboat at Jersey City, Mr. YOUNG is an employe on board the Cunard Steamship America. Some parties who were desirous of creating a disturbance, made an attack upon YOUNG, and three other persons who were with him, and, it is stated, used very abusive language towards them, on the ground that they were Englishmen. The difficulty began at the Ferry-house on the New-York side, and the attacking party continued their denunciations of England and Englishmen while on the boat. When they arrived at Jersey City, the leader of the gang opposed to John Bull, drew a knife and struck it into the right side of YOUNG's head, near the ear. Such was the force of the blow that the blade was broken, and a portion of it left in YOUNG's head. Dr. VARICK was sent for, and succeeded in extracting the broken instrument. The name of the party who made the assault is unknown, as he succeeded in making his escape immediately after he had given the blow.

abstract: Accounts from all parts of the West Indies show that great indignation was felt by people of all classes throughout the islands at the attack on the mail steamer Trent by the American frigate San Jacinto. Her Majesty's ship Cadmus, 400-horse power, 21 guns, Capt. HENRY S. HILLYAR, C.B., senior officer of the windward station, had arrived at St. Thomas' from Barbadoes, having gone there to protect British vessels from any similar outrage. Admiral MILNE, with his squadron, was daily expected at Bermuda. Dispatches from the British Consul at St. Thomas, and a copy of the protest of Capt. MOIR, of the Trent, had been forwarded to the Admiral.

abstract: The extreme impropriety of sending home details of military movements in advance, or in fact affording any premature information whatever, somewhat restricts the choice of subjects; but there is one whose interest is neverfailing, and in regard to which new developments are constantly occurring. The slave question cannot lose its importance --cannot become backneyed. There are now in...
lead_paragraph: The extreme impropriety of sending home details of military movements in advance, or in fact affording any premature information whatever, somewhat restricts the choice of subjects; but there is one whose interest is neverfailing, and in regard to which new developments are constantly occurring. The slave question cannot lose its importance -- cannot become backneyed. There are now in Beaufort District, alone, I am informed by official personages, nearly 16,000 slaves, whose masters have fled, and Beaufort District is but a small portion of the country at present in our hands. I have accompanied a number of the reconnoissances made in all directions from this post, both by sea and land; have witnessed the exploration of the country from Tybee Island on the South, to North Edisto on the North, an extent of at least sixty miles, and have penetrated as far into the interior, on some of these excursions, as our troops have yet gone. Everywhere, I find the same state of things existing; everywhere the blacks hurry in droves to our lines; they crowd in small boats around our ships; they swarm upon our decks; they hurry to our officers, from the cotton-houses of their masters, in an hour or two after our guns are fired. I am writing now, not what I have heard, but what I have seen. I am not sending you opinions, or conclusions at which I have arrived, but facts that I have observed. I mean each statement I make to be taken literally; it is not garnished for rhetorical effect, but put into such a form as will most exactly convey to the mind of a reader the impression made on me. I have seen negroes who reported themselves as just escaped from their masters, who came breathless to our forces, and said they dared not go back, for their masters would kill them; who told that their masters were at that moment armed and threatening to shoot any slave that did not fly with them; who declared they had tricked their owners and came away in boats that they were bidden to take back to the whites. I have talked with drivers and field-hands, with house, maids and coachmen and body-servants, who were apparently as eager to escape as any. I have heard the blacks point out how their masters might be caught, where they were hidden, what were their forces. I have seen them used as guides and pilots. I have been along while they pointed out in what houses stores of arms and ammunition were kept, and where bodies of troops were stationed. In a few hours I have known this information verified. I have asked them about the sentiment of the slave population, and been invariably answered that everywhere it is the same.

abstract: Commander WILLIAMS who commanded the mail-bags of the Trent, and made a very great fool of himself at the time of her visitation by Capt. He has been making a speech in glorification of himself at a dinner given in his honor; and if our readers are curious to see how absurd a rigmarole a [???] brainless, ridiculous old officer can utter on such an occasion, we commend to them the perusal of his remarks. He seems to have had a congenial and sympathizing audience.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the Morning Star writes as follows: "In the affair of the Iroquois the Ensoch Government gives another lesson of political sagacity by when it would be well for others to take example. The living by this Federal war-ship upon an armed frigate of the Governor of Martinique, is treated completely in the light of a mistake, and no insult was taken where no insult was intended. Some of the journals deny that the Iroquois actually fired, but say that the Captain was in the art of ordering, the bulkhea is to be knocked down in order to prepare for action, when the officer of the vessel which he supposed to be a Confederate ship breaking the blockade, thought of hailing him and informing him he was mistaken. Others were about to publish to the contrary, or, at least, that version which has circulated through Paris, and which states that the mistake was not discovered till the Federal had discharged a gun; but I am told by a redacteur of a Paris journal that a request was sent round by the auhorities that no mention should be made of the matter in such a way as to cause public irritation. When the news arrived here, some Southerners living in Paris went about, unable to conceal their joy, crying out, 'We're saved! we're saved!' But they must be greatly disappointed to find that the French Emperor is by far too politic to take as an insult what, as already said, was never intended to be [???] as such."
lead_paragraph: The Paris correspondent of the Morning Star writes as follows: "In the affair of the Iroquois the Ensoch Government gives another lesson of political sagacity by when it would be well for others to take example. abstract: Decidedly the most interesting announcement in the dramatic world is that issued by Mr. WALLAGE, to the effect that he will to-night inaugurate a series of careful performances of the standard comedies. That the veteran manager will fulfill his promise...
lead_paragraph: Decidedly the most interesting announcement in the dramatic world is that issued by Mr. WALLACE, to the effect that he will to-night inaugurate a series of careful performances of the standard comedies. That the veteran manager will fulfill his promise with scrupulous fidelity, admits of as little doubt as the fact that just our theatre-goers need bringing up to a higher standard of literary appreciation than the one which has been encouraged so long, and, we may add, so disastrously. It is time that some authoritative voice spoke a word for letters; uttered a protest against the bedizened monstrosities which pass muster with the good-tempered public as plays or spectacles. The carpenters and scene-painters have had their say for a couple of years, and no one remembers what they have said. It is well, therefore, that the memorable fruits of the drama should once more be exhibited to our wearied vision, and prove, as they abundantly will, that they have not become the worse for age. These revivals are always interesting when undertaken by Mr. WALLACE; just now they are poculiarly valuable. We have retrogressed so much, that their success is a test of our capacity for a higher kind of entertainment. A vile heresy has sprung up that any trash will do for a New-York audience, provided it is well pat on the stage; hence the literary man, as an ally of good management, has been abandoned. Mr. WALLACK will, we trust, bring him back to his old post of honor. To-night, GOLDSMITH's comely of "She Stoops to Conquer" will be played, with a cast which cannot be equaled at any other establishment.

abstract: A portion of our people will be disappointed at the result arrived at by our Government, in the affair of the Trent. But that feeling will have no deeper basis than a temporary and impulsive chagrin, that two such rebels as MASON and SLIDELL should have slipped...
lead_paragraph: A portion of our people will be disappointed at the result arrived at by our Government, in the affair of the Trent. But that feeling will have no deeper basis than a temporary and impulsive chagrin, that two such rebels as MASON and SLIDELL should have slipped through our fingers, in consequence of the interposition of the English Government on their behalf. And even this feeling will promptly yield to the profound satisfaction of the whole country, that we have honorably escaped the fearful perils of a war with England, which, whatever might have been its ultimate issue, would have given a certain triumph to the Southern rebellion. The real disappointment at the pacific settlement of this question will be felt in the dominions of JEFF. DAVIS. The rebels had taken fresh heart and hope, as well they might, at the prospect of having the whole military and naval power of Great Britain thrown into the scale on their behalf. The sudden destruction of that hope will fall upon them like a thunderbolt. It will do more to dishearten and paralyze their efforts than any other event, short of an overwhelming defeat at the hands of the Union forces.

abstract: It does not appear very probable that recruiting for the regular army will make much progress, unless some change be made in the regulations governing this branch of the service. The inducements of a shorter term of service than usual, increased pay...
lead_paragraph: It does not appear very probable that recruiting for the regular army will make much progress, unless some change be made in the regulations governing this branch of the service. The inducements of a shorter term of service than usual, increased pay more food, good clothing, one hundred dollars bounty on the expiration of the term of enlistment, and what should be greater than all, the chance of rising to the position of a commissioned officer, have not the effect, as they should have, of filling the ranks of the regular army. On the contrary, recruiting was never so dull as it is now, particularly in this City. The few applicants who do present themselves for enlistment are married men, and, therefore, cannot be taken without an order from the Superintendent. The Secretary of the Navy has adopted a plan which might be followed, with advantage, by the Secretary of war, viz.: that of advertising the different naval rendezvous and undertaking to pay the mileage of acceptable recruits from their place of abode to the nearest rendezvous. This plan will save the expense of opening additional naval rendezvous It was expected that Congress would at once act upon the recommendation of Secretary CAMERON, and authorise the payment of part of the $400 bounty to a recruit on his enlistment, but nothing has been done as yet. The allotment system, already in force in the navy, should be made applicable to the regular army as well. These two measures would no doubt lead to some activity in recruiting.

abstract: SIR: I have this morning received the note which you did me the honor to address to me yesterday, in answer to Earl RUSSELL'S dispatch of the 80th of November last, relative to the removal of Mr. MASON, Mr. SLIDELL, Mr. McFARLAND and Mr. EUSTIS from the British mail packet TrentI will, without any loss of time, forward to Her Majesty's Government a copy of the important communication which you have made to me.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Friday Dec. 27.

abstract: A Committee representing the Banks of this City met on Saturday evening, and after a prolonged sitting, determined to suspend specie payment, to take effect to-day. It was voted to make a further payments of $3,500,000 on the last $50,000,000 loan, for the purpose of enabling the Secretary of the Treasury to meet his January interest, and to pay a requisition in favor of the State of New-York, for advances made the National Government. The associate Banks of Philadelphia and Boston have undoubtedly taken a similar step, which will be followed by all the Banks of the country.
lead_paragraph: A Committee representing the Banks of this City met on Saturday evening, and after a prolonged sitting, determined to suspend specie payment, to take effect to-day. abstract: Sin: The arrest of Messieurs MASON and SUIDELL, on board the English packet Trent, by an American cruiser, has produced in France, if not the same emotion as in England, at least extreme astonishment and sensation. Public sentiment was at once engrossed with the lawfulness and the consequence of such an act, and the impression which has resulted from this, has not been, for an instant, doubtful.
lead_paragraph: DEPARTMENT, PARIS, Dec. 3, 1861.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen, Saturday evening, appropriated $500 each, to the Presidents of the Aldermen and Councilmen, for services as Health Commissioners. An appropriation passed to provide a drill-room for the new Thirty-seventh Regiment, State Militia.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen, Saturday evening, appropriated $500 each, to the Presidents of the Aldermen and Councilmen, for services as Health Commissioners. An appropriation passed to provide a drill-room for the new Thirty-seventh Regiment, State Militia. JAMES F. MURRAY, was reimbursed $113 for damage done to his house by a mob, on the night of election. The sum of $250 was granted the reader for extra services. The Board concurred in the Railroad bill of the Councilmen. The Board of Councilmen held a regular meeting and rushed through a series of resolutions, confirming the grant, as conveyed in the "Gridiron" Railroad bill. It was violently opposed by Messrs. KRECH, LENT, ORTON and PINCKNEY, but as all proposed amendments were voted down by a distinct vote, the opponents were forced to yield, and the measure was finally adopted -- Ayes 13, Noes 10. An injunction having been served on some of the members, in the matter of the purchase of the "Fort Gansevoort" property, it was referred to the Corporation Counsel, with a request to report at the next meeting. The NEW YORK TIMES and World were made Corporation papers.

lead_paragraph: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, Dec. 27, 1861.

abstract: Mr. G.F. TRAIN, the contractor for street-tram ways, delivered a lecture in the Town Hall. Tunstall, on the evening of the 10th, in aid of the funds of the Tunstall Atheneum. The Chief Bailiff presided. An extraordinary scene, which is thus described by the Birmingham Daily Post, took place on the occasion: "Mr. TRAIN was interrupted by a person in the hall expressing a hope that Mr. TRAIN would speak the truth. The Chairman immediately lose to order; but the person who had previously spoken asked if Mr. TRAIN would indorse the statement respecting his recent letter to New-York Herald. The Chairman said he must have silence, or he would leave the chair. Nothing daunted by this threat, the person continued. Mr. TRAIN had called the volunteers a setof fools, and, as a volunteer, he would not submit to that. The Chairman insisted on order, and, after some confusion, order was restored. Mr. TRAIN said, as the volunteers had been mentioned, he would reply to the observation by reciting a poem on the subject, written by ELIZA COOK. [The voice -- "Perhaps you don't believe it, when you say it." -- Applause and cries of "Shame."] The Chairman called upon the meeting to signify by show of hands whether the lecture should be proceeded with as announced, and nearly every peron in the hall responded in the affirmative. Mr. TRAIN said he had written a letter, but it contained nothing hostile to England. If America had done wrong, she would apologize for it; if she had done anything contrary to international laws, she would be the first to say so. Why did the English people settle the question before hearing the other side? Why did they not wait until they had heard from the other side of the water? North America was the friend of England, had always been, and always desired to be. Mr. TRAIN proceeded to demonstrate this amid frequent interruptions, during which the Chairman threatened to call in the police and have the disturbers ejected. The threatened war between England and America, Mr. TRAIN continued, must not take place. If America had done wrong in the Trent affair, she would apologise; but if she had not, neither England nor any other nation could make her apologise. ["Question," and confusion.] They talked about international laws, but did international laws apply solely to England? Were not other countries to participate in them as well? Could not the present dispute be referred to arbitration? He said that MASON was the author of the Fugitive Slave law, and that SLIDELL had, for a quarter of a century, been making hostile speeches against England. Capt. WILKES had only done what English officers had repeatedly done before; and if his act was illegal, so was that of the commander of the Trent in taking the Commissioners on board his ship. He did not say that America would give up the prisoners. He would have tried them in a Prize Court in New-York -- [hisses,] -- be would have convicted them of high treason; he would have hanged them, [hisses,] and then sent them to England, if England insisted on their being given up. [Confusion.] He repeated, England and America must not go to war. If they sent out a courteous dispatch to Secretary SEWARD, they would be as courteously replied to; but if they put a revolver to his head, and demanded of him to give up those men, they would rouse up in America some of the spirit he had seen now and then rising to the surface in that meeting. [A VOICE -- "We don't want our mails stopped."] Quite right. They (the Americans) did not stop their mails or their females. [Laughter.] Mr. TRAIN proceeded to speak on several other subjects, amid continual interruptions whenever he said, as he often did, anything touching directly on the popular English view of the American question. At length, wrought up to a pitch of intense anger, he exclaimed he was their guest that night, and he would not be [???]. He was not paid to come there; but if they did not want to hear him, he would go. The Chairman again sternly interposed, and order was presently restored. Mr. TRAIN went on to speak of the mutual interest of the two countries to be at peace with each other. He referred to the American navy, which, although small compared with the English navy, was capable of doing some work. He said a war with America would not be found so easy as it might be supposed, for the American coast was well prepared to resist invasion. They would find a Cronstadt at New-York, and a Sebastopol at Washington. They would not find it so very easy a thing to beat the Americans after all. A vote of thanks was passed to Mr. TRAIN, and the Chairman urged the meeting not to prematurely judge the merits of the American question.

abstract: Our City Fathers seem bent on making has while the sun shines. They passed, on Saturday night, two or three sweeping measures, one purchasing the Fort Gansevoort property for a market, and another granting an immensely valuable railroad franchise to a private company with out a word of public discussion, and, indeed, without the public knowledge. The experience of the last nights of our Common Council will prove valuable to the Legislature. It will show pretty conclusively the necessity of some radical reform of our City government.

The experience of the last nights of our Common Council will prove valuable to the Legislature. It will show pretty conclusively the necessity of some radical reform of our City government.

abstract: Little change has taken place, this week, in the position on affairs in England. It is, in point of fact, rather difficult to ascertain what the precise state of feeling is, or to estimate with much exactness the relative strength of the war and peace parties. The spirit of hostility to the United States still continues...
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 14, 1861.

abstract: D.L. PHILLIES, a United States Marshal of Illinois, arrived in this City, yesterday, from Cairo, in that State, having in custody CHRISTOPHER LENBRIDGE, of Hickman, Ky., and L.R. BURNETT, of Caledonia-Ill. The prisoners were arrested by order of the State [???] at Washington, upon the charge of being sympathizers with, and aiders and abettors of the Secessionists in Kentucky and Tennessee. It is alleged that they have been in the habit, for some time past, of conveying dispatches from the Confederates in one section to those in another, while they have all the time professed great love for the Union cause. Upon their arrival here they were immediately conveyed to Fort Lafayette.

abstract: The construction put by the Secretary of the Treasury upon the recent act of Congress, increasing the duties in the above-named articles. -- that the same applies to such as are in bond, as well as to importations hereafter made, appears to be clearly erroneous, and is working great inconvenience and harm to persons having stocks on hand. The law is not, and was not intended to be retroactive in its effect. Such is the declaration of its framers. It is never the policy of any Government to make such laws applicable to merchandise already imported.

abstract: The facts given in the letters received yesterday from our correspondents in South Carolina indicate a terrible condition of affairs in that wretched State. Ruin and dismay reign from the seaboard to the mountains. The political, social and financial ruin which South Carolina sought to bring upon the country has first overtaken herself. The plantation lords of the sea-islands and the coast -- the richest part of the State -- have fled in terror; the business and commercial portion of the State's only large city is in ashes; a great part of the poor whites -- and these constitute the bulk of the white men in the State -- refuse to fight; the slaves of the seaboard -- the densest slave section of the State -- are virtually freed and in anarchy; while this element is everywhere looked upon with distrust. The entire coast, from forty miles below to forty miles above Port Royal, is deserted by its white inhabitants, and the rattlesnake flag and the rebel batteries are swept from nearly the whole coast of South Carolina. The rebel soldiers are everywhere firing the, cotton -- which is the wealth, and life of the State. The way in which the rebel soldiers act seems to indicate a perfect panic -- as the pickets submit to capture without even firing a shot; and heavy bodies of rebels scamper off at the least indication of an approach of our troops. One of our correspondents avers that not a solitary instance of pluck has yet been exhibited by the South Carolinians. The State is suffering little short of famine; and even the coarse food of the slaves is doled out in scanty rations. The planters have demanded and from the State; but the State is as poor as they, and can afford no relief. Putting all the scattered facts together which have been collected by our correspondents, from refugees, deserters, captured rebels, and slaves, and the condition of South Carolina appears to be about as bad in every respect as it could be. There is no prospect of change either for the better; but, as the Winter advances, things are daily getting worse.

abstract: The steam-transport Empire City, from Beaufort on the 24th, and Hilton Head on the 25th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her advices, which are four day's later than were received by the Baltic, are interesting, and in some respects important. No demonstration of any kind had been made by the rebels against our...
lead_paragraph: The steam-transport Empire City, from Beaufort on the 24th, and Hilton Head on the 25th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her advices, which are four day's later than were received by the Baltic, are interesting, and in some respects important. No demonstration of any kind had been made by the rebels against our troops, the stories to that effect in the rebel papers being pure inventions. On the other hand, our troops are making rapid advances into the State, making their positions secure as they go, and scouting-parties are daily pushed in every direction -- one proceeding from Port Royal Island almost within sight of Savannah. A. portion of the Seventy-ninth Regiment had made a reconnoissance fifteen miles from Beaufort, and taken six rebels prisoners. These reconnoissances and scouts had established the fact that the rebels are able to concentrate, in a short time, upon any given point, from fifteen to twenty thousand men. Another important gunboat reconnoissance had been made, which had been pushed within fifteen miles of Charleston, at a town called Rockwell. Here a force of four hundred rebels was found, which fled in a panic when an inferior force of our men was landed. The Empire City also brings later news from Tybee Island. The Union forces there are still engaged on the intrenchments. It is expected that a movement will soon be made in the direction of Savannah. The number of rebel troops at that place is put down at about two thousand. On the 23d inst. a boat containing a number of rebels came down the channel from Savannah, to sound the bar, it is supposed, for the British steamer Fingal, which is loaded with cotton, and waiting to run the blockade. The boat was chased ashore, and two of the crew captured. The Empire City brings home several of the officers of the stone fleet.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN yesterday held an inquest upon the body of JOHN MORTON, who died on Saturday, at his residence, No. 151 Hammond-street, from injuries received in an affray on Christmas night, as published in yesterday's TIMES. From the evidence, it appears that there was a general fight between four men named WADE FIELDER, JOHN COLE, JEREMIZE FOY, and the deceased. The parties were all more or less intoxicated, and happening to meet on the corner of Greenwioh and King streets, about 6 o'clock in the evening, soon became involved in an affray.

abstract: About 7 1/2 o'clock last evening, a fire was discovered in the Judd Linseed and Sperm Oil Manufactory situated at No. 512 Cherry-street. The building is a very large one, being four stories in height, and about two hundred feet in length. It was built of brick, in the most substantial manner, for a manufacturing establishment. The fire originated on the second floor, and, as it is believed, from spontaneous combustion. The firemen were very promptly on hand, and after about half an hour, they succeeded, as it was supposed, in effectually extinguishing the flames. They therefore pulled up and left the premises. In about an hour after, the bells sounded again for the same district, and it was soon ascertained that the flames had broken out a fresh on the upper floors of the establishment. This time the firemen came on in large force, and worked with great zeal. But owing to the inflammable character of the material, the fire raged with great violence, and spread over the third and fourth floors with alarming rapidity. In a brief space of time nearly the whole of the upper part of the building was entirely destroyed. About one hundred feet of the second story was also burned. At least $20,000 worth of property was destroyed. It is fully insured, but in what companies, could not be ascertained. The steamboat of the Harbor Police was promptly on hand, and did very efficient service in protecting the shipping in the immediate vicinity, as well as in throwing water upon the burning building. This boat has an engine capable of throwing two streams of water with great force, and to the heighth equal to any ordinary building in town.

abstract: Benjamin Giles vs. James S. Libby and A.S. Whitney. -- The defendants were proprietors of the Libby House, a hotel in this City, and the plaintiff was their guest. Upon retiring to bed the plaintiff discovered that he was to be put into a room with mother person, and protested against it. He however, retired, locking the door, or turning the key, and hanging his watch on a nail in the wall. His money, about $25, was in the pocket of his pantaloons. In the morning he found the door ajar, and his fellow-lodger gone, together with his gold watch, pencil and money. In his complaint, it is alleged that the property was lost by the carelessness of the defendants, he being placed to sleep in a room with another person, and the room not being securely fastened.

abstract: A dispatch from Boston, received yesterday morning, announced positively that MASON and SLIDELL were to go out in the Niagara to-day, that vessel having been detailed for the purpose of taking them by Lord LYONS, and that the Persia, now in the St. Lawrence, would come round to take the place of the Niagara, and sail on the regular day. Subsequent dispatches, however, threw doubt upon the statement, but it was still insisted that the Niagara would be in readiness to sail at noon to-day -- the agents of the Cunard line in Boston expecting an order from Lord LYONs to take the Rebel Commissioners on board Mr. CUNARD, of this City, however, insists that the Niagara will not leave until her regular day, and this is probably the case, as our Washington correspondent telegraphs that the rebel Commissioners are not likely to go before Wednesday of next week, the regular time of sailing. It has been decided, after consultation between Lord LYONS and Secretary SEWARD, that they will not go on board a British man--of-war.

It has been decided, after consultation between Lord LYONS and Secretary SEWARD, that they will not go on board a British man--of-war.

abstract: In the Senate, petitions were presented from New-York, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, praying for the emancipation of the slaves. A communication was received from the Secretary of War, refusing to submit to the Senate the correspondence between Gens. SCOTT and PATTERSON. Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, introduced a bill, which was referred to the Judiciary Committee, declaring certain persons alien enemies, and sacrificing their property for the benefit of loyal persons. The Senate then adjourned until Thursday.

abstract: Our State is invaded, and Charleston is threatened, by land and by sea, with large forces. I, therefore, in conformity with an act passed the 7th instal entitled, "An Act to annul and suspend certain positions of the Militia and Patrol laws of this State," do hereby issue this, my proclamation, calling for twelve thousand volunteers, to be furnished for a term of service not less than twelve months, unless sooner discharged. These troops will be received and mustered in according to orders, below issued, by the Adjutant and Inspector-General.

abstract: DEAR SIR: In compliance with your request, at our conversation in Washington, I will put in writing the reasons why the Southern privateersmen should be regarded as prisoners of war, and not as pirates.
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK, Dec. 21, 1861.

lead_paragraph: The first performance of Mr. WALLACK's contemplated series of standard comedies took place last evening, and was the occasion of what really seemed to be a fashionable demonstration. There was a time, and that not long ago, when a Wallack audience could be distinguished from any other, but the sensational drama unhappily leveled it to the common standard. Last evening it seemed as if all the old forces had returned to their allegiance with the determination to bear the veteran triumphantly through the season. GOLDSMITH's play of "She Stoops to Conquer," was given, and with a distribution which included all the leading artists of the establishment. It would be more than a raice-told tale to dwell at any length upon the performances of Mr. LESTER WALLACE as Young Harlow: Mr. BLASE as Hardcastle; or Mr. REYNOLDS as Hustings. They were, as heretofore, excellent, and gave to the piece -- which lacks serious interest -- the lightness, hippancy and temper is required. Mr. HISOKIN HOLLAND as Tony Lumpkin was the best representative of the part we have seen on the American stage, imputing a lumpish breadth and jollity to the character which his predecessors have failed to convey. Two small parts, played excellently well by Mr. JOAN SENTON and Mr. YOUNG, deserve honorable mention, simply because such parts are usually [???] on the piece. The parts referred to are Jeremy and Diggory.

abstract: The third battalion of the First Massachusetts Cavalry, under Major JOHN W. EDSON, (old army officer,) numbering 420 horses and men, arrived yesterday morning. Both battalions are ordered from Washington to halt here until further notice. Col. FRANK E. HOWE has made arrangements to quarter the men and horses in the Third-avenue Railroad stables, Sixty-third-street. There are thus 850 men and horses of the First Massachusetts Cavalry now in this City. Col. WILLIAMS will be here to-morrow.

abstract: In the present confused and uncertain state of international law, it was impossible that naval hostilities should be carried on by a Power having such extensive commercial relations as the United States, without the occurrence of some vexatious complications between ourselves and neutral nations.
lead_paragraph: In the present confused and uncertain state of international law, it was impossible that naval hostilities should be carried on by a Power having such extensive commercial relations as the United States, without the occurrence of some vexatious complications between ourselves and neutral nations. In the adjustment of any such cases as may hereafter occur, we trust that the friendly forbearance, enlightened policy and wise statesmanship of neutral Governments will be as conspicuous as have been displayed by our own Government in the surrender of MASON and SLIDELL. The able paper of Mr. SEWARD, which we published yesterday, will be as satisfactory to the public as it is in harmony with the progressive principles of neutral rights for which FRANKLIN, ADAMS, JEFFERSON, MADISON, CLAY, and all our great statesmen have invariably contended.

abstract: ST. THOMAS, Dec. 10. -- The schr. Susan Cannen, of New-York, Capt. Page, from New-York to the coast of Africa, with a cargo of tobacco, rum, &c., arrived at this port on the 7th inst., having experienced a heavy gale when some four ds. out; lost sails, port, stanchions rails and bulwarks, bowsprit and rudder loosened, and other damage. Some portion of her cargo will have to be discharged.

abstract: Yesterday, the first day of skating, this season, was inaugurated at Central Park. At an early hour skaters of all sizes were seen flocking toward the Park. The "ball," much to their gratification, was up, and the lower poad was announced capable of bearing. Noon the skates were buckled on, and the skating season at Central Park may be said to have fully commenced.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the first day of skating, this season, was inaugurated at Central Park. At an early hour skaters of all sizes were seen flocking toward the Park. The "ball," much to their gratification, was up, and the lower poad was announced capable of bearing. Noon the skates were buckled on, and the skating season at Central Park may be said to have fully commenced. A few ladies were present, but only a very few who indulged in graceful gyrations on the ice. No doubt this was owing in a great measure to the boisterousness of the weather; on the first calm day, however, it is imagined they will turn out in as great a number as on previous years.

abstract: The Second Battalion of the First Massachusetts Cavalry Regiment arrived in this City from Readville, yesterday. Maj. JOHN H. EDSON was in command. The First Battalion is already at Annapolis, where it will be attached to Gen. BURNSIDE's Division. The Third Battalion arrived here last Saturday, and will remain at the Park Barracks with the Second till further orders are received from the War Department. This regiment, Col. ROBT. WILLIAMS, numbers in all nearly 1,300 men, all of whom are uniformed, armed and mounted. A list of the officers has already been published in the TIMES.

abstract: BOARD OF ALDERMEN -- TAKING IN SAIL. -- A STAMPEDE. -- A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening. Alderman TAYLOR, of the Fourth Ward, in the Chair. Alderman STRONG offered a preamble and resolutions, in view of the condition of the country and the high rate of taxation in this city, urging upon the representatives of this city in the Legislature to ask for a repeal of all the improvement acts involving the issue of City [???] asking the Commissioners under these acts to stay all action and discharge all employes; appointing a Special Committee of five to inquire and report what legislation should be had to reduce and restrict expenses to within the limits of the most rigid economy and secure permanent prosperity, by limiting debt and taxation; pledging the Board to a system of retrenchment and reform in city expenditures, and to discourage all expenditures and actions whereby taxes and assessments may be unnecessarily incurred, &c., &c. The resolutions were unanimously adopted, and the Chair appointed as the Special Committee called for, Aldermen Strong, Wallace, O'Keefe, Franks and Van Brunt. Some routine business was transacted, and several ineffectual attempts having been made to adjourn, Alderman STRONG moved that the Board go into an election for a Chairman pro [???]. No sooner was the motion made than every Democratic Alderman seized his hat and coat and made a rush for the [???], and the Board was compelled then to adjourn for want of a quorum. The secret of this movement was, that one or more Democratic Aldermen were absent. Having the Republicans of the Board in the majority. The Board adjourned for one week.

abstract: The reading of the minutes was dispensed with, the printer not having furnished them. Several bills and petitions were received and appropriately referred. An award was made of $1,070 for damages done to premises owned by B. Wheelwright by the use of the same for a House of Detention for Witnesses, and several bills for fitting up election polls were ordered paid. The annual report of the Clerk of the Board was received and ordered printed. The sum of $1,750 was ordered paid to Messrs. Roach on account of iron furnished for the new Harlem bridge, and $501 each to the parties in charge of the work. Adjourned until Monday next.

abstract: At this season--the close of the year--a resume of the principal events that have occurred during the past twelve months will be read with interest. No one can say that the record is dull or uninstructive.
lead_paragraph: At this season -- the close of the year -- a resume of the principal events that have occurred during the past twelve months will be read with interest. No one can say that the record is dull or uninstructive. For the convenience of the readerwe have prepared two chronological tables -- one giving the history of the rebellion, and of the operations, on land, the other detailing more particularly the operations at sea. Both are convenient for future reference, and give, almost at a glance, a correct and concise account of the rise and progress of this great Southern rebellion -- of the efforts that have been made to suppress it -- and of the naval and military engagements that the war has engendered.

abstract: Everything is reported quiet along the river line and in camp this morning.  Notwithstanding the great uncertainty of convincing in this spot for any extended time, all the regiments are employed in building log huts and stables, for the comfort of man and beast. Some of the structures are the result of great labor, and even of rustic architectural skill, and will probably remain for years, as specimens of Yankee ingenuity and taste.

abstract: Perhaps no expedition--not even that sent along the coast of the Southern States--has, during the present war, been projected, or is so pregnant with great results, as the one now preparing at St. Louis and Cairo, for a descent of the Mississippi. abstract: Col. W.A. WEBB, of the First Regiment Douglas Brigade, Illinois Volunteers, died at Smithton, Mo., on Dec. 24. He was born at Dover, Me., in 1834, graduated at West Point, was commissioned as Brevet Second Lieutenant in the Fourth United States Infantry, in 1853; and was subsequently promoted to a First Lieutenancy in the Fifth Infantry. Commissioned as Captain in the Sixteenth Regiment, he was appointed mustering and subsisting officer in Chicago, and having taken great interest in the formation of the Douglas Brigade, was elected Colonel of the First Regiment, which position he accepted by permission of the War Department. Col. WEBB was on the Star of the West when she was fired upon while attempting to enter Charleston harbor. Socially he was highly esteemed, and his career gave every reason to believe that he would have distinguished himself had he lived long enough to undertake any active service.

abstract: After the reading of the minutes and the reference of petitions, a communication was received from the Comptroller, in answer to inquiries as to the action of the Supervisors with reference to the new Court-House, and the land taken therefor, stating that that body had in all things compiled with the requirements of the statute, which was referred to the Committee on Finance. A communication was received from the Corporation Counsel, in answer to the resolution passed by this Board on Saturday, as to the validity of the injunction in the matter of the Fort Gansevoort property. Mr. Bronson states that the resolution reaches him at his house, where he is confined by illness, and that being absent from his house he is not prepared to pronounce upon the validity of the injunction. He adds, however, that this will cause very little delay, as Judge Dean will appear for the City on the 31st (this day), when the case will be argued, and a speedy decision no doubt had. The communication was ordered on file.
lead_paragraph: After the reading of the minutes and the reference of petitions, a communication was received from the Comptroller, in answer to inquiries as to the action of the Supervisors with reference to the new Court-House, and the land taken therefor, stating that that body had in all things compiled with the requirements of the statute, which was referred to the Committee on Finance. A communication was received from the Corporation Counsel, in answer to the resolution passed by this Board on Saturday, as to the validity of the injunction in the matter of the Fort Gansevoort property. Mr. Bronson states that the resolution reaches him at his house, where he is confined by illness, and that being absent from his house he is not prepared to pronounce upon the validity of the injunction. He adds, however, that this will cause very little delay, as Judge Dean will appear for the City on the 31st (this day), when the case will be argued, and a speedy decision no doubt had. The communication was ordered on file.

abstract: We publish in this morning's TIMES the first full and accurate account of the Mississippi gunboat and mortar fleet that has yet been given to the public--at least all the facts and details concerning it which the military authorities think proper to be published. The hour of readiness and the day of sailing of this flotilla have been so often promised as at hand...
lead_paragraph: We publish in this morning's TIMES the first full and accurate account of the Mississippi gunboat and mortar fleet that has yet been given to the public -- at least all the facts and details concerning it which the military authorities think proper to be published. The hour of readiness and the day of sailing of this flotilla have been so often promised as at hand, and so frequently deferred to an indefinite future that some folks have almost begun to think the whole thing a Western myth, or, at least, that it would not be ready until the rebels were crushed and the war was over. But it will be seen that the fleet is a thing of such vast proportions, and of so formidable a character, that it seems almost incredible that it should have been got to its present stage of readiness in five short months. The whole flotilla, consisting of twelve enormously strong gunboats, mounting nearly two hundred of the heaviest guns, and sixty-six mortarboats and their aids, are now at Cairo, taking aboard the powder and shot that will soon burst as thunder and lightning over the heads of the rebels of the Great Valley. Things at all the main points in the West now seem to be almost prepared for the word ready. The wonder is, not that they have been so long in getting to their present stage, but that it has been possible in so short a time to achieve such vast results.

abstract: RUSSELL, of the London Times, must be getting bilious. His digestion is out of order, or else his head is a little turned by the novel circumstances in which he finds himself obliged to write. He deals a good deal too much for his own reputation in political prophecy. He predicted three weeks ago that, if MASON and SLIDELL were surrendered, our Government would be dissolved. The "mob" would not stand it. He has seen them given up, and has yet to hear the first word of hostile protest from his dreaded "mob." He is now predicting "civil war" from the Abolitionists. The harangues of our Abolition lecturers, -- the presentation of a sword to FREMONT, and the ravings of what he very justly styles the "secession organ" in New-York, have alarmed him needlessly. He will live to see all his gloomy predictions falsified.

abstract: The public is naturally curious to know by what fortunate combination of prudence and sagacity we have avoided the perils in which the affair of the Trent seemed likely to involve us, and. have escaped a war with England. They are not long left in doubt. Our modest neighbor, the Herald, tells the world all about it. The result is due to the fact that we had at the head of political affairs a remarkably cool statesman, and at the head of the newspaper press a remarkably cool editor. Of both these facts there can be no doubt. "The American Government and the American Press, particularly the New-York Herald," (says the Herald of yesterday,) "are guided by lofty principles of statesmanship, the strictest rules of international law, and a due regard to the requirements of justice and humanity. Had Mr. Seward and the Herald," the Herald adds, "followed the inclinations of the mob, Earl RUSSELL's demand would have been replied to with defiance, and war would have now existed between England and the United States." Fortunately for the world, "Mr. SEWARD and the Herald" did not "follow the inclinations of the mob." "On the first receipt of the news of the arrest of the Trent," says the Herald, "we said if the proceeding should turn out to be irregular, and contrary to international law, of which there was some doubt, it would be the duty as well as the interest of our Government to make an apology and give up the traitors."

abstract: The law regulating the price of absolute necessities has passed the Senate of Alabama. It provides that salt, wheat, flour, bacon, lard, cotton, osnaburgs, kerseys, leathor, shoes, cotton or wool cards, shall not be sold for more than 60 per cent, adrance on last April prices. The penalty is fine, forfeiture and imprisonment.

abstract: VALE!--It is generally  surmised that those two interesting worthies, MASON and SLIDELL--whose names we have had occasion to write so frequently of late-- leave Boston, to-day, to resume that jaunt to Europe which Capt. WILKES cut short six weeks ago. There is evidently an intent to...
lead_paragraph: VALE! -- It is generally surmised that those two interesting worthies, MASON and SLIDELL -- whose names we have had occasion to write so frequently of late -- leave Boston, to-day, to resume that jaunt to Europe which Capt. WILKES cut short six weeks ago. There is evidently an intent to mystify the public as to their departure, however, for it is affirmed and denied, and denied and affirmed again. Perhaps it would not do to break the news too suddenly to the Bostonians, and make them utterly inconsolable at the loss. The rest of the country, however, ardently hope that the riddance may be as speedy as possible, and sincerely pray that they may not be drowned in transitu -- to the end that the other half of the proverb may at some future day be illustrated in their persons. There is one class of persons who will bitterly mourn the departure of MASON and SLIDELL -- the rebel leaders at Richmond, who would a thousand times rather have them as "Ambassadors" to Fort Warren, with the prospect of trouble between the United States and England in consequence, than at the posts to which they were accredited. As everybody knows how profoundly JEFF. DAVIS and his crew will be chagrined at the upshot of the matter, and as everybody is prepared to hear a howl of hypocritical taunting from their journals, it will, on the whole, be a very capital joke. But six weeks have passed since their journey to Europe was interrupted; they now resume it, but they go to Europe totally different men. They are rendered perfectly harmless. For the case they have raised has defined American policy in Europe, and when Mr. SEWARD's dispatch reaches the other side they will have done more to extinguish the rebel hopes of foreign recognition, and to raise the cause of the Union in England and France, than any or all influences together. The teeth of the serpents have been drawn, the wings of the birds have been clipped, and they are, on the whole, damaged dry goods. A kind of theoretical interest will attach to them as to persons identified with a cause celebre. And as the "Ambassadors" flit uneasilly around the outer doors of St. James and the Tuilleries, individuals of an antiquarian turn of mind will point to them as MASON and SLIDELL of the Trent.

abstract: DARING EXPLOITS OF TWO COLORED MEN. -- Officer SLOWEY, of the Detective Police, yesterday arrested two colored men named JOHN and PETER WHITEHEAD. The former is about 18, and the latter 21 years of age. They state that they are brothers, and natives of New-Jersey. They are charged upon several complaints with larceny and burglary. Not long since Mr. MOSES TAYLOR, residing in Bergen, N.J., where he is the proprietor of a store, was robbed, one dark night, in a very mysterious manner. Some time in the evening he closed his place of business, took his tin box, which contained $75 in money, a knife and considerable other valuable property, and proceeded a short distance to his house. When he reached it, he placed the box on the steps while he felt in his pocket for a key to unlock the door. Upon stooping down for the box a moment after, he found, to his great surprise that it was gone. It was most unaccountable, and no information could be obtained as to the whereabouts of the guilty parties until yesterday, when they were arrested at the house of a Mrs. BROWN, in Mercer-street, in this City. A clue to the culprits was obtained in this way: Last Friday night the house of JOHN FARDON, also a resident of Bergen, was broken open, and an overcoat and other property, amounting in value to $40, was stolen therefrom. The same night a barn was entered in the neighborhood, a fire kindled therein, and a horse taken from the stable and rode as far as Hoboken, where it was released. These offences greatly alarmed the Bergen people, who sent immediately to the New-York Detective office. A description of the men enabled Officer SLOWEY to trace them to the house in Mercer-street where they were found. When PETER WHITEHEAD was searched, the knife belonging to Mr. TAYLOR, was found upon his person. They were both taken to Headquarters, where, after a good deal of quibbling, they finally confessed that they were the persons who stole Mr. TAYLOR's box, and who shortly after broke into Mr. FARDON's house. At a late hour yesterday they were sent over to New-Jersey, there to be dealt with according to law.

abstract: Our people have felt that MASON and SLI DELL were among those upon whom lies most of the guilt of this wicked rebellion, and their surrender produces something of that same feeling which we all have when a notorious villain escapes from the clutches of the law by reason of a flaw in the indictment. But there are several things in the case which will offset that unpleasant feeling.
lead_paragraph: Our people have felt that MASON and SLIDELL were among those upon whom lies most of the guilt of this wicked rebellion, and their surrender produces something of that same feeling which we all have when a notorious villain escapes from the clutches of the law by reason of a flaw in the indictment. But there are several things in the case which will offset that unpleasant feeling. We must remember that they are not the only ones who deserve punishment. There are many other leaders of the rebellion, who deserve it as much as these two, and, if we succeed in bringing the penalties of the law upon them, we may be well satisfied to have these two punished only by banishment; and there is no doubt that nothing would have assisted the whole rebellious crew so much in their endeavors to escape those penalties, as a war between ourselves and England.

abstract: "There is a desire to invest in cotton. Some buyers are transmitting their orders to Mississippi, where they can be filled and admitted to a landing on our levee, under restrictions which may be considered as conducive to the general trade of our city, but, at the same time, they are not to be made public. The blockade of Mississippi Sound interferes greatly with the trade in sugar and molasses. The receipts of these two articles continue large, and are now, from interruption, greatly in excess of the demand. It will take some weeks to clear the accumulations at the several railroad depots. In the meantime, the weather continues very mild -- too much so for the yield of cane an this climate. Some bulls in sugar say that the crop of Louisiana will not be more than ample to supply the Confederate States, including, of course, Kentucky and Mississippi."

abstract: We have settled one controversy with England, which, if left unsettled, would have inevitably led to war.
